Early on I found out that the author is Sinead O'Connor's brother, so that's fun (and might explain the unflattering portrayal of whatever appeasement pope they had running the place at the time).There was a lot of lively writing in here, typical of the best of Irish writing. title: Ill Will
author: Chaon, Dan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: After Russia invaded Ukraine I began listening pretty religiously to Ezra Klein's biweekly podcast. Usually he sticks to economists, foreign policy woAfter Russia invaded Ukraine I began listening pretty religiously to Ezra Klein's biweekly podcast. Usually he sticks to economists, foreign policy wonks, authors of big histories. And I really like his thoughtful way of engaging with his guests, even as he tends at times to veer into high school stoner conversation territory. Sometimes he has other folks on, seemingly just to offer their interesting perspectives: a childcare philosopher, or authors like Margaret Atwood. Recently he had on Emily St. John Mandel, author of, among other books, Station Eleven and The Glass Hotel. I famously didn't really like Station Eleven, but enjoyed The Glass Hotel a lot and absolutely adored the TV show based on Station Eleven, so I was eager to hear the two talk. They talked about quarantine, parenthood, time travel, etc. It's worth a listen. But as is the convention on the show, Ezra's last question is "What are three books you'd recommend?" This was one of them.I had never heard of Dan Chaon (pronounced "Shane") or this book before, and horror isn't really my thing. But this was such a fascinating and engrossing book--part TV shows "The Sinner" and (the first season of) "True Detective," part Cormac McCarthy book infused with so much lurking menace that it felt like it hummed in the background when I wasn't reading it. Told in non-linear fashion, the book involves a series of adolescent cousins whose lives are upended when their parents are brutally killed. The book is split pretty evenly between the childhood (both before and after the killings) and their adulthood, as they grapple with the nature of blame and culpability, and their lives fall apart for mostly unrelated reasons. A recurring theme in "Ill Will" is the pliability of memory--can we selectively remember something? Can we selectively forget? How can we be sure that we haven't fabricated something, particularly something important and vivid, either in part or out of whole cloth? It's a fascinating and creepy book, and I'm excited to read more of Chaon and more of St. John Mandel's recommendations....more

title: A Very Punchable Face
author: Jost, Colin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was in North Vermont for a wedding last summer eating at a quaint restaurant when Colin Jost and his then week-old baby--as well as his superstar wiI was in North Vermont for a wedding last summer eating at a quaint restaurant when Colin Jost and his then week-old baby--as well as his superstar wife Scarlett Johansson and their retinue of other assorted friends and/or caretakers--strolled right by us to eat at the same restaurant. They looked a bit haggard, which is to be expected for parents of a newborn, but more than anything else, Colin Jost is surprisingly yoked. The guy had real dad presence. Perhaps this was because he was pushing around a 10-lb. infant and standing next to his surprisingly short wife. But I always thought he was maybe my height or a bit taller. How big is Michael Che, it made me wonder.Anyway, this book is fine; not as hilarious as Amy Poehler's or Tina Fey's books, but you can tell that Colin Jost is a tremendously hard worker and works very hard at his craft. Despite the book's title, he seems genuinely thoughtful and likeable, and it was an enjoyable chronicle of his journey from Staten Island, to Harvard, to SNL....more

author: Tsing, Anna Lowenhaupt
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a quirky and interesting book recommended to me by my friend Alice. It really made me want to forage, and taught me a lot not only about alteThis was a quirky and interesting book recommended to me by my friend Alice. It really made me want to forage, and taught me a lot not only about alternatives to capitalism as a framework for conducting a life, but also the degree to which my own ability to imagine or consider such things has been constrained by the heavyhandedness of the capitalist system we all inhabit. It did have a lot of filler that I didn't find all that interesting, and the ethnographer's tendency to make what seem like wildly overgeneralized claims (Laotians prefer X, while Cambodians prefer Y, etc.). But pretty consistently interesting throughout....more

review: I love Billy Porter--how could you not? He's so unapologetically himself, and a numinous human being. But for a lot of this book I was thinking this wI love Billy Porter--how could you not? He's so unapologetically himself, and a numinous human being. But for a lot of this book I was thinking this was a solid 3. It felt like it could use some editing at times, and one gets the impression from the book that Porter is not one to suffer edits to his work.But the end of the book chronicles Porter's meteoric rise to fame in way that endeared and inspired. Porter is a triumph of a person--to grow up Black and poor and unequivocally queer in this country is an immense burden for anyone to survive, and throw on top of it that Porter survived sexual abuse, became HIV+, and nearly lost his chance for America to see how amazing he truly is so many times, and you begin to understand the miracle it is for someone in his shoes to thrive. And thank gawd he did, because the world is a more interesting and beautiful world with his artistry in it....more

My main takeaway is a bit of advice that I've been mulling over ever since reading it: we think far more This was pretty entertaining, if a bit long. My main takeaway is a bit of advice that I've been mulling over ever since reading it: we think far more about what we do want than about what we don't want. This is kind of arbitrary if you think about it, and so many of us pitch headlong into situations that are somewhat miserable in order to achieve, possibly, ends we think we desire. But those who value freedom might have the better idea: understand yourself and know what you cannot abide and do everything in your power to avoid it....more

I swear, 40% of this book is aristocrats meeting each other and reciting their annual allowances of livres and louis d'ors they have. And the way that the machinations all work out just as intended and ruin these peoples' lives is yawn-worthy. title: Let the Record Show: A Political History of ACT UP New York, 1987-1993
author: Schulman, Sarah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The only other book I've read by Sarah Schulman was The Gentrification of the Mind: Witness to a Lost Imagination, which is considerably shorter and mThe only other book I've read by Sarah Schulman was The Gentrification of the Mind: Witness to a Lost Imagination, which is considerably shorter and more conceptual but focuses on the highly related subject matter of the New York City's loss in the wake of HIV/AIDS. That book is one I evangelize for, and I was excited to read a more granular, primary-source-anchored account of ACTUP, not only because of my interest in HIV/AIDS, queer history, etc., but because I've always been impressed by the creative and evocative ways that ACTUP made it impossible for an apathetic/hostile public to turn its attention from the scourge of HIV/AIDS. Reading this during a pandemic was often poignant and felt very germane. Not only are some of the same names relevant--for example: Anthony Fauci is very prominent, and often demonized in this book for his perceived slow-rolling of AIDS treatments--but it's impossible not to draw parallels, or, more often: distinctions. Because HIV/AIDS is never and has never been a pandemic, even though those it affects are considerably less siloed than was and is still believed. If there is a thrust to this book, it's that HIV/AIDS was allowed to decimate certain populations because in the best of circumstances the straight/white world didn't care, and in the worst of cases saw HIV/AIDS as condign punishment for a life of vice, or an expedient end to lives better disposed of than preserved.Vito Russo, an HIV/AIDS activist who died of the disease gave a speech titled "Why We Fight," and the speech in its entirety is included in this book. I have never been able to read through it without tearing up, and the few times I've tried to read it aloud to friends I have been unable to finish. But I think it's worth reading in full, because it speaks to the exigency of empathy.A friend of mine in New York City has a half-fare transit card, which means that you get on buses and subways for half price. And the other day, when he showed his card to the token attendant, the attendant asked what his disability was and he said, I have AIDS. And the attendant said, no you don't, if you had AIDS, you'd be home dying. And so, I wanted to speak out today as a person with AIDS who is not dying.You know, for the last three years, since I was diagnosed, my family thinks two things about my situation. One, they think I'm going to die, and two, they think that my government is doing absolutely everything in their power to stop that. And they're wrong, on both counts.So, if I'm dying from anything, I'm dying from homophobia. If I'm dying from anything, I'm dying from racism. If I'm dying from anything, it's from indifference and red tape, because these are the things that are preventing an end to this crisis. If I'm dying from anything, I'm dying from Jesse Helms. If I'm dying from anything, I'm dying from the President of the United States. And, especially, if I'm dying from anything, I'm dying from the sensationalism of newspapers and magazines and television shows, which are interested in me, as a human interest story -- only as long as I'm willing to be a helpless victim, but not if I'm fighting for my life.If I'm dying from anything -- I'm dying from the fact that not enough rich, white, heterosexual men have gotten AIDS for anybody to give a shit. You know, living with AIDS in this country is like living in the twilight zone. Living with AIDS is like living through a war which is happening only for those people who happen to be in the trenches. Every time a shell explodes, you look around and you discover that you've lost more of your friends, but nobody else notices. It isn't happening to them. They're walking the streets as though we weren't living through some sort of nightmare. And only you can hear the screams of the people who are dying and their cries for help. No one else seems to be noticing.And it's worse than a war, because during a war people are united in a shared experience. This war has not united us, it's divided us. It's separated those of us with AIDS and those of us who fight for people with AIDS from the rest of the population.Two and a half years ago, I picked up Life Magazine, and I read an editorial which said, "it's time to pay attention, because this disease is now beginning to strike the rest of us." It was as if I wasn't the one holding the magazine in my hand. And since then, nothing has changed to alter the perception that AIDS is not happening to the real people in this country.It's not happening to us in the United States, it's happening to them -- to the disposable populations of fags and junkies who deserve what they get. The media tells them that they don't have to care, because the people who really matter are not in danger. Twice, three times, four times -- The New York Times has published editorials saying, don't panic yet, over AIDS -- it still hasn't entered the general population, and until it does, we don't have to give a shit.And the days, and the months, and the years pass by, and they don't spend those days and nights and months and years trying to figure out how to get hold of the latest experimental drug, and which dose to take it at, and in what combination with other drugs, and from what source? And, how are you going to pay for it? And where are you going to get it? Because it isn't happening to them, so they don't give a shit.And they don't sit in television studios, surrounded by technicians who are wearing rubber gloves, who won't put a microphone on you, because it isn't happening to them, so they don't give a shit. And they don't have their houses burned down by bigots and morons. They watch it on the news and they have dinner and they go to bed, because it isn't happening to them, and they don't give a shit.And they don't spend their waking hours going from hospital room to hospital room, and watching the people that they love die slowly -- of neglect and bigotry, because it isn't happening to them and they don't have to give a shit. They haven't been to two funerals a week for the last three or four or five years -- so they don't give a shit, because it's not happening to them.And we read on the front page of The New York Times last Saturday that Anthony Fauci now says that all sorts of promising drugs for treatment haven't even been tested in the last two years because he can't afford to hire the people to test them. We're supposed to be grateful that this story has appeared in the newspaper after two years. Nobody wonders why some reporter didn't dig up that story and print it 18 months ago, before Fauci got dragged before a Congressional hearing .How many people are dead in the last two years, who might be alive today, if those drugs had been tested more quickly? Reporters all over the country are busy printing government press releases. They don't give a shit, it isn't happening to them -- meaning that it isn't happening to people like them -- the real people, the world-famous general public we all keep hearing about.Legionnaire's Disease was happening to them because it hit people who looked like them, who sounded like them, who were the same color as them. And that fucking story about a couple of dozen people hit the front page of every newspaper and magazine in this country, and it stayed there until that mystery got solved.All I read in the newspapers tells me that the mainstream, white heterosexual population is not at risk for this disease. All the newspapers I read tell me that IV drug users and homosexuals still account for the overwhelming majority of cases, and a majority of those people at risk.And can somebody please tell me why every single penny allocated for education and prevention gets spent on ad campaigns that are directed almost exclusively to white, heterosexual teenagers -- who they keep telling us are not at risk!Can somebody tell me why the only television movie ever produced by a major network in this country, about the impact of this disease, is not about the impact of this disease on the man who has AIDS, but of the impact of AIDS on his white, straight, nuclear family? Why, for eight years, every newspaper and magazine in this country has done cover stories on AIDS only when the threat of heterosexual transmission is raised?Why, for eight years, every single educational film designed for use in high schools has eliminated any gay positive material, before being approved by the Board of Education? Why, for eight years, every single public information pamphlet and videotape distributed by establishment sources has ignored specific homosexual content?Why is every bus and subway ad I read and every advertisement and every billboard I see in this country specifically not directed at gay men? Don't believe the lie that the gay community has done its job and done it well and educated its people. The gay community and IV drug users are not all politicized people living in New York and San Francisco. Members of minority populations, including so called sophisticated gay men are abysmally ignorant about AIDS.If it is true that gay men and IV drug users are the populations at risk for this disease, then we have a right to demand that education and prevention be targeted specifically to these people. And it is not happening. We are being allowed to die, while low risk populations are being panicked -- not educated, panicked -- into believing that we deserve to die.Why are we here together today? We're here because it is happening to us, and we do give a shit. And if there were more of us AIDS wouldn't be what it is at this moment in history. It's more than just a disease, which ignorant people have turned into an excuse to exercise the bigotry they have always felt.It is more than a horror story, exploited by the tabloids. AIDS is really a test of us, as a people. When future generations ask what we did in this crisis, we're going to have to tell them that we were out here today. And we have to leave the legacy to those generations of people who will come after us.Someday, the AIDS crisis will be over. Remember that. And when that day comes -- when that day has come and gone, there'll be people alive on this earth -- gay people and straight people, men and women, black and white, who will hear the story that once there was a terrible disease in this country and all over the world, and that a brave group of people stood up and fought and, in some cases, gave their lives, so that other people might live and be free.So, I'm proud to be with my friends today and the people I love, because I think you're all heroes, and I'm glad to be part of this fight. But, to borrow a phrase from Michael Callen's song: all we have is love right now, what we don't have is time.In a lot of ways, AIDS activists are like those doctors out there -- they're so busy putting out fires and taking care of people on respirators, that they don't have the time to take care of all the sick people. We're so busy putting out fires right now, that we don't have the time to talk to each other and strategize and plan for the next wave, and the next day, and next month and the next week and the next year.And, we're going to have to find the time to do that in the next few months. And, we have to commit ourselves to doing that. And then, after we kick the shit out of this disease, we're all going to be alive to kick the shit out of this system, so that this never happens again.COVID is undeniably a scourge, but the mortality rates are so much lower than HIV/AIDS that the two cannot be plausibly compared. In the United States, COVID mortality rates hover around 0.3%. At its peak in 1995 before the development of Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy (HAART), HIV/AIDS mortality exceeded 16%, and was above 30% for self-identified gay men; what's more, it had been above 10% for the prior three years.We moved heaven and earth in response to COVID, shut down our entire society, altered our way of life for years, took honest and cautious account of who might be harmed the most by its spread, and managed to create several astoundingly effective vaccines within a single year. For HIV/AIDS, developing HAART took well over a decade, and things like PrEP took more than three times as long. The contrast is as repellent as it is revelatory. There is no world in which we would have tolerated HIV/AIDS if even 10% of straight, white, non-drug-using people in rich countries had been falling victim to it. Because that wasn't the case, as Vito Russo says: they didn't give a shit. Queer people mourned the families it's so hard for us to build as they died off in droves; gay men died horrifically undignified deaths, emaciated and covered in thrush and sores and excrement while straight people blamed these victims for their behavior and sinfulness. This, too, contrasts painfully with COVID, where doing things like living your life--including doing things like having a sex life and pursuing romance--are expected, and even the most reckless behaviors are largely free of moral condemnation less than two years in.In 1985, Bob Hope told a joke about AIDS to an audience that included then-President Reagan and his wife, Nancy Reagan. "The Statue of Liberty has AIDS. They don't know if she got it from the mouth of the Hudson or the Staten Island 'ferry'." "Ferry" was a pun on "fairy" and "Hudson" was a double entendre referencing the Hudson River and also Rock Hudson, who was fairly well known to be a closeted gay man and the first high-profile celebrity to be acknowledged as having HIV/AIDS. President Reagan and First Lady Nancy Reagan purportedly laughed uproariously at the joke. Hudson, who was friendly with the Reagans from their time in Hollywood, begged the White House to intercede on his behalf to admit him to a hospital in France that he believed could provide the only treatment that might save his life, or at least mitigate the disease ravishing his body; Nancy demurred, and Hudson succumbed three months later. President Reagan didn't say the word "AIDS" until late in 1985, though his staff had been joking about it during pressers for years. Earlier this year, First Lady Jill Biden participated in a flashy ceremony honoring Nancy Reagan's depiction on a postage stamp.I mention Nancy Reagan's rehabilitation because part of me thinks that the time has passed for white/heterosexual society to contend with and make amends for its passive toleration of HIV/AIDS. America is a supremely flawed country, and it's understandable that its people need to deploy a lot of cognitive dissonance just to get on. But as queer people our rage should be enduring and incandescent, and it's all the more incumbent that we work in solidarity with other groups facing less analogous forms of oppression and disregard to pull them from the teeth of a brutal and self-interested society....more

title: Gay Bar: Why We Went Out
author: Atherton Lin, Jeremy *
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Gay Bar: Why We Went Out" has a weird format: it's a bit of a memoir threaded through the author's monograph on gay bars through the ages. The author"Gay Bar: Why We Went Out" has a weird format: it's a bit of a memoir threaded through the author's monograph on gay bars through the ages. The author grew up in the Bay Area, went to college in LA, and seems to have spent the majority of his adulthood in London, three of the best known gay metropoles; New York makes a few cameos as well, but absent are other notable gay cities--Sydney, Tel Aviv, Berlin, dare I include DC? As others have noted, this is a limited sampling, but for many gay folks the only cities to live in are these, anyway. Lin is a talented writer, as I think most of the s I've read and heard readily admit. He can turn a sentence, and drop esoteric quotes and references seemingly effortlessly. He also ably describes his own experiences at gay bars, sharing specific songs and feelings and moments in a way that the reader feels situated there with him. With that all said, I didn't really feel like I took too much away from this book. It felt like it didn't commit enough to either an interesting personal narrative or a comprehensive history to leave me with any lasting impression. As to the first, the author probably cannot help this; it's probably a rare thing to have a personal history worth putting to paper for others to consume, but I think that's all the more reason one would want to stick to telling others' stories--I think of The Deviant's War: The Homosexual vs. the United States of America by Eric Cervini and others that manage to convey important and underattended histories in engaging ways. This book had not enough of either to keep me very interested, and our book club managed about 10 minutes of discussion before moving on to other topics.Last night my friend Patrick, who invited me to this book club, sent around this article, by Bryan Washington, which talks about his own experiences in gay bars, but in more of an episodic, anecdotal way. Obviously, such topics are more appropriate for an NYT article and might not be able to frame a whole book, but I still felt like I got more out of this one article than Lin's whole book. Not only because Washington describes the experience of building gay community in less metropolitan settings (Lin spends a bit of time talking about Blackpool in the United Kingdom, but the balance of the book deals with the gay meccas), but because he talks about gay community in a way that Lin either purposefully or accidentally glosses over. Lin's telling is about sexual encounters, shocking sights and smells, and dynamics; Washington talks about the miracle of queer spaces, the way that queer people together are greater than the sum of their parts, the way we find each other through sex or substance abuse or niche cultural interest and from these unlikely origins create family; for all of Lin's baleful warning about apps, there's no replacing this lifegiving aspect of being a queer person, or the gay bar's role in facilitating these queer communities....more

title: The Confidence Game: Why We Fall for It . . . Every Time
author: Konnikova, Maria*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is a thorough and absolutely fascinating exploration of human psychology and the traits we all harbor (to some degree) that make us vulnerabThis book is a thorough and absolutely fascinating exploration of human psychology and the traits we all harbor (to some degree) that make us vulnerable to exploitation and trickery. It explores not only the foibles con artists exploit to get us to trust them (as well as to take from us what they want, once that trust is earned), but also the powerful impulse we have to disbelieve that we could have been duped. Psychological research (if not intuition) shows that it's far easier to reaffirm the probity of the person who wronged us than to admit we were chumps.Ego is a powerful thing, and most of us fancy ourselves above average in most capacities, something that in the aggregate is mathematically impossible--the Lake Wobegon effect, it's called. The mind cannot really cope with evidence that tends to undermine the powerful, baseline assumptions we have about the skill with which we are navigating the world (and that others so sorely lack), and so we negate it, even absent all glaring evidence suggesting we're the dummies. Konnikova explores ur-Ponzi schemes, demonstrating that even after the con artists had left the country with people's life savings for no conceivable reason other than to escape accountability for a clear scam, having paid out ludicrous dividends up until that point, those who had clearly been taken threatened violence to anyone who dared question the con artists' legitimacy and even hoped to double down on their poor choices, as soon as the con artist returns once this is all sorted out, of course. It also talks about how people who are down on their luck and desperate are the easiest and most effective marks for the talented con artist. Sadly, it was published in 2015, right before the ascent of Donald Trump (though of course he was a famous con artist before his successful foray into presidential politics), and so it does not mention this greatest con artist of our times (but I have plans to find her twitter account in search of her analysis). But it does explain why people like coal miners in West Virginia, having found the person they thought was their savior, who promised them impossible things and an exit from their desperate situations, having seen no dissipation of their misery, double down and support this man who has used them and played them as fools even more so in 2020 than in 2016. It's not too different from the ways that holy rollers have been cheating the poor and exploiting their misery since time immemorial. These subjects are expected, given the book's subject matter, but some of the others--such as the guy who conned his way into the top position on a Korean warship without any expertise, and then performed miraculous feats that any talented doctor would have been proud of--are interesting and notable for the insights into the motivations and methods of not only the imposters themselves, but their pliant marks.I've been extolling this book because it's a condensed and fascinating look into our intricate and quirky minds, why we do the nonsensical things we do and how none of us is immune, no matter how wise or shrewd we fancy ourselves to be. Highly recommended!...more

review: I've never seen the movie, but a colleague I talked books with rhapsodized about Ondaatje, so I thought I would give this a try. What to say? The ornaI've never seen the movie, but a colleague I talked books with rhapsodized about Ondaatje, so I thought I would give this a try. What to say? The ornate construction of this is something of a marvel. The character of the English Patient himself seems to represent Ondaatje's considerable erudition, his probably endless ability to rattle off esoteric details about European castles and paintings and personages, which I found engrossing if a bit implausible. I'm also not sure I understood Caravaggio or his intentions, or found his ability to ferret out secrets and inferences very realistic either, but the Kip character was fascinating and so well conveyed the racial dimensions of imperialism, the frosty paternalism of Britishness in the 20th Century.I think what was missing for me was more backstory. I felt like the characters left us just when we began to figure them out. Still, a really expertly constructed novel. Time to watch the movie, I suppose....more

title: Memorial
author: Washington, Bryan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really loved Lot: Stories, and the QTPOC Houstonians it portrayed. Washington is a great writer, and it was a smashing debut. Memorial, his second bI really loved Lot: Stories, and the QTPOC Houstonians it portrayed. Washington is a great writer, and it was a smashing debut. Memorial, his second book and first novel (as far as I know), deals with the relationship between "Ben" (Benson), a middle-class, HIV+ Black man, working at a daycare, and Mike, his overweight Japanese-American boyfriend, who works as a chef. They've been together for years, and things seem a bit lopsided, inspired by real affection but on borrowed time after a number of blowout fights, emotional distance, and entropy. The novel starts with Mike picking up his acerbic Japanese mother at the airport, driving her to the Houston apartment he shares with Ben, and promptly leaving for Japan to spend time with his moribund father in Osaka. The characters grow apart in two senses--they both grow away from each other and grow as individuals in the absence of the other--as Mike reconnects with his brusque father and Ben his own family, and each of them find romantic partners they connect with better individually. On many levels I related to the goings on in this book: as someone who has lost a parent, as someone who was in the process of wrapping up a relationship that was sustained by a lot of good but ultimately didn't have the legs to continue, as someone who feels alienated by the isolation of the pandemic (which the book does not cover). It felt accessible and true. But it also felt flat, like the characters lacked traceable arcs or achieved closure. I won't make any categorical judgments just yet, but maybe Washington is just more suited to short stories?...more

review: I go back and forth on Ishiguro--"Remains of the Day" is masterful storytelling, and "Never Let Me Go" feels like an epochal entry in the science fictI go back and forth on Ishiguro--"Remains of the Day" is masterful storytelling, and "Never Let Me Go" feels like an epochal entry in the science fiction/bioethical dystopia he seems to enjoy inhabiting. But then there are books like "The Sleeping Giant" that seem amateurish and embarrassing. But the man has a Nobel Prize, so what do I know?"Klara and the Sun" fell somewhere in-between. It had elements of what make "Remains" and "Never Let Me Go" great--namely, the masterful foreshadowing, the foreboding sense of mystery and darkness creeping in ever corner--but Klara was a difficult narrator, both wildly naive and improbably sentient. I also never really bought into the main conceit (view spoiler)[which is that parents would be willing to sacrifice their children's health and even their lives to give them an edge in a world (or at least an America, we have to assume) run amok with bioengineering advantage (hide spoiler)]Anyway, I didn't hate this as much as some but didn't like it nearly as much as his better works. ...more

title: Hidden Valley Road: Inside the Mind of an American Family
author: Kolker, Robert*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the fascinating story of schizophrenia as tragically manifested in one large, American family. It explores the etiology of the disease, which This is the fascinating story of schizophrenia as tragically manifested in one large, American family. It explores the etiology of the disease, which somewhat breaks from our usual models of diseases being inherited/genetic or acquired through contagion. Theories for the cause of schizophrenia swung between blaming environmental factors (often: overbearing or withholding mothers) to entirely genetic (anyone who had a history of depression, for instance, was suspect), and to evaluate the latter, families were often studied to determine what role genes played in the development of this disease. So when scientists became aware of the Galvin family, who had twelves children, six of whom were diagnosed schizophrenics, they sought to learn all that they could. Kolker walks us through the family history--the denial that anything was wrong in an outwardly congenial, large American family, the gradual development of recurring tendencies, the refusal to acknowledge deeply troubling tendencies and the tragedies this would portend--in painstaking detail; that's the real story here, with "schizophrenia" the idea/concept as backdrop. He leaves us in the modern day, where some questions have been answered but many still remain.I liked this; it's not a feel-good story by any means; not uplifting, but informative and insightful. Here's to hoping we continue to learn about this terrifying and mysterious disease....more

review: I'd give it a solid 3.5 out of 5. McCann has a way with language--the repetitive gives his voice a kind of imperative quality. Reading about New York I'd give it a solid 3.5 out of 5. McCann has a way with language--the repetitive gives his voice a kind of imperative quality. Reading about New York in any bygone era is a romantic indulgence for anyone who lived there afterward, and this is no exception. This book is one of those panoramic stories told by a dozen or so protagonists, whose lives intersect in variously profound and insignificant ways, not unlike Cloud Atlas or The Tsar of Love and Techno. It's hard to describe my reaction to the book--on the one hand, I enjoyed listening to it and was eager to finish when my library copy "expired" with a single chapter left. On the other, I'm left feeling a bit disappointed, like the characters were not meaty enough to leave a sustained impression in my mind. Only time will tell, I suppose. But McCann has already impressed me as a master of the written word, poetic and evocative. I'm sure I'll continue to read him and see where this slots into the oeuvre....more

title: A Confederacy of Dunces
author: Toole, John Kennedy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I haven't had the best luck re-reading favorite books from my early adult life. In most cases, the shine of nostalgia does not hold up upon the secondI haven't had the best luck re-reading favorite books from my early adult life. In most cases, the shine of nostalgia does not hold up upon the second attempt. But "Confederacy" is a notable exception.Back in college when I read for pleasure much more sparingly, I have to imagine I had an elaborate selection process, but for the life of me I have no idea why I would have picked up this book. But pick it up I did, and my life was never the same. I graduated a semester early from college but hung around a less notorious Charlottesville, whiling away the down hours at a pizza place reading this book and laughing like a maniac, the first book and to-date one of the only capable of eliciting such a reaction.I think a large part of it stems from my friendship throughout college with my friend Richard, who in many ways was like Ignatius: Richard had American parents but was raised in the toniest of British environs, attending a 500-year-old public school and (at the time at least) affecting a plummy upper crust accent. Richard was/is also huge, about 6'3", 250-300 lbs, and often with a giant frizzy 'fro. He was Ignatian in that he had strong senses of orthodoxy about the world, who was good and who should "be punished," and combined the slovenliness and erudition of Ignatius to a scary degree. Richard would often hold forth in the most officious of ways about recondite rituals like which hand to use when passing a bottle of port at the dinner table and when it was appropriate to wear white tails, yet he could almost invariably be found issuing these pronouncements recumbent on a ratty couch, dressed in torn jeans and a tall tee, usually covered in mustard or BBQ-sauce stains. He was as apt to quote Chaucer as an obscure character from a Ninja Turtles movie, and his life in college was as picaresque as they come. But the comparisons stop there (for the most part--in a twist of fate, Richard ended up moving to and running a restaurant in New Orleans--for which he recently wrote this amusing NYT op-ed), because unlike Ignatius, Richard is moored in reality, friendly, loyal, kind, generally normal, industrious, good to his friends and family, and (as far as I know) not unnaturally animated by the memories of his dead pets. But the first time I read this I was living with Richard, as I had in some form or fashion for three years of college, and we had created a sort of dialectic worldview with one another whereby every action and every college character was exasperatedly judged to be good or bad. There is strong appeal to a coherent (however unreasonable) worldview through which everything can be sorted, and one's heels can pleasingly dig in to the extent it is challenged or opposed as unreasonable by the wishy-washy or idiotic people--the dunces!--confederated against it. Ignatius is an educated troglodyte, a bloated caricature of sloth, bombast, and bigotry, someone animated more by petty animosities and delusions of grandeur than any principled crusade against the tyranny of modern times. But so much of comedy is being unreasonable, and Ignatius does it better than anyone else. A final note on the somewhat well-known tragedy of the author, who tried manfully to shop around his book, only to have it rejected because it didn't "have a point"; that idea seems positively quaint in retrospect, even denuded of the context of the author's tragic suicide at 31 and the posthumous Pulitzer the book so deservedly won. The sad thing is that the editors who read this work knew it was funny, knew it showcased incredible talent, and yet they held it back anyway. The author succumbed to vice and mental illness, and the rest is tragic history. But I keep coming back to thinking about writing something this funny, this thoughtful, this original, this good, only to be told that it won't be read, too bad, try again next time--the confederacy of dunces arrayed against the genius in a bitterly ironic, real-life twist. What a fantastic and burdensome gamble authors (perhaps in particular among artists) take when they endeavor to tell stories......more

review: In this book, Mishra takes on the consequences of a secular modernity that excludes too many from its riches in an attempt to diagnose the anger and nIn this book, Mishra takes on the consequences of a secular modernity that excludes too many from its riches in an attempt to diagnose the anger and nihilism animating so much rhetoric and action in the present. Tracing from anarchists in fin-de-siècle Italy and Russia to the selfie-takers in ISIS, Mishra portrays the anomie that contextualized these individuals' lives and the mythological golden ages they were agitating toward reinstating. He focuses on India's Modi and America's Trump in particular, which seem among the aptest subjects for analysis. Ironically (given that it is more of a whole book than a collection of articles), this felt less coherent than his "Bland Fanatics," but it brings the same rigor of analysis and brutally deadpan send-up of its subjects. Mishra continues to impress me with his intelligence and range....more

title: The Dead Are Arising: The Life of Malcolm X
author: Payne, Les
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had heard that The Autobiography of Malcolm X was too drenched in misogynoir to get through, but curious about Malcolm X's life, this presented a diI had heard that The Autobiography of Malcolm X was too drenched in misogynoir to get through, but curious about Malcolm X's life, this presented a different potential path of discovery. The book stemmed from the author's historical research, plus the unlikely opportunity to become close with and learn from one of Malcolm's siblings. The result is a pretty fleshed out story, though one that seems heavily tilted toward the younger, formative years of Malcolm X's life.The look we get into Malcolm X's early life is interesting if not surprising. Malcolm's family, who were acolytes of Marcus Garvey's Back to Africa movement, refused to abide by the white supremacist codes of early 20th Century America, which dictated where Black people could and could not live, what rights they were entitled to, and the threats they could expect for things as commonplace as not stepping off the sidewalk if a white person walked by. Inevitably, this resulted in squabbles and death threats, including the KKK menacing Malcolm's mother while she was pregnant with him. The family were also devout Christians--his father was a minister--and this seemed to lay the framework for Malcolm's later embrace of and proselytization through the Muslim faith--at first esoteric, then conventional--of his adult years.Malcolm X is so often portrayed as MLK's more acceptable civil rights counterpart, perhaps because his advocacy of an-eye-for-an-eye was less palatable (and continues to be less palatable) to white America than King's turn-the-other-cheek approach. It was interesting to read this during MLK Day, and to think about King's approach removed from this period by half a century in a period where historical figures, even admirable ones, get reevaluated under more critical contemporaneous standards. Should a political leader preaching respectability and incrementalism be criticized for doing so if their legacy is one of success, even if qualified success? Is MLK's legacy intact because his approach was and continues to be countenanced by white Americans, or is it because in addition to his incrementalist and institutionalist approaches, he also preached (conveniently less remembered) ideas that were quite radical? Is Malcolm X's relatively diminished reputation owing to the legacy of his actions, the piquancy of his claims, or our awareness of his own flaws (his longtime adherence to a movement run by a hypocritical lunatic, Elijah Mohammed, his misogyny, his homophobia, etc.)? It's tough to say, but this book often felt like it was trying a bit hard to excuse Malcolm's flaws while extolling his virtues, with the former perhaps justified by the undeservedly negative reputation X still somewhat enjoys in mainstream (read: white) American culture. It glosses over allegations of antisemitism blithely (i.e., "It's not that he hated Jews, it's that he hated all white people!") and misogyny (i.e., "Sure, he was brutal and abusive to white women... but never to Black women!"), and doesn't even attempt to hide his homophobia ("Malcolm hated queers."), and veers into hagiography in other explorations of the man's rhetorical skills, piety, and judgment. It also makes some absurd claims (e.g., saying that a Nation of Islam henchman was know to be "extraordinarily skilled"... with a pickaxe? Claiming that Elijah Mohammad's claims, in the Twentieth Century, of a "mothership" were no crazier than Judeo-Christian beliefs in a talking Burning Bush, as if the latter were not created by pre-literate people to describe the workings of a world they poorly understood, the former by a low rent grifter in the modern era). But more fairly it portrays Malcolm X as a man reacting reasonably to a world that brutalizes and disregards Black lives. As with MLK, who shifted from messages of racial equality to economic equality around the time (and perhaps because of this) he was killed, Malcolm X--having publicly eschewed Elijah Muhammad shortly before (and perhaps causing) his own death--shifted from a message that mostly boiled down to "white people are the devil" to "white people are not inherently evil, but society incentivizes them to exploit, denigrate, and maim Black people," and one wonders what might have happened had he lived to preach this modified message....more

title: The Biggest Bluff: How I Learned to Pay Attention, Master Myself, and Win
author: Konnikova, Maria*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book chronicles what happens when a PhD in psychology takes on the world of high-stakes, no-limit poker and succeeds. Konnikova was interested inThis book chronicles what happens when a PhD in psychology takes on the world of high-stakes, no-limit poker and succeeds. Konnikova was interested in the interplay between luck, skill, and success, and so found her way to the poker table.This book fell into a genre of gimmicky-seeming books I am usually reluctant to pick up, but I really enjoyed it. I found myself invested in the author's journey from true novice to internationally ranked player, and she intersperses it with enough psychological research and revealing self-reflection to make it worthwhile for everyone, not just people interested in gambling or its more respectable cousins (like finance, as she points out repeatedly and in my opinion correctly). This book is about being observant, understanding situations, knowing yourself, minding your cognitive biases, emending your erroneous past behavior in future contexts, knowing how and when you can calculate unknowns, and assessing your opponents/obstacles. I found myself wishing, for example, that I had known about this book before I switched jobs, because it would have allowed me to better negotiate my salary. But even if you don't get anything practical about it, it's still interesting and kind of a fascinating story. I recommend it....more

title: Bland Fanatics: Liberals, the West, and the Afterlives of Empire
author: Mishra, Pankaj
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A rare non-fiction book I could not put down, "Bland Fanatics" takes its title from a Reinhold Niebuhr quote, wherein he discusses the exponents of moA rare non-fiction book I could not put down, "Bland Fanatics" takes its title from a Reinhold Niebuhr quote, wherein he discusses the exponents of modern liberalism who exhort what they peddle--namely Western democracy--as the final form and telos of human society. In discussing the backslapping Anglo-American past 150-year period, Mishra points out the inconsistencies of the West's approach to the rest of the world, for instance Wilson deigning to grant sovereignty to the lesser Poles and Slovaks, but not daring to do so to the Egyptians or Vietnamese, specifically rejecting an audience with Ho Chi Minh in France with shall we say famous consequences. Having sent up the incoherent, inconsistent, and myopic framework used to justify not only the interventions and authority but also the prestige of the Anglo-American century, Mishra takes aim at those who insist on its primacy yet bemoan any cracks in its hegemony, from Churchill to Powell to Niall Ferguson to Jordan Peterson. Picking over the carcass of the now discredited idea that Anglo-American liberal democracy as deployed on the unwilling and unconsulted browner peoples of the Earth is the Only Way, or a good way, or a way designed to promote anything more than crass consumerism or neocolonial dynamics, Mishra lambastes the confidence and incompetence of Americans and Britons who conflate a legacy of power with contemporary wisdom, intelligence, and legitimacy. Showing more than telling, Mishra's exclamation point to this takedown is the leadership, at present, of the free world consigned to the wild-haired and buffoonish Donald Trump and Boris Johnson, both grotesque products of generations of privilege that has insulated them as much from responsibility as it has from scruple or the ability to attempt introspection. Although the book starts out as an exploration of the West's benighted attempts at "civilizing" (and really dominating) the non-white peoples of the Earth, especially where they sit atop resources requiring cleverer workarounds to achieve colonial exploitation, it also takes aim at the rudiments of British prestige and culture, especially where they have anchored firmer roots in its more rowdy and interventionist offspring such as America, Canada, and Australia. The Economist--which has as many subscribers in Britain as in its Commonwealth, and three times that many in America--earns special attention for the duration and particularly pointed nature of its contribution to Anglo-American economic nostrums and interventionist urgings (an editor skipping down the hallway singing "My enemy is dead!" after Pinochet's CIA-backed coup killed the democratically elected socialist president of Chile was a particularly revealing and grisly anecdote), as does Rupert Murdoch, for perhaps more obvious reasons. The BBC, and the "unteachably stupid" and ossified aristocratic class that dominates and bungles British foreign policy (as exemplified by the Eton-Oxford "chumocracy" of Cameron and Johnson, modern analogues of Lord Mountbatten, stick out as leaders whose pedigree suffices where quality is wanting) also merit merciless and entertaining scrutiny.This collection of essays is that much more notable for being so gripping despite being about something that obviously shapes my world, but is not very front-of-mind. It is just dripping with intelligent, droll thought, elegant writing, and interesting anecdotes. I have been exhorting it to everyone I can buttonhole, and do so here as well....more

title: A Libertarian Walks Into a Bear: The Utopian Plot to Liberate an American Town
author: Hongoltz-Hetling, Matthew*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the story of Grafton, New Hampshire, and the unlikely redoubt of libertarians it has become. The author wryly recounts this tale, focusing disThis is the story of Grafton, New Hampshire, and the unlikely redoubt of libertarians it has become. The author wryly recounts this tale, focusing distinctly on two issues libertarians grapple with, one famously ("Everyone's a libertarian until their house catches fire") and another less so (bears: libertarians believe that one should be able to do what one wants on one's property, including as concerns wildlife; when one woman began undertaking superhuman efforts to feed a colony of lay-about bears, gun enthusiasts clashed with state authorities in their attempts to mitigate the problem while everyone else remained helpless).This book is not a charitable take on libertarianism, and perhaps that is acceptable. I'm no fan of the doctrine, and for reasons the book chronicles: the idea that one can take all of the advantages of modern life and exempt oneself from them is not only childish, but inevitably courts disaster. Ultimately, we all live in a society and human tolls must be accounted for; ideally, we prevent them, even if it costs us. In Grafton, the poor are unable to prevent bear attacks, what little government presides is incapable of or unwilling to provide bear protection services that render bear-human interactions a rarity in surrounding locales, and fires run rampant while principled citizens dicker over peanuts and ponder whether all-volunteer fire companies can solve a problem that the rest of the developed world has already figured is a worthwhile expense that can be borne by everyone collectively.Anyway, it's an amusing yarn, but not particularly revelatory. I enjoyed it....more

title: The Stone Sky        (The Broken Earth, #3)
author: Jemisin, N.K.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The third and final book in the Broken Earth trilogy, and probably my least favorite. I would imagine it's tough writing these epic tales, especially The third and final book in the Broken Earth trilogy, and probably my least favorite. I would imagine it's tough writing these epic tales, especially in this genre: when science and fantasy merge, the balance at the beginning favors mystery, non-disclosure, intrigue. As the author carefully releases little morsels of information to clarify why things are the way they are, she runs the risk of losing the reader's interest by revealing a conceit that is not particularly satisfying or well-explained; viewers of "Lost" may appreciate what I mean. In this case the conceit was "magic." Granted, from the first pages of the first book we have supernatural things happening that are essentially magic--humans' ability to manipulate earth, rocks, tectonics, "sense" things underground, and flash-freeze entire cities in the blink of an eye. But Jemisin also meticulously built that world, and it was one that had significant limitations. When you gesture to "magic" as something vague and essentially all-conquering, it takes the fun out of it. Analogizing to another TV show/comic, it's why I always found action involving X-Men Wolverine, Cyclops, Gambit, Storm, etc. more intriguing than the storylines involving the essentially omnipotent beings like Apocalypse and Phoenix. Anyway, I will wrap up my nerding by saying that I still think this trilogy is worth reading and very entertaining. It just had trouble sticking the landing, which seems to be par for the course for trilogies in my experience....more

title: Shuggie Bain
author: Stuart, Douglas*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Shuggie Bain" was a difficult read for me. It's branded as a kind of poor, gay, Anglophone bildungsroman, but struck me much more as a tale of povert"Shuggie Bain" was a difficult read for me. It's branded as a kind of poor, gay, Anglophone bildungsroman, but struck me much more as a tale of poverty and alcoholism. At one point the titular character and one of his female confidants talk about their alcoholic mothers, saying that alcoholism is just a slow suicide for people who cannot face reality, and that sounded true enough. Even as Shuggie's mother's alcoholism abates at times, there is such a sense of foreboding and irretrievable doom that the few breaks of sunlight seem menacing rather than a reprieve. If you are close with anyone who struggles (or struggled) with alcoholism, I would imagine it could be difficult as well.Told amidst the surprising squalor and dismalness of working class Thatcherite Scotland, Shuggie is the effeminate only child of Agnes, a fading beauty and unregenerate alcoholic, and Big Shug, a ladies-man cabbie. Poverty immiserates as a rule, and that's certainly the case here. Infidelity, lack of economic opportunity, alcoholism, and Catholic/Protestant antagonisms spoil the relationship, and the children bear the brunt of the fallout. Unlike other books in this genre I've catalogued before (The End of Eddy, etc.), this book is not about the main character's sexual awakening so much as it is a background leading into his adolescence and adulthood. Shuggie Bain is well written and emotive, but an unrelenting and emotional slog. If you're up to it, I think it's worth the read. But the book is as dreary as a Glasgow winter, just be prepared....more

Instead of (view spoiler)[an over-the-hill gay man swanning all over the globe, doubting his appeal only to reunite with his much younger lover, a story that I never found believable or very interesting (hide spoiler)], McCauley's David inhabits a much less glamorous station in life, having been dumped by his most recent lover (who is engaged to a rich surgeon), inhabiting a career he doesn't love, and not having much in terms of financial security to show for his travails. In desperate need of a change, he leaves San Francisco and goes to stay with his ex-wife in maritime Massachusetts, encountering a colorful cast of characters and forming meaningful if not predictable relationships throughout. Heartwarming and funny, I have been browbeating everyone I can buttonhole who loved "Less" to read this and let me know their thoughts on how the two compare. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This felt like it went by too quickly. It's a short story collection from a young author I'd never heard of before, but this was winning plaudits--of This felt like it went by too quickly. It's a short story collection from a young author I'd never heard of before, but this was winning plaudits--of both the formal and informal kind--for months now, and I knew I had to pick it up to see what all the hype was about. I suggested it for my book club, which would have been really great in hindsight, given the DC-based title story at the end of this collection, but we went with another book instead. Still, I'm really glad I picked this one up.With the exception of the final story, a kind of Trumpian, post-truth, Left-gone-amok "The Human Stain," the other stories felt a bit too evanescent to really stick with me. They were well written, and they cover a lot of topics, touching on familiar touchstones of American racism and racial strife without feeling hoary or warmed over. But I think the last story, with its almost gothic air of mystery and foreboding, its explorations of wealth, privilege, race, politics, friendship, and the safety, ease, and ghastly appurtenances of whiteness, stands out among them all and will stick with me for a while. I'm still thinking about its Sopranos-esque ending.For how short this is, it packs a wallop. I'll definitely read her other book, also apparently highly lauded, as soon as I can get my hands on it....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was really well written and intense, so much so that for the first time in memory, I found myself a bit exhausted and exasperated living in the aThis was really well written and intense, so much so that for the first time in memory, I found myself a bit exhausted and exasperated living in the author's head. The premise is that a 30-something gay, having left NYC for LA and not in possession of wealth or the perfect body, seeks out an otherworldly solution for his brokenness. He is in recovery from addiction and coming off a few very painful breakups, so when he hears about a shaman who can cure everything, he leaps at the opportunity.As I said, Lansky is such a skilled writer and an observant narrator, but sometimes--especially when cataloguing the materialistic things, e.g., the Creed cologne bottles or the fur trim of a designer coat--it felt hard to take seriously, especially when these details vied for space on the same page with (or stood in as metaphors for) breakthroughs and more transcendent realizations. There's a certain type of gay whose currency seems to consist entirely in being fluent in identifying, ranking, and hoarding such details, and while I get the impression that the author wanted us to associate those with his former self--the pre-enlightenment iteration--it didn't really come off that way in the end. Regardless, I hope the author (presumably the narrator) is happy, and seems genuinely headed in that direction....more

review: I love this book from the beginning. I was finishing The Fifth Season on a car ride home from visiting my mom, my first real departure from DC since tI love this book from the beginning. I was finishing The Fifth Season on a car ride home from visiting my mom, my first real departure from DC since the pandemic started. I finished it with about 30 minutes remaining and frantically looked around on my phone for something else to tide me over. At a stop light, I realized I had three days left on a rental from the library: "Deacon King Kong," a book that had received rave s from bookmarks.com. I hadn't even downloaded it, it just had been reserved. Within twenty minutes, I was hooked.The book follows a charming cast of characters, all old New York mainstays, as they navigate the drama that touches off the action: a doddering old widower drunk--Sportcoat, or Deacon King Kong--shoots the projects' chief drug dealer in cold blood, right in the face. The insights into the characters' backgrounds, their connections, and their colorful pasts and how they came to Brooklyn unfolds in a charmingly Dickensian manner, and a lot of ground gets covered and issues reconciled by the time the book ends.I had read this author's The Good Lord Bird before, and it has similar elements. I don't remember being blown away by it, but I certainly enjoyed it. But I think this book shows off the author's whimsy, talent, ability to develop humorously flawed characters whom you root for and enjoy seeing resolve their issues. 5/5, highly recommended....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a strange little book. The precocious teenage children of dissolute, upper crust, arts-class parents--friends from an unnamed college--form aThis was a strange little book. The precocious teenage children of dissolute, upper crust, arts-class parents--friends from an unnamed college--form an intricate society amongst themselves. At some point they strike out on an adventure and come across some richer, more elite youths. I thought that was where the story was going--maybe not quite town v. gown but suit v. tux. But after a heady couple of days with these Eloi youths they return to the home they're renting for the summer right before a massive storm destroys everything. Given that this book had Hamptons vibes, I thought it was a recounting of Hurricane Sandy. The house is destroyed and the children once again strike out on their own, but this time with very dark results. I won't spoil it but it turns out this wasn't Sandy and society has more or less collapsed. I suppose this is a tale of climate change intertwined with the luxury and wealth that will be needed to survive it, should it get really bad. I didn't really find this book that plausible or well constructed--lots of Chekhov's gun violations. But it had good writing, was evocative and was easy enough to get through. ...more

review: I picked this up forever ago, and to be honest it didn't do much for me at first. I think I found the shifting back and forth between the times beforeI picked this up forever ago, and to be honest it didn't do much for me at first. I think I found the shifting back and forth between the times before Shakespeare and his wife married and around the time Hamnet dies distracting and it made it harder for me to ground myself in the plot. Beautiful writing, but that's seldom enough for me.Flash forward several months later and my friend Jeff and my mom had really exhorted this one to me, so I thought I would give it a shot. It's really well crafted, consistently lyrical, and a really affecting tale of love and loss in the times of a different and far more virulent, unknown pandemic: the bubonic plague. Much of this is pure conjecture, which the author readily notes--we don't even know what Hamnet died of, for instance, much less have any certainty that it was the plague--but that gave the author the license to speculate (for instance: never once does Shakespeare mention a plague in his plays; it could be that he wanted to divert and remove people from their miserable and uncertain lives; but it could also be that the topic was simply too painful for him, and so he refused to address it) and weave an engrossing tale.Highly recommended....more

review: "Weather" came highly recommended by a number of people I follow, and I'm glad I put myself on the library list. I didn't know much about it going in-"Weather" came highly recommended by a number of people I follow, and I'm glad I put myself on the library list. I didn't know much about it going in--I admit, I originally thought it was a series of short essays--but it's really just a deadpan novel about an unmoored mother raising a child in New York City among the banal outrageousness and stupidity that characterized the years leading up to and following Trump's election, with a focus on the environment. It dwells on marital satisfaction, parenting, global warming, ennui, addiction and family loyalty in a surprisingly short and brisk way. It's peppered with jokes and reflections on modern life and all of its dissatisfaction. Although written before the pandemic, it felt strangely appropriate for the moment....more

title: Drive Your Plow Over the Bones of the Dead
author: Tokarczuk, Olga
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "The tigers of wrath are wiser than the horses of instruction"I related to this book on so many levels, and enjoyed it so heartily. It starts out ordi"The tigers of wrath are wiser than the horses of instruction"I related to this book on so many levels, and enjoyed it so heartily. It starts out ordinarily enough: a woman of little consequence is called by her neighbor to attend to the body of a neighbor who violently choked on the bone of a deer he had recently slaughtered, and the woman is affected by it deeply. The narrator, a student of Blake and a self-described "crone" interacts with her neighbors in various frustrating and alienating ways, and begins to propound a theory about why various men begin meeting their violent deaths: the animals are fighting back against their slaughter. She is by no means coy about sharing this theory with friends and strangers alike, and as a third audience the reader has to decide whether she is descending into madness, or casting a series of events in a light that reflects her own theory of justice and happenstance, or both.(view spoiler)[It became quite obvious to me early on that the narrator herself was doing the killing, given her disgust with meat-eating generally and her pointed vitriol toward hunters in particular. Of course this wasn't fully revealed until the penultimate chapter, but the proliferation of murders of men who had scoffed at and rebuffed her attempts to prevent or mitigate the slaughter of wild and abuse of domestic animals could not have been a coincidence. This book is a fascinating exploration of vigilantism--whether it makes sense to abide by the rules of a society whose rules and principles you find so arbitrary, hypocritical, and backward; whether you lose yourself in the process or can trust yourself to mete out justice, or that your sense of justice will endure. It also underscores the link between wisdom, motivation, and anger, clarifying more than once that the latter can be the source of cogency and righteous action, something I often feel as someone whose reaction to injustice is seldom sadness and often indignation, and who rarely feels more articulate or unflagging than when he is angered by a sense of injustice.And there's also the way the author addresses being ignored or of no consequence. For better or for worse, I've always felt this feeling more severely than I see it borne in others, and I enjoyed how the protagonist weaponizes being looked over, after years of accepting it. Try as she did to effect important changes and to get people to listen to her the conventional ways, they would pay her heed in the end. None of this is to say that any of her actions are sane or warranted. But it's interesting and invigorating to witness. Especially as concerns her disassociation from a violent, male, hypocritical and testosterone-guided society, it is not so difficult to imagine that rejecting and subverting the power structures in a violently antisocial way might not be such a hard break for someone; the self-recrimination to act 'sanely' might become a pesky voice to ignore, rather than an admonition guiding all of life's choices. (hide spoiler)]I loved Tokarczuk's voice in Flights, but it lacks a cohesive plot. This book harnessed all of the weirdness and arcana within a more conventional plot structure, and I loved it....more

title: The Deviant's War: The Homosexual vs. the United States of America
author: Cervini, Eric*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the story of Frank Kameny and the other folks who toiled for lesbian and gay rights in the period before Stonewall. The author, a very thoughtThis is the story of Frank Kameny and the other folks who toiled for lesbian and gay rights in the period before Stonewall. The author, a very thoughtful and toothsome (someone called him a "snackademic," lol) young scholar--Eric Cervini--lays out the respectability politics that guided this stubborn and tenacious young man to become the first advocate for lesbian and gay equality in the workplace.As a gay civil rights lawyer, and given the momentous 7-2 Supreme Court decision in Bostock that extended Title VII protections to LGBT people, I read this eagerly and with great relish. With that said, the author takes what might have been a dry historical monograph and imbues it with personal details, amusing anecdotes, and commentary on the wider society to make for what I think was a very enjoyable read. We chose this for our book club and this past week, we were lucky enough to host the L.A.-based author via Zoom. He graciously sat with us for a full hour, talking about gay DC, the failings of the LGBT rights movement to support the civil rights of other groups, the failure of queer men to adequately support queer women and trans people, and had thoughtful, intriguing answers for all of our questions. I highly recommend this book to anyone who wants to know about the early stages of the LGBT rights movement in the United States, or who is interested in the tensions between conventional and radical elements within a movement ostensibly agitating for the same goal, or who is interested in understanding (some of the) tensions that still divide those who fight for LGBTQ+ civil rights and those who fight for civil rights based on sex or race....more

title: Exciting Times
author: Dolan, Naoise
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't think I've ever read any two books by two different authors that were more alike than "Exciting Times" and Sally Rooney's "Conversations with I don't think I've ever read any two books by two different authors that were more alike than "Exciting Times" and Sally Rooney's "Conversations with Friends." "Normal People," Rooney's second novel--which itself seems to draw alternate criticism or praise for its similarity to her first novel--doesn't even come close. I loved "Conversations with Friends," so why the three stars here? Well, I think it felt too similar, almost a high brow simulacrum of the original. Witty, early-20s, Irish, female protagonist pursuing emotionally unavailable handsome guy? Check. Off-the-cuff ruminations on communism and the vampiric nature of capitalism? Check. Endless conversations with little plot? Check. Ambient queer vibes? Check. Perhaps the only meaningful differences were this book's focus on the English language (and its recalcitrant offshoots), the location (Hong Kong), and the absence of health issues. But these books were shockingly similar, startlingly so. So I guess I intend to recommend this to others, it's entertaining and incredibly easy to read, as was "Conversations with Friends." Perhaps not as thought-provoking, and the writer is certainly talented. I just look forward to reading something of hers that does not appear to be a simulacrum of another recent standout work....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: John Hodgman, the king of holding forth, does it again. By "does it again," I mean both that this is funny, thoughtful, and human, though also nothingJohn Hodgman, the king of holding forth, does it again. By "does it again," I mean both that this is funny, thoughtful, and human, though also nothing new if you've read his other books, particularly the recent ones. Given its evanescence, Hodgman dwells heavily on the nature of celebrity, its capriciousness and perks, but also the downsides. I related very strongly to his quest for medallion status on Delta, having once gone to absurd lengths to secure it myself (though I very much dispute his characterization that Platinum is not superior to Gold. That is pure rot). Anyway, almost missed this in my library queue before it expired and very glad I didn't. It was a reliable and whimsical companion as I pottered about during quarantine, or took drives to grocery stores or waited in line at the post office, distracting me from the molasses-slow workers and too-close customers that otherwise may have turned my internal rage-screams into external ones. Thanks, John Hodgman!: I know you can relate to the indignation but also approve of taking the polite, sympathetic path....more

review: This is a short book that begins with major "As I Lay Dying" vibes. Two children tote the rotting corpse of a parent, searching for a proper place to This is a short book that begins with major "As I Lay Dying" vibes. Two children tote the rotting corpse of a parent, searching for a proper place to bury him. The story then veers forward and backward in time, switching narrator from Lucy to her deceased Ba (father) to provide the background to how these folks of Asian descent ended up in North America (it seems like this takes place in the US, and there are lots of scenes in San Francisco toward the end, but much of it could have taken place in Canada), and to provide a bit of color to characters who are otherwise only seen through the imperfect gaze of an observant child. The two orphaned daughters take vastly different paths in life, but the genesis of each is in the treatment (and mistreatment) they face as racial others on the frontier, and the expectations and circumstances placed upon them by their parents and by the larger society as children. It's a mournful tale but one well told, and poetically written....more

title: In the Dream House
author: Machado, Carmen Maria*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: We read this for one of my book clubs, and I really enjoyed it. I used a clumsy analogy in my bookclub that I don't think landed, but it stuck with meWe read this for one of my book clubs, and I really enjoyed it. I used a clumsy analogy in my bookclub that I don't think landed, but it stuck with me as I read these very short vignettes detailing the development and degeneration of a queer relationship into emotional abuse. I remember in high school my trigonometry teacher telling us that a circle could be described as an infinite number of lines tangent to a single function, with the circle being "rounder," the better described by the greater number of lines contributing to its rounded shape. These insights were so brief--not more than a few sentences in some cases--but they described such a vivid dynamic. It's probably impossible to recreate the experience or the relationship in any reliably complete or objective way--just as a finite number of tangents articulates an imperfect circle--but by giving us so many looks through many different lenses, Machado gives us the next best thing. Machado endured abuse that I won't call unbelievable, (because I do believe her) but rather unfathomable. I truly found it hard to relate, not least because I have adverted to far less problematic and psychopathic behaviors to justify ending a relationship. But I have to believe that lots of emotionally abusive relationships unfold this way, and though she does her best to educate her readers on the ways in which queer relationships are no less susceptible to such abuse than straight ones, it still felt like there was something fundamentally awry, something beyond just the badness of the abusive dynamic to begin with: it felt unnatural to see this dynamic unfolding absent a gendered power imbalance.Anyway, maybe that's my naivete or just my extrapolation of my own experiences, or the fact that I've never read about any queer abuse dynamics before, whether between men or women (or any other combination of genders). But I still found it unsettling. Ultimately I'm happy for Machado (the acknowledgements were tender and beautiful), and I'm glad I gave her a second chance after a disappointing introduction. I've been evangelizing for this one and loaning out my copy to anyone who will take it, and eagerly await her next issue....more
