title: Say Nothing: A True Story of Murder and Memory in Northern Ireland
author: Keefe, Patrick Radden
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this right on the heels of Milkman, which I greatly enjoyed. This might be read as the non-fiction accompaniment, as they both came out recentlI read this right on the heels of Milkman, which I greatly enjoyed. This might be read as the non-fiction accompaniment, as they both came out recently to significant acclaim, and both deal with N. Ireland's Troubles period.The impetus for this book is pretty wild: Boston College somehow convinced a number of people who were deeply involved in IRA activity to speak candidly bout their experiences and even to confess to many of the violent crimes they took part in over the years, in the interests of preserving the stories of the guerrilla side (presumably the British narratives will all be declassified at some point and in any event are better documented than the non-governmental group's). Improbably, many of the most deeply implicated folks readily spoke to the coordinators of this project, thinking that a private American university's clout and remove from Northern Ireland would be sufficient to preserve the secrecy of the participants until they died, which was their incentive to become involved and speak candidly. Obviously there are international treaties and court systems that can override whatever "clout" is meant to be and that can supersede any such promises, and the stories began to leak before many of the most implicated folks had passed away. That's the genesis, likely, of so much of the material that made up this book. But the drama about the consequences and reckoning these folks faced is secondary. Instead, the real pull of this book is the insider's look into IRA dynamics, the secrecy and deceit that characterized everything they did, and the powerful zeal animating nationalist activism. It's also interesting to view, in retrospect, how quickly a place like Belfast can change from a veritable war zone to a mini-London, with all of its Georgian decorum and prosperity. Ireland, too, in this book is portrayed in the way it had always been portrayed to me as the offspring of Irish grandparents: beautiful, but squalid, cold, backward, stubborn, and poor poor poor. Now, by some measures Ireland is the most prosperous non-microstate in Europe, and one of the richest countries in the world. Obviously this is owing to many factors, but it's hard to imagine that could have happened if bombs were still regularly going off in Belfast and Dublin. Luckily we're past those times, and with Brexit and demographic trends being what they are, a united Ireland may not be too far in the offing. One is not necessarily left with the impression that this would be a good thing, or that the zeal is even still there for it to take on the epic dimensions it did in the latter half of the 20th Century, but it will be interesting to see whether seven centuries of bitter division can be forgotten in the face of overwhelming prosperity. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is not your typical campus novel. I've read that the author sought to center himself as a Black, gay man in a campus novel, because he had seldomThis is not your typical campus novel. I've read that the author sought to center himself as a Black, gay man in a campus novel, because he had seldom if ever read anything reflecting his experience. For Wallace, the Black, gay protagonist: hell is white people, and he cannot get away from them. Grad school does tend to be quite privileged, and in a country like the United States where privilege correlates most closely with race, it is not surprising that almost all of Wallace's cohort and academic program are white people from privileged backgrounds. Having been spurned, underestimated, and unwanted by these people before--despite his hopes for escaping the benighted South and finding sanctuary in the enlightened (?) North/Midwest--he often tries to avoid them, but when you live in Madison, WI there do not seem to be many alternatives. with some exceptions, these white people are all pretty insufferable, wanting to live out a pastoral, liberal ideal but too cowardly to call out the cartoonish racism that Wallace is subjected to on a regular basis. Anyway, I liked the writing in this book but I'm a bit confused by the ending. It takes a weird turn and I'm not sure what we're supposed to take away from it. Apparently it took the author five weeks to complete this, which is stunningly impressive considering how good the first two thirds are but also might explain why it feels like it didn't stick the landing....more

title: Why We Sleep: Unlocking the Power of Sleep and Dreams
author: Walker, Matthew
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Started reading this on a recommendation from a friend. This was a tough book to listen to, honestly. It talks not only about why we sleep, why it's iStarted reading this on a recommendation from a friend. This was a tough book to listen to, honestly. It talks not only about why we sleep, why it's important, and why we dream, but about the deleterious effects of not getting enough of it. This part was the hard part--they basically make it seem like if you're not getting 7-8 hours per night (spoiler: I do not), then you're walking around lobotomized, setting yourself up for a lifetime of Parkinson's and cancer, in addition to every other type of decline you can imagine.If you're like me, you bristle at such claims. On the one hand, they seem of the sort peddled by writers of some "wonder food," who claim that everything bad comes of not getting enough of it, and so much--an implausible amount of--good can be wrought from availing yourself of its wonders. This, of course, is an inapt analogy, because we can all get by fine with or without most diets, but none of us can live without sleep. And even those of us who can "get by" on less sleep are probably deluding ourselves, as those who truly show no cognitive decline when they get 5-6 hours of sleep per night are vanishingly rare, something like one in 50,000 to 100,000 people. I think where I've settled is that I buy the claims generally but understand that they operate in the aggregate. It's not that I think that I am not impairing myself in the short-term (hopefully not the long-term, but *gulp*), it's just that I don't think that I am as negatively affected as most people by getting less sleep than recommended. I came to this realization after the chapter on obesity, which is not something I have had to contend with, whether in times of bountiful sleep or times of lesser, despite the baleful warnings this book issued. I believe that I would be in worse shape if I slept more, as I use a lot of the time that people spend snoozing working out, and any fatigue I get from losing out on sleep feels primarily mental rather than "corporeal." Anyway, interesting read. I do think it will alter my approach to sleep, though it remains to be seen how. Something to think through....more

review: I'm interested in this author, but this book didn't stick the landing. It's set in a "Get Out"-esque world where racist displays are exaggerated as a I'm interested in this author, but this book didn't stick the landing. It's set in a "Get Out"-esque world where racist displays are exaggerated as a narrative and thematic device to make germane commentary on racism in this country. The main character is a black lawyer living in the American South, married to a white woman and the father of a biracial son whose skin he continually tries to bleach so that he can pass for white. He is trying to make partner and mortifies himself (and his family) in pretty horrific ways in order to get by and get ahead in a world that is controlled by both white people and their deputies in non-white communities, and tilted against the progress or survival of people of color.The concept is interesting, and the writing starts out pleasantly snappy and tart. But I think the plot meandered a bit too much. I'm also not really sure what the reader is meant to take away from the book, particularly given its bleak and enigmatic ending. ...more

title: Apeirogon
author: McCann, Colum*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The drought has ended. After many months, I have come across a truly exceptional book. "Apeirogon" follows shortly on another (extremely good) book toThe drought has ended. After many months, I have come across a truly exceptional book. "Apeirogon" follows shortly on another (extremely good) book told in a similar fashion, Carmen Maria Machado's "In the Dream House: A Memoir," which uses a somewhat similar storytelling device. As it turns out, I wrote a not particularly articulate  of that book, in which I tried to describe the act of storytelling by describing an apeirogon, or an infinitely sided shape, though I didn't have the vocabulary for describing it at the time. Like Machado, McCann's book has many chapters, often using topics as varied and orthogonal to the plot of the story as the migratory habits of birds, or the death of the first socialist president of France, or the Troubles in Northern Ireland to tell a rounded if imperfectly detailed story, in this case about the ceaseless and senseless bloodshed and human trauma that stem from the Israeli occupation of Palestine. The two protagonists of this story are actual people, fathers of slain daughters, one Jewish Israeli and one Palestinian Muslim, who each lost a child through senseless violence stemming from the occupation. This book is just suffused with humanity, and it's a mix of shocking, amazing, and witnessing grace to understand these men, to inhabit the worlds they occupied and the forces that should have contrived to make them anything but what they turned out to be--deeply compassionate, empathetic people dedicated to ending one of the gravest human rights and democratic failures of modern times. I have seen so many people on this website decry this book and admit that they abandoned it part way through, because they were so upset by the allegedly anti-Israel bias it exhibits. Shame, shame, shame on these people, who are so dug into their strident beliefs that they cannot even devote the patience to witness the full unfurling of the stories of people who have lost far more to this conflict than they ever will, yet have had the nuance of opinion and grace of understanding to avoid the pitfall of lizard-brained, reactionary hate and have chosen to use the position their grief has given them to advocate for peace and understanding. One does not have to come away from this book thinking that Palestinians do no wrong and that the State of Israel is an unjustifiable evil. But to abandon it is an act as much of cowardice as it is of ignorance.I got my name from a book written by Leon Uris, a Jewish American who had never stepped foot in Ireland when he wrote Trinity. The book appealed to many of the Irish diaspora, including my parents, who named me after its protagonist, Conor Larkin. I always marveled at how someone from a culture so different from the one he portrayed could tell a story so evocatively, and marveled at his ability to do so. I'm not sure if Irish author Colum McCann has visited Israel or Palestine, but the symmetry of his feat is not lost on me.Read this book. It is a marvel....more

title: Small Fry: A Memoir
author: Brennan-Jobs, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Lisa Brennan-Jobs is the biological daughter of Steve Jobs, who needs no introduction, and this book tracks her life knowing him to varying degrees, cLisa Brennan-Jobs is the biological daughter of Steve Jobs, who needs no introduction, and this book tracks her life knowing him to varying degrees, chronicling her own development and his difficult and often cruel form of parenting. One comes away with the notion that Steve Jobs was an absolute sociopath--being a tyrant to adults in the workplace is one thing, but a man who makes seven-year-olds cry at dinner because he doesn't like their voice or what dish they ordered, or who has billions of dollars but won't pay for his daughter's college tuition, or who says "too bad" when his daughter--whom he has pressured to live with him in order to be "part of [the] family"--asks him if he wouldn't mind coming to say goodnight to her every once in a while because she is lonely is truly an ogre.Seriously, the guy is a monster, and his moments of goofiness or occasional largess or charm really make up for so little of the bad behavior that I don't really understand why the daughter stuck with him. I suppose power does that to you, and when you're used to thinking you're an infallible genius, it's no longer enough to have everyone do whatever you ask them to do; they have to anticipate every possible bad reaction you might have and walk around on eggshells to avert their mere possibility. Somehow, despite having a mother who also seemed to have her own issues, Lisa turned out--at least in the subjective light of self-portrayal--a pretty grounded person with good values and a compassionate heart. I think the ending leaves it a bit ambiguous and up to the reader to decide whether Lisa forgives Jobs, or whether he deserves it. But regardless of how you feel about this man, it's a fascinating look into the personal life and personal shortcomings of a person who influenced all of our lives considerably and likely will continue to do so....more

title: Barracoon: The Story of the Last "Black Cargo"
author: Hurston, Zora Neale
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Such a strange book--I can't really rate it because it's not really a work of authorship by ZNH, nor is it something that I think you can rate as "gooSuch a strange book--I can't really rate it because it's not really a work of authorship by ZNH, nor is it something that I think you can rate as "good" or "bad" by the subject himself. By way of a little bit of history, a few decades before the Civil War (and many years after the British Empire outlawed the practice), the Congress outlawed the trade in slaves brought from abroad. While this occurred long before the subject of this book was even born, given how valuable slaves were, many profiteers took it upon themselves to engage in the skin trade and bring people over from Africa. One of them was Cudjoe Lewis, and he was the last of these to survive when Franz Boas, father of modern anthropology at Columbia University (and subject of another book I am reading right now, coincidentally: Gods of the Upper Air: How a Circle of Renegade Anthropologists Reinvented Race, Sex, and Gender in the Twentieth Century), sent his acolyte Zora Neale Hurston to Florida to interview him.It's interesting, because his life spans Africa and then slavery and then attempts at Reconstruction, such as they even existed in deep Florida. Cudjoe had a really tough life, probably even by free Black standards of the day, and the tale is a mournful one. There are the expected tales of whites leaving their former slaves with nothing, black bodies as grist fed into the rough machinery of an industrializing behemoth, and the wanton violence that was visited on his family until he was the only one left. ZNH captures his unique dialect, grammar, and cadence, in a way that is hypnotic, and one wonders whether the more modern discomfort for writing out grammatical errors and slang would have prevented this book from being written....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A bittersweet coming-of-age tale set in the mucky nether regions of Florida, Swamplandia! chronicles the travails of an entertainment family fallen onA bittersweet coming-of-age tale set in the mucky nether regions of Florida, Swamplandia! chronicles the travails of an entertainment family fallen on hard times and recently down a matriarch. It's told from the viewpoints of two main characters: the precocious eldest (and only) son, who is eager to escape the backward swamp in which he was whelped and the scrappy youngest, a girl, who desperately wants to keep the family's alligator-themed entertainment park afloat. The middle sister and the distant father are seen through their eyes, and what starts out as lighthearted fun told in a child's voice quickly becomes rather dire and adult. This book conveys a lot of foreboding and mystery, dwelling as it does on a lot of Jungian discomfort with the reptilian, the murky, the turbid, the reclusive, as well as an intimate and sometimes unflattering picture of Florida. I can see why this book generated a lot of buzz when it debuted. It was satisfying and engrossing, and above all unpredictable. I enjoyed it....more

I guess I'd also take off points for not always feeling terribly realistic. I don't know what forms of expression modern British racism takes, but the types of things white people in this book feel comfortable saying to black people were jaw-dropping. Is it really so explicit in England? If not, then this one gets even more points taken off for being hamfisted about an issue that it doesn't deal with as well/realistically as it does anxiety, for example. If so, Jesus--Britain, get your shit together! Another aspect that felt unrealistic was that Queenie is for some reason deeply in love with some dweeby white guy named Tom who can't even bother to defend her against his family's casual racism and doesn't support her in her struggle to overcome psychological trauma. title: Gods of the Upper Air: How a Circle of Renegade Anthropologists Reinvented Race, Sex, and Gender in the Twentieth Century
author: King, Charles*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the story fo Franz Boas, Margaret Mead, Zora Neale Hurston (and others), and how they upended a largely U.S.-centered notion of white/EuropeanThis is the story fo Franz Boas, Margaret Mead, Zora Neale Hurston (and others), and how they upended a largely U.S.-centered notion of white/European cultural and genetic superiority. From inauspicious beginnings and against headwinds of Nazism in his home country (to say nothing of the taxonomic and "meritocratic" tendencies of his adopted home, the fin-de-siècle United States), Boas established anthropology as an academic discipline at Columbia University, and immediately began recruiting some of the most luminous minds to develop under his tutelage, Mead and Hurston included. Mostly their task was to establish cultural relativism, and I think the following summarizes the ethos well:There can be no real analysis of human societies without the prior assumption that one’s own way of seeing the world isn’t universal, [Ruth] Benedict said. Every society, including our own, suffers from the tyranny of the capital letter: we tend to equate our own behavior with a thing we label Behavior and the ways that seem natural to us with a thing we call Human Nature. But all societies are in fact just snippets of a “great arc” of possible ways of behaving. Which particular snippets a society develops depends on a whole host of accidental factors, from “hints” provided by geography, environment, or basic human needs to more or less random borrowings from neighboring societies. These choices might be reasonably durable, which allows anthropologists to study them in context—to write down, in a given society, how babies are born, how boys are ushered into adulthood, or how girls are married off well and expeditiously. But they are never glued in place. All societies change.Implicit in that summary but not stated outright is the idea that because all societies change and any given society may (at any given time) value or disdain certain behaviors or attributes, no group of humans is naturally better or worse than any other, just different and possibly better or worse along certain dimensions. We tend to give those dimensions value (e.g., tendency to produce philosophers we know, or buildings we regard as beautiful, or authors we revere), but those values reflect our own biases more than any transcendental truth about human capability or purpose. In the end, the book dealt with a lot of only minorly interesting personal dynamics between the in-group and their taggers along, and so turned into something of a slog. This was particularly so given that the main thesis, though important, is graspable pretty easily and early on. Still, after giving it an initial middling  I find I have been thinking about it a lot and even recommending it to some people, so perhaps I liked it more than I thought....more

The disease causes people to enter into sleep without end, many of them dying months later and a small proportion able to eventually wake up. It's fine, but nothing especially novel.There's some talk at the end about the effect the dreaming had on the people who were eventually "cured," how they look younger and feel irretrievably changed, unable to dismiss their sick dreams as less real than the world they have woken up to. I feel like the book could have used some of these avenues to get really interesting. Instead, it mostly glanced over them. Missed opportunity, I think....more

title: Dancer from the Dance
author: Holleran, Andrew
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Read this for my gay (gayer?) book club, and liked it a lot. I had never heard of it or the author, but I found it extremely entertaining, even as a gRead this for my gay (gayer?) book club, and liked it a lot. I had never heard of it or the author, but I found it extremely entertaining, even as a gay who was never really in the circuit in NYC and who has never stepped foot on Fire Island. This was all about Malone for me. He was endlessly entertaining, truly either the perfect commemoration of a voice that has endured for generations or the instantiation of a gay archetype that continues to this day. As we discussed in book club, this book was also interesting for having been released right before AIDS mushroomed into full-blown epidemic. Gay culture seemed to have developed in many baroque, intriguing, alluring, and disturbing ways. There was so much hedonism and promiscuity, and it's easy to see how those were both good and bad things, simultaneously. It's also easy to see how a contemptuous cishet society would link gay holocaust to the types of behaviors portrayed in this book, characterizing the scourge as condign punishment for the most scandalous sybaritism this side of Gomorrah. And as a factual matter I don't think you could say those statements were wrong, though assignment of blame and culpability are an entirely different matter. But it's interesting to see in so much of the puritanism within and without the gay community how internalized that feeling is, that any sufficiently uninhibited behavior is "asking" for punishment. It wasn't until much later that people began to acknowledge that this was a particularly virulent disease and one that was uniquely linked with a particular subgroup's maligned form of sexual activity, and that these things were much more likely to be purely and tragically coincidental than at all connected in some more cosmic sense. If it had been a bunch of straight people dying because they move to the suburbs and catch diseases related to lawn care regimens, I doubt we would be blaming them or warning that a renewed wave of lawn-care enthusiasm is a harbinger of a second pandemic, but humans are simple creatures prone to cognitive biases, and so I imagine the condemnatory mindset will persist.Having lived through the recoil following the worst of the AIDS crisis and living in the drug-positive, PReP-enabled 2010s, it feels in some ways as though we're back at that moment depicted in this book. Maybe a bit "before" it, but it's hard to make exact comparisons. There were parts of this book that seemed alluring, and there was some nostalgia for a time I never experienced, and probably never will. But would my life have been better if I had lived back then? I probably would have been some miserable suburban closet case, and if I had broke free to live the lives of the men in this book, I probably would have had a ton of anonymous sex and done a lot more drugs, but I certainly have those avenues available to me still and don't find them particularly alluring.Maybe it's just that that time will never return, that culture will never again be as vital and vibrant, robbed as it is of its frisson of danger and intrigue and the complexity of semiunderground social strata. But books like this are the next best thing. ...more

title: Very, Very, Very Dreadful: The Influenza Pandemic of 1918
author: Marrin, Albert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's weird that we don't talk more about the flu. Specifically, it's weird that the Pandemic of 1918 isn't up there with the Holocaust and WWII in terIt's weird that we don't talk more about the flu. Specifically, it's weird that the Pandemic of 1918 isn't up there with the Holocaust and WWII in terms of notable massacres of the 20th century. Sure, we talk about it some--I think a few of my grandfather's sisters died in it, and that's to be expected, given that about 1 in 40 who got the disease died, and children and people living in poor, urban areas were more likely to get infected. But I feel like it's not given its due. Aside from being extremely deadly--far deadlier than all the wars of the 20th century combined, according to this book--it's wild how truly global the pandemic was, and how unprepared for it the world was. Accelerated by the squalor of urbanization, WWI, and increasing globalization, this pandemic was unlike anything before or since; indeed, much of our current flu preparedness methodology is a reaction to pandemics such as the one from 1918. Perhaps the scariest section was the last one, which talked about the future of the flu. Ever wonder why you only have to get the polio vaccine once, but you get a flu vaccination every year? Well it's because the latter is extremely volatile and changes all the time. Volatility means that it is constantly evolving, and so far we have been able to check it pretty well. But a contagious flu--which (and this is so wild to me) can only ever come about if bird droppings find their way into a pig's digestive tract, which pig then spreads it to human--is capable of some really scary mutations, including the Bird Flu of the early 2000s, which could only pass directly from birds to humans but had a SIXTY PERCENT kill rate (compare that with 2.5% for the deadliest flu ever). The "problem" with the bird flu was that it could not be passed from one human to another. And yet under lab conditions (thank god), certain scientists have created versions of the bird flu with the mutations that would, if given to a human, be contagious from human to human, potentially setting off a global holocaust the likes of which we've never before seen, and that would make the Black Death look benign by comparison. These scientists were ostensibly conducting research, in the event that someone tried to use such a contagion for malign purposes; after all, it's hard to sneak a nuclear bomb into a country, but you can carry a deadly flu without any detection whatsoever. And then there's always the chance that something like this could evolve on its own. I don't think we have any means for dealing with such a scourge. Scary, scary stuff.ETA: in the age of corona virus, we definitely do not have the means for dealing with this scourge....more

title: Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?
author: Albee, Edward
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've always had a thing for works that expose the grotesque undercurrents of genteel suburban living. Richard Yates, Jonathan Franzen, Fitzgerald, JohI've always had a thing for works that expose the grotesque undercurrents of genteel suburban living. Richard Yates, Jonathan Franzen, Fitzgerald, John O'Hara. So when I found this in one of those community library cubicles near my house, I thought I'd snap it up. It sat on my book shelf for a few months, and I grabbed it as something disposable and lightweight for the trip to Oaxaca I've just begun.It started off fine enough, but the whole thing is just not very credible. I get that people drank a lot in the 1950s and 60s, and the culture was vastly different and more permissive than is true of contemporary America, but the amount of throwing up and sloppy drinking that goes on among a group of four people whose average age is in the 40s beggars credulity. More so even than the amount of drinking is the late hour! These people start hanging out at 1am? And keep ranting at each other menacingly until dawn? And it's not like there's a solid foundation for their encounter--the whole thing starts off on such a sour note that I would have been out the door after my first drink, in bed by 1am. So no, I do not find it credible.It prevented me from enjoying it after about a third of the way through. Maybe it's the story told to fit the strictures of the theatre, and I'd feel differently seeing it acted out. But this one was not for me....more

title: Women Talking
author: Toews, Miriam
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is Miriam Toews' reimagination of the deliberations of the women of a South American Mennonite colony who had been repeatedly drugged and then raThis is Miriam Toews' reimagination of the deliberations of the women of a South American Mennonite colony who had been repeatedly drugged and then raped over the course of many months, by their brothers, their cousins, their friends, and neighbors, women older than 50 and some just toddlers. The clerical patriarch insists that the physical residue of their assaults betokens visits from demons, the wages of immoral behavior and thought. Only by catching one of the perpetrators in the act are the women able to force confessions and seek respite from the scourge. We find them discussing how to move forward after the men have been reported to local Bolivian authorities and incarcerated before standing trial. The women are essentially given an ultimatum: forgive their attackers and continue to live in this community or refuse them forgiveness and be kicked out of the community for the withholding. This all happened in real life, and the women--who are not allowed to read--debated how to move forward and had one trusted male record their deliberations. Toews has a pretty airy, light way of dealing with heavy subjects--the other book of hers that I read, All My Puny Sorrows, is about suicide--but it felt more jarring here than in the other. Some of the women almost see themselves as livestock, and think they would do well to stop making such a "big deal" out of it. Some women fault the ones who got pregnant through these rapes, claiming it stains their purity and their future offspring alike. Some women resign themselves to their fates, acknowledging the wrong but unable to imagine a life outside of the insular community they have always known, and the necessities that men have always provided them. The subject matter is difficult, but I began to appreciate it as an allegory of how sexual assault is treated in our society. Toews exposes the horrors of this particular insular society, and the sheer depravity of it all makes us think, "How backward!" But I'm not sure that this society handles sexual assault too differently than we do. Women are always called on to let these things go, to reimagine them as either complicit in the act or having asked for it in some way. There is always outsized solicitude for the life of the attacker, and less for the well-being of the victim. Women who have been denied education or have been forced out of gainful employment feel trapped, and other women understandably lack the energy to bring their attackers to justice, given the headwinds and recriminations they face. And, as here, women's stories are more often than not told by men.This book was thought-provoking. Difficult at times, but I find myself recommending it often. If you can stomach the subject matter, I would recommend it....more

review: Coming off my Michelle Obama biography, this one felt a bit very familiar: non-white girl from an impoverished family in an American inner city goes tComing off my Michelle Obama biography, this one felt a bit very familiar: non-white girl from an impoverished family in an American inner city goes to Princeton, then an Ivy League law school, and struggles against bigoted expectations to rise to the very top of American politics. Obviously they've had different routes to power, and that power manifests itself in different ways. And as an attorney, a SCOTUS justice is naturally going to manifest hers in ways that is more germane to my career than a First Lady would. Sotomayor I think lives in RBG's shadow a bit but her jurisprudence is no less progressive (and indeed, in some cases she will be the lone holdout), and she brings a type of compassion to her legal analysis that is decidedly absent from the terse and cerebral writings of RBG. But I think the mantle is hers when, in some decade hopefully far removed from now, RBG leaves the Court. She is a remarkable woman and a true empath....more

title: Becoming
author: Obama, Michelle*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I put myself on the list for this one forever ago, and had kind of forgotten that I had done so when it finally rolled around. I guess I have conflictI put myself on the list for this one forever ago, and had kind of forgotten that I had done so when it finally rolled around. I guess I have conflicted feelings about the Obamas. I was an Obama champion from before he announced his candidacy for the presidency, and was really pretty overjoyed when he won not only the nomination but the presidency in 2008. Oh the promise he held. But he fell back down to earth, and there are things I resent about his presidency in hindsight. I think he had the financial industry by the throat and decided to dust them off and give them more than a helping hand, and that this has been bad for our present, and will be extremely bad in the not-remote future; I think he ended up wielding a hawkish foreign policy that was too cavalier about civilian deaths; I think his immigration policy was too aggressive and unremitting; and perhaps worst of all I think he is kind of a naif--about human nature, about how politics works, about America. And what are we to make of a Barack Obama presidency if it leads to Donald Trump's?But I guess I had never really thought too much about Michelle. I knew she was a Princeton and Harvard Law grad, and so I always thought she came from a tony background. But that is certainly not the case. She is a true American success story. And this book really shows her in a wonderful light. She is not a braggart, she is not maudlin. She just comes across as a truly humble but principled and hard-working person; she cares about her family and her causes, but disdains politics; and she adores Barack. She is injured by the racist and misogynistic things that people have said about her, but she is not shy about calling it like it is and saying she would not have been subject to such indignities if she were not a black woman. She does not devote her book to railing against Trump, but she does call him out as a bully, a racist, a misogynist, and someone whom she will never forgive for putting her family's safety at risk. That takes guts, and it is a notable deviation from what Barack can (or probably even would) do. And so I appreciated her candor and really grew to respect her--she embodies all of the hope we had about Barack's presidency, unblemished by the messy reality of it all.And this book is also amazing for providing insight into how lovely Barack seems as a person, the dignity and self-possession with which the First Family was required to carry itself, and the amazing journey they had throughout their eight years in the White House. If you are inclined to write this off as a fluffy memoir to appeal to the masses, you're doing yourself a great disservice! ...more

author: Besson, Philippe
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've described this novella as a French "Brokeback Mountain," or "The End of Eddy" with a sadder ending. Perhaps I make reference to other works becauI've described this novella as a French "Brokeback Mountain," or "The End of Eddy" with a sadder ending. Perhaps I make reference to other works because it doesn't have quite enough substance to stand on its own two feet, but the writing (whether Besson's or the translator's, i.e. MOLLY RINGWALD'S!) is gorgeous. This for me brought up a lot of feelings about youth--nostalgia for things that I never experienced. I don't know if you'd call that yearning, or saudade, or sehnsucht, but I think I was too self-aware, too obsessed with the perfection of the act of heterosexuality I was pulling off to even entertain the possibility of some sort of meaningful teenage gay fling like what transpired in this book. Aside from that, I think it reminded me of how different each generation of gay men lives their lives and bargains with social expectations--I really can't imagine most people living a life like Thomas's these days, but a generation ago it was probably pretty normal. But oh, the human toll! I am glad to have been born into more progressive times....more

title: Trick Mirror: Reflections on Self-Delusion
author: Tolentino, Jia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If the attendees of my gay book club and various members of grouptexts are any indication, the Jia hype is for real. She has become something of a triIf the attendees of my gay book club and various members of grouptexts are any indication, the Jia hype is for real. She has become something of a tribune for the millennial generation: funny and razor sharp, introspective and curious, she writes in a way that very often feels inspired. I followed Jia as she developed through stints at the Awl, the Hairpin, Jezebel, and finally the New Yorker, where she seems to have finally encountered an audience commensurate to her talents and the importance of the issues she grapples with. Reading this book was a bit surreal: not only does Jia's work resonate as someone who belongs to the generation whose interests and experience are central to her writing, but we also ran in similar circles at the same college. It's odd enough to have someone describe the honeyed and cosseted life of your college experience to you, but it's even weirder to think "I was at that Girl Talk show where you talk about doing MDMA for the first time" and "I know this person whose peacock wedding you're describing!" Jia and I orbited in similar circles at UVA--I was friends with a lot of people in her sorority and she was only a year below us--but I don't recall any particular interactions in college aside from one email exchange we had joking about "As I Lay Dying" sequels. But I have no desire to overstate (or state) a relationship for Goodreads cool points. Ultimately I didn't have any strong impression of her upon graduation other than that a lot of people I was (and am still) friends with thought she was next-level cool. It wasn't until a few years later that traces of the numinous mind we're more familiar with in 2019 began to surface. She had this amazing blog (which she has regrettably made private) where she would say brilliant, pithy, poignant, piercing things about books, people, the Peace Corps, etc. I read it assiduously, and kicked myself for not getting to know her in college; it turned me onto (among others) Winesburg, Ohio. At a certain point the blog dried up and I continue to mourn its loss, but Jia's writing continued to sharpen as it became better known on the aforementioned sites. I remember in particular one post about her sitting in a cafe in Central Asia, going to the bathroom, and coming back to realize that she had left her laptop out to be stolen, and with it the novel she had been working on (and had not saved to the cloud, or email, or whatever people were doing in the early aughts to save their work). I remember thinking what a shame it was that some person stole and probably destroyed this laptop for a few hundred bucks, considering the work of intelligence and insight and perspective it no doubt contained. But I also remember mourning as a reader who would never get a chance to read her thoughts in book form. So it was with nostalgic excitement that I picked up "Trick Mirror," likely unimaginable at the time of the theft, and read Jia's first book. And it was just as entertaining, insightful, glancing, and tender as are the articles on which she built her reputation, and just as indicative of the thoughtfulness I've admired from afar, hopefully not too creepily, for the past decade....more

title: A Generation of Sociopaths: How the Baby Boomers Betrayed America
author: Gibney, Bruce Cannon
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Man, this book made me resentful. I'm sure I have some Boomer friends (certainly family), and I'll save them the trouble of saying "Not all Boomers!" Man, this book made me resentful. I'm sure I have some Boomer friends (certainly family), and I'll save them the trouble of saying "Not all Boomers!" But this generation really shit the bed for the rest of humanity. The author presents it as almost idiopathic (though the toss-off factoid about sociopathy--and growing up as a Boomer in America--being correlated with lead paint exposure was both humorous and merits more consideration), and I'm not so much interested in the "why?" or "whether?" of the sociopathy diagnosis. But I do resent that a generation that was given more than any other developed the most indulgent victim complex possible, ruining it for the rest of us in the process. The author suggests that younger generations' attitudes toward one's relationship to society betoken a less sociopathic mien, and that we might remake society in reaction to the atrocious histrionics, myopia, and selfishness of the Boomers. I don't know--hope springs eternal, but I'm not really sure the planet can take much more of Boomer luxuriation. Anyway, this was good. Entertaining, funny, polemical but grounded in facts. Recommended....more

review: This is the book we chose for both of my book clubs this month, and had the first one of them last night. I think I liked the story here, but the poetThis is the book we chose for both of my book clubs this month, and had the first one of them last night. I think I liked the story here, but the poetry everyone rhapsodizes about threw me--it interrupted the story in a way that felt self-aware and embarrassing. The plot at times reminded me of The End of Eddy: a "queer" book (and this one incorporating elements of race and immigration that the former lacked), but one that was just as much about navigating life in communities dispossessed of economic opportunity, and the brutality that leads to their denizens exerting on others and on themselves. This book wins points for showing flawed people in magnanimous, humanizing light, the ways that queerness strengthens and strains family dynamics, and depicting young love in a really convincing and tender fashion. But ultimately, between its brevity and the distracting and awkward sallies at poetry, it didn't leave too strong of an impression....more

author: Hollinghurst, Alan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I hadn't read any Hollinghurst before this, though I'd been recommended him countless times in the past. When I first started reading this, I was enthI hadn't read any Hollinghurst before this, though I'd been recommended him countless times in the past. When I first started reading this, I was enthralled. It's so luxuriantly gay. It packs all the Oxbridge class intrigue and homoeroticism of Brideshead Revisited, but really doesn't substitute innuendo for sex in the way that earlier authors might have felt restrained from doing. This book caroms between a few different storylines, bouncing between generations in a way that at times defies credulity--young gay men are apparently very likely to be gerontophiles? Homosexuality is openly practiced and nonchalantly discussed in WWII-era Oxford? Gay fathers have gay sons? Yes, at times it felt poured on a bit thick. But maybe that's the world Hollinghurst inhabits.I gave this three stars rather than four because it just dragged on for far too long. There are a series of two-dimensional characters--forgettable women, posh English arrivistes, and unimaginative North/South American characters--thrown in toward the end that really did not need to be there. I kind of lost the thread there at the end and was just waiting for it to be over. A good editing this could have used....more

title: Everything I Never Told You
author: Ng, Celeste*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read "Little Fires Everywhere" with a great deal of anticipation, and although a lot of my friends loved it, I thought it was pretty uninteresting. I read "Little Fires Everywhere" with a great deal of anticipation, and although a lot of my friends loved it, I thought it was pretty uninteresting. I guess the writing and character development were OK, but the story did nothing for me. But I told a friend about this and he recommended her debut, which he said was shorter and better in many of the ways I described mattering to me. Cut to my new life in DC, and my adorable neighborhood is honeycombed with neighborhood "lending libraries." In my experience, these are either full of extremely esoteric (e.g., a T.C. Boyle book written in German) or specific (e.g., folk songs of the Arapaho tribe) books, neither of which I tend to liberate from their halfway homes. But you never know, and it makes an adventure of a stroll to be treasure-hunting, so I have been doing more peeking than usual. One that is close to my house is a particular trove: I've found Vonnegut, Amy Bloom, and a well loved copy of this book, so I pounced.Interestingly, I read most of it on a flight to Seattle, to attend the wedding of two dear friends. One of them is the middle daughter of a white-American/Chinese couple, raised in Ohio among high-achieving people, not unlike Lydia, the character whose death sets this story in motion. My friend Sarah couldn't possibly be described in most of the ways Lydia is described, but this book does tell a compelling narrative about teenage anxiety in high-achieving homes, and the degree to which society's retrograde feelings about race and gender operate to foil people's dreams.But this book is not--or not just--a particular slice of mixed-race Ohioan life. The universal theme that this book explores so well is the difficulty families have with honesty and openness, the misunderstanding that inevitably flows therefrom. Poorly written TV dramas (anything Sorkin, but others too) often employ this weird conceit: characters could easily clear up a lot of confusion and set things right by revealing their true motives and clarifying their thought processes, but instead they play the noble hero and the other person hates them only out of ignorance of their true nobility. It's very tired, but this book admirably avoids the trope, offering plausible and sympathetic reasons why we might occlude the truth....more

review: What a treat this was! I can't give it five stars because c'mon: it's a book about usage, and fully 1/3 of it is devoted to humorous instructions thatWhat a treat this was! I can't give it five stars because c'mon: it's a book about usage, and fully 1/3 of it is devoted to humorous instructions that are nevertheless admonitions about how not to misspell and mix up words. Dreyer is as clever as he is imperious, officious and cocksure. To be certain, I was listening to this on audiobook, which can often feel like a one-way conversation, but one gets the impression that it would be no different--no less rapid-fire, no less officious, no less unidirectional--if he were to hold forth in person: lots of "but you would never do that," and "we needn't resolve that here; just say X." To my great horror, I had been practicing any number of the faux pas he dispatches. But, for the most part, these rules appeared fit the contours of my orthodoxy, if not always my practice. Impressively, Dreyer avoids coming across as pretentious (for the most part), and dresses down many of the "rules" promulgated by pluralities of school teachers, mothers, and British. His is a capacious codex: you can end a sentence with a preposition, but let's leave the word "spatulate" (spatula-esque) to one per document, shall we? I think we can all work with that....more

title: Bad Blood: Secrets and Lies in a Silicon Valley Startup
author: Carreyrou, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Elizabeth Holmes, founder of Theranos and subject of much of this investigative work, is such a complex character: charismatic, driven, brilliant, welElizabeth Holmes, founder of Theranos and subject of much of this investigative work, is such a complex character: charismatic, driven, brilliant, well intentioned, something in her was either malformed to begin with or begins to breakdown at some critical point, leading Theranos to be exposed as the massive fraud that it was. It would be easy to say that this was Sunny--the diminutive and nasty Svengali-like boyfriend twice her age who co-ran Theranos for most of the period in question--but that's too simple an explanation, one that smacks of both sexism and racism, and couldn't explain everything. The interesting thing about this book is that we only hear from the people around Holmes, and not all of them have come forward. It's like piecing together the motivations of a mass shooter from the accounts of the survivors--we can have our suspicions and our theories of motivation, but we will never know the answer unless and until we hear from the perpetrator herself.Perhaps it's mostly/only because I am an attorney, but the end of the book struck me as a particularly unflattering portrayal of my profession. We are left to infer about Holmes' conduct and motivations, but there can be no question about the behavior of David Boies and his firm, and they behaved appallingly. At least there's a silver lining in Rupert Murdoch and Henry Kissinger having been fleeced of tens of millions of dollars in the process.Though slow at times, this book really picked up toward the end. It's good journalism and a fascinating tale well told....more

title: Eichmann in Jerusalem: A Report on the Banality of Evil
author: Arendt, Hannah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Arendt was such a brilliant thinker and writer, and those qualities are certainly on display here. This book chronicles the administrative apparatus oArendt was such a brilliant thinker and writer, and those qualities are certainly on display here. This book chronicles the administrative apparatus of the Holocaust, and spotlights Adolf Eichmann, the man responsible for ensuring that the Final Solution was a finely-tuned German machine. By exploring the ideas of guilt and agency in the Holocaust, that most horrific of circumstances, Arendt prefigured the experiments of Milgram, et al., who showed the disturbing propensity humans have for contributing toward the most ghastly of ends, so long as they are not the ones pulling the trigger. Arendt doesn't convincingly establish whether Eichmann felt real guilt about his role in the Holocaust--he admits it was a crime against humanity yet claimed that he had no agency to refuse to give the orders he gave, sending untold Jews to the gas chambers--but she does reveal him to be a slightly stupid, vain man, always in search of a soap box.Arendt also examines the role that Jews played in acquiescing to and even abetting their own destruction. Understandably, this is a controversial point, and one that she was savaged for making. But while it's important not to blame the Jews or any victims for the suffering to which they are subjected, the points Arendt raises are important for understanding how these massively bureaucratic atrocities are committed. Collective action problems are as old as humanity itself, and I would imagine the problems get worse in situations of mortal danger, but as Arendt points out, the survival rate of Jews who fled or went into hiding was remarkably higher than of those who went with the flow, hoping that obedience would save them, and the Jews who helped Nazis by turning over Jews and/or their property to the Nazis did not fare much better. Collective uprisings are always going to be hard, especially against knowledgable and cruel foes, but Arendt's chronicle shows that oppressed people might do better to establish resistance as the default, instead of an outlier option....more

review: This is one of those books: people who really need it are not going to pick it up, and people who are already on board probably won't get too much outThis is one of those books: people who really need it are not going to pick it up, and people who are already on board probably won't get too much out of it. I like to think I'm in the latter camp; perhaps that overly flatters me, but there wasn't a whole lot going on in this book that I hadn't thought about, or struggled with, only to come out on Kendi's side. Who knows, maybe this will be a book that people get for their benighted friends and relatives as gifts to spark conversations, or to agitate well-meaning people who dislike racism but don't do anything about it from their perches of comfortable inaction. Either way, not a bad or difficult read from an author whose work I have uniformly enjoyed....more

title: The Bridge of San Luis Rey
author: Wilder, Thornton
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I feel like I might have to go back to this one at some point. It starts with this haunting meditation on determinism vs. deism, and then launches intI feel like I might have to go back to this one at some point. It starts with this haunting meditation on determinism vs. deism, and then launches into the conceit: an ancient Incan rope bridge between Lima and Cuzco--of legendary integrity and beauty--collapses, killing five people who were attempting to cross it at the fateful moment. A gnostic monk observes the chaos and tries, but fails, to assay the lives of those that perished in an attempt to triangulate whether God is vengeful or disinterested, and we get some insight into the antecedents of the folks who died in the chapters that follow.The stories are strange and malformed, written exquisitely but with evocative details missing, almost in the style of Sherwood Anderson. Wilder can certainly turn a sentence, however, and the characters stay with you. I feel like I might come back to this one, as I have many times with Winesburg, Ohio, to try to understand them and their dark, unknowable worlds a bit better....more

title: Capital City: Gentrification and the Real Estate State
author: Stein, Samuel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is excellent. I was far too sanguine about urban liberal "things" like city planning, BIDs, TIFs, etc.--the helpmeets of the young technocraThis book is excellent. I was far too sanguine about urban liberal "things" like city planning, BIDs, TIFs, etc.--the helpmeets of the young technocrat who thinks that cities are the apotheosis of mankind. What I didn't realize is how ineluctably these things lead to displacement and gentrification, the continuous erosion of the city as pastiche and into a play land for the elite rich. While I enjoyed having my assumptions and beliefs challenged, I didn't find the author's solutions very compelling. When you're told that investment in communities is bad because it leads to gentrification, and that disinvestment is bad because it starves communities of resources, you feel like you're being set up for some comprehensive, achievable solution. But the solutions he posits--community home ownership, Havana-style--seem at best impossible and at worst just naive. Havana is not a place I would describe as one where people are happy with housing allocations, and I say that having interviewed dozens of Habaneros a few years back. Regardless, this book is pithy and extremely smart. I'd recommend it to anyone trying to understand how cities work, which equities and constituencies are being served by which policies, and which of your biases toward urban policy you want to maintain having read what Stein has to say....more

title: Falter: Has the Human Game Begun to Play Itself Out?
author: McKibben, Bill
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In some ways, this is the scariest book I have ever read. McKibben's object is questioning whether humans--because of natural limits or the consequencIn some ways, this is the scariest book I have ever read. McKibben's object is questioning whether humans--because of natural limits or the consequences of our actions--are doomed to plateau, regress, or die out.McKibben takes a panoramic view of the poor choices we have made and the various precipices we have driven ourselves off of as a species. In the same way that Yuval Hariri (whom he name drops multiple times in this short book) chronicles all of the ways in which humans may be progressing, McKibben gives us an oddly lighthearted survey of the dangers we face yet refuse to recognize. It's scariest and most effective as an accounting of how utterly we have fucked ourselves, by way of fucking our planet, our only home and source of resources. McKibben's goal of scaring his reader was so complete that when he started to introduce solutions, I wasn't even receptive to his suggestions. They seemed too much like half-measures. Massive solar panel banks? Nonviolent resistance? What in the world would make him think that such things are sufficient, given the knowledge we already have about how irreversible the damage we have done is? Instead, when he trots out ideas like "we have to genetically engineer subsequent generations to be more empathetic, to understand that the consequences of their actions accumulate and are difficult to chart out" my thought was not "atrocious! we must not sacrifice our principles!" but instead "yeah, we must just be flawed as a species to have gotten to this place; let's just change the entire paradigm."Probably not the goal he intended, but an evocative book nonetheless. An important read in this day and age....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Very well written, immensely sad, an auspicious debut. "There, There" shows how violence, genocide, and disregard echo through generations of AmericanVery well written, immensely sad, an auspicious debut. "There, There" shows how violence, genocide, and disregard echo through generations of American Indians, reverberating in their lives in the form of instability and misery, to varying degrees. A central conceit of this novel is that Native Americans only have their story told a certain way, typically as either the "noble savage" trope or as miserable wretches drinking their days away on barren reservations, either way written by non-native folks. Orange, himself an American Indian, transcends these strictures, using imbricated short stories to demonstrate the great texture and variety and sorrow of the modern Indian experience.No happy endings here, but worth a read folks....more

title: The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's a trope in this book that I really like: a person makes a claim of dubious merit and specificity (that Ms. Jean Brodie is "in her prime") abouThere's a trope in this book that I really like: a person makes a claim of dubious merit and specificity (that Ms. Jean Brodie is "in her prime") about herself, and then everyone else adopts it out of convention until it is mentioned to the exclusion of any more normal or accurate statement. It's whimsical and Dickensian, in my mind--though I struggle to recall a character with this particular tic--with a whiff of Ignatius Reilly to it.Here, Ms. Jean Brodie, a petty schoolteacher with a yen for continental fascists shepherds a brood of young Scottish lassies through their school years. She emphasizes from the outset that she is in her prime years, and any doubt about her quality or fitness for the job is gainsaid by another, who reminds the doubter that Brodie is in her prime. It should be noted that Ms. Brodie's prime takes place in her late 50s, and her life is divided fairly plainly into two camps: during her prime and after her prime, when she has fallen into ruin. Her downfall is pretty satisfying, as the character--whether during or following her prime years--seems ignoble, clueless, and drawn to brownshirt tendencies. Sic semper fascistae!...more

title: Sons and Lovers
author: Lawrence, D.H.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I thought this might be pretty good, but man was I disappointed. Only by remembering Lucille and Buster Bluth's Oedipal hyjinks was this one made bearI thought this might be pretty good, but man was I disappointed. Only by remembering Lucille and Buster Bluth's Oedipal hyjinks was this one made bearable.It starts out serviceable enough--a young woman from a comparatively higher station falls in love with a charismatic, working-class collier, the latter of whom turns out to be a sot with occasional violent tendencies. Some children are born and they factor into and influence these dynamics. As the kids age, it's not really clear who will be the main characters--the oldest child and consummate charmer "William," the younger son "Paul," the mother or the father. Paul, who apparently stands in for the author in this bildungsroman, starts out as a seemingly marginal character(view spoiler)[, only coming to prominence after William dies (hide spoiler)]. Eventually he becomes more prominent, and the father dries out a bit and fades into the background. So then it's just Paul, his on-again-off-again (and-on-again-and-off-again) girlfriends, and his mother for about 400 pages. The mother is clearly an imposing character with considerable sway over her son, but they're probably a bit too close for a healthy relationship. I think what made this book so excruciating was that they never really go into why they are so preternaturally close to begin with. There's just a lot of holding each other tenderly and saying things in triplicate (e.g. "My son, my son, my son!"; "My love, my love, my love" “Muther, muther, muther”). Also, Paul goes from detesting to being absolutely in love with each of two women approximately 100 times throughout the book, and he never really tells us why he has such an extreme ambivalence nor meditates on his true feelings, he just goes from lustfully yearning for possession of these women to hating them, usually over a small slight or inoffensive comment. Totally unflattering, obnoxious, and infuriating to read over and over ad nauseam. Anyway, this one was a trial; cannot in good conscience recommend....more

review: Well, well, well, this was a treat."Trinity" follows the personal life and later career of J. Robert Oppenheimer, so-called father of the atomic bomb Well, well, well, this was a treat."Trinity" follows the personal life and later career of J. Robert Oppenheimer, so-called father of the atomic bomb and quoter of the Bhagavad Gita ("Now I am become Death, the destroyer of worlds"). It sketches a picture of him through the reactions of ten or so people, some of whom knew him well, others barely at all. Maybe it's because it takes place in the same heady time period as most of his oeuvre, but this book felt very influenced by Don DeLillo--the characters are all introspective, detached yet observant, somewhat unable to cope with the modern world they inhabit, unreconciled to the post-World Wars America, denuded of its galvanizing myths and thereby exposed as uglier than it thought itself. And, as with DeLillo, the good writing was beautiful, and the best narratives (I'm thinking the reporter and the anorexic, in this book)--gripping and unforgettable....more

review: I usually love post-apocalyptic disaster novels, but "Station Eleven" didn't do it for me. The genre isn't very sophisticated, so I figured a popular I usually love post-apocalyptic disaster novels, but "Station Eleven" didn't do it for me. The genre isn't very sophisticated, so I figured a popular entry would satisfy. Many of my friends have loved this one, but it didn't do it for me. I think my primary issue was the ratio of backstory to post-apocalyptic timeline. There's no prescribed ratio, but if you're going to dwell on the past, it should probably be for a good reason. Here, I couldn't really understand what the purpose of Arthur's various wives/affairs and acting escapades was. Also, the stuff with the prophet was resolved way too quickly to feel satisfactory as the lurking danger representing the fallout from the collapse of society, which for me is usually the most interesting aspect of these books.Oh well. If anyone has any good post-apocalyptic thrillers to recommend, I'm all ears!...more

There's some playful exploration of conventions and narrative, a loose way with writing and meaning that feels refreshing. But after a while it seems to be winking just a bit too much, and it seems designed to cover for a thin story without much substance. The author reveals herself (or her character) as one of these dreadful women who announces to all and sundry that she is just a gay man born into a straight woman's body. Whatever that means. Never mind that this is a self-assessment and not something gay men seem to have corroborated. It feels cruel to say that this book was a waste of time, because it only takes an hour or so to read. title: Ghosts of the Tsunami: Death and Life in Japan's Disaster Zone
author: Lloyd Parry, Richard*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Ghosts of the Tsunami" chronicles the aftermath of the 2011 tsunami. The fifth most powerful earthquake ever recorded killed a handful of people in s"Ghosts of the Tsunami" chronicles the aftermath of the 2011 tsunami. The fifth most powerful earthquake ever recorded killed a handful of people in seismically prepared Japan, but the water it dislodged wreaked unprecedented catastrophe, killing tens of thousands more. While many communities on the east coast of Japan were devastated, a particular rural community had an entire generation of its children wiped out in a tragedy this book attempts to encircle. "Ghosts" is as much a compendium of the insuperable human tragedy of losing one's child (or children, for many) as it is an exploration of the peculiarities of Japanese culture viewed through this most macabre lens. It evoked a series of emotions out of proportion to its length, if not its object. I read this, improbably, for my "bro" book club. We usually read pretty gritty stuff, but it's fictional grit, so it lacks heft. Most of the participants have young children, so I have to imagine this was a really difficult book for them, given how rough it was for me. But it came along at a good time--when you are moping around because you gave a lackluster interview, there is little that can better put into context how incredibly fortunate and lucky your fragile, cosseted life is than reading about parents sifting through tsunami muck for pieces of their children's bodies. This was haunting and beautifully written; I'm glad I read it, even if it was always uncomfortable and made me ineffably sad. ...more

review: 3.5 stars.I evangelize for Nell Zink, but she's a confusing author. I have very positive memories of Mislaid and The Wall Creeper and Nicotine, but I 3.5 stars.I evangelize for Nell Zink, but she's a confusing author. I have very positive memories of Mislaid and The Wall Creeper and Nicotine, but I don't think I've given her more than three stars more than once. She's clearly wildly smart and has interesting things to say about society and capitalism and relationships and the environment, but I feel like the stories usually unravel, or fail to conclude in a satisfying manner.Doxology focuses on punk-adjacent New Yorker parents and their development from scrappy scene kids to unprepared parents to accidental millionaires, true Gen X success stories. Their daughter Flora is also portrayed in a way that brings the novel into the present, to the era of Trump and a DC that is turning into an unaffordable gentrified Disneyland. Heady to read while you're inhabiting it, to be sure. The first fifty pages of this made me smile despite myself, but the last 200-or-so pages of this felt like some tedious Ann Patchett, shot through every once in a while with morsels of razor sharp commentary. We'll see how I feel in a year's time....more

title: The Age of Innocence
author: Wharton, Edith
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In some ways the New Yorkiest of books, Wharton's vantage into a nascent American "society" feels more Bostonian in retrospect. In the book, we are prIn some ways the New Yorkiest of books, Wharton's vantage into a nascent American "society" feels more Bostonian in retrospect. In the book, we are privy to the goings on of wealthy Fifth Avenue types, centered on our protagonist Newland Archer, a jeunesse doree with more wealth than pedigree, though certainly not lacking in either. Wharton early on establishes the hierarchy, with the descendants of the patroons (in real life: Van Rennselaers) and planters (in real life: Randolphs) comprising the only real aristocracy in America, while the rest of them happily thicken society's broth as genteel parvenus, basking in the glow of their tenuous connections to Old Europe, with its more developed art scenes and social niceties. This framing is why I maintain that the book is less New York--which is really all about wealth, as the Vanderbilts would show the Astors, and as the Trumps would show us all--and more Boston, which has always been big on downplaying obscene wealth and esteeming lineage above all else.This book is charming for cataloguing the quirks and tendencies of what would come to evolve into a very rarefied set, but as it shifts to cataloguing a love affair lacking in much credibility, it grew less compelling. Wharton is talented for sure, and I look forward to reading "House of Mirth," but I won't carry this one with me for long....more

title: Appointment in Samarra
author: O'Hara, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As I continue in my half-hearted attempts to fulfill my New Year's resolution, I am beginning to get a feel for the patterns of modern American literaAs I continue in my half-hearted attempts to fulfill my New Year's resolution, I am beginning to get a feel for the patterns of modern American literature, especially for the white men who disproportionately represent the more famous authors in its canon. There's a heady sense of entitlement to everything the American Dream promises: comfortable living earned through pluck and occasional effort, a pervasive expectation of safety (except for the occasional drunken scrape or tipsy car crash), a boorish and careless demeanor toward women and children, and an irresistible urge to smash up the pleasant life that centuries of capitalism and prosperity and patriarchy have conspired to render them. This last characteristic is particularly notable in books of this type, and is alluded to by the title of this book: an ancient Middle Eastern yarn about the ineluctable nature of death.Books like this prefigured Richard Yates and John Updike, John Cheever and "Mad Men." The ennui of the suburbs, the maddeningly destructive temporary reprieves of dark liquor and extramarital sex: it's all there, superficially familiar and genteel but rotting faithfully beneath the surface. Hemingway was already plumbing the last of the grand, noble battles of the century while these protagonists instead fought purposelessness and a sense of existential dread. It's depressing stuff, but I just can't get enough. While lustily reading the first few pages of this book I described its appeal to someone as "exposing the American Dream as a fraud." He called the idea passé, saying that only Republicans (or less malignant naifs) would believe in the sham. I can't dispute the assessment, really--this book was published more than fifty years before I was born, and I can't imagine it was breaking new ground even at the time. But there are things that these books do so well, and in O'Hara's case they’re credible dialogue and showing depicting the defeat and sense of submission of those who put their faith in the American Dream....more

title: Algorithms of Oppression: How Search Engines Reinforce Racism
author: Noble, Safiya Umoja
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sites like Google and Yelp have become so indispensable to our modern lives that it becomes easy to accept them as they are without interrogating theiSites like Google and Yelp have become so indispensable to our modern lives that it becomes easy to accept them as they are without interrogating their systemic flaws. As recently as this year, we saw people arguing in good (if benighted) faith that an algorithm cannot be racist or sexist because it is based on math. But Noble's experience and research showed that this is very demonstrably untrue: while searches for "white girls" bring up a sampling of mostly unoffensive images, the search for "black girls" brought up mostly porn until Google corrected the difference; typing in "This English major taught herself calculus" would draw Google's suggestion "Did you mean 'This English major taught himself calculus'?" and suggested autotext for black women is much more racist and sexist than the equivalents for white men or women. So much of the internet, functioning as it does as an aggregate, is assumed to be benign. But it doesn't take much critical thinking to understand that bigotry--being a thing that all societies share in varying degrees--will be instantiated by group behaviors, particularly when they are done anonymously, as is the case with most of our internet activity. Noble spends this book unpacking the ways in which we give the internet too much credit for neutrality, showing that inaction by sites like Google and Yelp has serious ramifications, and pointing out the ludicrousness of their claims that they are powerless to anticipate, prevent, or mitigate the harm that is caused by the reification of the bigotry that gets pumped out by their algorithms.This book is short and has the tone of a doctoral thesis. It feels like a good start to this important topic, but one that needs to be expanded on in great breadth and depth....more

title: Utopia for Realists: How We Can Build the Ideal World
author: Bregman, Rutger*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I ended up really liking this book. It explores a lot of ideas that we reflexively reject, likely because they go against common sense. Ideas like "juI ended up really liking this book. It explores a lot of ideas that we reflexively reject, likely because they go against common sense. Ideas like "just give poor people cash" seem not only politically infeasible, but unwise. And sadly, our politics is dictated by soundbites and conventional wisdom, and we wonder why we only dig ourselves deeper into wealth inequality and dissatisfaction with government at all levels.This book explores concepts like universal basic income, open borders, and cash substitutes for our current forms of welfare/charity, in a way that makes me hopeful they might one day be implemented on a large scale, or at least experimented with. Not that ideas that make all the sense in the world for our peer countries have ever really prodded the United States into action--see, e.g., universal healthcare and noninterventionist military policy--but I might be able to dust off that Irish passport and decamp for one of the more enlightened countries once this one starts to really tear itself apart.Lest I leave it on that unsavory note, I wonder whether the silver lining from this Trump administration might just be that we are so screwed up or have such a political mandate that trying these things out becomes palatable, if not necessary. I just wonder why--when one political party is trying to drag us backward and the other one, overly proud of its respectability, insists on keeping us in stasis--there isn't more of a yen for something radical and outside the box. Here's hoping more of the 2020 candidates trade on the yen for something different and begin exploring these things through their platforms. Even if they don't implement them, this book correctly notes that the Overton Window would be shifted thereby. ...more
