title: Dopesick: Dealers, Doctors, and the Drug Company that Addicted America
author: Macy, Beth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you can stomach a glimpse at the worst plague to ravish America since the AIDS epidemic, this is not a bad entree. Dopesick explores the opioid epiIf you can stomach a glimpse at the worst plague to ravish America since the AIDS epidemic, this is not a bad entree. Dopesick explores the opioid epidemic where it has taken hold most relentlessly: the backwater towns of Appalachia that progress long ago abandoned. A lax regulatory structure, the opportunistic Sackler family, and a lack of economic opportunity set the stage for this exploration of a truly scary journey, one that seems essentially inescapable for those unlucky enough to have fallen into its clutches.The most galling thing about this book is that we seem to have a partial solution--MAT, or medication-assisted treatment, which makes use of less abusable opioids to wean you off of heroin or oxy without the dreaded "dopesickness"--but that governmental regulators/funders are either too squeamish/sanctimonious about the idea of using drugs to conquer addiction or too cheap to understand the benefits of doing so. We have such an allergy to helping people in need in this country, particularly when their needs are "untoward" like drug addiction. A cynical part of me thought that maybe this might be different, given that white people are associated with the ravages of this drug, but even that doesn't seem the case.I am heartened that 2020 hopefuls such as Elizabeth Warren are making tackling the opioid epidemic a key part of their platforms. I hope that whoever wins in 2020 gives some relief to those suffering under the yoke of this addiction, whether that is in the form of MAT (and subsidizing things like transportation to clinics, childcare, etc. that otherwise prevent people, especially low-income people, from seeking treatment), job training, "ban the box" laws, or otherwise, unlike Trump, who paid lip service to the scourge only to engage in characteristic sloth and defund agencies that were marginally helping in the past. And I hope that this imbues middle/white America with a bit more compassion toward drug addicts and other victims of the War on Drugs now that it has creeped into their neighborhoods and basements....more

title: Kill All Normies: Online Culture Wars from 4chan and Tumblr to Trump and the Alt-Right
author: Nagle, Angela
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So this pithy book packs a lot in. Reading this, I started thinking about the Internet as the opposite of what we consider to be Society. I'm venturinSo this pithy book packs a lot in. Reading this, I started thinking about the Internet as the opposite of what we consider to be Society. I'm venturing beyond my pay grade here, but Society seems good for, perhaps above all else, suppressing your amygdala a bit and clamping down on those animal urges. It's a functional trade--we swap immediate gratification for safety and predictability, in an equilibrium that is always changing based on who is contributing and what they bring to the equation. Essential to the bargain is the idea that you will likely be punished for any transgression; even if it turns out that your darkest tendencies aren't very uncommon, it's just too risky to ventilate them. But not on the anonymous Internet. And Nagle paints the picture of the ghastliest, most macabre passel of ghoul-virgins you can imagine, marshaled by the likes of Milo Yiannopolous and his successors, inspired by Steve Bannon, and peopled by the faceless iconoclasts of 4chan. Nothing about their behavior is especially interesting or inspired—it's just transgression for transgression's sake, a mob of inattentive children having their fun with the god-mode of human interaction before it grows tedious, probably becoming libertarians if sufficient outside interaction and genetic luck speeds them to escape velocity, and becoming whiney incels ("involuntary celibates") if not. I have nothing but contempt for these people, clinging to their white pride and cartoonish misogyny, and it's hard to miss how the validation of crassness and spleen have pitched into the dynamic that gave us the modern Republican Party, headed by the biggest ass to ever bray.Shortly after she chained herself to Twitter headquarters, I realized that I had, by pure chance, interacted with a pre-famous (and bottle blonde) Laura Loomer, heroine of sorts to this “movement,” when I went to the Women's March in early 2017. I told her (ignorantly but erroneously) that it was illegal for her to film me, and also that her MAGA hat sucked (accurately). She responded that once Trump was inaugurated, all of us "beta males" were going to find out what a real alpha can do. Well, Laura is back on her bullshit today and having some sort of lawn party on Nancy Pelosi's Napa estate, proving, ironically, that walls don't keep unwanted visitors out. I am just so goddamn ready for the time when we aren't even given the opportunity to ignore these milksop reprobates......more

title: All the King’s Men
author: Warren, Robert Penn
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have had this book lying around forever and only just now got to it, owing to my 2019 resolution. It started off pretty electric--the dialogue is taI have had this book lying around forever and only just now got to it, owing to my 2019 resolution. It started off pretty electric--the dialogue is taut and the foreshadowing is masterful. This book is very much in the sweet spot of influence, where its pungency and style are clearly echoed in the many other great and influential books that followed in its wake and emulated its affects. The writing is both belletristic and masterful--RPW is the only person to have won the Pulitzer in writing and in poetry, and the latter skill comes across in the narrative very clearly. He is an adept writer and has a way with a phrase.For all of its initial momentum, though, "All the King's Men" unraveled a bit across its deceptively short 440 pages. The quality of writing remained high, but RPW started interpolating stories and anecdotes of questionable use, and the careful unfolding of plot lines began to give way to a more relaxed, less engaging style. Also, for all of RPW's careful attention to detail, many of the plot twists began to feel contrived. This is perhaps apparent from the beginning, where the main character, a governor, and an influential judge all live on the same street, which furnishes about 80% of the main characters in this book. I'm not the most active reader, and so I rarely predict the direction of a plot, but I think I saw every twist and turn in this one long before it was explicitly broached in the text. I also would have loved more of the Boss and less of his henchman, our main character. The Boss is such a fascinating person, and the build-up to his governorship would have been a fascinating thing to gander at.But I'm glad I read it. I will definitely read him again--this is such a foundational American South text, and a great political thriller to boot. A great beginning to my resolution and a powerful rejoinder to the idea that famous and revered books do not deserve their reputations....more

review: This was so good!At one of my book clubs, we have a tradition of discussing "extracurricular" books--books we've read on our own or want to read, and This was so good!At one of my book clubs, we have a tradition of discussing "extracurricular" books--books we've read on our own or want to read, and it's been a bonanza for me, and something that I'll really miss when I move to DC this month. This one started out that way, but I think the praise was so rapturous that the book club decided it would be the next selection. Sadly, I'll have already moved by the time it's discussed, but I'm glad to have read it anyway."Home Fire" concerns a British-Pakistani family whose men are linked with terrorism, and the family of a British Home Secretary--a secular, assimilated man--who is embroiled in the politics and personal struggles with what it means to really be British/European, and the unfair burdens and outsized sacrifices the majority will place on anyone who bears markings of the outsider. Although this takes place mostly in Britain, it's something we are very familiar with in America, where Muslims are practically required to condemn every act of terrorism linked to other Muslims, something that conservative white politicians are never asked to do in the face of far more prevalent white nationalist terrorism.The conceit is a bit contrived, and it starts off slowly, but it really builds to a crescendo. And man, that ending--did not see it coming. Entertaining and important, a rare combination. ...more

title: Milkman
author: Burns, Anna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Such a weird book but one that hypnotizes with its strange conventions and driving narrative. This is a story of one woman's youth in Northern IrelandSuch a weird book but one that hypnotizes with its strange conventions and driving narrative. This is a story of one woman's youth in Northern Ireland, during which she is pursued by an IRA operative known as the "milkman." Given that it takes place during "The Troubles" and given her pursuer's job, the unnamed narrator is immersed in the politics of the era and the panopticon that develops among the people--Catholic and Protestant, affiliated and non-affiliated--to monitor her actions as well as those of every other person. This book employs a number of strange conventions--no one is called by their given or last name, just a series of nicknames or stand-ins for names (e.g., "third brother-in-law," "Somebody McSomebody," "Maybe Boyfriend"), and there is a lot of intriguing foreshadowing (i.e., the narrator will mention something very interesting in her unrelenting stream of consciousness narrative that happened, but it won't be fully explained for many, many more pages). But the thing that roped me in most was the kind of unrelenting, galloping way in which this book was narrated. Every anecdote is explored fully and licked clean before moving on. Every screed feels like it has the whole of history animating its authority.It's a really well told tale of The Troubles, and a good narrative complement to the also very popular right now Say Nothing: A True Story of Murder and Memory in Northern Ireland, a non-fiction account of The Troubles told through the tale of one prominent IRA family. I strongly recommend this one....more

title: Normal People
author: Rooney, Sally*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Rooney's debut was something else; for most of it, I didn't feel like I was reading anything other than an ordinary book with a fetching cover (if badRooney's debut was something else; for most of it, I didn't feel like I was reading anything other than an ordinary book with a fetching cover (if bad title). But as others began to read it, it really became something of a sensation. Even people who didn't love it--on here and in book club--would find themselves embroiled in conversation with its evangelists, revising their opinion of the book upward in real time. If it doesn't charm from the jump, it gets its hooks in you, I suppose. It's legendarily hard to follow up on a smash debut. Some friends and colleagues went to an overcapacity book tour event that Rooney held in Brooklyn that they said felt like a religious revival. Yet from those with whom I'd rhapsodized over "Conversations with Friends," it seemed like the follow-up was doomed to the usual fate. Lots of people said that they were disappointed, that it lacked whatever unnameable magic of the first. I didn't know what to expect.I ended up really liking it. I'm not sure it will stick with me in the same way that "Conversations" did, or be as much of a topic of conversation, but it felt as finely crafted, better at developing characters, even. I'm not sure I've ever shipped two characters more than I have Connell and Marianne. Perhaps it's my generation's wont, but we love nothing more than the nerd blossoming and getting the popular kid, from "She's All That" to "The O.C." It practically has class dimensions to it, though Rooney imbues this story with more explicit ones, given that the same seems to be her preoccupation. And I would say the only significant criticism I have of this book is (view spoiler)[that they don't really end up together, despite all of their many bites at the apple. It's so obvious that they are soulmates, and that other people make them miserable. (hide spoiler)]This book deals with a lot of emotional and physical abuse. I think the consent levels varied throughout, and I admit those topics made me pretty uncomfortable. That might be a gendered thing, I'm not sure, but there was a foreboding darkness throughout this tale that made me uncomfortable, reluctant in a fairly unique way to see what it foretold. Many of the people who didn't like this book said that it made them sad. I can't disagree with that; it's a tough novel to read and I can't say I think its ending portends well. But those novels can be educative and enriching experiences as well, if not exactly enjoyable. Regardless, my enthusiasm for Rooney as an author is undiminished....more

title: How to Get Rid of a President: History's Guide to Removing Unpopular, Unable, or Unfit Chief Executives
author: Priess, David*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book concerns America's history of consternation with its presidents, and what it has tried or threatened to do to remove them from office or renThis book concerns America's history of consternation with its presidents, and what it has tried or threatened to do to remove them from office or render them impotent. Far and away, aside from perhaps assassination, the easiest way to pretermit a presidency seems to be by ensuring that the guy doesn't get reelected. Aside from that, there's impeachment, which historians/constitutional scholars seem to agree is a political action and doesn't need to be grounded on any specific action, or the easier but less official practice of denying the agenda of any president and overriding his veto--in other words, using a supermajority of the legislature to replace the executive for most practical purposes, as was done when the impeachment of anti-Reconstruction Andrew Johnson failed to oust him from office.One point this book really emphasizes is that impeachment is not an absolute last measure, to be avoided except in the absolute worst circumstances. It was not intended to be "the worst thing ever," or some sort of nuclear option. But I do think that's what we've come to regard it as. When Constitutional mechanisms are never exercised, they tend to acquire a totally unfounded patina of extremeness. For example, there are two ways to amend the Constitution--one is by amendment and one is by calling a constitutional convention; because we have literally never used the latter and only used the former, the latter seems more "extreme," even if there's no evidence that the Founders thought of or intended for it to be that way. I found myself thinking a lot about the much-exalted "wisdom" of the Founders while reading this. There is ample evidence that the Founders thought the Constitution would and should be rewritten very often, and the fact that there were twelve amendments to it within its first fifteen years is testament to the intended mutability of the document. But the document itself and all of its internal mechanisms were promulgated with a lot of (flawed) assumptions in mind. The Founders, to their credit, really thought highly of the educated citizen. They were probably living in the apex of civic, democratic virtue over the past two millennia, so we can't really blame them, but they really thought that people were not very susceptible to manipulation or dishonest/corrupt politicians, and really approached the whole project of government with some pretty rosy opinions about how human nature operates and what people could be trusted to do. They also didn't anticipate the rise of political parties or the varieties of "truth" available to the modern citizen, and made few provisions for either in the workings of the Constitution. This oversight is particularly evident in the impeachment mechanism.Centuries later we have an executive whose power has mushroomed beyond the Founders' comprehension (the result of both Democratic and Republican administrations, it must be said). We have political partisanship that seems a far more powerful and consistent motivator than truth or the commonweal. And we have at least one party that understands that, in the short run at least, from a partisan point of view it's far better to have a flawed, corrupt, disgrace of a president of your own party than to admit fault and take responsibility for wrongdoing to ensure the preservation of non-partisan institutions/norms. This is why (I predict) Trump will never be impeached, and probably why no president ever will be impeached. Even in the very depths of Trump's popularity, I can't imagine him getting more than 2-5 GOP Senators to convict him, and that will never be enough to satisfy the Constitution's 2/3 requirement. I was speaking with a friend recently about Nixon. Analysis of Nixon is a surprisingly small portion of this book, but one thing is certain: Nixon could have destroyed the White House tapes, and he could have been more obstructive. He could have taken the Senate to the brink and seen what they might have done to him, even if they ultimately followed through with impeaching him (which I think they would have). He didn't, and this is because, for all of his flaws, Nixon had some small interest in institutional legitimacy and the preservation of the system above his own nearly limitless self-interest. My friend mused that if Nixon were more Trumpian, he never would have been impeached, and I think that also might be true. Certainly at the onset of the Watergate revelations Republicans treated all initial evidence with skepticism, using terms we are now supersaturated with, such as "witch hunt" and accusations of a partisan hack job. I guess it's possible--entertaining a different counterfactual--that if Nixon had had Mitch McConnell as his Senate Majority Leader, he would have doubled down and avoided impeachment, but we will never know. While we know that executive power has been growing exponentially and the Legislature is increasingly unwilling to use its powers to check a president, particularly when a majority has a president of its own party, what we haven't really been exposed to until recently are the ideas that a president is basically above the law. While impeachment is undeniably the method by which a president can be removed from power, if we all agree that a president is extremely unlikely to be impeached, whether they have a Democrat or a Republican Senate, then essentially the president is above the law. Even in the unlikely event that there is enough political will to prosecute the crime after the four- or eight-year term of a president, there really isn't anything that we can rely on to interrupt the presidency of someone whom we know or strongly suspect has committed serious crimes, even if those crimes were in service of installing him in the office in the first place. And this is the case even though the Vice President--in every conceivable scenario a person of the same party as the president--would be installed in his stead. This really points to a cult-of-personality model of democracy, a type of divine king whose powers are finite but whose impunity is anything but. What would the Founders think?...more

title: The Largesse of the Sea Maiden
author: Johnson, Denis
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I didn't even know this was by Denis Johnson when I picked it up. I think it was just on a bunch of "Best of" lists, and, frankly, I ignored it for soI didn't even know this was by Denis Johnson when I picked it up. I think it was just on a bunch of "Best of" lists, and, frankly, I ignored it for some time because the title made me think that it was just another entry in the past year's canon of fish-fuck fiction. Not sure what the title is about--perhaps to his last days spent at Sea Ranch, CA?--but this book consisted of five disconnected, medium-length stories, seemingly set in inland locales. I liked some more than others--the Cass/rehab/epistolary story comes to mind, as does the story whose protagonist, oddly, shares my last name. Others were less compelling, but that's the nature of these collections, I suppose; in most cases, at least. Johnson is dead now, with this being his last work. I read "Jesus' Son" and liked it; maybe someday I'll get to his other works, though I've heard that "Tree of Smoke" is hit or miss. Regardless, RIP to a weird guy/compelling writer. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you want to read a bunch of people who self-describe as feminist gun owners (something I think is fully coherent) who had reservations about votingIf you want to read a bunch of people who self-describe as feminist gun owners (something I think is fully coherent) who had reservations about voting for Trump but did so anyway (something I think is completely incoherent), you should read this book. It puts all of the Trump supporters who the NYT et al. have been trying to "figure out" since 2016 into neat little taxonomies, and attempts to explain how they were all activated in just the right way to put Trump 70k votes ahead in the three states--MI, WI, and PA--that delivered him the presidency. Personally, I'm over it. I am so tired of hearing so disproportionately much about these people: how their political beliefs and petty bigotries are entitled to respect just because, and how they should be celebrated rather than pilloried for buying into the fantastical, contradictory, and loudmouthed bullshit Trump spewed to get elected and continues to harp on in his eternal complaint about how unfairly he's being treated. Blech. ...more

title: The Marshall Plan: Dawn of the Cold War
author: Steil, Benn
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I forget why I reserved this at the library--perhaps our interests become dad-lier with time? The Marshall Plan isn't of intrinsic interest for me, evI forget why I reserved this at the library--perhaps our interests become dad-lier with time? The Marshall Plan isn't of intrinsic interest for me, even as a former history major who focused on the post-WWII period in college. I think it was because I was interested in a pre-Nixon America that was more interested in magnanimity than gloating or retribution. Interestingly enough, the Marshall Plan was anything but magnanimous. I don't mean to imply that generosity is diminished for having elements of self-interest, but this book lays out just how aggressive the Marshall Plan was. The author presents America's two main objectives as: 1) making Europe into a self-sustaining marketplace for American goods, and turning war-ravaged Central Europe into an ideological and physical breakwater for the lumbering Soviet menace to the East. Whether America would have been stirred to its largess in the absence of these interests is left unanswered, but one gets the impression that America would not have given so readily to its Western European allies or the belligerents it helped vanquish without them. The Soviets knew what America was planning, and they were put in a tough situation: if they called out dollar diplomacy for what it was, they would risk looking unreasonable, cheap, and envious. Despite the objections that they couched in the contemporary vernacular of post-colonialism, the Marshall Plan is in many ways the precursor to the EU and NATO, the import and influence of which are in more doubt now than ever. Having finished this, my takeaway is not that the Marshall Plan is something we should pan or be ashamed of. But like so many of the complex phenomena that are glossed over in our civics texts, it should be viewed in its proper context. ...more

review: Baldwin does it again. Not as poetic as some of his other works, this book clearly prefigures more modern works such as An American Marriage, which atBaldwin does it again. Not as poetic as some of his other works, this book clearly prefigures more modern works such as An American Marriage, which attempt to relate the ways in which white supremacy finds its way into even the most private and intimate of settings. Baldwin's skill is clearly on display when he renders the warm scenes between Clementine's family, or between Clementine and Fonny at the prison. But his calling cards--close adherence to a single plot and in-depth exploration of the main characters--are on display throughout. I don't think this story will stick with me for a long while, but it was an enjoyable and short read. Would recommend....more

title: A Bright Shining Lie: John Paul Vann and America in Vietnam
author: Sheehan, Neil
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well, I finally finished this beast last night, and with it my sudden interest in anything and everything Vietnam War. I think I leapt headlong into tWell, I finally finished this beast last night, and with it my sudden interest in anything and everything Vietnam War. I think I leapt headlong into the subject because I was convinced that this was where America started to get it really wrong--fighting colonialist wars, whose outcomes were manipulated by unscrupulous actors like Nixon and Kissinger; having the knowledge of the atrocities we were capable of but not holding ourselves accountable, because patriotism/tribalism wins out over the humanity of the brutalized other; the dawning feeling of vulnerability and decay that is still being exploited by demagogues to speed, rather than reverse, our decline.But I never really found that borne out. Not because Vietnam wasn't awful, but because I don't think it's really fair to the victims of a longer history to say we had some claim on moral probity before that. It's probably only white dudes like me who have the naiveté required to believe something as silly and demonstrably false as "America got it right, mostly, until the 1960s!"But I do think that the fear of decline has a potentiating effect. Particularly because we now know that conservatism is so/primarily motivated by fear, this defeat by a militaristically primitive, poorer people really seems to have quickened the fear in the minds of a previously mostly inert group of middle Americans, fused with their contempt for hippy culture and women's lib, drug experimentation, etc. to prefigure the throbbing amygdala governing modern conservative hate/fear culture. Unfortunately, this book did not really go into that much, ending pretty abruptly (for a 900-page book) with the death of JP Vann, its protagonist. But I will continue to try to locate the germ of modern conservative thought in this era....more

title: Clock Dance
author: Tyler, Anne*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Willa's life is hemmed in by domineering others, first her mother, then two successive husbands. "Clock Dance" takes us through various snapshots of hWilla's life is hemmed in by domineering others, first her mother, then two successive husbands. "Clock Dance" takes us through various snapshots of her life, with the most substantive of them being the quixotic journey she makes from Arizona to Maryland to help her son's ex-girlfriend, who has been shot in the leg. Willa gets enmeshed in the community there, and finds that she really enjoys being needed and being valued, which come at a premium with her second husband, Peter.I wouldn't say it's a very coherent narrative, but like Elizabeth Stroudt's novels there is a lot of enjoyably quirky local affect enjoyed through interpersonal exchanges amidst mundane goings on. I didn't love how thin this book felt, or its conclusion. I'm intrigued by what Anne Tyler can do with a better plot, since she draws characters so well. But without a more intriguing, engrossing plot, I'm not sure I would be too eager to read her again....more

title: Washington Black
author: Edugyan, Esi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Beautifully written, complex, interesting, "Washington Black" tells the story of a gifted young enslaved person who grows up in Barbados and hitches hBeautifully written, complex, interesting, "Washington Black" tells the story of a gifted young enslaved person who grows up in Barbados and hitches his apple cart to an abolitionist man of science, traveling the world and plying his trade and exploring what it means to be considered human in a variety of different contexts. Though written by a Black woman, the first half of this book veers uncomfortably into white savior territory. I think by the end it rescues itself and that maybe everything before was done deliberately, but the relationship between Titch and Wash is the structure of this book.I would give this 3.5 stars, and I round down (despite the beautiful writing and typically engrossing plot lines) because it leaves a lot of unfired Chekhov's Guns. We get so many poignant glimpses into the lives of many characters, most of them Black, who disappear without further explanation. Meanwhile, white characters seem perennially able to skirt death and to survive for future encounters. Maybe this itself is commentary--chattel can be cast off, discarded, written off in a ledger, whereas white people of privilege reap more than their fair share of good luck. Either way, I guess I was just a bit disappointed and left unsettled by some of the plot lines that were never tied up....more

title: The Pisces
author: Broder, Melissa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: LOL, this book.At turns engrossing and gross, erotic and tin-eared, I'm not sure what to make of it. It starts off serviceable enough: our protagonistLOL, this book.At turns engrossing and gross, erotic and tin-eared, I'm not sure what to make of it. It starts off serviceable enough: our protagonist is the personification of fallowness and dead ends, going through the motions with her doughy, noncommittal boyfriend of eight years in dusty, geriatric Phoenix, Arizona, phoning it in on a humanities Ph.D. that is clearly going nowhere. She breaks off the relationship perhaps a bit more hastily than she was ready for, and then decamps for Venice Beach, where the book does a decent job of sending up the Tinder dating lifestyle while making cheap sallies at SoCal culture, where everyone is a vapid, gluten-free, ultra-triggered navel-gazer. The book gets somewhat more serious when the big reveal occurs, which I won't spoil or mention here (I thought it was obvious from the cover alone, but YMMV). I liked the romance, and I thought some of the sex scenes were pretty steamy and well written. I also didn't really see the final twist coming, but it was a dark one. But I think what I'll remember this book most for was its absolutely absurd lines. On more than one occasion on an otherwise silent bus they caused me to exclaim, "Are you kidding me?" Upon reading one particularly piquant line, I had to look up the author, because it was so eye-roll-worthy that I was certain it was a man, probably some knockoff John Updike troglodyte. But no, the author appears female. I guess ladies be writin' cringeworthy lines, too! I didn't manage to record many of them, but this one might take the cake:"Like Claire, I too wanted a thousand cocks. Didn't we all just want a thousand hard cocks attached to the bodies of boys who have died for us, still warm, to plug our infinite holes?"Yep. So, like I said: LOL, this book....more

title: Priestdaddy
author: Lockwood, Patricia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can't remember when I first heard of Patricia Lockwood. I actually remember three distinct moments: as a devotee of The Awl, I remember reading her I can't remember when I first heard of Patricia Lockwood. I actually remember three distinct moments: as a devotee of The Awl, I remember reading her "Rape Joke" several years back. I don't remember my thoughts on it but I do remember thinking it was good and it generating a lot of buzz and conversation. Years later I read about the concept for this book, which sounded gimmicky (this is a memoir of Lockwood and her family, headed by her father, who is a practicing Roman Catholic priest, owing to some weird loophole in church practice), but interesting. Then I came across her psychoanalysis and exegesis of the oeuvre of John Updike, titled "Malfunctioning Sex Robot" and was hooked. This paragraph in particular I think highlights Lockwood's incisive mind and brand of humor:When he is in flight you are glad to be alive. When he comes down wrong – which is often – you feel the sickening turn of an ankle, a real nausea. All the flaws that will become fatal later are present at the beginning. He has a three-panel cartoonist’s sense of plot. The dialogue is a weakness: in terms of pitch, it’s half a step sharp, too nervily and jumpily tuned to the tics and italics and slang of the era. And yes, there are his women. Janice is a grotesquerie with a watery drink in one hand and a face full of television static; her emotional needs are presented as a gaping, hungry and above all unseemly hole, surrounded by well-described hair. He paints and paints them, but the proportions are wrong. He is like a God who spends four hours on the shading on Eve’s upper lip, forgets to give her a clitoris, and then decides to rest on a Tuesday. In the scene where Janice drunkenly drowns the baby, it wasn’t the character I felt pity for but Updike, fumbling so clumsily to get inside her that in the end it’s his hands that get slippery, drop the baby.But it wasn't until I read the London Review of Books' John Updike sendup that I looked into what she had written and discovered she was responsible for all three works. Seeing that her only book--Priestdaddy--was already in print, I checked it out from the library and then promptly let the title expire, collecting but never cracking the book once. Fast forward a few months later and several friends on my book-oriented group-chat independently identified it as a laugh riot, so I put myself back in the library queue and waited it out. Friends, I have gone a long time without truly loving a book, with 2018 probably being the last time I really emphatically gave a book five stars. "Priestdaddy" looked to be a great candidate for breaking that streak: it's hilarious from the first few pages, particularly if you have parents who are both conventional and idiosyncratic, grew up Catholic, and have an appreciation for people's tics and quirks. This book starts out so very strong I didn't want to read it all at once, preferring to extend my enjoyment. But by the second half of the book, the pace and originality of the prose does slow a bit. Not enough to be unenjoyable, but it can feel like filler at times. Lockwood gets big points for the poetry of her prose, which is beautiful and wryly funny, often in the same paragraph (not an easy feat). But, sadly, the streak is not broken because the second half could not keep up the excellence of the first.Still--a book a heartily recommend. I don't think you will regret it....more

title: Vietnam: An Epic Tragedy, 1945-1975
author: Hastings, Max
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was pretty explicitly written to capitalize on the mania around Ken Burns' "Vietnam" documentary, which I still haven't seen. I think I shouThis book was pretty explicitly written to capitalize on the mania around Ken Burns' "Vietnam" documentary, which I still haven't seen. I think I should probably check it out. What I wanted out of this book was an understanding of American chicanery and manipulation of public sentiment to prosecute this war that we never should have been involved with in the first place, and I'm not sure I got that. Not because it doesn't mention it--it does--but because it is weighed down by the myriad anecdotes of skirmishes, interpersonal dynamics, and day-by-day clashes that are of historical note but not something I am particularly interested in.One thing that struck me was that after My Lai, 69% of Americans excused the massacre, saying something like "We can expect these things to happen in war." The author, a Brit and certainly no American apologist, notes that the character of a civilization cannot be judged based on whether its soldiers commit atrocities, but by whether the populace countenances them in retrospect. Regardless of whether you credit that metric, the United States fails abjectly by either assessment. I'll be reading "The Brightest Lie" with my law school roommate next. Maybe that in combination with the Burns documentary will give me a more cogent understanding of the politicking that enabled us to enter into and stay involved with this unjustifiable destruction for so long....more

title: Severance
author: Ma, Ling*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Severance" follows Candace, a first-generation Asian American living a disaffected life in NYC. She has a pretty boring job printing and sourcing Bib"Severance" follows Candace, a first-generation Asian American living a disaffected life in NYC. She has a pretty boring job printing and sourcing Bibles, living in a city increasingly depopulated by a strange Chinese fungal plague that leaves all who come in contact with it in a state of catatonia, performing endless, repetitive tasks. For some reason Candace is immune, and joins a quirky band of survivors outside of the city, infected (as is typical in such hypothetical societies) with religious revivalism and a penchant for treating women as chattel. The first half started off great, and the narrator is deadpan: she and her compatriots fossick for weed in America's desolate towns and maintain their disdain for the suburbs. I would say I started off liking this book, but ended up being pretty dissatisfied. The ending was very abrupt and seemed somewhat meaningless, and the juxtaposition of the author's former publishing job and NYC life with the endless repetition of rote tasks by "the fevered" lost its cleverness almost immediately. Had high hopes for this one, given my love for dystopian novels with quirky twists. But it left me cold....more

title: Submission
author: Houellebecq, Michel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My friend handed this to me as a recommendation, and given that my intern had rhapsodized about it earlier in the summer and I had earlier read  Mark My friend handed this to me as a recommendation, and given that my intern had rhapsodized about it earlier in the summer and I had earlier read  Mark Lilla's "The Shipwrecked Mind," which is half devoted to analyzing this book, I thought I had better read it to see what all the fuss was about.This book belongs to the dissolute academic genre, which established male authors seem so drawn to. Perhaps it's because there's so much overlap between authors and professors, or because professors are kind of professional dilettantes, allowed if not expected to be learned on a narrow, esoteric subject, making the author's verisimilitude lift much more manageable when describing their days, thoughts, machinations. It often felt like "Disgrace" by Coetzee--our protagonist is also an academic lightweight afflicted by ennui who views women as masturbation devices. But the subject matter is very of the moment. France in the near future has split along ideological lines between an increasingly rockribbed hard right led by none other than Marine Le Pen, and a divided socialist left, increasingly split with a "Muslim Party." It's not always clear what positions this Muslim Party takes, other than "distributivism" (a kind of family-oriented ethos which sacrifices the bureaucracy and dispensable organs of government for what seems like a universal basic income and lots of private, religious subsidies aimed at accomplishing similar ends), but the leftists need these folks to hold off a menacing right, and make a seemingly shrewd devil's bargain with the eminently reasonable and respectable head of the Muslim Party: head of the Department of Education in exchange for a parliamentary majority.Well, education is apparently a big driver of culture in France, because soon everyone is wearing the hijjab and taking multiple wives. Saudi money lubricates the transition, and by 2022 the fashions of Paris are not too different from those of Tehran. Throughout the book we are confronted with this idea that Europe post rejection of Christianity is in suicidal decline, and rather than sundering it further as many on the right warn, the influx of immigrants from Muslim countries is the only thing that can rejuvenate France. The patriarchal, pro-masculine, pro-polygamy nature of Saudi Islam is the only thing that can rouse the West from its decadence, personified in the alcoholic, wayward Lothario narrator. It's hard to tell whether this is satire or admonition--perhaps that's what makes it good?--but I think I'm going to have to consult Lilla once again to determine my thoughts on this one......more

title: Identity Crisis: The 2016 Presidential Campaign and the Battle for the Meaning of America
author: Sides, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book summarily puts to bed the canard that the 2016 Election was about "economic anxiety," and pretty convincingly demonstrates that Trump succeeThis book summarily puts to bed the canard that the 2016 Election was about "economic anxiety," and pretty convincingly demonstrates that Trump succeeded because of his ability to activate the racist and xenophobic anxieties of people, aided by a bunch of freak factors that mostly aligned in his favor. Never straying too far from the data, the authors show that people were not really motivated by their concerns about their jobs or the state of their retirement accounts, but by their racist and xenophobic tendencies, as demonstrated by the high correlation between support for Trump and exhibitions of sexism, or beliefs such as "black people could get ahead if they just put in the effort" and "immigrants are a drain on our society." Does a book like this even matter, though? I don't really know. We on the left probably believed this already, anyway, and those on the right are so knee-jerk reactive to charges of racism that they'll either offer bad faith arguments for why the above does not in fact evince racism or why liberals are the REAL racists. No, its findings will not be satisfying in that regard. But it is interesting to consider what it means for politics in a world where media is so important and race anxieties are fair game for major politicians to cultivate. I suppose the good news is that there is a more than sufficient base for opposing the types of folks who are turned on by Trump's appeals, and we have seen that as recently as the 2018 Midterms, which occurred after but were mostly presaged by this book. Here's hoping we learned our important lessons come 2020......more

title: Augustus
author: Williams, John

review: It's bittersweet to have finished the third and final of John Williams' novels, but it was hard to resist, given how much I loved "Stoner" and thorougIt's bittersweet to have finished the third and final of John Williams' novels, but it was hard to resist, given how much I loved "Stoner" and thoroughly enjoyed and admired "Butcher's Crossing.""Augustus" is an epistolary novel, and I was chary of the format both before and during my reading of the book. But in the end I came away thinking that Williams was even more of a virtuoso than before I picked it up. It's certainly not the easiest way to write a novel, but it offered unique insights into the characters that might have felt clumsy in a more typical novel format. As to the content, it's amazing to consider all of the important, memorable people who all pretty much knew each other during this time period: Caesar, Augustus, Tiberius, Cleopatra, Mark Antony, Brutus, Cassius, Ovid, Demosthenes, Herod. I guess Jesus was hanging out there, too. I wonder whether they were really all so special or if we just have memorialized them to the exclusion of others, and so have a selective bias for remembering them. Anyway, this book inspired me to learn much more about Roman history and both its antecedents and its successors. Any suggestions would be most welcome, and please read John Williams when you get the chance!...more

review: "The Great Believers" follows two plot lines: gay Chicago in the midst of the AIDS crisis, and Paris in 2015. The first takes us through a gay communi"The Great Believers" follows two plot lines: gay Chicago in the midst of the AIDS crisis, and Paris in 2015. The first takes us through a gay community struggling to cope with a devastating plague, and the indignities borne of a larger culture that was at turns apathetic, contemptuous, and complicit. The second is mostly there for retrospective, it seems, a meditation on parenthood and loss, but a dispensable plot that mostly just felt like it was watering down the better, earlier one. It has hints of rapture and armageddon, evocative of "Angels in America," and felt like a better written, more succinct "Christadora." Like the best of AIDS literature, it showcases a vast array of contrasting and coexisting phenomena: rapid transitions between anger and resignation, ghastly betrayal amongst heartening loyalty, prudence and intemperance, superhuman strength displayed amidst weakness and fragility. It ably conveys the horribly lonely and hopeless feeling of the young and beautiful and free dying too soon, the endlessly tragic fact that real people who had love and acceptance and happiness denied to them finally secured these things only for them to be sources of their untimely demises.It was hard to read at times, but I really liked this book a lot and definitely recommend it....more

title: We the Corporations: How American Businesses Won Their Civil Rights
author: Winkler, Adam
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you're interested in understanding how we got to the point where corporations have more say in our democracy than The People, look no further. AdamIf you're interested in understanding how we got to the point where corporations have more say in our democracy than The People, look no further. Adam Winkler, a professor of law at UCLA, has written a corker. I might be biased as a history nerd/major and a lawyer, but I found this history--essentially of the idea of corporate personhood--to be fascinating and methodical. Winkler starts by explaining an alien if not absurd concept to the modern, unenlightened reader: corporations--which were designed to pool the resources and liabilities of many different people to accomplish very specific ends--were very rare at Common Law, required government permission to exist, and needed to have a function that was salutary to the commonweal to justify their exceptional rarity and special rights. Examples included funds to build canals, aqueducts, bridges, and universities. These corporations--including still extant institutions like Harvard, Yale, and Dartmouth--existed at the pleasure of the state, and could have their charters revoked at any time for a number of reasons, at least under the British system. But, when in the early Nineteenth Century the state of New Hampshire tried to take control of a university within its borders to which its predecessor colony had granted a charter (through the British Crown), the Supreme Court issued a fateful decision. SCOTUS did not extend the British Crown's ability to disestablish a corporate charter to the successor state of New Hampshire, with the [i]ultra vires[/i] reasoning being that the state owed some deference to the people and property comprising the corporation, in this case Dartmouth College. Fatefully, corporate personhood gained a toehold in America, and through it--the world.Although corporations are not mentioned in the Constitution and there is reason to believe that the Founding Fathers were suspicious of their influence upon democracy, the passage of the Fourteenth Amendment, sadly and ironically, was used to buoy the case for corporate personhood. Arguably the most important of all the amendments, the Fourteenth Amendment provides for many things--incorporation of many of the Bill of Rights amendments, citizenship for emancipated slaves, and equal protection under the laws of the country. It was a Reconstruction Amendment, and it's impossible to argue in good faith that its main object was not the extension of citizenship to all men (though, of course: the usual disclaimers about women and other groups not being ushered in as citizens after the Civil War). Intentions be damned, Winkler walks us through the shameful failure of the courts to actually protect Freedmen, juxtaposed by their zeal for using the Amendment to fashion newfound rights for corporations. This was aided by the outright lies of folks like Roscoe Conkling, who traded on his reputation and his role in drafting the Fourteenth Amendment (shrewdly, after all his fellow drafters were dead) to falsely state that among its main purposes was the protection of corporations. Well, the rest is history, and it's interesting history at that. There's no doubt that with a conservative lock on the Supreme Court and lower judiciaries over the next few decades, corporations will be empowered even more. Their speech rights are ascendant, and those of non-corporate individuals (also known as "people") are in decline. It's a sad state of affairs, but it's your duty as a citizen to know it and to rail against it if you find it unjust. So go out and read this book!...more

title: The Power
author: Alderman, Naomi*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was our recent book club pick, and a funny thing happened, somewhat without precedent: everyone agreed in their assessment of the book. We all thThis was our recent book club pick, and a funny thing happened, somewhat without precedent: everyone agreed in their assessment of the book. We all thought it started out strong, had a cool concept, that it sputtered a bit toward the end but overall we enjoyed it. But then we spent most of the rest of the book club ragging on it for its weird inconsistencies and random plot elements. The power is a book about women developing electroconductive abilities and giving men some long overdue what-for. I could sit here and carp about the flatness of the characters or the laziness of certain details, but I think the most interesting thing to consider about this book is what underlies the actual power imbalance between men and women in our world. The conceit of this book is just one big thought experiment: what if the almost universal physical advantage that men have over women were reversed, instantaneously? Would the gynocracy that some (yours truly included) pine for at times be a more just, compassionate world, or just as depraved and cruel as the patriarchy we actually inhabit, just with different overladies? There was disagreement about whether the real dynamic was due entirely to differences in physical strength (as opposed to strength plus women's ability to gestate and birth children, or some innate differences between men and women, or some combination of these three factors), but I thought this book was most interesting for its exploration of what it might look like to "reset" a reality like that, and to explore what human beings--who seem to naturally fall into hierarchies of power--would do. The world we currently inhabit, to varying degrees, must be conceived of as a more genteel one than the ur-state, the proverbial caveman with his club, dragging his concubine to the cave for cave sex whenever he pleases by dint of his superior strength. Nowadays most men in even the most repressive societies don't go around raping every physically weaker woman they see, even if the percentage who do is disturbingly, unsettlingly high. And yet even in the safest and most modern of societies, the physical menace of men that many women feel--whether constantly or in certain situations--is very real and extremely disquieting. We often talk of the persistence of rape culture in acts of sexual violence and coercion, but it's a more difficult undertaking to untangle the ways in which a species has developed its norms and comportment around the predicate assumption of male recourse to violence. And The Power explores that first generation after such a "reset." I think it's a bit disappointing that the book almost entirely dispenses with the cultural apparatus of repression, which I assume would still weigh heavily on the actions of women, even if the physical dynamics were reversed. The book sticks mostly to the physical dynamic, but it was somewhat interesting to see that first generation flexing its muscles, or skeins, as it were. And in the end, the author's winking indications that power corrupts all humans in the same ways are clumsy and impossible to miss, a bit boring by the end, even. But this book sure is good for prompting discussion of these issues!...more

review: I can't tell if this book is written as an homage to "One Hundred Years of Solitude," but it felt that way at times. There are little allusions to theI can't tell if this book is written as an homage to "One Hundred Years of Solitude," but it felt that way at times. There are little allusions to the book throughout (e.g., "Different generations of men, all having the same name, like some Latin American novel."), and it has the same meandering, fluid transition between characters, dramatic events, and epochs. I can't say I liked this one as much as Marquez's masterpiece, but that is a high bar to clear. This book admittedly started out difficult to follow (the characters are all so briefly touched upon that I had trouble keeping them straight), but it picks up a rhythm and the stalagmites of characters begin to accrete personalities. There is a pretty touching scene toward the end that really kicked this from three stars to 3.5/4. I went from feeling neutral to lukewarm gradually, then to explicitly positive pretty immediately. So I can't necessarily recommend this book (others who have picked it up have told me they had trouble with the prose style, etc.), but if you do decide to read it make sure to give it a chance. It might surprise you....more

title: My Year of Rest and Relaxation
author: Moshfegh, Ottessa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: With this book, I become an Ottessa Moshfegh evangelist. There's a semi-caveat there: she seems to have a motif, from which she doesn't deviate a wholWith this book, I become an Ottessa Moshfegh evangelist. There's a semi-caveat there: she seems to have a motif, from which she doesn't deviate a whole bunch. But if it keeps being as enjoyable as MYRR, Eileen, and some of her short stories, then I don't imagine there will be a problem. I picked up her newest novel from the library en route to a last-minute trip to the Balkans, where I met up with some of my best friends who all live in London, surprising two of them. Unbeknownst to me, one of these friends was actually reading it for her book club, having never heard of or read her before. Perhaps, if she's got intercontinental appeal, she doesn't much need my evangelism...Either way, I think I liked this less than Eileen, but it definitely made me laugh out loud more often. I devoured it on a single plane ride, and was sad when it ended. How much longer until her next book? What will it center on? I'm dying to know!Upper class New York was more accessible to me than the dreary, down-and-out New England of Eileen, but the main conceit of this book--I don't think it's a spoiler, because I'm pretty sure it's in every blurb I've seen for this book--is that the main character decides to check out of life by taking a punishing cocktail of (mostly) fake pharmaceuticals, her life maintained in the background by wealth and a rudimentary support staff of sorts. When life is annoying, or stressful, or seems pointless, the luxury of a drunken night of oblivion in bed alone can seem too decadent to resist; Moshfegh just experiments with that to the extreme, untethering her heroine from the constraints of societal norms and expectations to show what it would be like to just completely check out, to fully disconnect, to time warp, in effect.It's pretty dark territory at times, but the book ends on a somewhat uplifting note. Check it out, especially if you liked Eileen....more

review: I began following Corey Robin on Facebook a few years ago, and at some point I made some snarky comment to him. Apparently he is one of these public pI began following Corey Robin on Facebook a few years ago, and at some point I made some snarky comment to him. Apparently he is one of these public personalities who engages with his followers, and he really let me have it. At first he just made a snide remark about my comment being Spiro Agnew-esque, and I rolled my eyes and snarked back. We got into a pretty heated back-and-forth, and I don't think it was either of our best sides on display. But, although I still don't love his Facebook comments, I have always admired how prolific and articulate and challenging his articles are. I recommend him to you!So I decided to look into his two books. I had read some negative s of this one, but I wanted to pick it up anyway. It's true that the first part is prettttty dry. There's a lot of very esoteric discussion of Hobbes and Montesquieu that I'm not sure I really absorbed or was what I came to this book for. But toward the end there is some provocative discussion of the workings of American government and pluralism and the negative aspects of things like separation of powers and civic society that I found interesting after a lifetime of having de Tocqueville crammed down my throat. I'll be reading his more recent book, "The Reactionary Mind," but more for what I've read in his shorter-form writing than this work....more

After reading (and liking) her "July's People," I picked this up. Gordimer has a way with words. She puts things succinctly, viscerally. She captures the fraught nature of race in South Africa--not a simple concept--in remarkably economical terms, particularly the nature, no doubt familiar to her, of white liberals in an apartheid and post-apartheid racially terroristic state. While some of these were good--the language in the first story is haunting, mantra-like, and the stories of the Holocaust Jews and the benighted flight will stick with me--some of them felt silly (e.g. the first-person narrative of the tape worm being flushed from its host's body). Tate likes to tell you all of the ways that our costs are increased, pennyante, in ways that we typically never know of. Her predisposition seems to be that it's ridiculous that these things keep getting added to our bills, which is a reasonable enough proposition. But what she never tells us is whether these added costs are intended to relieve some expense later on, elsewhere in society, which seems like an important component of the economic analysis.Anyway, not my cup of tea. Did not finish....more

review: The Unwinding tells a story of where we are in this country, people arrayed against corporate and political interests, mourning the dreams they were pThe Unwinding tells a story of where we are in this country, people arrayed against corporate and political interests, mourning the dreams they were peddled, and trying to get by in an increasingly inaccessible marketplace. It's heavy on the anecdote, and seems to be modeled on John Dos Passos' "U.S.A. Trilogy," with every chapter begun with pop culture snippets and the anecdotes occasionally shown to vaguely intertwine. There's a lot that presages Trump here--Peter Thiel saying that pessimism would be the winning political ticket, people yearning for a time when America was "great," the sleight of hand that directs the ire of economic stagnation toward minorities and immigrants and away from corporations and tax-cutting Republicans. review: Well, this had its ups and its downs. I'm very into old-timey, neo-Biblical writing styles, and Melville is about as baroque as it gets. So the writinWell, this had its ups and its downs. I'm very into old-timey, neo-Biblical writing styles, and Melville is about as baroque as it gets. So the writing was a thrill for me at the beginning. At times it was downright difficult to understand what was meant to be conveyed, but for the most part it was just a matter of acknowledging the idiosyncrasy. The story started out pretty great, too. I wanted the whole thing to be a bromantic romp between Ishmael and Queequeg. But the novel itself is oddly constructed. There are lengthy discursions on the nature of cetaceans, the color white, the various meats to be prized from cetacean corpses, etc. These discursions interrupt the plot of the novel in a way that is at times difficult to follow, and beggars the latter. So this book started with a bang and then grew less endearing, but it's hard to diminish such an accomplishment, even if the sum of the parts is greater than the value of the whole. ...more

review: This comprehensive book explores how the Civil Rights Era directly facilitated the modern carceral state, through the initiatives of Republicans and DThis comprehensive book explores how the Civil Rights Era directly facilitated the modern carceral state, through the initiatives of Republicans and Democrats alike. At a recent remove, our prison populations matched the complexion of our country. But images of cities being "torn apart" by non-white agitators and the specter of non-white people with power, demanding rights shook genteel, suburban America to the core. The flip side of the "Great Society"--of dubious lasting success--was Law and Order, a regime that continues to thrive and enforce racial injustices that seem almost Apartheid-esque in their disproportionality. This book talks a lot about what was happening on the ground, in individual precincts and cities, which I found less useful than its more macroscopic takes. But all around it was interesting, well-written, and a cautionary tale to progressives (very much including myself) who can be disinterested the tiresome but politically influential class and race anxieties of white people, never really activated more so than when minorities demand equality....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm preparing for a trip to South Africa later this month, and was told that Coetzee and Gordimer were indispensable reading. So I picked up this and I'm preparing for a trip to South Africa later this month, and was told that Coetzee and Gordimer were indispensable reading. So I picked up this and "July's People," not realizing that these two authors are not only Nobel laureates, but make up half of Africa's Literary Nobel class. I can't comment on the two authors just yet, but the two books have a lot in common: plots involving privileged white people having trouble accepting that different rules and different power dynamics obtain in the much poorer, less white lands outside of Jo'burg and Cape Town; terse prose and relentless plot development. I'm not finished with "July's People" just yet but I have to imagine I will end up liking it better. This book felt too disconnected, too unresolved. It reminds me of the kind of book I hated to explicate in high school English class--there's so much ambiguity that almost any interpretation is credited, not unlike a horoscope. I just didn't enjoy it as a work of literature, not to say anything of the disturbing subject matter. The technical mastery is something to behold, but this was not a pleasant or compelling book, for me at least....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's easy to forget that America isn't uniquely the polychromatic land of racial injustice and misunderstanding, given the peers it telegraphs for itsIt's easy to forget that America isn't uniquely the polychromatic land of racial injustice and misunderstanding, given the peers it telegraphs for itself. But at some proximate remove South Africa was a racial war zone, and the 'uppance came for good and bad alike. This book explores the distillation of the power dynamic that we all (at least in America and other outposts of capitalism) tolerate, despite our hollow egalitarian claims to the contrary: the non-white facilitation of white comfort. It's brutal and revealing, just not especially well portrayed. The plot skips and lurches, it's thin on details at times, and the narrators change without warning. It can be confusing, but the author's talents more than justify giving her another shot....more

review: This is the rare book that many friends have recommended to me simultaneously. My bud Julie excoriated it, but I was still excited about it when the email finally arrived, informing me that I could download it.At the beginning, I liked it a lot. As a member of a multi-child family in the tedious suburbs, I am drawn to these stories, particularly to the extent that they build up nuanced personalities. But that stopped early here. It seemed like this was a copse of stories, most of which got chopped down at the beginning and then frustratingly (and confusingly) never got revisited: the alcoholic teacher; the patriarch of the perfect family; Moody. What ever ended up happening to these folks? I wasn't even invested enough to hope for a sequel, the disposal of them just felt so perfunctory. review: This was our June book club pick. It won out over "Fun Home" and "A Brief History of Seven Killings," two of my absolute favorites, in our Pride-themeThis was our June book club pick. It won out over "Fun Home" and "A Brief History of Seven Killings," two of my absolute favorites, in our Pride-themed book club. I'm glad to have read this book because it was the only title I hadn't read, and also because lesbian literature is something I am realizing I'm woefully underexposed to.This roman à clef stars a bright young woman in provincial Florida with designs on greatness. Common as a feature in queer youth lit (e.g., "The End of Eddy"), the protagonist nurtures her intelligence as an escape hatch from the conformity and stolidity of the repressive South. To the extent that she actually flaunted her homosexuality in the 1960s South, I give this woman massive props. The New York stuff was all pretty conventional, decrepit, 1970s NYC stuff. We all agreed that the book oversold people's sexual suggestiveness and made sex the focal (end?) point of most entanglements with people. But we also agreed that the author had a fun voice, a charming story, and spun and interesting tale.But seriously we polled the group on their knowledge of good lesbian fiction and most of us couldn't come up with more than one or two. My friend Alice recommended a lesbian steampunk novel called (exquisitely) "Fingersmith," but that's about the extent of my knowledge. Help me out with some suggestions, goodreads?...more

title: Nixonland: The Rise of a President and the Fracturing of America
author: Perlstein, Rick
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think I used to say that we're lucky that Trump is incompetent, because his combination of spleen, ignorance, vanity, hatred, and dishonesty--when pI think I used to say that we're lucky that Trump is incompetent, because his combination of spleen, ignorance, vanity, hatred, and dishonesty--when paired with a competent actor--would surely be Armageddon. Well, the truth is that we had him, and his name is Richard M. Nixon. Oozing with hatred, grievance, and tapped into the amygdalae of the discomfited white majorities in this country, Nixon inaugurated our present dynamic, where two sides of the aisle regard each other as a mortal threat to the Republic and all that is good, where truth and decency matter less than political tribalism, and where grievance and insecurity are weaponized to their fullest extent to scupper and roll back progress--Nixonland, as the author would have it.Not that we weren't riven by cultural fissures before this point, but we have had little hope of our better angels governing us in the time since due to his influence. It's remarkable that it could come out that a party's president rose to power and aimed to retain it by extending the war in Vietnam, killing scores of innocent Vietnamese and sacrificing thousands of American citizens for no lasting purpose. And it's amazing that fifty scant years since, the GOP has remained one of the two main political options in this country, not at all reconstructed but, if anything, more rock-ribbed and truculent than Nixon could ever have hoped for. Before Trump, the GOP had perhaps as strong a claim to being the party of Eisenhower, Bush I, and Teddy Roosevelt as it did to Goldwater and Nixon. Reagan and Bush II merged the two warring impulses in their administrations. But Trump is the latter camp's apotheosis. Doctrinaire know-nothing-ism, celebration of ignorance, validation and operationalization of all unearned grievance, greedy fingers ever picking at the scabs we so rarely form over our fissures and recriminations. Whether that has staying power in the long run is something I doubt less and less as the country continues to disappoint. But, taken in a moderately optimistic light, the lesson of Nixon is that eventually the charlatans and the liars get their comeuppance. As we head into midterms, as Mueller's investigation wraps, and as the Supreme Court is irretrievably politicized, this revealing quote from after Nixon's resignation will give me hope:"It’s a piece of cake until you get to the top,” [Nixon] mused with Ken Clawson. “Then you find you can’t stop playing the game the way you’ve always played it because it is part of you and you need it as much as you need an arm or a leg.” And here is the nub. “So you are lean and mean and resourceful and you continue to walk on the edge of the precipice because over the years you have become fascinated by how close you can walk without losing your balance.”...more

review: When I was in fifth grade, I won a county poetry contest for a poem I wrote, prosaically titled "Trees." The poem had a taut, A-A-B-B rhyming pattern,When I was in fifth grade, I won a county poetry contest for a poem I wrote, prosaically titled "Trees." The poem had a taut, A-A-B-B rhyming pattern, mined precocious adjectives from a thesaurus, and concluded with the cringeworthy line, "People and trees: incredible connection." If you want to save the time it takes to read 500 pages and skip the saccharine plot, I am happy to dig up the entirety of the poem for you, because they have the same goal and accomplish the same end. This book, which I enjoyed for about 100 pages, might better be called "Trees, Actually." Like the movie "Love, Actually," a bunch of strangers have their lives upended and relationships manufactured around a common conceit, except instead of Christmas, it's trees! None of it really makes sense and is mostly overwrought, with the only difference between the two works being that I actually quite liked "Love, Actually," even admitting its absurdity. But this book was just tedious, a bunch of otherwise normal people abandoning their lives, responsibilities and all conventions to fight back against cartoonish tree-killing villains.It is true that we all need to become better stewards of the environment, and this book gets points for its good intentions and cool factoids about our arboreal friends. But almost anyone who makes it through this book is probably already converted to the environmentalist cause (or at least whatever substrate involves believing "trees = good"), and I wager that anyone who wasn't will be turned off by how silly and mawkish this book is. Read Naomi Klein's This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs. The Climate instead.ETA: a Pulitzer!? The year after "Less," too. Really makes a guy grumble...more

title: The Road to Unfreedom: Russia, Europe, America
author: Snyder, Timothy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Keep making the world a shittier place, and you will ensure a constituency of angry, easily manipulable folks in perpetuity. Russia perfected the art,Keep making the world a shittier place, and you will ensure a constituency of angry, easily manipulable folks in perpetuity. Russia perfected the art, pivoting from failing communist state to kleptocratic oligarchy during the post-perestroika Russia by scapegoating the United States and Europe for Russia's immiseration, harkening back to a false but rosier picture of Soviet Union under Stalin, at its apogee in WWII. Russia, purveyors of a negative-sum politics in which everyone is worse off for the untruths peddled and instability sown (but with Russia losing relatively less on both measures), is openly working to subvert the stability of regimes that have outmaneuvered it economically and politically. By changing the rules of the game, of truth itself, Russian potentates shore up their own power while the Russian state weakens its foes. It is a wily, bold, and thoroughly Russian gambit, and it has paid off handsomely.And whether you're in Britain worried about Brexit, France, Austria, and Poland worried about fascist far-right movements, or the United States under Trump, you are suffering because of the effects of these efforts. I wish that I felt like we were waking up from a nightmare we've indulged for too long, but after a day like today when the GOP Senate intends to push forward after the Kavanaugh/Ford circus, I wonder if the tendency that is being exploited wasn't always there, and whether the germ of petty irrationality is irremediable once established......more

title: Globalists: The End of Empire and the Birth of Neoliberalism
author: Slobodian, Quinn*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I visited Stanford University for the first time in years this past summer, and saw that the author was giving a talk on this book at some point. I loI visited Stanford University for the first time in years this past summer, and saw that the author was giving a talk on this book at some point. I looked it up and it sounded interesting--why not find out more about this neoliberal impulse that benights those who have had power in Western and especially U.S. politics over the past 70 years? Overall this book was way above my pay grade, but I'll take a stab at summarizing it.This dense but expertly researched work traces the development of world economic orders from the Hapsburg Empire to the development of the World Trade Organization. Summed up succinctly, it discusses the emergence of neoliberal thought as the process of keeping capitalism safe from democracy. Following the twilight of colonial power, Western metropoles fought to preserve the economic inequities that characterized those relationships, using paternalistic language and coercive development aid and trade as a way of suggesting that the long subjugated and plundered peoples of the world were "radical" and "disruptive" for demanding fairly equitable redistributive equitable measures. Whether through severe sanctions imposed for the nationalization of rapacious extraction industries or their subtle but strong support for the apartheid regime in South Africa, these folks did not want anything to get in the way of free trade at the lowest prices possible, justice be damned. In addition to this backdrop of reaction to decolonization, Slobodian addresses the other supranational entities that have emerged in the last century, including the EU, that place markets beyond the power of national governments, while granting property rights to individuals outside of the citizenry. He argues that this has largely been a capitalist push, and has marginalized democracy in general and labor in particular as a consequence. Finally, he discusses the role of law in propitiating global capitalism, where "laissez faire" ironically required quite a robust set of rules and regulations as base assumptions. We tend to view the post-WWII period as one of great prosperity and cooperation, but this book has made me wonder who really benefits, and who loses out because of that cooperation. If our international systems provide more ballast for private interests than mechanisms for rights and equity redress, then how much pride should we be taking in them? I'm not hopeful that a truly equitable system of international economic redress would ever gain traction, but I hope it's at least possible for international legal systems to evolve in a way that they can resist the antidemocratic impulses that have characterized their development over the past century....more

review: "Awkward"--it's become practically an interjection in our world, where a million records bear witness to our embarrassments, where our whole life is r"Awkward"--it's become practically an interjection in our world, where a million records bear witness to our embarrassments, where our whole life is recorded for excruciating , where our access to so much of each other's lives makes us increasingly worried about how our own are being sized up. Melissa Dahl is here to save us from our endless navel gazing and nail biting--telling us that we needn't worry so much about awkwardness, given that the concept mostly applies to situations that others don't interpret in the same uncharitable way we might, or are too self-involved to take note of. Dahl charts the relationship between confidence and groundedness and the potential for discomfort--which is of course at the heart of our need to call out every awkward, cringeworthy thing--and exhorts us to forgive ourselves more, embrace new things, and generally lean into the cringeworthiest parts of our lives for the positive good that can be wrung from the process. It's good advice!...more
