author: Franken, Al
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book brought up a lot of emotions!I have to say it--I think we were wrong to railroad Franken. And by we, I guess I mean Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand?This book brought up a lot of emotions!I have to say it--I think we were wrong to railroad Franken. And by we, I guess I mean Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand? *Sigh* Look, the Republicans are a bunch of misogynist moral hypocrites. We all know this, even as the party that fights harder for women's rights and more accountability for abusers suffers the penalties of its scruples. But do Al Franken's churlish acts--all of which occurred before he was a Senator--justify not only his resignation as a powerful and compelling United States Senator and champion of women, but also the unforced error of having to run another election in 2018, when control of the Senate could alter reproductive freedom for a generation? I really don't think so. We have an accused rapist in the Oval Office, and a party full of doubters of victims of sexual harassment and assault controlling both branches of Congress. I like to think that if the Dems were faced with losing the Senate or Presidency because they had to support a credibly accused serial sexual assaulter, they would choose integrity over expediency, as the Republicans have so cravenly failed to do. But the Democrats were not faced with that decision in Franken's case--his behavior was regrettable but it came from before he was in the Senate and at a time when mores about making light of sexism were behind the times for everyone. So the only way Franken's decision can be rationalized is as a reprieve from the distraction that bad-faith actors propounded, and would have continued to harp on even as they do nothing to probe the moral horror presented by their own party's president. I just hope that we remember that Franken is a good man who understands how these things work, which is why he resigned, despite massive popularity and strong progressive (and pro-women!) bona fides. But Jesus fucking Christ, when will the left in this country realize that you can't win a fight with a hand tied behind your back?...more

title: Homesick for Another World
author: Moshfegh, Ottessa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Welp, I've gone and binged on Ottessa Moshfegh (last syllable rhymes with "leg," I found out when googling around for her Twitter handle, which she obWelp, I've gone and binged on Ottessa Moshfegh (last syllable rhymes with "leg," I found out when googling around for her Twitter handle, which she obviously is too cool to have). I've come away very pleased and this has been evidenced by my eagerness to evangelize for her to everyone I meet. Really, this is kind of a questionable practice, because the books and short stories are pretty weird. I guess I trust anyone who is interested in contemporary literature to at least keep an open mind about outré plots and to understand the skill she possesses for writing entertaining, weird stories. But, you know: YMMV."Homesick for Another World" is an apt title: most of the stories center on a benighted main character's unrealistic escapism, a perhaps unfounded sense of belonging elsewhere ginned up solely from not fitting in "here," wherever that may be. As with "Eileen," Moshfegh has her finger on the pulse of the seediest parts of modern life/America. She writes viscerally: you can see the pimples patinated with cakey concealer, smell the mothballs mingling with halitosis, feel the regretful hangovers. And although there were a few lesser entries in the middle (including her two "New Yorker" entries, puzzlingly enough), this collection started and ended strong. Pick it up if you have the chance!...more

title: Grant
author: Chernow, Ron
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For my penultimate status update on this book, I adapted one of my favorite Simpsons gags. The straightman in the joke says something like "Libraries For my penultimate status update on this book, I adapted one of my favorite Simpsons gags. The straightman in the joke says something like "Libraries are wonderful! See, even Cletus uses the books here." Cletus then takes a turtle out of his coveralls and lifts Leon Uris's "Trinity" (incidentally, where my name comes from) above his head and attempts to crack open the turtle for some good eatin'. Uris' novels were popular but not exactly highbrow and certainly not economical fiction. Aside from the joke at Cletus' expense, I always thought there was a bit of the wry implication that books the size of which he usually produces are more notable for their abundant content than their brilliance. Thus, we find the longwinded Chernow (although in my version of the joke, I misidentified him as David McCullough, though I feel like this is a pretty reasonable misidentification on my part), of whom I suspect saying the same puts me in the minority of Americans. This is a lengthy tome, and I kept notes on my thoughts, intending to write a lengthy  critiquing it. But I just can't bring myself to do that on a beautiful Saturday afternoon. The truth is that I didn't love the first half of this book, devoted to the tedium of the Civil War and Grant's role in winning it militarily. It is pretty amazing that Grant was basically a failed businessman with few prospects into his mid-thirties, and his fine command of the armed forces really changed his lot late in life. But aside from that, it felt repetitive and overindulgent with factoids. I liked the presidential years and the nifty world tour he took thereafter much more so than I did learning about his childhood and his role in the war, but it still felt like I was just finishing this because I had invested so much time into it already. Chernow perseverates about how uncorrupt Grant was, instead characterizing him as bumbling and trusting; it's not clear to me what difference this makes given the frequency and magnitude of the times Grant was duped, but the author sure takes up the mantle of exonerating him. Sadly, I think the book undersells Grant's role in two of our greatest national tragedies, the destruction of the way of life of Native Americans and the failure to vigorously uphold Reconstruction. We think of Lincoln as the founder of the Republican Party, and as the man who freed the slaves. We tend to elevate him as the personification of liberty and the anti-slavery crusade. But Lincoln's views were not especially radical or inspired by virtue so much as expediency, and it's one thing to free the slaves, but the decisions that came after about how to expiate the sin of slavery are the ones of most import. Grant, as the first elected president following Lincoln, really held the reigns for that task, and although he can't be fully faulted, we all know what happened. Chernow blames the indignant Ku Kluxing South, unscrupulous media men who used whiffs of Grant's many scandals to try to undermine support for the president, and thus Reconstruction, and insists that Grant was a stalwart supporter of the freedman. But, having heard his evidence, I find that interpretation of history beggared by the facts. Grant calculated just as much as Lincoln, and at a certain point it just seemed like the tantrums thrown by the South were too irritating and uncontroversial for the Republican Party to keep fighting or provoking. To reconstruct an enslaved race was always going to be harder than the war fought to make such an undertaking possible, but Republicans and Northern whites soon began to wonder whether "all this trouble" was really worth it. Hadn't the country been disrupted enough? Hadn't we given the African race the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments? What more could they expect? Or so the arguments started to go. And we see Grant swayed by these argument in, for instance, his refusal to remediate Southern uprisings and violations of freedmen's civil rights because Republicans in Ohio claimed that their election prospects would accordingly dim. The rest is history, as they say, and historians such as Chernow can easily lapse into centrism, rehabilitation, and teleological thinking. That may have happened here, it's difficult to say. But my scruples about letting Grant off the hook too easily and Chernow's biases aside, this is an incredibly important moment in American history, and for that other readers might partially enjoy this book for the same reason I did....more

title: Children of the Days: A Calendar of Human History
author: Galeano, Eduardo
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My original intention, in 2018, was to read one page of this book every day of the year. I fell behind and never caught up. I failed again in 2019, buMy original intention, in 2018, was to read one page of this book every day of the year. I fell behind and never caught up. I failed again in 2019, but reaffirmed my intentions in 2020. The year brought more unexpected misery than good, but one of the latter things was it allowed me to have most of my idle moments (most moments, unremarkably) in my bedroom. It sat on my desk for months, and I rarely went more than a week or two without picking it up and getting back on track. The concept is that the author tells a story, sometimes a folktale but often a historical fact, often little known in the English-speaking world, for every day of the calendar year. When these are based on actual calendar dates (e.g., September 11, May 5), they correspond to that date in the book; when they are based on seasons (e.g., Easter, Ramadan), they are only approximate. As a Uruguayan writer, Galeano writes disproportionately about the Latin American experience. He seems to aim to provoke, flipping the script on those who view the West and the imperial powers of North America and Europe as unblemished heroes. I enjoyed it thoroughly, and learned a lot....more

title: The Color of Law: A Forgotten History of How Our Government Segregated America
author: Rothstein, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This succinct history puts the lie to the idea that people congregate with others of their race mostly out of preference and custom, and that the mateThis succinct history puts the lie to the idea that people congregate with others of their race mostly out of preference and custom, and that the material side effects thereof (wealth, educational opportunities, etc.) are blameless incidents for which we bear no collective responsibility. In a scant 200ish pages, Rothstein bludgeons you with anecdote after anecdote of federal, state, and local officials or policies that disrupted working and middle class white and black Americans' attempts to live in integrated environments, and presents devastating evidence of the wealth gap that has opened between the races in large part because of this government-designed segregation. Whether through evictions, police refusals to protect the homes of African Americans in white neighborhoods from marauding gangs, VA refusals to grant mortgages to black GIs unless they bought in black neighborhoods, or cities' deliberate attempts to maintain the complexions of all-white and all-black neighborhoods while destroying most integrated ones, all levels of government were complicit in the 150+ year long effort to preserve the badges and incidents of slavery and to ensure that blacks remained a separate and distinctly lower class than whites. Sadly, it seems that these are things that are too shameful to admit to ourselves. They cloud our rosy myth of a just, egalitarian, and meritocratic society, and they're too complex to compress into a neat argument in a culture governed by soundbyte discourse. How we could right this wrong is a complex and interesting question, but it's not clear that we possess the understanding and empathy to decide that housing segregation is something that even needs to be redressed. But this is hardly unique: slavery is not particularly complex, nor is substandard schooling post-Brown v. Board, yet none of it registers in the mind of the average American as something deserving of reparations. But the dollar figures that Rothstein presents--the degree to which the government has forced black people in particular into communities where their ability to generate wealth then turns nugatory--are hard to argue with, and the causality is so recent that there are people alive today who were born into integrated communities with which the assorted governments of this country had not yet had the chance to meddle. All of this makes Rothstein's proposed solutions at the end of this study that much more crucial and interesting--chimerical though they may be.When I got back from my vacation this weekend I showed some of the pages of this book to our deputy commissioner, who is currently suing at least one residential community that was explicitly founded for whites, aided by the government in this mission, and forcibly exclusionary of black tenants. We are trying to hold them accountable for far more recent transgressions, but all with the aim of achieving a more equitable society by redressing past wrongs. It's plodding, incomplete redress, but especially as a government worker in a more enlightened administration, it's what is right and necessary and I'm glad to be a part of it....more

title: Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House
author: Wolff, Michael
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So I have this tendency to do the worst things to myself, acknowledge the damage I'm doing, yet remain utterly incapable of reforming my destructive wSo I have this tendency to do the worst things to myself, acknowledge the damage I'm doing, yet remain utterly incapable of reforming my destructive ways. As any frequent readers of this page will know, I am not exactly sanguine about the Trump presidency, nor are my s of the books chronicling the lead up to it my happiest ones. But I also have the capacity for reform, if I am sufficiently jarred. I think it was Kanye (thanks, Ye?) tweeting about god knows what nonsense that got me to kick my compulsive Twitter habit, and more recently with all that's been going on in Gaza I have stopped checking the Facebook for reliably horrible hot takes from people whom I'm connected with. And I gave up on reading post-mortems of the 2016 Election because it's just too horrible to relive and we've got enough horror to live through in the present. So just what the hell was I doing reading this potboiler after making such healthy decisions? you might be asking yourself.Well I don't have a great excuse, but I'm very glad I did read this. When this book came out, I remember reading about what an unreliable hack the author was, an assessment that came even from disinterested parties and people on the Left. And the media was mostly focused on the constant ratfucking that goes on in the Trump White House, which was not that surprising (or interesting, really), given how horrible and unqualified and thin-skinned this passel of idiots seems to be. But I think I was running low on books and this was about to expire, so, I figured: why not give it a whirl?I'm glad I did! I still don't find the backbiting to be particularly interesting, though whether it's credible is a different judgment. What I found most engaging was just how deluded these people are, though it's not hard to believe given how truly divorced from reality you have to be to even step foot into that White House at any level and expect any modicum of success or admiration, from the President on down. This White House is a living embodiment of the Dunning-Kreuger effect, of detached, base narcissism the likes of which is pretty amazing to witness. Jared and Ivanka REALLY do think that they can reign in Trump's and the alt-right's impulses! Trump really doesn't think he's treated fairly or acts objectionably! Jared really does think that bringing peace to the Middle East is as easy as having Saudi Arabia and Egypt ally with Israel (!?!?!?) to take out Iran, and then... peace and prosperity will somehow ensue? Ivanka actually believes that she will be the first female POTUS! It's just so amazing, claw-your-eyes-out preposterously stupid. And yet, this is our reality. I will combust in an eternal flame of schadenfreude when this White House is sundered by impeachment, forced retirement, or, ideally: resounding defeat in 2020.Perhaps the most striking thing about this book (hopefully a sign that it's heavily embellished and fabricated? Though I honestly didn't get that impression) was that I came away liking, of all addled-masses-of-cirrhosis-bad-hair-and-tonsilloliths--Steve Bannon! I still think he's a ridiculous pseudo-intellect who makes unwarranted connections between "dad history" and present events, but he came across, in the acme of irony, as the most sober person in the room on most occasions. Trump fires Comey and he excoriates "the geniuses" (Jared and Ivanka), foretells the passion of Hope Hicks, and decides that Trump is, at most, a one-term president. For all of his supposed wisdom it's hard to sympathize, given how obvious it was to anyone that Trump is too unreliable and broken to be the figurehead for any principled movement. But Bannon has a lot of funny zingers and really has contempt for most of the loathsome people in the White House, including (one gets the impression) Trump himself. Bannon has been out of the spotlight lately, and it's not clear if that's calculated or an unintended consequence of his fall from grace, post-Charlottesville, which is about the point at which this book concludes. The book's final sentence made me laugh out loud, however, because it was so ridiculous, on-point, and *sigh* probably prophetic. Bannon was holding forth on the front steps of his DC redoubt, speaking to the author about how Trump had lost his way, had probably blown up his presidency with all of his dunderheaded mistakes, and how Bannon, having retained the Breitbart crowd and never having lost the faith or patronage of the shadowy Mercers would actually be running for president, in 2020, which he predicted he would win. The final words of the book are his: "It's going to be wild as shit." Indeed....more

title: My Own Words
author: Ginsburg, Ruth Bader
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's not an exaggeration to say that I fear the death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg more than I do nuclear war. I feel like the country could possibly recoveIt's not an exaggeration to say that I fear the death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg more than I do nuclear war. I feel like the country could possibly recover from the latter, but I'm really not sure about the former. This says a lot about the character of the Court in modern times--its politicization, the wisdom of having life tenure, the desecration of Gorsuch's confirmation, and not a small bit about how lucky we are to have such a brilliant, pioneering, charming person anchoring the liberal wing of the Constitution. But let's focus on her life and not her death, shall we?This book isn't the biography I had hoped for: it's a pastiche of opinions, speeches, op-eds, and a smattering of life details, not really in the proportions I wanted. But it's probably the easiest way to slap together a biography-manque when your cultural profile is at its zenith. Ruth is a champion of women, and she has shaped all of our lives thereby. But she shaped mine in a special way. My first job after law school was at the Women's Rights Project of the ACLU, which she founded way back when. The Women's Rights Project still exists, and my fellowship allowed me to fight discrimination against pregnant women in the workplace (and men! Side note: RBG had the amazing foresight to understand that women won't be equal in the workplace or society until we stop seeing pregnancy/reproductive discrimination as a "women's issue" and sought to represent men/fathers thereby. Notably, she is very good about attributing political victories and changes in opinion to women and men. I think this is important, not because men deserve to be thanked in the same breath as women but because men's egos--especially those of allies!--are often quite fragile and it's easier to laud than worry about salving a spurned ego). Impact litigation wasn't for me, but I admire and respect the hell out of what they do there, and while I was reading this I even referred a client there who had been fired the day after announcing a pregnancy--this is still happening in 2018 in California, so one not only wonders how much further we have to go, but where we might be without the trailblazing of incomparable warriors like RBG.Aside from her raw, awesome intelligence, what comes across so clearly in this book is RBG's humanity. She seems like a genuinely kind person, thankful for her blessings and still passionate about the people on behalf of whom she takes up legal battles. I wish I possessed her hope that recent disturbing judicial trends were just blips, or that the Court can remain a bulwark against the political pathologies of the Executive and Legislative branches... but as long as she's alive there's hope!...more

title: Open Veins of Latin America: Five Centuries of the Pillage of a Continent
author: Galeano, Eduardo
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I took a class in college titled something like "U.S. History in Latin America." It was to fulfill a requirement, but as these things tend to turn outI took a class in college titled something like "U.S. History in Latin America." It was to fulfill a requirement, but as these things tend to turn out, it ended up being one of my absolute favorite classes. I never knew what an imperialist power the U.S. had been, nor how universally meddlesome it had been in the affairs of the (non-white) countries of this hemisphere. In American public school we're taught that the Monroe Doctrine is almost an act of gallantry--a clarion call to the privative nations of Old Europe that meddling in the affairs of free people is a thing that would no longer be countenanced by the United States, the first nation to break those shackles. But, as we all know, that story is a bit too cute and oversimplified. The United States held itself out as a benevolent big brother type in the hemisphere, but really it just used its privileged position and burgeoning might to siphon off what Europe had been doing to line its own coffers since the 1500s. I liked this book, but it felt repetitive and could have been trimmed. Books like this one expose these truths, though often they run to tedium. Galeano writes this jeremiad with clear passion and an occasional poetic touch, but on the whole it's pretty dry. ...more

title: Sweetbitter
author: Danler, Stephanie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 4 stars for this fun and surprisingly complex debut. I think I liked this most for its nostalgia value. The author is few years older than I am, but t4 stars for this fun and surprisingly complex debut. I think I liked this most for its nostalgia value. The author is few years older than I am, but the New York City she describes mirrors the memories I have of when I first lived here: overindulgence, strict observance of a northern barrier at 23rd street, a panoply of East Village bars, all with "bar" in their name ("Mars Bar," "Art Bar," "Park Bar," "Big Bar," "Beauty Bar"... these places all existed and I got drunk in each one of them in my early 20s!). Listening to LCD Soundsystem and The Knife's "Heartbeat" on repeat, not quite understanding how this city operated but knowing that I was in over my head and that "jaded" was a pretty safe default disposition despite being a 22 year old who spent most of my life in the jejune suburbs. This book made me salivate, between its fruits de mer towers, escarole salads, and blue steaks. I've never had much of a palate (nose?) for coke, but I very much envied the drinks this kid got to drink: the endless Viogniers, Pouilly Fuisses, Sancerres, the Macallan 18s, the negronis and the Côtes du Rhône. My god!But aside from the tantric degustation, I think what I enjoyed most about this book was that the main character was not an ingenue. She's a bit green, sure, but mostly as to New York City. Not as to love, men, success, work, older women, etc. The book doesn't end in the trite way I feared it would, and the drama--albeit hardly representative of what I understand restaurant culture to consist of--is interesting and sprightly plotted. Sure, there are annoying "Sex and the City" influences--at one point, the narrator says "What I learned is that in New York City, there are no rules." Gag--but overall the writing is light, bright, and entertaining. I was an unexpected fan....more

title: The Despot's Apprentice: Donald Trump's Attack on Democracy
author: Klaas, Brian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Brian Klaas is a guy I follow on Twitter. He's also a pundit of sorts, and a professor at the London School of Economics, where my best friend from coBrian Klaas is a guy I follow on Twitter. He's also a pundit of sorts, and a professor at the London School of Economics, where my best friend from college also teaches. I went to visit her in London in January and almost got to meet him, but the timing didn't work out. Regardless, he covers authoritarian rule in the modern age and warns of Trump's worryingly authoritarian inclinations. This book is short but very thorough. Klaas catalogues the characteristics and tendencies of the authoritarian ruler through historical example, and describes the method of the autocrat's actions. For each tendency he notes, he articulates the ways in which Donald Trump has exhibited the behavior. The cumulative effect is disturbing.But ultimately, and for the same reason that we all haven't scrambled for Canada, we know that Trump is not going to achieve autocracy in the United States. And this is for no other reason than that he is an incompetent fool. It's unnerving to note how little resistance a competent, determined Trump would find if he were to try to subvert our form of government, but for the time being we can be glad of small but important favors. And Klaas notes the differences. Although he makes frequent comparisons between Trump and Hitler and Stalin and Amin, he is scrupulous about always pulling back and clarifying that Trump is really not in the same league as these folks, they just exhibit the same tendencies. What Klaas really does a fine job of is enumerating the ways in which our norms are being eroded, and how that primes the system for takeover by a competent Trump ("Trump 2.0") going forward. The Founding Fathers were convinced that democracy was a struggle to maintain, and we have gotten all too complacent with the idea that it can't be subverted, that our core institutions will endure. And none of that can be taken for granted in the age of Trump. The question Klaas asks of us is: will we do enough to make sure that these weaknesses in our system are cured, or is Trump the more disgusting yet ineffectual harbinger of the despot to come?...more

title: Bobby Kennedy: A Raging Spirit
author: Matthews, Chris
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So Bobby Kennedy is pretty much my dad's favorite politician of all time. I knew so little about him other than that his was a mighty potential to havSo Bobby Kennedy is pretty much my dad's favorite politician of all time. I knew so little about him other than that his was a mighty potential to have been lost in a time when America never needed it more. That and he had earned the same two degrees I had from the same two institutions, though in the wrong order. I also took a 12-person Spanish class with his grandson, also named Conor, when I was in law school and the latter in undergrad. He was so quiet and handsome and showed up so infrequently that I thought he was a disenchanted student athlete. Little did I know that he had made international headlines months before by briefly dating Taylor Swift! Man, these Kennedy's really have a way of capturing our attention, don't they?I don't know what I expected to get from this book, but I don't think I found it. RFK was definitely a champion of the little guy, and Matthews does an able job of connecting his runt-of-the-litter role to Bobby's later sympathies. But he was also pretty chummy with Joe McCarthy, and took some anti-Progressive positions in his time. I guess I was just looking for a bit more inspiration, but what could competently slake that thirst in these despairing times?...more

title: The Heart's Invisible Furies
author: Boyne, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Confession time: I'm a grouchy, stolid man whose problems with the construction of this book made me less than enamored of it. It was often cute and sConfession time: I'm a grouchy, stolid man whose problems with the construction of this book made me less than enamored of it. It was often cute and sad, but just as often saccharine, fluffy, poorly constructed, overlong, and wildly unrealistic. I liked the first half of the book much more than the latter, and thought of it as a gay, Irish The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay. But after a certain point, I really began to hate Cyril for his cowardice. And I'm not a monster--I know that I speak from a relative point of privilege. But it's not that I begrudge Cyril his inability to deal with his difficulties. It's that Cyril had a few critical choices between actions he knew would ruin others' lives (and sometimes also his own) and actions that would have taken bravery (but not superhuman quantities of it) but would have been the right thing, and he almost always chose the former. I think, in typically Irish Catholic fashion, we're meant to think that the punishment that Cyril receives--certainly proportional to his wrongdoing--expiates his sins, that they redeem him somehow. But I didn't find this to be the case. I want to read the book about the principled man in the face of adversity, whether he is doomed to misery or finds his reward in the end. I don't care as much about the unreliable coward who is callous with the lives of those who loved him, even if he does get punished for it or finds a form of happiness and satisfaction in the end.And aside from that, the storytelling seemed clumsy at times. So many of the plot lines seemed unnecessary, the attempts at humor felt flimsy, the number and distribution of gay characters felt unrealistic, and my god... the coincidences! I run into my neighbors less often over the years than these farflung people ran into each other, always without trying! Anyway, for most people without hearts of stone this will be a cute and enjoyable book. For my own personal tastes, Kavalier and Clay is better seasoned with repressed queer themes, charm, and world-spanning coincidences....more

title: Thanks, Obama: My Hopey, Changey White House Years
author: Litt, David*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My goodreads friend Julie recommended this to me, and I’m very glad that she did. I’ve belatedly gotten into podcasts—mostly for when I’m pottering arMy goodreads friend Julie recommended this to me, and I’m very glad that she did. I’ve belatedly gotten into podcasts—mostly for when I’m pottering around my room tending to my plants or doing a half-assed weekly clean—and the boys from Crooked Media have been a nice entrée into the genre. The most famous of these are Jon Favreau, Obama’s wunderkind head speech writer, and Jon Lovett, the consensus funniest speech writer in the room. But while these are probably the two most famous speechwriters, the youngest member of the team was the best known to me, a really great guy whom I got to know fairly well toward the end of undergrad: Kyle O’Connor.Kyle gets mentioned 3-4 times in this book, the first time about 100 pages in. Kyle got scooped up by the Obama team while we were still in college, when his candidacy seemed like a longshot and where a junior speechwriting gig was probably a practical stepping stone rather than a career-altering decision. But we all know how unexpected and whirlwind the Obama 2008 campaign was. Kyle was busy during those years and we didn’t keep in the best of touch, but he gave us insights into this unknowable life through occasional emails and Instagrams from Air Force One.Kyle is mentioned in the book really only as the person positioned right above the book’s author in terms of the hierarchy of speechwriters. He’s also probably not mentioned because—though certainly interpersonally funny—his main assets are probably earnestness, clarity of thought, ability to communicate effectively. The closest I came to influencing political speechcraft was when I found myself on an email chain started by Kyle, soliciting our feedback on how to address the nation in the 2011 State of the Union address. Kyle asked about 5-6 of us for our thoughts on how to address gridlock. At the time, I was apoplectic over the Republicans’ obstructionism and equally upset with Obama’s very patient, arguably overindulgent extension of good will to them and willingness to compromise. We all know how these overtures were rewarded, but if there’s one thing this book really reveals between the slapstick, it’s what a good, fine man and politician President Obama was. Aside from all of the burdens he had to carry as the first Black president, he was also uncommonly deferential, optimistic, and decent toward a Republican party seemingly animated by nothing so universal as simmering racial resentment. We all know the outcome, and history will tell whether decency and proper procedure will once again come to define our federal politics (though I’m not very optimistic). But reading this memoir in the midst of the Trump presidency, characterized by white victimhood, racist and xenophobic dog whistles, hollow braggadocio, inability to accept blame or responsibility, opaqueness of process, and eagerness to take credit for every positive while shirking or blaming others for every liability, I am thankful that we had eight years under a president who cared about good government and operated in good faith. My response to Kyle in that email was that we should lay the blame for the economic miseries of the population on the Republicans, who had control of congress and thereby had far more control over the economy than did the president, who does not enact laws. In hindsight, I understand just how inappropriate this suggestion was; not only does the American public not really seem to understand that the president doesn’t control the economy, and can only do so to the extent Congress is willing to cooperate with him, but it would have been off-message in the extreme. And none of this is to say that Republicans deserve cooperation or the benefit of the doubt. But if we are presently witnessing the conflagration of American democracy, history will bear witness to who brought a fire extinguisher and who brought the gasoline. We very recently had a man in the Oval Office whose decency and good faith were inexhaustible, and we currently have a man whose piggishness, immaturity, and ineptitude defy credulity. May our next choice reflect the temperament of the person we feel better represents us as a people, and may President Obama’s legacy counsel us to make the wiser choice.ETA: I almost forgot to mention what an asshole Harvey Weinstein comes across as in this book, and that's without him even sexually coercing the author! Litt must feel quite vindicated and good riddance to that monster....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Whew, this was a corker! Eileen is a filthy young woman without much coherent personality who kind of just exists in the margins of a world where peopWhew, this was a corker! Eileen is a filthy young woman without much coherent personality who kind of just exists in the margins of a world where people are either too stupid or too depleted to notice her. When I say I find her disgusting, I don't mean to say that reading this book turned my stomach--on the contrary, it was enthralling--but that if I met someone who approximated Eileen Dunlop in real life I would have the strong urge to compulsively wash my hands after having done so. And I'm a person who more often than not eats a meal after riding the subway having forgotten to wash up. Eileen just radiated staleness, disrepair, and degeneration in a way I haven't really felt projected as completely outside of Kafka's "Metamorphosis." There were apertures of humanity in there, but they didn't make a whole lot of sense; more anomaly than anything else, and were few and far between. A wholly engrossing if unrealistic character.And man, what a fine writer Moshfegh is. I cannot wait to read more of what she's got....more

title: But What If We're Wrong? Thinking About the Present As If It Were the Past
author: Klosterman, Chuck
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So this was an interesting gimmick: thinking about our present society and beliefs from a hypothesized future vantage. It's obviously a fool's errand So this was an interesting gimmick: thinking about our present society and beliefs from a hypothesized future vantage. It's obviously a fool's errand to try to look at all that we "know" at present and wonder what of it will eventually be dismissed as naive or ill-informed (the author posits our present view on gravity, of all things!), but Klosterman is not after Nostradomus' mantle, and instead wants us to evaluate how confident we are in our present knowledge and why. So, as I said, it's an interesting thing to consider. I fear (and Klosterman makes a note of this) that encouraging this could lead to the amplification of obviously harmful tendencies, such as the politically motivated efforts to discredit the science that demonstrates that anthropocentric climate change is occurring. But there is probably so much truth that we miss out on because some authority has declared something "known" and there are strong taboos against questioning whatever the knowledge is. Moreover, we have in common with probably every single previous generation the smug belief that we have cornered Truth to the greatest degree and that there might be nothing left to be figured out. I think the point of the book is one worth embracing: assume that everything we "know" could be true but accept that nearly everything is up for debate or in need of clarification....more

author: Perrotta, Tom
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved "The Leftovers." Loved it. Not the book, mind you. Or maybe the book... I'm not sure because I haven't read it. But I probably would have likeI loved "The Leftovers." Loved it. Not the book, mind you. Or maybe the book... I'm not sure because I haven't read it. But I probably would have liked it. But the TV show is just about the most wonderful meditation on the agnostic idea that we're all we're here for, and none of us is entitled to (or should be expecting) an explanation for all of the weird, unfair, inexplicable, and numinous phenomena comprising our lives. You should really watch if you haven't already.Tom Perrotta wrote "The Leftovers" and consulted on the production of the show throughout its run. Before that he studied under Tobias Wolff, and so it's no surprise that he writes intimate, funny, quirky stories of pretty regular people. And this book, if we're being honest (and succinct) is a book about a group of people much discussed but rarely the focus of literature in our modern society: the MILF. Our main character is a MILF struggling with empty nest syndrome and reclaiming her sexuality following a life devoted to others. It's a fun read and Perrotta has a surprisingly light touch.There's also a bunch of transgender stuff, struggles with addiction, explorations of toxic masculinity. It felt a bit flat toward the end but the man can tell a story pretty well....more

title: Never Let Me Go
author: Ishiguro, Kazuo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So I didn't like this nearly so much as I did "Remains of the Day." They were both equally British, and if there were a Nobel prize for British-est liSo I didn't like this nearly so much as I did "Remains of the Day." They were both equally British, and if there were a Nobel prize for British-est living author, I think Ishiguro would have been recognized long ago. But the sense of tempo and mastery of cadence that makes "Remains" so amazing made this feel like tantric reading. So much adumbration! So little revelation! Get on with it!The book raises a ton of moral quandaries--our book club discussion was unusually vigorous--but I didn't really find this book enjoyable at all. It was very bleak, the characters were sympathetic but not especially likable, and action almost nonexistent. Really the biggest tip of the hat, I think, should go to Ishiguro for using a biomedical ethics framework as a metaphor to explore the monstrosities that we tolerate, even normalize, in the name of "Well, what else could we do?" and "There's no better way" when the real answer is hardly ever that simple or exculpatory: Do we need to eat meat, destroy the environment, or earn millions of dollars per year while we soak the poor? Must we tolerate such vast disparities in wealth, health, education, and opportunity? Should we just shrug off the scourges of rape, sexual assault, misogyny, homophobia, transphobia? Bar refugees? Rationalize racism? Must people of color serve as pincushions for police bullets? Are we comfortable with stigmatizing disabilities? Are we on board with ignoring genocides if they suit our leaders' geopolitical interests? "Wouldn't we rebel and fight back if we lived in such an unjust and cruel world?"...more

title: Stamped from the Beginning: The Definitive History of Racist Ideas in America
author: Kendi, Ibram X.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ibram Kendi's monograph on racism is an impressive compendium of history and analysis stretching from the time when racism and capitalism co-evolved dIbram Kendi's monograph on racism is an impressive compendium of history and analysis stretching from the time when racism and capitalism co-evolved during the Age of (European) Exploration all the way to the present. Kendi takes a novel approach to classifying the actions, thoughts, and actors across these generations, classifying them as segregationist/racist (the races ought and must be kept apart, as they are different), assimilationist (people fundamentally differ by race, but can learn from and aid each other if done properly and at the right pace), and antiracist (all people are created equal and race and anything attributed thereto is a social fabrication). These concepts are simple to deploy and Kendi does so, establishing an elaborate taxonomy of the past half millennium that skews far more so to the segregationist and assimilationist than to the antiracist. It's dizzying reading figures such as W.E.B. DuBois, Martin Luther King, Jr., and Barack Obama described as opportunistic assimilationists or even racists, but you can't really argue with Kendi's method, even if you dispute the ambit of any particular classification. He is remarkably consistent and unsparing, reserving unalloyed praise for individuals such as Malcolm X, Sojourner Truth, and other folks whom history has predictably buried because of the radicalism of their embrace of an idea that has still not gained due purchase. The book ends with the election of Barack Obama, with its ecstatically myopic declarations of the end of racism and a post-racial America. You could have been forgiven for gleefully declaring this on Election Night 2008, but I don't think anyone who knew much about race and lacked an ulterior motive was seriously declaring it thereafter. Worse yet--even knowing the depths of and attachments to racism in this country, no one could have predicted the mess we'd have made of it only a decade hence, when ventilation of racist thoughts is practically a requirement for a Republican to win a primary.So where does Kendi fit into this country ruled by rockribbed racists and their toxic and intractable ideologies? I think we are meant to realize that the litany of assimilationist failures, well-meaning and "progressive" as they often were, were nevertheless half measures that are never going to cut it. To understand racism is to understand that humans are all fundamentally equal across all spectra he associate with race--skin color, hair texture, the shape of our features, the sizes of our skulls, our weight and height, how hairy we are, etc. etc. Yet one must also acknowledge that vast inequality has erupted based on conglomerations of these factors that we call race. And finally, we have to understand that those inequalities are in large part the direct and indirect result of the policies, power dynamics, colonialism, enslavement, plunder, disregard, paternalism, disenfranchisement, and imprisonment of certain groups to benefit other groups. To be antiracist, one must believe that the power dynamics that have distorted our society (and all others) are unnatural and would not have occurred in any remotely recognizable way absent the weaponization of racism. And, perhaps most importantly, one must be committed to the incredibly drastic, politically impossible measures one must support in order to even attempt to achieve equality at some future point. ...more

I confess to being annoyed at first because of the poetic sensibilities--it felt like an attempt at depth that came across as clumsy and poorly thought out. But as the story evolved it grew on me. review: So I really enjoyed this book, and I can't really figure out why. It's not profound in any way, and a lot of it even takes the form of a shopworn caseSo I really enjoyed this book, and I can't really figure out why. It's not profound in any way, and a lot of it even takes the form of a shopworn case study, well told. But the best reasoning I can come up with was that it was flattering to me...!Not because I'm particularly original--I'm an attorney, after all--but because it actually lauded a certain kind of restraint that I believe I'm possessed of. The book did not exhort throwing out all conventions, but rather to be sensible and accept restraints and to discard conventional thinking within them. Given that I'm a lawyer, the field whose whole "thing" is adhering to convention, I must be either a masochist or highly deluded about the degree to which the above describes my mien. But it at least describes how I think I operate when thinking about social and legal issues, or that I aspire to. ...more

review: A solid 3.5 stars for this one. Kevin Wilson is a young author, and he's got some chops. This was an interesting idea for a book, and was executed reaA solid 3.5 stars for this one. Kevin Wilson is a young author, and he's got some chops. This was an interesting idea for a book, and was executed reasonably well enough: an enigmatic billionaire tries to fund a fully immersive group-living experiment where nine couples and a single mother raise their children together, hopefully to beneficial effect, guided and monitored by a wunderkind doctor. The doctor, the single mom, and her son are the only two distinguishable characters in the text, with the other nine children, their eighteen parents, and the other characters were either mostly interchangeable or too evanescent to merit mention. The story grapples ably with themes of love, loss, sharing, and the ownership aspect of family and intimate relationships. For the most part, it felt like a mashup of the Blithedale Romance and Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory, and made for light, quick consumption....more

title: White Rage: The Unspoken Truth of Our Racial Divide
author: Anderson, Carol
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's a true-enough trope of propaganda that the best way to nullify any anticipated criticism of oneself or one's ideology is to preempt it by levelinIt's a true-enough trope of propaganda that the best way to nullify any anticipated criticism of oneself or one's ideology is to preempt it by leveling it at the opponent most likely to bring it. I think of this often when (mostly white) conservatives accuse liberals and those on the left of being whiny "snowflakes" because we bridle at such light-hearted fun as, say, labeling entire races of people as rapists and killers, or making jokes about mass military slaughter. These people laugh off the indignation, considering us fragile and overwrought and even fun to provoke, selling mugs commemorating the pride they take in our umbrage. But of course these are the same people who have conniptions over NFL players kneeling during national anthems, who froth at the mouth when the "Christ" in "Christmas" is subbed out for the more economical "X," and invest themselves deeply in peddling alternate histories in which Columbus and whole legions of Confederate war dead are rehabilitated as good, heroic people deserving of ennoblement in statuary guilty of, if anything, a few peccadilloes that we would do best to forget because, after all, didn't Hillary Clinton once use a private email server?This book explores the antecedents of these hypocrites in all their plenitude throughout history. Abolition without proper Reconstruction left an uneducated, unmoneyed class of people severely handicapped in their quest for equality, and visibly identifiable as an inferior group susceptible to coercion. Throughout the post-war period ersatz slavery persisted, and for every inch of progress that people of color wrested from the white hegemony, racial resentment emerged in fierce counterpoise.This is the story that "White Rage" tells--how it's never enough for people of color in the United States to achieve, against insurmountable odds, the slightest bit of advancement on their own; they also must be humbled, taught their place, taken down a peg--often with violence, degradation, and when all that fails--legal and bureaucratic strictures that undercut the progress so improbably attained. The Election of Barack Obama as the first Black president, being the most visible and perhaps unlikely of achievements, has catalyzed the worst of this reactionism, and we're all living through the aftershocks in the most disgusting and openly white supremacist of administrations in a century. But Carol Anderson ends on a high note, asking us to change our society to reject white supremacy and to inaugurate a better polity. May we finally rise to the challenge!...more

title: The Crisis of the Middle-Class Constitution: Why Economic Inequality Threatens Our Republic
author: Sitaraman, Ganesh
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm very glad that this man is an advisor to Senator Warren.Employing a panoramic view of history, Sitaraman analyzes how previous successful states/eI'm very glad that this man is an advisor to Senator Warren.Employing a panoramic view of history, Sitaraman analyzes how previous successful states/empires defined the rights of various classes, and how the American experiment was very much propounded in a land of economic parity, and that the Founders intended/assumed that it would stay that way. Much of the stability required for checks and balances requires a predominant buffer class that can mediate between the rapaciousness of the upper classes and the jealousies of the lower. This sounds all well and good, but it seems that if the importance of a strong middle class were so foregrounded in the minds of the Founders, they would have enshrined it in the text of the Constitution in some way, or would at least have provided for stronger mechanisms for sustaining it. Ultimately, I find Sitaraman's evidence for his central premise wanting. Much of it is presumed (e.g., the Founders were erudite students of political history and must have appreciated the peril of allowing an upper class or lower class predominate), or inferred (e.g. the lack of a class requirement for the House-of-Lords-manque U.S. Senate indicates our refusal to empower the upper classes). Also, for all of his impressive grasp of American political and legal history, Sitaraman's conclusion about the incompatibility between the Founders' vision and class inequality of political power doesn't exactly hold. After all, this current Gilded Age is not the first our country has suffered through, nor is the Constitution so allergic to massive disparities in wealth that it has been sundered while suffering them.I would probably give this 3.5 stars, though. Like I said, the author's grasp of legal and political history, particularly of the American type, is impressive. Plus Sitaraman offers intriguing solutions for ensuring that disfavored classes have a say in governance: lottery elections, tribunates, etc. It is to be expected that the gleam of the Founders' vision is dulled in the light of dimmer days, but these are the books we should be reading to understand how we might solve the problems they neither anticipated nor adequately shielded us from....more

review: Read this for my "bro" book club. We typically sit around eating steaks and drinking beers and reading short, masculine, violent, and dark novels (I tRead this for my "bro" book club. We typically sit around eating steaks and drinking beers and reading short, masculine, violent, and dark novels (I think our track record is The North Water, Jesus' Son, and The Road). Or at least this is our ambition because we're all effete, urban nebbishes who, when gathered, look like we're hosting the world's most esoteric and tedious podcast, and after about 30-45 minutes we've just devolved into a long pun-off or Scheherazade-esque recounting of the inside jokes of the last decade. Anyway, one of our group read this and sent the word out to the rest. Having read and loved his "Stoner," I was definitely intrigued. Given the description above, the main character is someone we could probably have related to best: over-educated city-types who have no business maintaining an interest in the dirty, gritty exploits that national lore has romanticized. Mr. Andrews hails from Boston, the son of a Unitarian minister and Harvard drop out with somewhat less luck and lucre than the more famous of his counterparts, Mr. Gates and Mr. Zuckerberg. He contracts with a grasping bunch of hardscrabble types and they go off on a wild, ill-fated journey whose consequences are adumbrated but still, difficult to swallow. Williams is an incredible writer--I was half asleep for this and during the "thirst" sequence I woke up from my stupor to quench my thirst, the rendering was so exquisite--but I think this paled in comparison to "Stoner," which is really one of the best books I've read in recent years. I do tend to go in for the quiet, interpersonal dramas over the rollicking, butch epics, and this was definitely good, but not really anything I'd recommend except if prompted for the specific genre. Still, it makes me terribly excited for "Augustus."...more

title: Antifa: The Anti-Fascist Handbook
author: Bray, Mark
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I first picked this up, this was my "Eat, Pray, Love" on the subway: what do the two have in common, you ask? Well what better way to get your grWhen I first picked this up, this was my "Eat, Pray, Love" on the subway: what do the two have in common, you ask? Well what better way to get your groove back than frolicking through India and Europe giving fascists whatfor! Just kidding. They do not (I assume) have anything in common; rather, I felt some embarrassment about being seen reading it on the subway, and so would contort my hands in such a way that it would be near impossible for anyone to read the cover. Partially this is because the "movement" has been discredited as some sort of left-wing false equivalent of the pallid, amoral, virginal, keyboard-warriors of alt-right. But mostly because I had an image of antifa as black-clad paramilitants, spoiling for bloodshed and this contrasted sharply with the jaunty scarves and light, lambswool sweaters I've been wearing during this uncommonly balmy winter we've been having. For the most part the shame was directed from without--liberal colleagues would snicker, raise eyebrows, roll eyes, etc., the typical dismissiveness that the center-left trains toward the left. And perhaps some of you reading this feel the same way. But I think this really just goes to show how successful conservative voices are at manipulating narratives to bestow false equivalencies.Part of it also owes to the left's ineptitude when it comes to branding: as I'm sure you all know, "Antifa" stands for "anti-fascism." This is a pretty reasonable position to take, especially given the previous century of violence kindled in fascist conflagrations. But I don't think the general public really does know that, and so the group needlessly forfeits its crucial historical legacy. When I reserved this book I personally was most interested in the "no platforming" issue. Perhaps it's my time spent working for the ACLU, but I'd always taken the Millian/Jeffersonian approach to free speech: any idea should be tolerated and allowed to live or die on its own merits. I would tell people that it's the one thing the United States does better than other countries, and our gift to the world. Post-Charlottesville I really had to reevaluate this position, and I remember having a conversation about the incompatibility between First Amendment rights and Second Amendment rights the day before the ACLU changed its position to no longer represent free speech claims if the claimants were armed (I support their change of heart, despite supporting strong free speech rights). Additionally, we have to wonder whether free speech principles require a platform for ideas that have been thoroughly debunked already, which raises the question of whether idiots such as Milo Yiannopoulos are owed one for what amounts to Flat Earth "ideas" about women, trans people, immigrants, Muslims, etc.But where does that leave private assembly? The idea of free speech under the First Amendment tends to be poorly understood by the public; in reality, it only applies to government censorship, which is why there's no Constitutional issue when some celebrity says something idiotic and then the public, exercising its speech through its dollars, decides to boycott that product until the celebrity bonehead endorser is dropped from the sponsorship deal. So this is why there is no issue when a private university disinvites someone purely on the content of their speech, or why fascists are free to meet in their own homes and discuss the most vile ideas, organizing anything they want short of open insurrection. When we talk about those types of free speech, we are talking about the "value" of free speech, which is one of many liberal values that we all (or almost all) claim to cherish. But because there is no legal/Constitutional component, this value merely rests in equipoise with other liberal values, such as: the importance of voting and representation, welcoming of diversity, the equality of all people, representation by the people, safety and ability to earn a living, etc. These are things that fascists oppose for all but a minority of the population. And so fascist ideas will always exist where there is free speech, even as free speech will always be threatened to the extent that fascist ideas are not kept in check in the theoretical world. Hence: antifa. The question of how much non-violent intervention (glitter bombing, throwing ballbearings upon march routes, drowning out fascist messaging with song, threatening the job security of fascists, etc.), coercion, doxxing, and violence is necessary, and in what proportions, is the thorny one. As an important caveat, it is critical to mention that liberal values and governmental failsafes utterly failed to prevent fascism before, and so the idea that the government or people's good will should save us is painfully naive. But the gnashing of teeth comes about because we worry, rightly, over the slippery slope when we (again rightly) seek to quell fascist rhetoric and action. And here I think is the best thing I took away from the book: not a complete, absolutist prohibition on violence, not an exact formula for conquering fascism, but rather one historical truth, which is that antifa exists only as a reaction to creeping fascism. It has never taken over a government, and it has never mushroomed into a PC police state. And just as we don't wring our hands and decide not to fight forest fires because oh-my-god-what-if-it-gets-out-of-control-and-we-end-up-with-firefighters-putting-out-our-campfires, we have no reason to believe that antifa poses any threat outside of the immediate metastasis of fascism that it forms in reaction to.So please read this book. The first half is somewhat dry history, but the second is practical, interesting, and thought-provoking. And for the love of god educate and push back on those, especially on the left, who have a knee-jerk skepticism about this complex and important phenomenon, because we live in precarious times....more

review: Nell Zink! Please write more! I loved this book. As others have said, it's very smart. Weird, but smart. Zink hints at all sort of Southern taboos andNell Zink! Please write more! I loved this book. As others have said, it's very smart. Weird, but smart. Zink hints at all sort of Southern taboos and secrets in this short novel, but her masterful blending of the idiosyncrasies of the worlds of both the tony and peckerwood South--how charming that various characters opine that rabbit fur coats hardly connote wealth and that "If you left white people alone, they would put crawfish in a blender" in the same novel!--perhaps suggests a mixed economic heritage of her own. Although the gender and sexuality issues often seem improbable (and what is it with straight female authors thinking it's fine to conflate homosexuality with pederasty? I'm looking at you, Hanya Yanagihara!), the dialogue is fascinating and the story ceaselessly engrossing, generating an impressive plot over a short number of pages.And there's a whole part about Woodberry Forrest and UVA! And they're pitch perfect. Brava, Nell Zink. I'm very impressed by this author....more

Davis is a woman who has been persecuted and demonized throughout her entire adult life, and who has used her unique experiences to forge a sharp, incisive political vision for a better world. She resists the characterizations that others put on her and pushes her interlocutors to understand the folly of their divisions as well as the unseen sources of the strength that lies in their unity. I think I would have liked this better if she distilled her ideas into a narrative/monograph, but overall an important read....more

review: I read this for a book club, and it started out pretty well. This book is comprised of three interlinking stories--one a seeming roman-a-clef whose maI read this for a book club, and it started out pretty well. This book is comprised of three interlinking stories--one a seeming roman-a-clef whose main character is a thinly veiled cipher of the author, a wealthy and failed homosexual straddling the Middle East and America; a fantastical story of jinni and mystical oases; and a semi-historical account of some guy named Baybars.I got all English 101 on this book at first, thinking that there must have been a reason for the imbrication. Why have three competent stories chopped into tiny pieces and shuffled around, if not to draw parallels and establish analogues? But as the plot plodded on, I grew less and less confident that these parallels would emerge. The conversation at the convening of the book club revealed similar frustrations and no greater insight into why the book was written this way. Some of this has influenced my two-star rating...I guess what this book did well was establish themes subtly. The inverse proportionality of family closeness with wealth; the ways in which homosexuality is signaled an tolerated in non-Western societies; the complicated dynamics that bind and rend families. I just wish it had been a bit more coherent!...more

title: The Blood of Emmett Till
author: Tyson, Timothy B.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I finished reading this documentary of unnecessary hate killing as another unfolded. As I absorbed the comments and tweets talking about how we forfeiI finished reading this documentary of unnecessary hate killing as another unfolded. As I absorbed the comments and tweets talking about how we forfeited on the gun control debate after Sandy Hook, I couldn't help but wonder whether we might be living in a very different world if one of those grieving parents had followed the lead of Emmett's mother, Mamie Till.Confronted anew by a murderous shooting spree, this country is grappling with questions that are at once horrific and yet somehow hoary. Increasingly, the commentariat vents its frustration with the rote unfolding of events in the wake of heinous gun violence: anti-gun outrage, followed by pro-gun policing of timing and tone, before the wholly depressing and inevitable failure of not only action but resolve amongst our elected politicians, who invariably respond by offering “thoughts and prayers,” differing from each other only over whether they will accept the patronage of the NRA or merely abide its corrosive influence on our society. Commentators and politicians have their constituencies, and they message accordingly; the pitch and amplitude of their rhetoric is calibrated to the rest of us, the many without a platform or a Senate vote who have only our own consciences and communities to lobby, the measure of our agony and outrage as the only limits on what we can push for. And so the failure to make meaningful inroads to gun control brings up an uncomfortable question: if we are truly shocked by these massacres, and if we are, as we say, a truly decent people—why does change never come?The simple answer is that interest groups such as the NRA have a stranglehold on our political process. Until politicians show a modicum of spine, all political capital will go toward defeating absurd pro-gun laws, with no hope of affirmative gun control legislation on the horizon, regardless of the coalitions running the branches of government going forward. And it is tempting to credit these responses, because what else could explain the vast chasms between what even Republican voters want and what our legislative bodies do when it comes to supporting common sense gun-control laws?To concede that the horror we express at these atrocities and the consensus we have reached as a society are not sufficient to override the influence of the NRA is therefore tempting. But to resign oneself to such outlooks is to admit that there are intractable problems in this country, and the heroism and grace displayed by Mamie Till—mother of Emmett Till, the fourteen-year old African American boy beaten, mutilated, murdered, and desecrated for a petty solecism against a white woman in Jim Crow Mississippi—in the wake of her child’s lynching cautions against such defeatism. Since perhaps the Civil War, if there’s ever been a more necessary but quixotic movement, it’s been the movement for Civil Rights for people of color in the United States. Hindsight gives us a bias toward remembering these events as well choreographed by the brilliant women and men who coordinated much of the marquee events of the Civil Rights Movement, but at least one momentous decision was made outside of this machinery: the courageous decision of Mamie Till to show the world what racism and white supremacy had done to her child, and to go far and wide to ensure that anyone who would listen would never have the chance to forget his humanity. If gun violence seems a hopelessly intractable problem in the United States in the current day and age, try to imagine (or remember) what the struggle for civil rights looked like in 1955. As Timothy B. Tyson notes in his new book, “The Blood of Emmett Till,” “Indifference to black lives did not begin in the twenty-first century. Nor was Mississippi entirely a foreign country to the rest of America in the 1950s. It simply did not matter to most white Americans what happened to black Mississippians; they did not know and did not want to know, and routine terrorism did not dent that indifference until the Emmett Till case.” Lynchings, wholesale terrorism, denial of suffrage, and grossly unequal status for Blacks throughout the country (but especially in the South) were not at all unknown to white Americans in the 1950s, but imagine the plentitude of rich excuses available to the typical, decent white American at that time for not agitating for the advent of civil rights. As Tyson tells it, It was only when Mamie Till decided to publish the indescribably brutalized corpse of her young son that the nation was forced to take part in a battle for its soul. That image—which is seared into the memory of anyone who has ever beheld it—not only forced White America to acknowledge its malign neglect toward people of color, as Tyson tells it, it also galvanized a legion of Black Americans, informing everything from Rosa Parks’ refusal to give up her seat on a bus to contemporary protests of police brutality and indifference toward black lives. One reason why there seems to be a paradoxical and unsettling lack of proportionality between the number of victims killed and the willingness to act is that we can’t fathom the loss when the numbers rise. At first, this seems crass, but it is fully consistent with what we know from experience: 20 (Sandy Hook) homicides is an unforgiveable number, and so is 13 (Columbine), but they barely register in comparison with 11,622 and 10,828, the number of gun homicides in the United States in the years when those massacres occurred, respectively. Without serious intervention, these individual “record-breaker” numbers and yearly aggregates are virtually certain to increase, and it is also a near certainty that we will disclaim them as inhuman, beneath us, badly in need of addressing, and a scourge on a compassionate republic. But if nothing ever changes, then of what use is our indignation?Without personalization of tragedy, without empathy, without searing images that reveal the wages of our inaction, we actively abet these 59s and 49s merging into the five-figure homicide rates. This will require heroism, but an appetite for this grace has already been shown. Individuals in the style of Mamie Till, such as Nardyne Jeffries (https://www.thetrace.org/2015/10/guns...) and Jessica Ghawi (http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-wa...) have already begun this important effort, but it is time that the media stopped witnessing these tragedies and did their part to confront them by showcasing the horror—emotional and physical—wrought by a network of gun control laws that has killed literally millions through its sheer manipulability and inadequacy. If the media were to focus on everyday gun homicides with a fraction of the zeal that they reserve for non-white terrorism, and if the victims were given a platform from which to share their accounts, this battle might be in far different shape.Obviously the Civil Rights Movement is far from over, and so personalizing and rendering empathetic the everyday victims of gun violence is no panacea. But no one can deny that Mamie Till’s speeches and her decision to have an open-casket funeral were galvanizing, important events for a civil rights movement that at least held the promise of eventual equality for people of color in this country. When Mamie Till made the decision to have an open-casket funeral, she denied the rest of the country and the world the opportunity to ignore him, to think that maybe his conduct could have merited his treatment, that Emmett’s was a forgettable life; her words were: “Let the people see what they did to my boy.” If we are indeed a decent nation, we need to be confronted by the lives that some consider to be the price of our gun culture. The direction that we take will show whether these are claims of truth or hollow aspirations....more

title: Racecraft: The Soul of Inequality in American Life
author: Fields, Karen E.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a powerful and highly intelligent exploration of the idea that racecraft is no more legitimate than witchcraft, and that the racism that folloThis is a powerful and highly intelligent exploration of the idea that racecraft is no more legitimate than witchcraft, and that the racism that follows from it is no more natural or explicable than the development of superstitions and punishments that flowed from centuries of adamant belief in witchcraft. It's a helpful heuristic--witchcraft makes sense to a group of people in search of explanations for complex, inexplicable phenomena. Witchcraft is rife with contradictions, completely fabricated justifications, and harmful consequences, and once removed from its orbit, we see how utterly silly the belief therein so clearly was. But if we know that race is a fiction, then why do we still cling to, legitimate, and accept the myriad contradictions, poisons, and atavisms that flow therefrom through the discredited concepts of "race" and "racism"? This book probably posed more questions than answers, and it definitely made me question whether seeing injustice through a racial lens is productive or regressive over the long run. ...more

review: I'd never read any of Sapolsky before, so I can't report a proper comparison, but this book on cognition and behavior seems to have been inspired by tI'd never read any of Sapolsky before, so I can't report a proper comparison, but this book on cognition and behavior seems to have been inspired by the successes of Yuval Noah Harari. Like Harari's works, "Behave" bites off far more than the uninitiated could ever hope to chew on his or her own and distills it to its essence, rendering esoterica accessible for dilettantes such as yours truly.Perhaps because of the nature of the material he covers, Sapolsky employs a more scientific argot than typically seen in this panoramic genre. But overall, he does his best to cover a truly impressive range of psychological phenomena, experiments, studies, data sets, etc. It's difficult to isolate an area or topic that I found most compelling, chiefly because each tidbit seemed to suggest so much about who we are as a species and why we behave as we do. But I can't totally suppress the idea of buying a physical copy of this and covering the political perception chapters with marginalia in advance of a quest to wrest cognitive biases from the manipulators on the right. Someday, maybe....more

title: Authority        (Southern Reach, #2)
author: VanderMeer, Jeff*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Normally I eat pretty healthy. Not really because I possess any special piety, but because my body just doesn’t feel that great when I don’t eat well.Normally I eat pretty healthy. Not really because I possess any special piety, but because my body just doesn’t feel that great when I don’t eat well. I still eat as much meat and fat as I want, but I grow lethargic without veggies, and soda makes me feel worn out, and anything processed just doesn’t taste great to me, so it works out to be a pretty great deal where I can eat what I want and stay healthy. But over the past two weeks, my local grocery store has had this annoying deal. They are charging a measly $5 for 1.9lbs of sour patch kids. And not just any sour patch kids—it’s the bag with the blue guys in it! I bought one bag and thought, naively, “Oh, this will be a nice thing to have at my work desk, so others can come by for a nice, sweet treat.” Well, so much for that. After a period of several stressful days compounded by hunger because I couldn’t really escape the orbit of my desk, I made it through the entire bag, less a few handfuls for coworkers nearby. The first couple of bites are great, but after a while I really just return because it’s there, and my body remembers being satisfied by it, but as I shovel more handfuls of sour-coated, homunculus-shaped gelatin down my gullet, I do it knowing that I’m not really being satisfied. In fact, overall I think the effect might be a small net negative.And such is the work of Jeff VanderMeer, I am starting to realize. Both of his first two entries in this trilogy (and to a lesser extent, “Borne,” his unrelated but thematically similar newest book) have started out with such promise. About halfway through, you realize that the initial high is illusory, but that doesn’t really stop you. You keep going in, even as it becomes totally clear that each book is going to leave more intriguing topics broached but not satisfactorily addressed. It’s not quite in “Lost” territory yet, but for all intents and purposes it can be properly compared thereto.I’m not really a “sunk cost” fallacy guy, so I wouldn’t have any qualms about not finishing this if I truly didn’t like it. The thing is, it’s all pleasant and alluring enough, even if you know you won’t be satisfied when the end comes. And for the same reason that when I saw that the sale was still on, I picked up a second 1.9 lb bag (do not judge me so harshly, dear reader, for I am too weak and riddled with cavities to bear the shame!) and then proceeded to demolish it in less than a week, I’m sure it’s only a matter of time before I pick up the third installment in this series and piggishly make my way through that as well. I’ll let you know if I am pleasantly surprised!...more

The latter half I wasn't as enthralled by; they featured more reflection on the idea that life is about quality, not quantity, but the stories seemed less moored in the premise and less compelling on their own merits.But I think most people would like this book, especially those who enjoy family sagas and Jewish-bygone-NYC stories....more
