title: The Reactionary Mind: Conservatism from Edmund Burke to Sarah Palin
author: Robin, Corey
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Robin starts out this second book of his by addressing a complaint about an earlier version (whose scope was "Edmund Burke to Sarah Palin" rather thanRobin starts out this second book of his by addressing a complaint about an earlier version (whose scope was "Edmund Burke to Sarah Palin" rather than "... to Donald Trump" . . . one shutters to think what the next edition might be entitled!). Apparently it was too much of an excursus, a collection of essays than a cogent narrative. I haven't read the original version; I can't imagine it changed that much, though analysis of how much our country appears to have changed since Sarah Palin was en vogue could suggest otherwise. But at least compared with "Fear," I think he's achieved his object. It does wade tediously into the philosophies of Burke and Locke, et al., but deals less with esoterica than did "Fear," for which I was grateful. The final third of the book is what we came for--the analysis of the conservative mind, from Buckley and Goldwater through to Reagan, the Bushes, and Trump. At base there is a fundamental aversion to peace and tranquility; threats are perceived to greater degree by the conservative mind, and so remaining in stasis--or more likely progressing, though on metrics like aesthetics or social justice that don't hold valence for conservatives--is seen as decline. The remedy for this decline is the exercise of power, the stoking of insecurities and fears, and the gestures to a mythic past when effeminate and foreign-looking others were kept at bay or under heel. Fascinating profile, but I still like his essays more!...more

title: The End of Eddy
author: Louis, Édouard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Whew, this was a tough one. And not really what I was expecting. I had been preparing myself for a book about bullying and tortured adolescence. CertaWhew, this was a tough one. And not really what I was expecting. I had been preparing myself for a book about bullying and tortured adolescence. Certainly that's a primary motif, but I was impressed and unprepared for the other heavy themes that pervade this work: extreme white poverty in a non-American "First World" setting, and its perilous admixture with toxic masculinity. "The End of Eddy" chronicles the disturbing, violent, and neglected upbringing of its author, a young man from Picardy, in the northeast of France. In a town where obesity is prized, insulation and sanitation are rare, poverty spans generations and governs upward mobility, and alcoholism catalyzes all sorts of domestic abuses and wanton violence, our narrator relates his troubled place among it all, where he had to navigate the anti-intellectual and heteromasculine currents that rocked against his nature. His sexual orientation is the source of his torture--he is bullied, he is ostracized, he loathes himself, and his family show disappointment and confusion about his proclivities--but is ultimately the source of his salvation, as it was a break that allowed him to reject all of the other harmful tendencies that his family and his community embraced, either through necessity, justification, or exhaustion, as a result of the poverty in which they were mired.Those of us on the American left often idealize Europe for the successes of their socialized states, for the safety net they have cultivated for the betterment of their societies. Obviously every net has holes, but it seems beyond debate that the wealthy democracies of Europe, Oceania and Canada have deliberately and successfully cultivated much stronger and comprehensive safety nets than we have here. And this being a historical phenomenon, poverty is more familiar to us, a common feature of our national narrative. But when I think of French poverty and misery I think of Les Miserables. Understandably this omits a long portion of the interim history, during much of which the average Frenchman was probably much worse off than the average American. Yet in the modern era, the positions seem to have been emphatically reversed. So to witness a French community infested with the same pathologies that inhabit the poor white communities of this country--where education is not seen as a good in and of itself nor as a way to escape poverty; where homophobia and misogyny are used to shore up the masculinity that poverty has etiolated; where xenophobia and racism are used to paper over one's own community's sins and to scapegoat the lack of economic opportunity; where alcoholism and poor health are predictable symptoms of penury--was jarring, to say the least. And so although I heard about this book through gay friends and it is usually pitched as a gay book (and the s on the back cover are all by famous gay authors), it seems far more accurately to be an ethnography of poverty and metastatic masculinity in a context that is at once familiar and yet unexpected. Definitely a harrowing and worthwhile read....more

title: St. Marks Is Dead: The Many Lives of Americas Hippest Street
author: Calhoun, Ada*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I first moved to NYC, I lived on the corner of Orchard and Houston streets. I didn't know much about New York before moving there, but I lived wiWhen I first moved to NYC, I lived on the corner of Orchard and Houston streets. I didn't know much about New York before moving there, but I lived with three of my best friends in a three bedroom apartment on the same block as Russ & Daughters and within spitting distance of Katz's Deli. I grew to love my neighborhood, but I would stare longingly at that gleaming bastion of fun and youth that beckoned to the north of Houston Street. In my mind, the East Village was the quintessence of young Manhattan living, and I crossed the psychic barrier of Houston Street as often as I could for Veselka breakfast sandwiches, Mud coffee, Indian beneath the acid trip decor of Panna II, or this place that sold nothing but poutine whose name now escapes me. I think I swore that one day, when I had a bit more money I would live in the East Village. And no street was more East Village-y in my mind than St. Mark's.A decade hence, the allure of the East Village has significantly waned, and I go out of my way to avoid walking down St. Mark's, particularly east of 2nd Avenue. The street is just too kitschy, and replete with NYU students. The exception is when we go to Holiday Cocktail Lounge, somewhat ironically adopted by my college friends as one of our two go-to bars, but even then I studiously avoid the areas where people spill into the streets and stumble out of Middle Eastern restaurants clutching gyros and pita.I think my new reaction might be of a new type. The East Village seems like a palimpsest, with every new decade comes an older generation lamenting the inauthentic entry of a new vanguard, from the Stuyvesants to the Germans to the Jews to the Puerto Ricans to the Ukrainians to the hippies to the druggies to the punks to the crusties to the yuppies, every group looks on a decade afterward and waxes nostalgic for the St. Mark's of a decade ago. But I think whatever magic St. Mark's had was gone before I first beheld it, because it looks roughly the same and seems to serve the same function--weirdness and kitsch and affordability, all sanitized, despite the persistent patina of grime. As a microcosm of both Manhattan and of NYC in total this should be expected, but the St. Marks of generations past seems like it would have been pretty amazing....more

title: The Short and Tragic Life of Robert Peace: A Brilliant Young Man Who Left Newark for the Ivy League
author: Hobbs, Jeff*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As wordy as it is, this book's title is its best summation. Robert Peace was by all accounts possessed of an incandescent mind, talented at everythingAs wordy as it is, this book's title is its best summation. Robert Peace was by all accounts possessed of an incandescent mind, talented at everything he did, wise and generous beyond his years, and imbued with values and priorities beyond reproach. A profound sense of loss haunts this book--the loss of this incredible man's potential, what our society is robbing itself of by the waste laid by cycles of poverty, the war on drugs, and racism. Not that I have much faith in the "American Dream," particularly as it is available to the poor and people of color, but there are usually some exceptions, where a mixture of fortuitous innate characteristics, luck, and circumstances propel individuals of exceptional ability beyond their fraught circumstances and into the reaches of power and influence. The unscrupulous and specious point to these outliers as proof that the system works, and the rest of us wring inspiration from these stories and use them to underscore our conviction that success should not be so reliant on the caprice of luck. But a profound hopelessness inheres when an individual possesses all of the traits and circumstances necessary to escape the impossible and to gift the world with his or her brilliance, only to be swatted back down at the lip of success. This book is tragic and necessary, and it fueled my anger and amplified my sadness during a week when America's White Supremacist tendencies were so disturbingly elucidated in my beloved Charlottesville. Do yourself a favor and pick it up. Dwell on how much work we have to do to expiate our original sins of racism and inequality. And ask yourself what you're going to contribute to that effort so that we can begin to benefit from rather than mourn the lives of individuals like Robert Peace....more

title: Harsh Justice
author: Whitman, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This dryasdust work, written by an eminent Yale Law professor, has an interesting premise: because the United States, unlike Continental Europe (as exThis dryasdust work, written by an eminent Yale Law professor, has an interesting premise: because the United States, unlike Continental Europe (as exemplified by the modern states of Germany and France), never had an aristocracy and was founded on Republican ideals of egalitarianism, the former and the latter developed radically different approaches to dignity in imprisonment. Essentially, the United States never had tiered punishments, and things that tended to be high-status crimes in Europe (political dissent, bankruptcy) were not even illegal in the United States. A modernizing impulse on mainland Europe led to a gradual equalization of punishments, first with the extension of the guillotine and beheading (in the West, beheading was the punishment meted out to the elite, while hanging was a form of debasement and defilement left to the lowborn), and then with an extension of perquisites formerly only enjoyed by the rich and well connected. In America, however, our general allergy to aristocracy retarded the modernizing impulse, and then for a variety of reasons we stuck with an egalitarianism of low punishment rather than embracing a more clement approach for all.A few gripes: Whitman probably doesn't get to his main points until around page 170. In a normal book this wouldn't be too much of a burden, but this book was only 210 pages, and it took me weeks to read, it was that dense and dry, so I felt that it was a bit unnecessary. Also, perhaps because it is focused on almost to the exclusion of all other potentially explanatory phenomena (including this book's thesis!), Whitman really fails to address the role of race and slavery in his assessment of America's decision not to "level up" status punishment instead of our decision to leave degradation as the common trait among all our forms of punishment. Finally: man this book needed an editor; so many typos and mistakes....more

review: This book has an interesting premise--octopi and their close relatives, unlike all other semi-intelligent beings (such as birds, whales, dolphins, pigThis book has an interesting premise--octopi and their close relatives, unlike all other semi-intelligent beings (such as birds, whales, dolphins, pigs, and apes, etc.), diverged so early that their intelligence is less a variant on our own (like the aforementioned ape and pig intelligence) than a sui generis form of intelligence, the closest we might ever get to encountering alien sentience. Octopi show attitudes toward people and things, curiosity about objects, and base level comprehension of the dynamism of their surroundings, all in ways that Godfrey-Smith goes out of his way to explain cannot be explained, as in so many other animals, as mere functions of necessity or reactions. Octopi have some sort of comprehension of the world; they have a distinguishable stratum of activity and quirks that unquestionably elevates them above mere automata. And of course they're physically weird and distinct in all of the ways that the inhabitants of the briny deep tend to be.Although this book could tend toward tedium, left some big questions unanswered, and anthropomorphized a bit too liberally, it was really interesting and weird (in a good way!) overall!...more

title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
author: Harari, Yuval Noah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Another engrossing longtake from Yuval Noah Harari. This book starts with a panoramic chronicle of humanity's earliest offshoots and eventual consolidAnother engrossing longtake from Yuval Noah Harari. This book starts with a panoramic chronicle of humanity's earliest offshoots and eventual consolidations. It leaves off where his second book (though the first that I had read) begins: at the point where we start to use technology, genetic modifications, and inorganic accoutrements to diverge from our past and the destiny to which our genes confines us. At times this felt a bit scattered, though I suppose that this is a peril of the genre. But it was very entertaining, provocative, and interesting throughout. As in his other work, Harari is most interesting when he questions our assumptions and vitiates common values and world views. In particular, here, he makes short work of Western ethnocentrism, the hopeful but unsupported concept of a teleology to human purpose, and of our presumed superiority to other life forms. Harari emphasizes, often poignantly, that humans are no stronger, more determined, more noble, more loving, more moral than our co-residents of Earth, the thousands of other types of animals that live alongside of us. The only real differentiators are our intelligence and our ability to cooperate. I think we tend to emphasize our intellectual superiority above all other factors, whether out of vanity, insecurity, or habit. But superior intelligence is the necessary condition, but it is not sufficient for promoting anything close to what we currently call society, progress, technology, etc. It's not especially profound, but I do think it's generally underemphasized that humans' dominance over the planet cannot be attributed to our superior intelligence, or at least not directly. Isolated tribes in the middle of Papuan or Amazonian jungles are just as likely to have the same kernel of intelligence as you or I, but their societies, even if replicated but still atomized across the globe, would hardly be more dominant than any other apex species. Instead, it's our intelligence that facilitates our ability to cooperate, and it's our ability to cooperate that allows us to direct our energies toward making life easier, better, safer, freer, and more numinous. It's only through cooperation that we have been able to do so much, and it's the absence of cooperation--whether in the form of nationalism, war, tragedy of the commons, or other ill--that correlates with stagnation and decline. Certainly something to think about as societies all over the West are becoming more closed off, more selfish and jealous, more prickly and hair-trigger....more

title: The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck: A Counterintuitive Approach to Living a Good Life
author: Manson, Mark*

review: I didn't really know much about this book going in, but I think I saw it in the window of the local cool bookstore, which usually means it's some mixtI didn't really know much about this book going in, but I think I saw it in the window of the local cool bookstore, which usually means it's some mixture of en vogue and good. I probably would have been less interested had I known that it was a presumptuous self-help book, or by a straight white dude not much older than me whose only previous title was Models: Attract Women Through Honesty. So I'm glad that I didn't have too much by which to prejudge this book, because it was sage in its own way.He doesn't coin this portmanteau, but it's a type of Cruddhism: crude Buddhism. Wise, paradoxical, and not necessarily self-evident truths told in a blue manner. Manson kind of cuts through the bullshit and encourages us to not sweat the small stuff. He draws distinctions between his exhortations and the two extremes (the jack of all trades and the person who cares about nothing, or at least purports to), and suggests that we triage our focus to only fixate or get bothered by the things we have control over and on the things that we actually care about. He mixes in some interesting and revealing anecdotes--though sometimes it's unclear whether he's using a story to exhort us not to give a shit or to highlight how focusing on one particular thing is detrimental--and tells some personal stories, all while hammering home the same message. Overall, a surprising and enjoyable short read. 3.5 stars....more

title: Less
author: Greer, Andrew Sean
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So this has been on my "to read" list for a while--alluring cover, splashy advertising, have seen even (presumably) straight people reading it on the So this has been on my "to read" list for a while--alluring cover, splashy advertising, have seen even (presumably) straight people reading it on the subway. Looked like a winner! Sadly, it was not to be."Less" is the story of a gay man who has lived a minor life of renown on the outskirts of a more luminous circle of literary talents, had great loves that fizzled from his own neglect, and lots of frisky and fun stories in between. On the cusp of 50 and his younger paramour having recently gotten engaged, he sets off on a world tour of escapism and last hurrahs. I think "Less" is supposed to be funny, and it does have some whimsy to it, but at heart it's a cautionary tale of the thing that many gay men fear--that our constant vigil for something slightly better will, before we know it, leave us lonely, bereft, and unloved in the not-so-old age bracket where we have half of our lives left but have already graduated beyond our community's morbid, age-regimented standards of desirability. As a 31 year old, I have already incorporated this neurosis. It's difficult to say why I didn't like this book without spoiling it, but I'll make an attempt: I felt like the characters were not very developed, and the vignettes were so tangential to each other that I only found out, to my astonishment, that this book won the 2018 Pulitzer when I googled it to investigate whether its peripeteia was a retelling of some Greek legend I didn't know or had forgotten, a meta-reflection on Arthur Less's book. I think the ending is sweet, but it certainly didn't feel well-earned. "Spatchcocked" would have been a more fitting title, and at least a gay-er, less groanworthy pun than the one that actually concluded the book. (ETA--"Eat, Gay, Love" also could have summed this up well).On a parting note, this was the most recent selection for one of my two NYC Gay Men's Book Clubs, and I had to miss the discussion because I was working that night. One of the things we've discussed in that club is why books written by and about gay men tend to always be harrowing or tragic in some way. And in a group that is supersaturated at 40 people, it was surprising and telling that not one of us could name an exception to that rule. Maybe the value in this book, written as it was by a boyish looking 50-something gay man, is in filling that lacuna?...more

title: Devil's Bargain: Steve Bannon, Donald Trump, and the Nationalist Uprising
author: Green, Joshua*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I tried to reserve this months ago when I first learned of it, and only got off the waiting list around the time that Charlottesville unfolded and BanI tried to reserve this months ago when I first learned of it, and only got off the waiting list around the time that Charlottesville unfolded and Bannon was summarily booted from the White House. I was unsure of whether it still made sense to read, but having done so I am convinced it was worthwhile. Since his ouster, pundits have been tripping over themselves to herald the debut of a more polished, less divisive, more independent, and more pragmatic Trump. Many of these assign responsibility to the no-nonsense environment inaugurated by General Kelly's takeover as White House Chief of Staff, but having finished "Devil's Bargain," I'm convinced that Trump is merely a cipher and Bannon's idiot microphone, gone quiet now that his provocative and destructive interlocutor has been jettisoned.But backing up a bit, Bannon is himself an interesting, improbable creature. He's certainly smarter than Trump by leaps and bounds, and wiser, too. The only area where they both seem to have preternatural skill is in the realm of instinct, where each has a knack for tapping into the wounded id of the brooding and unsuccessful white person, typically male. But neither is a genius, Bannon just arrogated that title because the comparator intelligence of the group surrounding him was so paltry. Bannon is a voracious student with eccentric and quixotic hobbyhorses ranging from Christian mysticism to Marxist nationalism, but ultimately he just seems like a person possessed of a crystalline vision of the inevitable future, but lacking the short term specifics and pragmatism to bridge the gap; a man possessed of far more persuasive ability and powers of manipulation than wisdom or goodness. But perhaps more than anything, Bannon is the product of a perfect storm of luck. It's not that a Harvard Business School and Goldman Sachs alum would be surprising to find in the upper echelons of any presidential administration, especially one that is so nakedly plutocratic and morally nihilistic--on the contrary. But Bannon didn't follow the normal trajectory. Instead he was out shilling weird Tridentine Catholic propaganda films to the Vatican, which led him to make films about Sarah Palin's run for VP (mystifyingly called "The Undefeated"), but not before falling into Seinfeld royalties by accident, representing Fred Durst and Ice Cube, and most recently running a scheme with Brock Pierce, aka the young star of the "Mighty Ducks" franchise, to use abusive Chinese labor to generate computer loot that would in turn be sold to Westerners for real life cash. It all sounds like a conspiracy theory, but also totally plausible in this increasingly unbelievable world that we inhabit.Once Bannon got connected to the Mercers (think of the Koch brothers but with more secrecy and less restraint), there was a brief flirtation with the Cruz campaign before he realized that Trump could be his Trojan Horse, the man who would deliver him to the apex of power and allow for the destruction of the corrupt political establishment from the inside. I guess it still remains to be seen whether the GOP or the two-party system will survive the Trump presidency, but it's staggering how much discord Bannon was able to sow in only a few short months in power by completely shredding norms and alienating every politician he might have courted.While I do think that much of the hooplah over Bannon's genius and longview is overblown, there's no doubt in my mind that he was singularly powerful for two reasons: he picked a winning (if insane) strategy for the 2016 Election, and he really did maintain a Rasputin-esque control over Trump's messaging while in office. As to the first, there's no evidence that the American people ever really liked Trump, nor that they had much faith in his policies--certainly not enough to win him the election. Instead, Bannon seized on the distrust of the Clintons, the antipathy to dynasty, the rank misogyny simmering in so much of the uncourted electorate, and the chimerical grievances of young, disaffected white men to gin up a whirlwind of sustained hatred against Hillary Clinton, an imperfect but highly qualified and generally moderate candidate who came to be seen by all but the totally committed left as dishonest, corrupt, untruthful, careless, and unlikeable. Bannon pulled out all the stops--I was sickened when I remembered that Trump intended to seat all of Bill's accusers in the front row of the second debate to unnerve Hillary, but unsurprised that this was Bannon's scheme--and wrecked just about every norm we could have marginal pride in while doing so. With the help of the Mercers, who refused to condemn Trump even after the "Access Hollywood" "grab 'em by the pussy" tape emerged, they savaged Clinton, and with the godsend of the Comey letter, that was just enough to pull off what was the greatest--and most upsetting--upset in American political history.As to the second, Bannon amplified Trump's tendencies to refuse to apologize, to dogwhistle to all sorts of reprehensible bigots, to energize his base, and to make statements of great, hubristic bravado. Because everything is terrible, this book reveals Bannon's personal motto: Honey Badger don't give a shit. And it's true: as manager of Breitbart, Bannon would routinely make false statements, or trump up claims that were demonstrably false at the time, and would refuse to retract them. Why? Because honey badger don't give a shit. To people who only want politics as entertainment, for whom hatred sustains and is a pastime, objectivity does not matter one stitch. In a fragile world of wounded male id, apologizing is what these people think they have been doing their entire lives, and the dominant narratives and policers of truth are all biased anyway, so why capitulate? Instead, Bannon took the factual nihilism and allergy to objectivity that characterizes so much of the right and rightwing media in particular and turned it into an art form. This played into his successes with the destruction of Hillary Clinton, as mentioned above.So now that he's removed from office, whither Bannon and his baleful influence? It's unclear, but I have a hunch. Throughout the first part of this book I found myself pining for a liberal/leftist Bannon to come onto the scene, who could exploit the bugbears of the other side and animate the left's anger and sense of scandalization, because as it is now we're still struggling to decide whether Clinton or Sanders should shut up and accept blame for the 2016 loss. But there's a reason why these rumor mills and fake news outlet enjoy so much currency and sway on the right but not the left--the former trades in absolutes, a black-and-white view of the world, while liberal policies and trains of thought always inhabit the grays of the spectrum; and if you let in a bit of doubt, a caveat here or there, there is always going to be room to critique and accept blame for something that you recognize is imperfect but support all the same. While this can often make liberals seem milquetoast and self-defeating, it's a conscientious way to think about things as complex as dignity, punishment, society, government, and justice. But conservatives seem far more susceptible to the non-nuanced point of view, far less susceptible to question anything that they believe or that seems superficially to adhere to their core principles and values. I speak in embarrassingly overbroad terms here (it is a book , after all), but I believe these things to be true about both sides, especially as the pitch and ardor of each side increases.But with Trump lacking his Rasputin, it's not like he's become more moderate, he's just easier to kick and bully about. By all accounts Bannon was a "real alpha"! But now Trump is surrounded by moderate Republicans who want to govern in a reasonable conservative way and understand the need for compromise and decorum. He's also surrounded by Democrats, through whom he has found he can obtain rare and highly coveted plaudits by cooperating just the slightest bit. With Gorka out, there's maybe only Stephen Miller left in the "burn the whole world down" cabal that Bannon unquestionably led. So does this mean that Trump will have more or less success? Well, it depends on what you think "success" means--I think it will be better for Democrats, and certainly he will be less incendiary, which is a good thing for our country. But having read this book, I am confident that his chances of winning reelection have never been lower. Bannon was a master assassin of character, and he knew that by continuously launching preposterous stories backed by a loud and angry constituency in the alt-right, he was able to enlist the media in his efforts to show Clinton to be just as bad as Trump, if not worse because Trump, at least, was a wildcard who might really pan out. We know that no amount of hypocrisy or flip-flopping will ever be enough to alienate the majority of Trump supporters from his cult of personality. But without a bogeyman in 2020 as seemingly perfectly engineered for exploitation as Clinton was, and lacking an enthusiastic constituency to rally behind Trump (presumably without a "Wall" or Obamacare repeal to show for his first term), and with Bannon-helmed Breitbart now using its influence to undermine Trump's support and mystique, he's absolute toast. Good fucking riddance. ...more

title: Shattered: Inside Hillary Clinton's Doomed Campaign
author: Allen, Jonathan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was really interesting but bleak. I'd recommend it to anyone who is interesting in finding out what went wrong from the inside of this campaign, This was really interesting but bleak. I'd recommend it to anyone who is interesting in finding out what went wrong from the inside of this campaign, and who can stomach it this soon after the doom it chronicles.I watched this election with intense interest, first as someone excited about the possibility that a economic iconoclast like Bernie Sanders posed, and then horrified by the possibility that Donald Trump could become president. I never really felt strongly about Hillary Clinton either way--I frowned on a lot of her politics and her seemingly cautious approach to things in the primary, but thought she would be a very capable and even-handed president; I thought she herself was inspiring even if her leadership would likely be worryingly neoliberal. When Trump became the nominee, I clung to her by default, but I never grew to love her as a candidate. Sure, I phone banked for her every chance I got from her Brooklyn office, and yes I am a bit taken by identity optics narratives (though: queery whether things have gotten better for people of color in the United States since the first non-white president was elected...), but I only really got excited about a Hillary Clinton presidency insofar as she was the last bulwark against Republican lunacy.Having read this book, I think that we can only really blame Hillary for this catastrophic and seemingly avoidable cataclysm of an election result insofar as she is responsible for picking the team that ran the election and the people who defined it. The role of sexism in this election is beyond question--a disgusting revelation about where we are as a nation despite our lofty rhetoric, and a vivid reminder of how much farther we have to go. And the media's complicity in furthering Trump's antics and approbating his childishness--harming our civic debate and eroding our norms for short term ratings boosts--is almost as appalling. But even given these X factors, this result was far from inevitable. Aside from Hillary's own "scandals" (honestly--fuck anyone who thought that Hillary's emails were a legitimate reason to not vote for her and/or to vote for Trump) and the campaign's inability to handle them, data fetishists like (the aptly named) Robby Mook seem most to blame for this disaster. A mix of hubris and a preternatural focus on the numbers really seem to have doomed this campaign from the start. Additionally, the book focuses heavily on the primary and the damage it may have inflicted on the general campaign. What I took away from it is just how arrogant and dismissive the campaign was toward the nearly equal number of Democratic primary voters who preferred another candidate, and one with a very different agenda. The fact that Elizabeth Warren was one of the final four VP candidates--the result of campaign aides insisting that this would be a way to mend relationships with the Bernie wing--and that they went with "duller than a year-old razor" Tim Kaine, really shows how arrogant, spiteful, or out of touch the whole group was. The worst is that Hillary took the blame for all of this, despite her openness to Warren as VP, her skepticism of Debbie Wasserman Schultz, and her strong interest in economic justice for all, especially minorities and women, as expressed through her wonky and detailed policy positions.In the end, I divided the major players into heroes, villains, and neutrals:Heroes:* Hillary & Chelsea Clinton* Michelle and Barack ObamaNeutrals:* Podesta* Huma* Bernie* Kaine* BidenVillains:* Mook* Debbie Wasserman-Schultz* Bill Clinton* Comey* Intransigent Bernie supporters (but only after he conceded the primary)The inside story, really, is wild. It really me relive the rollercoaster, for better or for worse. I guess the worst part was reliving the awful night of when the terror of unreality set in; but happily, a mixture of incompetency, internal strife, and corruption have conspired to keep the impact at bay. At least for now. Let's hope the next campaign learns all the lessons it can from this book....more

title: No Is Not Enough: Resisting Trump’s Shock Politics and Winning the World We Need
author: Klein, Naomi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Given how trenchant Klein's books normally are, I was a bit surprised that she turned this around so quickly. It's her shortest book by far, but it loGiven how trenchant Klein's books normally are, I was a bit surprised that she turned this around so quickly. It's her shortest book by far, but it looks to have been conceived of, written, edited, and published over... 4-8 months? Kind of remarkable. So I wasn't surprised to see that much of it recapitulated many of her old books: the "No Logo" portion talks about Trump as a hollow idea, something that is set at a remove from reality and that achieves its power through spin and association, not through any connection to quality or to any efficacy with governing; the "This Changes Everything" frame basically talks about how we're already way past screwed when it comes to the environment, and how we need to frame any goals for our future within the environmentalist paradigm and the decolonizationalist and reparationist frameworks that this increasingly entails; and "The Shock Doctrine" frame talks about how Trump is going to use this model--not coincidentally a model perfected by his antecedents in the GOP and through his buddies in the Kremlin--to concoct the apotheosis of kleptocracy. So, basically, if you've read the rest of her oeuvre, she tees up how you should think about Trump through each of its overlapping lenses. But she adds in a part at the end where she clarifies the title of this work. She emphasizes that it's not enough to be opposed to bigotry, ignorance, rapaciousness, greed, and crudeness; we need to be the party or parties or movement that suggests permanent, appealing, and prosperous alternatives to the untenable habits that characterize our modern world and most impactful societies. She concludes with a declaration of sorts that lists several high-minded but not totally inconceivable goals and aspirations, which has apparently achieved some currency within Canada. Sadly, they seem like they might be totally implausible in a United States in which Trump could become president, but he seems to be making such a hash out of it in only six months that the Shock Doctrinaire in me wonders whether this isn't the time to push for some really bold reimagining of what is possible......more

title: No Logo
author: Klein, Naomi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm trying to read through all of Naomi Klein's oeuvre, because I think she is one of the great diatribists of our time. "Shock Doctrine" is one of thI'm trying to read through all of Naomi Klein's oeuvre, because I think she is one of the great diatribists of our time. "Shock Doctrine" is one of the most eye-opening pieces of non-fiction I've ever had the privilege of reading, and "This Changes Everything," about climate change, has changed my behavior and attitude toward my surroundings probably more than any other book. "No Logo" is not as impressive an entry into her pantheon, but it prefigures the talent that she would display in her later works. Perhaps it's because it was a bit dated--references to the influence of MTV and Nike abound; brand hegemons like Apple--whose share price has since increased by a factor of about 300x--do not even merit mention. Sweatshops were the cause celebre of the 1990s, and it's hard to say whether we hear less about them because corporations recognize that it's no longer profitable to employ exploitative sweatshop labor (as Klein points out: revenue and not morality is always the gravamen of this calculus), or because we grew fatigued by the effort and tolerate them now, or at least their slightly less exploitative post-1990s iterations.One highlight of the book came toward its end, when Klein talks about the agency of youth consumers and of disenfranchised yet culturally relevant black and brown youth who live in the nation's cities. It's pretty incredible that brands as powerful as Nike and Disney caved to the pressure of these individuals, who understood themselves to have been chumps for paying 30x the cost of a shoe, and having engaged in the exploitation of other marginalized people throughout the world in so doing, all to pad the larders of megarich companies who had co-opted their sense of style and fashion to begin with. It's kind of great that people won't tolerate hostile corporate forces invading their space. To wit, I've been venturing beyond my West Brooklyn/Lower Manhattan ambit of late, and have found myself in the Bronx, in Central Queens, and in white ethnic enclaves like Greenpoint. Milo Yiannopoulos, the smugly execrable male Ann Coulter/low-rent Oscar Wilde with a bronzer problem who is currently afflicting our society with his "provocative" yet wholly warmed-over ideas in the Trump era, is putting out his own book, entitled "Dangerous." I'm all for free speech, and come from the Millsian/Skokie line of ACLU types who think that one of the only things America is truly great at, and has benefited from, is its staunch defense of freedom of speech in the public arena. Even if they were repellent, which they surely are, I would defend Mr. Yiannopoulos' right to advocate his views. But freedom of speech is important for allowing new ideas to surface, not for perseverating the same "Muslims are bad!" "White men are responsible for all cultural innovations!" and "Women make up rape allegations for attention!" tommyrot that has been around since the Crusades, if not earlier, and has been widely discredited for centuries; we need this type of public voice like we need lectures about why the Earth is flat. Mr. Yiannopoulos is a gadfly, and he has never propounded an original idea other than that he is somehow noteworthy, as far as I can tell. Anyway, I noticed that ads for his book, "Dangerous," were cynically posted all over the subway stations in less gentrified areas, ostensibly because people in the other areas would not tolerate their living spaces being desecrated by such an inane, bigoted idiot and his quest to enrich himself by sowing dissension. And happily, I noticed that of all the ads on the subway, even in the areas not teeming with effete latte liberals like myself, these ads were almost always the only ones torn down, desecrated, denounced, destroyed. As Klein notes, there may be no legal theory to support these actions, but one of the most powerful ways in which people can revolt against the invasion of their spaces and communities by hostile, capitalist attempts to make money off of them and their neighbors is through hostile, pointed destruction of the property that these forces use to accomplish their aims. I'm sure that Mr. Yiannopoulos would have some tired quip about the breeding of these people or their motivations, and how it shows that the left (read: the not extreme right) is intolerant of free speech, but this really just reflects an overbroad view of the protections to which private property and money are entitled, and a cramped view of the ways in which speech, protest, and dissent can, should, and will increasingly be expressed....more

title: Private Citizens
author: Tulathimutte, Tony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So of the many book clubs I’ve involved myself with, one stands out as the oldest and perhaps best. We rotate hosts, and to avoid a tragedy of the comSo of the many book clubs I’ve involved myself with, one stands out as the oldest and perhaps best. We rotate hosts, and to avoid a tragedy of the commons situation, whoever hosts supplies all the food and wine (occasionally beer and liquor, as well), and gets to select three books that the group may vote on. I selected this book, in addition to Beartown by Fredrik Backman and The Master Butchers Singing Club by Louise Erdrich. Private Citizens squeaked out the win, and I took to reading it without much prejudice as to whether or not I’d cotton to it.Another tradition of this book club is that we go around the circle and say what our initial thoughts were, starting with the host. So I piped up and said what I thought: the book was funny, smart (but perhaps “too” smart), clever, and well-written. It had its rough spots, but particularly for a debut novel it was excellent, and I was eager to see what the author put out next.Well that was the last encomium the book was to receive, because everyone else pretty much hated it. One person mentioned the editing, many mentioned the sloppy, self-aware grasp of feminism, the Oedipal ending felt too heavy-handed, everyone disliked pretty much every character, and many found the despair-amongst-such-privilege theme to be downright offensive. The thing is, I don’t disagree with any of the above. And so maybe it’s just that I can deemphasize the foibles and have a greater affinity for what the book did well, which I thought was tell interesting stories, offer up witty banter, explore a microcosm of society, etc. Everyone did agree that the writer had talent and would in all probability write something good one day; but I’m still a bit too sheepish to recommend it to others with any degree of confidence…...more

title: American Lion: Andrew Jackson in the White House
author: Meacham, Jon
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I decided to read this because of the inevitable Jackson comparisons to our current president, whose supporters are so desperate for legitimacy and soI decided to read this because of the inevitable Jackson comparisons to our current president, whose supporters are so desperate for legitimacy and so ignorant of history that they clamor for a comparator president, even if that comparator president is often described as brutish, unhinged, racist, and genocidal. Meacham doesn't paper over or apologize for Jackson's most execrable qualities--namely his tolerance for slavery and his unapologetic and genocidal attitude toward Native Americans--but he undertakes to tell a more personal tale of Jackson. In a way, it's admirable, because we have a tendency in this country to consider all Great Men either untainted heroes or unregenerate villains, when few seldom resolve so cleanly. But in another way it's a bit disturbing that the balance of this book favored Jackson's warm paternal side (not only to his adopted family but to the nation as a whole) and his more admirable qualities (his loyalty to the Eatons, for instance) while giving disproportionate short shrift to his most unpardonable sins.In a way, I see why Jackson and Trump are often compared: both represent departures from long traditions of "establishment" politicians, who had both the experience and the polish of politesse; both were regarded by Coastal and Northern elites as unlettered idiots who whipped the people into frenzies reflecting the baser sides of their natures; both used novel ways to communicate with the public (John C. Calhoun, roguish as he himself was, accused the president's communication with the Boston Globe of being unconstitutional, since he thought the only legitimate means for POTUS to communicate to the people was through speeches and addenda to laws!); both were thought to portend the downfall of the experiment of American Government. I suppose we shall see whether this last comparison's inaccuracy credits the 45th president as significantly as it does our 7th...But I couldn't help take note of the rather more pronounced ways in which these two presidents differ radically. Jackson was a lawyer who had a strong (if idiosyncratic) understanding of how the government should work, and its relationship to The People. Jackson apologized when he thought it necessary. Jackson believed that the power of the presidency derived from having been chosen by the majority of the people; Trump crows about his Electoral College victory, an institution that Jackson regarded as anti-democratic and elitist. Jackson was legitimately religious and had a knowledge of scripture, and took the separation of church and state so seriously that he refused to join a church until after he finished his presidency; Trump has probably never read a page of scripture in his life. And of course Jackson grew up in poor, marginalized circumstances, orphaned from a young age and never very rich, and we all know Trump's story.Bad as Jackson was, he seems to have at least been principled, if deeply misguided with terrible consequences. He seriously enlarged the power of the presidency, perhaps inexorably, and cherished the integrity of the union above all else. He seemed to have cherished his family and intimates, and endeavored to be the father to others that he never had himself. And there are all sorts of amusing anecdotes in which he threatened to murder people who gave him their slack jaw and attacked armed assailants with little more than pluck and his cane. Definitely a badass, if also a bad apple. In comparison, Trump lacks the drive, intelligence, and strength of will to accomplish his own, modern version of the evils Jackson wrought, and he lacks all of the few but considerable virtues Jackson possessed. We can at least be thankful for that....more

title: The Political Mind: Why You Can't Understand 21st-Century American Politics with an 18th-Century Brain
author: Lakoff, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So Lakoff, writing in early 2008, seems to think the Democrats have a messaging problem. Prescient guy! He beats on about liberals' failure to weaponiSo Lakoff, writing in early 2008, seems to think the Democrats have a messaging problem. Prescient guy! He beats on about liberals' failure to weaponize empathy, and to claim that progressivism is American. Perhaps it is the Reaganaut decade I was born into and the imitators that followed, but this seems like too simplistic a take. Americans seem different--not because of some demented pathogen or hideous mutation we carry within us, but because we've been "#1" for so long that, rather than change course and admit defeat as anomie and decay spread, we double down and our most self-destructive, short-sighted qualities grow concentrated and magnified. Lakoff does talk about the powerful sway of risk aversion, but rather than characterize it as something that Americans of all political persuasions might feel because of our declining grandeur and collapsing arcs of progress, he imputes it to conservatives only. I feel like he misses his own point....more

title: Jesus’ Son
author: Johnson, Denis
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As I read this tiny book on my subway commutes the past few days, people would look at me with the same wary but affectionate mien with which they takAs I read this tiny book on my subway commutes the past few days, people would look at me with the same wary but affectionate mien with which they take in old church ladies reading the gospel or Hasids reading scripture--some sort of vague nostalgia for religion that people can retain for the rare person who practices in public in a way that is unobtrusive to others. That is they would, I assume, until they saw the flood of color-barred pills on the cover like so many holiday candy corns. This was for a book club that I missed, but I decided to read it anyway because I hang out with these bros all the time anyway and it'll probably come up. It was poetic and weird, intense and oddly funny at times, but in an unsettling way. Johnson seemed to have been striving to highlight the seediness that is always gathering in the unswept corners of wholesome America--the drifter who admires the Mennonite couple and then spends days trying to spy on them fucking; the dopey father, family ensconced in station wagon, who pulls over to ask the orderly whether it's snake roadkill he's picking at, only to peel out when the orderly shouts something like "No, it's a dead mother rabbit and she's full of babies!" I think I liked it but I'm glad it was short, if that makes any sense.For fans of Junky and The Last Wolf & Herman....more

title: Manhattan Beach
author: Egan, Jennifer*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A solid 3.75 stars, rounded up. I like Jennifer Egan, even though I feel like it's become a bit taboo to say it. "Goon Squad" had its heyday in the peA solid 3.75 stars, rounded up. I like Jennifer Egan, even though I feel like it's become a bit taboo to say it. "Goon Squad" had its heyday in the period just before I reinvigorated my love of reading, and so it was in the first wave of books I picked up. And I loved it! I still think of it fondly, even if I hated that PowerPoint chapter. But my peers often take a jaundiced view of it, in a way that's always smacked to me of performative middle schoolers abandoning a band they liked because it became too popular. But I'm still a Jennifer Egan fan! We live in the same neighborhood and one day I hope to stumble across her and buttonhole her to tell her all of this in passing.I didn't like this as much as her previous effort, but it was enjoyable in many of the same ways. Lots of elaborate connections, traversed epochs, engaging female characters. But there were flaws as well: Dexter Styles was not the best developed character and oftentimes his story arc defied credulity--what kind of WASPy, old-money military man in the 1930s allows his daughter to marry a gangster? And what ever happened to Grady? And more of the Boatswain, please!On the whole I think it felt like a low-rent "Rules of Civility." I'm not sure I'd recommend it to anyone with particular enthusiasm, but I definitely enjoyed it....more

title: Evicted: Poverty and Profit in the American City
author: Desmond, Matthew*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I read books like "Evicted," all I can think about is how surreal it is that so many people live in such voids of dignity, respect, health, safetWhen I read books like "Evicted," all I can think about is how surreal it is that so many people live in such voids of dignity, respect, health, safety, and opportunity, and that these are facts that somehow coexist alongside a ubiquitous myth that we've ever been a great society, or a people worthy of emulation. Shame, shame, shame on us. When I worked at the ACLU's Women's Rights Project we started taking on a lot of the nuisance abatement cases, wherein typically female victims of abuse are given the agonizing choice of enduring intimate partner violence or calling the cops, where the latter option runs the risk of spurring a for-fault eviction, imperiling present as well as future housing security for the person and her family. I can't imagine how thick, or unfeeling, or incompetent one would have to be to think that such policies are equitable or necessary, and yet they are by no means an aberration, but rather a feature of the system. They blanket our state and local legal regimes, and it's only the advocacy of impact litigation outfits like the ACLU that is stemming their tide; for every story we hear about in Desmond's book or in a federal district court, you have to imagine there is an unceasing stream of silent others who skulk away with what dignity they can salvage and whatever important items they can carry with them, no practical solution anywhere close to imaginable. Desmond actually talks about landlords who discriminate against mothers with children, because children are more likely to be tested for chemical and hard metal poisoning, leading to landlord liability. Think about the layers of inhumanity and depravity it takes to keep poor families from living in shitty housing, just to protect an already unconscionable rent money haul. This country and its people really get me down sometimes....more

title: A Fine Mess: A Global Quest for a Simpler, Fairer, and More Efficient Tax System
author: Reid, T.R.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So, I can't exactly recommend this book. It is, after all, about taxes. Taxes are boring, everyone has unlettered and predictable opinions about them,So, I can't exactly recommend this book. It is, after all, about taxes. Taxes are boring, everyone has unlettered and predictable opinions about them, and the subject is endlessly abstruse. But they're also very important. Beyond clumsy suppositions about liberals favoring more taxes and conservatives loathing them, I found this account fascinating for revealing one of the few political areas of substance where conservative and liberal policy goals are consistent with each other. It is in fact possible to raise more money and lower tax rates! We can lower the taxes on the richest, not chase away corporations, implement a VAT without it being regressive, and do all of this while raising more money and radically simplifying the nature of our byzantine tax code! BBLR! Suffice it to say, it'll be interesting to wade into the promised tax reform debates and not immediately assume that our government is run by a cabal of greedy idiots intent on ruining anything good about this country/world for plutocratic purposes. I mean, I'll probably end up that way, but at least I can come in with an open mind and a lack of presumptions about what conservative policies do. So if there's a fix out there, then why not adopt it? In a word: politics. And also a hefty dose of the ridiculous idea that American exceptionalism means "everything we do contributes to us being the greatest!" rather than "almost everything that we insist on doing differently has become an embarrassing albatross with nothing more to justify it than convention and stubbornness."Anyway, this book, I gather, is written by a frequent NPR commentator. I kept getting surprised about how interesting the subject matter was but that's kind of what NPR does so well: makes something mundane and boring into something worthy of exploration. Hooray for taxes!...more

title: Bad Feminist
author: Gay, Roxane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Roxane Gay is a bad feminist, as are we all. This book even occasionally dwells on these facts, and when it does it's at its best. There are lots of cRoxane Gay is a bad feminist, as are we all. This book even occasionally dwells on these facts, and when it does it's at its best. There are lots of careening asides about Scrabble and the author's dubious claims to laziness (do lazy people write books?), but this book has a lot of interesting insights into how our culture demonizes and misconstrues the (eminently unobjectionable) idea that women and men should be equal. It's never as simple as wishing it, and we all--through our conscious and unconscious biases and behaviors--do our part to prevent the idea's reification. When Gay gets into a groove, she is spellbinding. She can launch into a screed like few others. But while I found this to be powerful and important in most cases, at many other times it felt like she was adopting a strident view not admitting of nuance. For example, Gay says something like she wanted to slap a colleague who said that a text on racism should perhaps be taken more seriously because it was written by a white woman. Fair enough. But then in later chapters Gay floats the idea that a commentary on gender and sex by (male) artist Thornton Dial could maybe be taken more seriously because it was created by a man. I don't think Gay's suggestion here is hortatory--she is not suggesting that this is the only way it should be considered--but she is at least allowing that there might be some merit to considering the viewpoint of the less marginalized group. Yet this charitable and open-minded approach is often something she denies to others. By the end of the book, I was distracted by what a different Roxane Gay 2.0 might have said in her antiphon to this book: saying that Wendy Davis' hair looked perfect during her 13-hour long filibuster against restrictions on reproductive health care? Rank sexism. Her claim that it is a shame that derelict and abusive black men in cinema are left off screen because it purposefully signals black male absenteeism? Society's desire to visually gratify their belief that black men are brutish misogynists. Etc. etc.Because of her skill with pointing out our hypocrisies and loss of proportionality when it comes to gender and race, I couldn't help being reminded of another great commentator of our times, Ta-nehisi Coates. But unlike Gay, Coates takes a less judgmental stance, allows for the possibility of redemption and nuance, and directs you to come to the conclusions on your own. I couldn't help but think that Gay's approach could have been still better had it adopted elements of this approach....more

review: So I'm kind of surprised about this book. Usually I find the PYTs like Weike Wang to be less alluring than my peers and taste-sharers, but it seems thSo I'm kind of surprised about this book. Usually I find the PYTs like Weike Wang to be less alluring than my peers and taste-sharers, but it seems that the relationship was inverted this time around. Most of my GR friends were unimpressed by this, but I really liked it!Wang describes the life of a disenchanted graduate student in dreary, boreal, Boston, a life I recall all too well. She does it via economical sentences, clever chemistry analogies, random trivia, and the humorous lens of depressive ennui. The parts about the immigrant/Asian/female graduate student experience I thought were pretty stereotyped, but the wry approach to relationships, academia, infants, mismatched partners, and nuclear family dynamics really rang true for me.This is a short book by a promising and refreshing young author. Check it out if you can endure the library waitlist durations....more

review: I loved this. Upgrading to five stars.We just had our book club discussion yesterday, and of all the books we've covered over the past year, I don't rI loved this. Upgrading to five stars.We just had our book club discussion yesterday, and of all the books we've covered over the past year, I don't remember any others garnering universal praise. We all agreed that it was perhaps a bit overlong, but so charming, witty, funny, and weird; but at the same time, we all acknowledged how bleak the book was in most regards, and wondered at this curious dissonance. This is absolutely a must for anyone who likes sprawling, pseudo-historic epics with wildly implausible interpersonal connections holding the whole together. Think The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay with less tragedy and more laughter and 50 years hence.I kind of forget what I wanted to say about this book, and/or maybe just conflated it with what others said about it last night. Instead of trying to resurrect those reflections, I'll share my dream casting of the book, given that it's supposed to be turned into a miniseries with Meryl Streep playing the mother and no one else yet announced:Samuel: Toby MaguireFaye: Meryl StreepGuy Periwinkle: John SlatteryBethany: Blake LivelyBishop: Alex PettyferJudge Brown: Jonathan BanksAlice: Meghan MullalyLaura Pottsdam: Anna KendrickPwnage: Danny McBrideGrandpa: Ian McKellen...more

title: Twilight of the Elites: America After Meritocracy
author: Hayes, Christopher L.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I like Mr. Hayes. This book, though his first, seemed to be apter fare than his more recent book about race--A Colony in a Nation--which rarely felt aI like Mr. Hayes. This book, though his first, seemed to be apter fare than his more recent book about race--A Colony in a Nation--which rarely felt additive and, though coming from a good place, mostly felt like "So what?" Not much contained therein that you couldn't cull from a far shorter and more poetic Coates or Alexander extract. But perhaps he was writing for a different audience? Oh well. This is more his bailiwick, it seems. A drum that needs beating, and with the hands of his ilk.This book was good mostly for its suggestions on what to do about the intractable problems it assays. So many of these books wax loghorrheicly about the past and then don't give up much about what their authors think about future fixes. Useful to know history, yes, but a bit of a bait and switch. Here, Hayes suggests that we tap into the disaffection of the liberal, educated demi-elites in the upper middle classes. I'm intrigued by the idea, though its failure to take root is hard to miss. Ultimately, I'm most impressed by his prescience with regard to the whole "fake news" phenomenon. Oh what an impossible hole that will be to climb out of is!...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is plenty charming, which, to me, seemed readily apparent from the title, as well as the premise. Our hero is a hip, sharp, octogenarian ManThis book is plenty charming, which, to me, seemed readily apparent from the title, as well as the premise. Our hero is a hip, sharp, octogenarian Manhattanite out on a stroll on New Year's Eve, 1985. During her excursion we are treated to her encounters with a true salmagundi of New Yorkers, during which she displays her Rabelaisian wit, her fearlessness and openness, and her fondness for reverie. The jaunt and the encounters are usually vehicles for exploring both the city as it looked in the 1980s and Boxfish's life, lurching ever upward from ingénue bluestocking to Peggy-Olsen-esque dominance of the advertising world through her confidence in her competence, male predominance therein notwithstanding. I'd give it a solid 3.5 stars--this was a warm and alluring book, but it did seem to lose some steam in its second half. I also began to note that, for all of the fluidity of her encounters with intimates, her conversations with strangers seemed wooden, staged in an ungainly way and lacking in verisimilitude. Still, I'd recommend it to anyone who has ached to see what a more high-born and pioneering Peggy Olsen might have looked like in her aged years....more

title: Homo Deus: A History of Tomorrow
author: Harari, Yuval Noah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you're a fan of "Big History" books, like Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies, that aim to comment upon human nature and propensitIf you're a fan of "Big History" books, like Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies, that aim to comment upon human nature and propensity using the entirety of history as their source materials, then I highly recommend this book. Harari takes our current predisposition toward and ability to take part in upgrading ourselves and commentates upon the frangibility of our underlying presumptions. Moreover, he skewers (what he considers to be) the naiveté of our thinking of ourselves as, variously: fundamentally different from animals, immune from obsolescence, or unique in a way that cannot (eventually) be replicated by the most mundane and thoughtless of automata and algorithms. I will say that it seemed like this (very impressive, very trenchant) book was weakest when Harari glibly asserted that we humans are mere aggregations of algorithms. Arguments often merely asserted--using "possibility" rather than "plausibility" as their main ballast--that it's not a matter of whether things as complex as language, emotion, and feeling can be *perfectly* reduced to algorithms, but when. From the purely legal/logical perspective--an industry whose perseverance, by dint of its reliance upon the ambiguity of language, would seem safer than most others--we would say that just because something is feasible, possible, or seems probable, this has no bearing on its eventual occurrence. But maybe that's just a lack of imagination on my part... or prideful antipathy toward anything that suggests my own jogtrot mundaneness ;)Either way, you should read this. It's pop-y and digestible, but it offers a really interesting and provocative perspective on our self-important species....more

title: Black Earth: The Holocaust as History and Warning
author: Snyder, Timothy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I decided to read this one because Timothy Snyder, a history professor at Yale, has been making a lot of high-profile, baleful predictions about TrumpI decided to read this one because Timothy Snyder, a history professor at Yale, has been making a lot of high-profile, baleful predictions about Trumpian autocracy. I kind of wanted to see how sensationalist he was in one of his books, and I'm always eager to try to use history as a way to understand the present.The thesis of the book comes most succinctly in its final pages:Gustaw Herling-Grudzinski, . . . wrote that 'a man can be human only under human conditions.' The purpose of the state is to preserve these conditions, so that its citizens need not see personal survival as their only goal. The state is for the recognition, endorsement, and protection of rights, which means creating the conditions under which rights can be recognized, endorsed, and protected. The state endures to create a sense of durability.Snyder focuses his attention for most of the book on elucidating the Nazi/Soviet destruction of the states that buffered them, and how this immiserated the majority of world Jewry scattered amongst them. The findings are really quite shocking; in addition to the barbarity that is never forgotten yet freshly sickening upon each renewed encounter, the differences in treatment between Jewish citizens of Denmark vs. Estonia, and those of France vs. those of Greece, are truly astounding. Snyder makes a really strong case for the idea, certainly not new, that Jews and other atomized, conspicuous minorities have only the bureaucracy and protection of the state when passions grow enflamed and institutions and customs break down.Perhaps this is why he is so choleric about the Trump presidency. While I agree that our mores are in complete shambles, and the heralded destruction of government gives me pause, I think (hope) that the Trump administration's incompetency and lack of coherent ideology will be enough to stave off the horrors of Nazi and Soviet atrocities, and anything resembling them in form if not size. But it's still so sad for our country. And really, the United States (and Britain, as it turns out) should stop applauding itself for intervening to stop the Holocaust. As Snyder mentions: by the time the doughboys landed at Normandy, most of the worst of it was over. Bureaucratic interposers are the unlikely heroes of this book, with diplomats from China, Japan, Portugal, Spain, Sweden and other less congratulated nations issuing sham passports that saved tens of thousands of lives. Meanwhile, in an America demonstrating its tendency toward miserliness and apathy to the travails of "others," our Jewish refugee policy was contemptible in the extreme. To wit:"Between July 1942 and June 1943, only 4,705 Jews were admitted to the United States. Fewer than the number of Warsaw Jews who were killed on a given day in Treblinka in the Summer of 1942."Perhaps if we spent less time congratulating ourselves we would understand our humane obligations better? Maybe if we understood how short we've fallen in past times of need, we would be more charitable, neighborly citizens of the world....more

title: Outline
author: Cusk, Rachel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A tactic familiar with professions as diverse as interrogators, lawyers, and psychologists is to resist the polite urge to fill silences with small taA tactic familiar with professions as diverse as interrogators, lawyers, and psychologists is to resist the polite urge to fill silences with small talk, to refrain from being your conversation partner's crutch, in the hope that the other guy will be sufficiently destabilized by the solecism to overcompensate with his own palaver. Interrogators hope to get access to secret, front-of-mind information; attorneys seek an uncharacterized narrative; psychologists aim to obtain insight into thought processes free from outside coaxing. Regardless of the outcome sought, the outpouring is meant to be purer and more precious than that which can be elicited through the normal foxtrot of conversation, where the give-and-take permits more time to regain one's footing, and to predict through experience where the conversation will go. For this reason, and perhaps for a sense of verisimilitude, this type of soliloquy is rare in novels. And while I’m not sure I would call “Outline” a novel, I’m not sure the distinction much matters. I see this book as an additional entry in a list of recent books that blur the boundaries between the short story collection and the novel, and do so with stunning prose, a masterful grasp of tone, and the impressive inventiveness required to gin up the cast of disparate, quirky, and realistic characters. A very interesting short read!...more

title: Imbeciles: The Supreme Court, American Eugenics, and the Sterilization of Carrie Buck
author: Cohen, Adam*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've always been intrigued by the case of Buck v. Bell. I did my undergraduate degree in history at UVA, and focused on American history in the South,I've always been intrigued by the case of Buck v. Bell. I did my undergraduate degree in history at UVA, and focused on American history in the South, specifically in the past Century. As someone who figured he would one day end up in law school, and Constitutional law seeming far more majestic in undergrad than in law school, I paid special attention to seminal American case law during my undergraduate studies. Carrie Buck, the plaintiff in this case, went to school at Venable Elementary School, a magnificent Palladian building where I often voted and more often passed on tippled walks to frat houses. Buck's story is somewhat incidental to the setting of this book, but it is tragic and important to know: after having been raped and gotten pregnant thereby, Ms. Buck was sterilized by the state of Virginia for having "loose morals" and for being "feeble minded." These were the rough categories (they also lumped in epileptics, a group whose stigmatization seems even more bizarre than the others in retrospect) that somehow defied substantive due process analysis over the years and resulted in 60,000-70,000 Americans being sterilized--most of them against their will, many of them without their knowledge--in the Twentieth Century in the United States. Carrie Buck wasn't even of low intelligence, and neither was the only daughter she ever had, but the justifications never really mattered to anyone who supported eugenics, a slippery pseudoscience that prospered in the United States and gave Hitler and his ilk some of their most reprehensible and destructive ideas about racial purity and inspired their histrionics over civilizational decline. I think my favorite feature of this book was the deserved savaging of Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr., a towering walrus-visaged elitist whom we are instructed to adulate as law students. Holmes' legal writing is held up as some sort of Olympian standard, and legal writing instructors practically swoon over the supposed brilliance of his prose. But I could never get it out of my head that he wrote this case--including its famous epigram that "three generations of imbeciles [was] enough"--and from this book I learned that he was not only proud of his role, but drew energy from it! What a paternalistic ghoul, and what an object case in the lack of justice afforded to the poor and marginalized, even from amongst the vaunted heroes of our judicial system....more

title: Destiny of the Republic: A Tale of Madness, Medicine and the Murder of a President
author: Millard, Candice
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's a word I'm looking for to describe the feeling that this book made me feel, and I suspect that it doesn't exist in any precise form in EnglishThere's a word I'm looking for to describe the feeling that this book made me feel, and I suspect that it doesn't exist in any precise form in English. The concept would be missing something or regretting not having had the chance to appreciate something that you've never encountered. I suppose I've felt this way about monuments--the Hanging Gardens of Babylon! the Colossus of Rhodes! the old Penn Station!--and about the ultrarevered and legendary--Abe Lincoln! Emma Goldman! Nikolai Tesla! Benjamin Franklin! Buddha!--but almost by definition it's difficult to have such feelings about people you didn't know were great. Cursory Google searches have yielded some promising contenders--the German Sehnsucht and probably most closely the Welsh Hiraeth--but I've yet to come across anything that captures the sensation of feeling deep regret over never having met or enjoyed the potential of someone you didn't know was great, someone like President James A. Garfield. This book is largely about him, his virtues and his seriously improbable rise to the presidency, and the demented, deluded maniac who laid waste to his great potential. Garfield was in the style of true reformist Radical Republicans, and one wonders if more like him were raised to the position whether we might have had an actual Reconstruction and a more equitable society in the modern era. At least as Millard portrays him, he is virtue crystallized, and an honorable, friendly, hale man at that. Aside from Garfield's rise and brief reign as president, the book is composed of explorations of Garfield's murderer's delusions, Alexander Graham Bell's quixotic attempts to deploy science to save the moribund Garfield, and pre-modern medicine's fumbling attempts at curing the ailing president, who likely would have lived had he been left to simply rest and not been surrounded by prodding, cleocentric mountebanks lousy with bacteria and positively covered in surgical goo. Blech! I often think of our country a century removed and think in terms of the differences that technology wrought, but this book does a great job of not only demonstrating how chaos and necessity spurred much of our medical development, but how unnecessary we once thought were safeguards on politicians' lives. Overall, a fascinating window into that murky, neglected time between the Civil War and the turn of the 20th Century....more
