title: A Colony in a Nation
author: Hayes, Chris
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a short book, and it sports some plaudits on its back cover from some serious heavyweights. So I guess I was expecting to be wowed a bit. I'm This is a short book, and it sports some plaudits on its back cover from some serious heavyweights. So I guess I was expecting to be wowed a bit. I'm not sure it got me there, but there were some interesting points, however briefly they were explored. The book uses the heuristic of The Colony (inhabited by racial minorities, most of whom are Black, and the poor, most of whom are minorities) and The Nation (where the rest of us live) to expose the "Two Americas" that we inhabit. The Colony receives order (submitting to the police state or risking death, even absent Constitutional authority) in return for giving profit (in Fergusson-type scenarios where fines for petty crimes subsidize the rich and white) to the Nation. None of this is a particularly fresh take, nor is this topic much enhanced by being interlarded with stories of Hayes' white-boy privilege, the only thing that really sets this book apart from the works of other, earlier (mostly Black) authors and social critics. So for most of the book, my assessment was "So what?" But Hayes redeems himself slightly toward the end. He explores some interesting ideas about American's love for retribution (compared with our European counterparts' more humane approaches) being rooted in our election of prosecutors and (ironically) our lesser tolerance for aristocracy (the idea being that Europeans began to think that more clement "aristocratic justice" should eventually be extended to all, while we in the colonies started with a perhaps admirable tradition of treating all malefactors to the stocks, even if the days of throwing the book at the rich with equal frequency are long past us). He also touches on the role of guns in maintaining racial hierarchies, and highlights America's incarceration mania by mentioning that if America were all white, we'd still have the 16th highest incarceration rate in the world, a simply staggering statistic given how suffused our society is with the doctrine of white supremacy.The problem is that he never really explores these interesting points! And why not? He only made it to 220 pages! Did he need to make a deadline or something?...more

title: Exit West
author: Hamid, Mohsin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One day while walking through Brooklyn's expansive Prospect Park, I happened upon a scattering of about 15-20 novels, discarded on and below a park beOne day while walking through Brooklyn's expansive Prospect Park, I happened upon a scattering of about 15-20 novels, discarded on and below a park bench. Some of them I had previously read and some of them sounded familiar. Among the latter group was Hamid's The Reluctant Fundamentalist, the sole book that I snatched up. It's a taut thriller related in one sitting; a short but suspenseful and well-crafted book exploring Western and non-Western values and power balances. It was entertaining if a bit over the top, and I was eager to see where the author went next. So when this book started generating a lot of buzz, I became intrigued. I reserved it from the library in an avalanche of other books, and until a friend whose taste I respect lauded it, I thought it would be one I just ended up returning to the library before fines began to accrue.In this, Hamid's next book, the author takes on the global refugee crisis, imbuing a story with humanity, uncertainty, and intrigue through a simple but effective science-fiction conceit. As with his previous book, this one is remarkably short. But unlike with his last book, I didn't think the economy of words or plot lines did the story any favors. This book felt a little thin on plot--like there could have been a hundred more pages exploring Nadia and Saeed's futures (not to mention 50 fewer of the tangential stories featuring unnamed characters whose place I'm still not sure is justified).Hamid is an excellent writer--poetic, truth-giving, compassionate. So this book was easy and enjoyable to read. I just felt like there was more to these stories than atmospheric descriptions of far-flung places and protean relationships....more

title: Stiff: The Curious Lives of Human Cadavers
author: Roach, Mary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Definitely enjoyable, if you're not squeamish. Law school debates, which strain in principle under the most fabulous of hypothetical facts, would ofteDefinitely enjoyable, if you're not squeamish. Law school debates, which strain in principle under the most fabulous of hypothetical facts, would often devolve into discussions of whether or not necrophilia should be illegal--not for anyone's prurient interest (as far as I know, that is!), but as a way of teasing out what interests we had in our bodies after we ceased to inhabit them, and whether this prohibition wasn't just the most culturally defensible (but ultimately incoherent) manifestation of society's exercise of its ability to police under the aegis of moral authority, even absent any identifiable victims. Inevitably this would dredge up conversations regarding what constitutes an injury/victim, and the whole conversation would be very illuminating (if you could stand the particular hypotheticals). More than anything, the reactions from genteel passersby were priceless. These reactions and several of my more hidebound friends' outright refusal to participate led me to assume that there was some predisposition animating our collective preoccupation with how we treat corpses. Cremation--an act of commission that destroys the body shortly after it becomes a corpse--seemed to be the preference of the secular and agnostic/atheist types, whereas plain old burial represented a more catholic (and big-C Catholic, it turns out--the process became much more popular following Vatican II's relaxation of prohibition on cremation, according to this book!) and traditional Western means of disposing of a body. I suppose I dismissed the preoccupation with burial remains and whatnot as a parochial tendency to want to elevate humanity above everything else, or as sentimental attachment to esteeming ourselves as more than matter and the electric impulses that animate us. I considered myself on the former end of this spectrum until reading this book. It made me squirm more than a few times due to the author's ribald take on death and the human body, but it turns out that even she had her limits, spare as they are in appearance. The author takes a very dry, humorous approach to death without seeming disrespectful, and covers a lot of ground, sharing interesting anecdotes and facts in the process. This irreverent tone regarding taboo topics seems to be her shtik, and I'd definitely give her other books a try....more

title: An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations
author: Smith, Adam
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So I guess this is the ur-text of capitalism, and I'm assuming it was all very impressive when it was published in the 1770s, but 200 years hence, in So I guess this is the ur-text of capitalism, and I'm assuming it was all very impressive when it was published in the 1770s, but 200 years hence, in what I can only hope is late-capitalism, it just felt a bit boring. Smith even apologizes at the outset for his discursion into tedium, and he's not just being humble here. It really is a tedious book, though the effort he put into marshaling evidence for his points is impressive, particularly given what was likely available to him at the time.Ultimately I was hoping for more insight into the normative underpinnings of Smith's philosophy, because I gather that capitalism as forecasted in this book is a bastardized version of what Smith advocated. Sadly, that was not what I found; I may need more of a tertiary study of his life to access that truth, as I'm still curious to see where his motivations really lay....more

title: Hillbilly Elegy: A Memoir of a Family and Culture in Crisis
author: Vance, J.D.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Update: I think I held back a bit because all sorts of people loved this book when it first came out, and there was a plausible (if unlikely) world inUpdate: I think I held back a bit because all sorts of people loved this book when it first came out, and there was a plausible (if unlikely) world in which J.D. Vance was a legit maverick and not some sociopathic hack, but I think that ship has sailed with his move to Ohio (post-venture-capital stint) and full embrace of Trump's worm-brained worldview. Don't waste your time with this complete prevarication of a book. Original :I've got mixed feelings about this, but that's a required caveat for books "of the moment," I suppose. "Hillbilly Elegy" is Vance's tale of growing up poor and backward among loving but unstable characters in the increasingly common areas sapped of opportunity and inhabited by white people. Vance's story is simply astounding, from the "hillbilly justice" that his grandparents meted out for the smallest affronts, to the myriad anecdotes of conspicuous consumption, domestic violence, drug use, and atrocious parenting, to Vance's miraculous ascent to the acme of American professionalism and the intellectual elite. And he's an able writer, too, avoiding the tortuous sentences to which lawyers are attracted (*ahem* and which so often infect the ramblings on this page!), writing in a clipped, pithy voice.But there were a few things that bugged me about this book. First, I am the product of a pretty stable and normal middle class suburban upbringing, so I really could not relate to much of his childhood or adolescence, which make up the vast bulk of this book. Accordingly, I took Vance at his word and didn't assume anything was embellished or exaggerated for effect. Yet our legal educations were about as similar as you could get--his third year of law school at Yale was my first year at Harvard, and I knew several people in his small class--yet the world that he describes seems different from anything I've been witness to either first-hand or close second-hand. The central motif of the book seems to be that "hillbillies" are hardworking, goodhearted individuals who have lost the ability to get by in today's society, and this has amplified their more destructive tendencies--violence, pride, fear of the foreign/new, substance abuse--to their collective detriment. Vance is the object lesson in why that is so sad, wasteful, and regretful--he holds himself out as someone for whom a rare permutation of fortunate factors conspired in his favor, rocketing him to the top of the legal and professional worlds (and look out for him in the next Ohio gubernatorial race, folks, because I bet Vance will bill himself as the anti-Trump Republican in the Evan McMullin mold), where he flourishes. There are a few different ways to take this: the cynic would say that Vance is exceptionally intelligent, and a gifted and charismatic writer the likes of which are hard to find, even in the vaunted gothic halls of Yale Law, while the optimist would think that there are probably so many people just like Vance yet not so lucky whom the poverty and cultural vices of Appalachia undercut unnecessarily, arbitrarily depriving the world of their considerable gifts. I would agree with both positions, but the conspicuous thing is that Vance spends so much of his time detailing how unprepared and untutored he is for the professional, academic, East Coast urban world. And I think he's laying it on a bit thick.At one point in the book Vance mentions that elite law schools such as Yale are never ending rat races: getting in, getting good grades, writing onto law , wangling prestigious clerkships, trying to plot your career out decades in advance. This, in sum and substance, is accurate. But it's less accurate in the specifics of his description. Vance tries to demonstrate the importance of law  by suggesting that there are certain jobs that won't even look at your application if you haven't made it on the Yale Law Journal, but that is almost verifiably untrue. Sure there might be some crusty old Eli judge who only hires Yale people and has a snooty preference for law  types, but even Supreme Court clerkships--the shiniest of prizes to which law students aspire--don't require that you were on law , nor even that you went to an Ivy League/top 10 school. There's another point at which Vance describes his confusion at the 15 different forms of cutlery at an unimaginably stuffy New Haven dinner thrown during the offensively decadent law firm courtship process, and laments that he didn't have any idea where to start or what to use for which dish, but I'm willing to wager that the vast majority of Yalies who don't remember this scene from Titanic wouldn't have a clue, either. Later in that same vignette he wonders what the office of career services meant when they instructed students to "act normal" during interviews, likely overlooking (or not understanding) that for folksy, "regular" guys like himself, he had nothing to worry about; that instruction was likelier for the legions of cerebrally brilliant but socially inept and off-putting folks pullulating at the elite law schools of the country, yet he turns it into another secret handshake to whose meaning he is not privy; it's just not the case. There's also the one time far earlier in the book when he casually drops that his mother and whichever man she was dating at the time pulled in over $100,000 per year between them, which is an ample amount on which to live, even with children, in all but the most expensive areas of the most expensive cities in this country, and must be practically royalty money in the area of Appalachia from which he hails. And finally, I could never get it out of my head that Vance's linkedin profile lists him as having worked in venture capital for the past year (in San Francisco if I recall correctly), one of the few lucrative paths for elite law students that is not easier to go down than a greased slide, indicating to me that his whole "I'm a rube, but I'm a smart one! I just needed some instruction that all these other kids seemed born with!" shtik is a bit disingenuous. I certainly have an upbringing, undergraduate experience, and post-college resume more conducive to private equity than he does, and arguably attended a law school that is likelier to send you down that acquisitive path, but I wouldn't have had the foggiest idea of how to go about becoming a speculative financier, and it's telling that all but the most calculating of law school peers forewent that path as well. A final point about authenticity: I was even surprised at the end of the book when Vance announced that he'd voiced the audiobook himself; he belabored his Southern twang and yet his voice for the hours I listened to it sounded as Mid-Atlantic as your average cosmopolitan newscaster.My second point is less a critique, because I don't think this is really up to Vance, but I feel like this book is being read by white liberals who are eager to "understand" why Trump won the election (or at least to be able to say they've read this book and to push for more complex explanations of disaffected white America, which was the goal of yours truly), and less by the individuals whom it was designed to paternalistically admonish--Vance's fellow hillbillies. There's a lot that I don't like about the book--it takes a far too sanguine view on things like white Americans' reasons for disliking President Obama (unstated but impossible to miss was this future-Ohio-gubernatorial-candidate-friendly takeaway: it has almost nothing to do with race!), and it gives manipulators like Fox News and prosperity gospel churches far too much of a pass considering how much of the book is dedicated to describing a warped, unhealthy culture. But it is written by an insider (the above criticisms and skepticism notwithstanding), and it does charge these people with taking seriously the deterioration of their lives and with recognizing the etiology of these various pathologies as of their own making. I think it could be very useful, but I would imagine it's being read far more frequently in Brooklyn than in Kentucky. Overall I'm glad I read it, interested to see what trajectory Vance's life takes, and eager to hear what others thought....more

title: Dark Money: The Hidden History of the Billionaires Behind the Rise of the Radical Right
author: Mayer, Jane
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Between the influence of the Kochs brilliantly elucidated by this book and the "stealthcare" bullshit pulled by that neckless turtle Mitch McConnell tBetween the influence of the Kochs brilliantly elucidated by this book and the "stealthcare" bullshit pulled by that neckless turtle Mitch McConnell this week, how can anyone really think that republican democracy still serves the interests of The People? The Founders made a lot of assumptions, many of them incompatible with the 21st Century reality that we inhabit. Namely: * That the citizenry could count on media of repute to champion and effectively disseminate truth* That citizens would not stand for corrupt or inept politicians, no matter their sympathies to the ends those politicians aimed to advance; and * That good ideas would prevail on their own merits, not on the wealth or standing of those espousing them. I'm of the opinion that we are too oversaturated with ideological news sources, too mired in bureaucracy to effectively deal with corruption and ineptitude, and too polarized by the two-party system, respectively, to cope with serious threats to democracy that the Kochs--ultimate fagins of malversation--present. So on that count, this book was depressing. Paraphrasing my friend Christine: this book was great, but in the end it just made me really angry without much of an outlet for that frustration.But it did get me thinking.First--why are these moneyed interests so viscerally anti-Obama? Only in myth is the Democratic party anything but the handmaiden of corporate America. Sure, Democrats might slap the absolute worst offenders with effectively meaningless fines for actions that in any peer nation would constitute high crimes, but the stock market has soared under Democrats, and the rich have reaped the vast majority of it. I would like to think it's something more than racism, but that also doesn't account for the Koch's militarization behind Trump and against Clinton. And I think simply swapping sexism for racism in the equation is a bit too simplified. But I'm baffled by the business community's desire to leave Trump in power instead of a relatively moderate, corporation-friendly--not to mention temperamentally stable--candidate like Clinton. Could it be that the Kochs and their constituency have lost it? That their emotions carry the day? Unclear, but unanswered by this otherwise trenchant text. Second--one of the things that this book chronicles so well was its delineation of the Kochs' role in legitimating marginal libertarian thoughts through little more than tons of pressure and money. Conservatives have achieved significant success through their use of indispensable funds and brinksmanship to first present, then normalize, radical ideas. Far from aping this strategy, Democrats have responded in typically feckless fashion, glancing nervously to an ever rightward-shifting middle for their choices of policies and bugbears. Part of this is an ingrained, generational fear of being labeled "anti-American" and "communist," holdovers that will hopefully die off with the expiration of the old guard who still search beneath the bed at night for Joseph McCarthy. But it made me wonder: what could a left-leaning plutocrat propose in order to re-center and make more progressive the current narrative for Democrats in politics? One thing that most people seem to agree on is that the Democrats lost the 2016 Election in large part (if not primarily) because they failed to address or offer solutions to the economic marginalization of the poor and middle classes, especially among more-likely-to-vote rural whites. If these people are really so desperate, are we still inhabiting a political climate in which it is taboo to embrace class consciousness and wealth redistribution? If these people were desperate enough to vote for a clownish charlatan like Donald Trump, are they really going to sour on a politician who boldly admits that she supports, nay demands, a strong redistribution of wealth? That healthcare should be paid for by the rich of this country? That the richest only get to hold on to their wealth and power because we have forbeared from gibbeting them and taking their stuff, which is the historical way of things when the hardworking poor and middle classes are pushed to the brink by greedy and unfeeling plutocrats?This is all probably too Jacobin for an America where Donald Trump could be elected president, but part of me believes the timing is more opportune than ever. George Soros--if you're reading, call me!...more

title: The Moth Presents All These Wonders: True Stories About Facing the Unknown
author: Burns, Catherine
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My friend Brendan has this saying, something he calls the "Grand Unifying Theory of New York." It's a bit grandiloquent and certainly misnamed, but thMy friend Brendan has this saying, something he calls the "Grand Unifying Theory of New York." It's a bit grandiloquent and certainly misnamed, but the logic is sound. Essentially, he maintains that you're totally free to cry in public in New York, because of some combination of 1) people are accustomed to emotional outbursts in public here; 2) we're all too rushed and self-absorbed to really notice anyone else; and 3) it's hard to spot people you know amidst the throngs of humanity. This book allowed me to test the "theory" out this week, because I found myself sobbing on my subway commutes, reading these short and incredibly poignant stories of loss, joy, disappointment, healing, and just unfathomable grace. This book, like few others, exudes humanity. Nearly every story--and there are plenty; they are short--conveys so much about a person or a particular experience, and does so extremey evocatively. This is a book that I will be giving out as a gift for years to come, and The Moth is a source that I hope I'm just beginning to get acquainted with. Read this and remind yourself how numinous the human experience can be....more

title: The New Tsar: The Rise and Reign of Vladimir Putin
author: Myers, Steven Lee
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So this book was informative, but it felt like it was told at a remove. I suppose this is to be expected of a secretive and powerful man, but it read So this book was informative, but it felt like it was told at a remove. I suppose this is to be expected of a secretive and powerful man, but it read like an elaborate retelling of tons of journalism and public information. It's odd that we know so much less about our current leaders in this age of supposed transparency than we knew of so many of our more prolix forebears.I guess I was dissatisfied that this book, in spite of its bulk, failed to divulge much about Putin's mindset or disposition. People glibly call Putin a 'psycho,' which seems part based in fact, part based in admiration, and more than a little bit a holdover from Cold War animosities and distrust of Russian counterbalance to Euro-American hegemony. But aside from his desire to maintain absolute power and his childish need for approval from the West, I'm not sure we were given that, so much as we were presented with the facts and encouraged to make our own conclusions, not that much different from before grappling with this 600-page tome.Maybe that's what good journalists do--Steven Lee Myers was, after all, the NYT bureau correspondent for the Moscow desk--but it felt detached. I gather that The Man Without a Face: The Unlikely Rise of Vladimir Putin is pretty good; maybe that will scratch this itch?...more

title: Dark Matter
author: Crouch, Blake*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have this creeping fear that I might be a hoarder in the making. My smallish Brooklyn apartment doesn’t allow for much accumulation, but I have cramI have this creeping fear that I might be a hoarder in the making. My smallish Brooklyn apartment doesn’t allow for much accumulation, but I have crammed it full of all sorts of unnecessary raiment and gewgaws that I sometimes have to pause and purge. This gives me a week or so of calm, but then I just find uses for the new space I’ve freed up. Books are part of this pathology, and I have a pile of library books at the foot of my bed, some of which I have renewed more than 20 times from the Brooklyn and Manhattan Public Libraries. Why do I keep getting new books to the neglect of these ones gathering dust on my floor? I don’t really know. A normal reaction to this accumulation might be “I should read or return them before I collect any others!” but my reaction is “I don’t have any more space to fit physical books, but my iPhone has all of this space and the libraries’ websites just make it so easy…” so I end up downloading a ton of books that way. I listen to audiobooks on double speed, so I make short work of them, but there are definitely some books that lie moldering in my eBook “pile”—apologies to Don DeLillo’s “Zero K.” Anyway, given that there’s no downside to collecting these books—you can’t even be charged overdue fees! They automatically expire after 14 or 21 days!—the worst of my acquisitiveness occurs at these moments.In one of these binges, I came across a book that seemed to be popping up quite a bit in others’ s and had been displayed prominently in a number of visually alluring bookstore windows. But other than that credential, I didn’t have much reason to believe that it was good or that I would like it.But this book was so good! It is taut and interesting, clever without spiraling into metaphysical minutiae, has a protagonist whom you’re rooting for, and touches on some really powerful questions, like what would it be like to have taken the path less traveled? What are the tradeoffs of ambition and cultivating a personal life, and what lengths you would go for—and what you might sacrifice—in order to protect the ones you love. To do all of these in a highly conceptual theoretical physics milieu (I will spare you my amateurish concerns and observations about the relationship between human nature and observation and the fabrication of multiple universes) is all the more impressive.Bravo, Blake Crouch!...more

author: Cudahy, Brian J.

review: This was fine. I saw it as a recommendation in the comments section of a blog I follow on NYC transportation--Second Avenue Sagas--and thought it mighThis was fine. I saw it as a recommendation in the comments section of a blog I follow on NYC transportation--Second Avenue Sagas--and thought it might be an interesting read. What I am always looking for is discussion about the building of individual lines, the drama that ensues, the compromises brokered, etc., etc. Unfortunately, these narratives tend to proceed in more macroscopic fashion, addressing things like budgets, the IRT/BMT/IND, and entire boroughs, rather than decisions that went into individual lines/stops.Oh well. For my money (or library card, as it were), I think 722 Miles: The Building of the Subways and How They Transformed New York by Clifton Hood is the superior NYC subway monograph. I did finally find out the convoluted system by which the subways signal each other and prevent crashes, but my quest to understand the genesis of the G train (aka the "IND Crosstown Line") persists!...more

author: McBride, James*

review: 3.5 strong stars, with the balance tilting toward 4. This was a right enjoyable picaresque, telling the story of a quirky and wily John Brown, who rai3.5 strong stars, with the balance tilting toward 4. This was a right enjoyable picaresque, telling the story of a quirky and wily John Brown, who raided Harper's Ferry in the lead up to the Civil War. The narrator is a Black boy of twelve who spends the greater portion of the novel in a state of bemused ambivalence about the quixotic adventure.Probably my favorite part of this book was its folksy Southern sayings, whose amassing is all the more remarkable given that the author was raised by his white, Jewish mother in Red Hook, about an hour's walk away from where I live in Brooklyn. A sampling of my favorites:* "His hair was so nappy you could light a match on it"* "She was so pretty I wouldn't kick her out of bed for eating crackers"* "He was jangling so much that he sounded like a walking hardware store"* "She had a face that could make a train leave its track"* "Her breath smelled so bad it could stop a clock"* And in one single paragraph he not only describes a woman as "pretty as a peeled onion" but also "calm as lettuce"... whatever that means.Brown is so headstrong and confident of the righteousness of his plan, not only for the country but for the Black folk who might get killed in the process, that I thought that this tale might serve as an object lesson in the perils of white saviorhood. It reads like an affectionate but quizzical look at this strange man, at least up until the tender last scenes.Overall the characters are well developed and the action is spritely and entertaining. I enjoyed this one a lot....more

review: Got this on a recommendation from a good friend who tends to share my sense of humor, love of puns, and affinity for cultural quirks. This was definitGot this on a recommendation from a good friend who tends to share my sense of humor, love of puns, and affinity for cultural quirks. This was definitely enjoyable, and had many of the best, most humorous aspects of The Sellout. I think I may have been handicapped a bit by the fact that I wasn't really familiar with the legends of Theseus on which this book is based. Because of this, interactions and scenes that may have been exact analogues ended up seeming a bit spatchcocked, and the book caromed around Philadelphia and New York with an almost dreamlike cadence--transitions were largely elided, characters would enter and interact with undue familiarity, and the drama vacillated between the mundane and the bizarre. Overall a cute, humorous book with some grade-A wordplay and Yiddish, but lacking in certain key narrative areas....more

title: Landslide: LBJ and Ronald Reagan at the Dawn of a New America
author: Darman, Jonathan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So, I guess the premise of this book was that both LBJ and Reagan saw themselves as fatidic heroes in trying times, but rather than save the nation asSo, I guess the premise of this book was that both LBJ and Reagan saw themselves as fatidic heroes in trying times, but rather than save the nation as each set out to do, they overpromised and oversimplified, kindling the passions of modern partisans unproductively. Their opposite messianic narratives are ones we know well: Reagan's, that government is the bane of freedom and enemy of prosperity; and Johnson's, that government checks the baser instincts of man and is the only force potent and restrained enough to inaugurate peace and prosperity. It's an intriguing premise, but one that mostly just bookends the bulk of the book, which seems to be a narrative of the psyches leading these men to the presidency and the internal tribulations that rankled their ambitions. In other words, it was informative, but it perhaps overpromised. I liked this book, and it sure as hell made me want to read an unbiased book about Reagan, much as this will probably earn me the same stinkeye on the subway that I reserve for people wearing "Make America Great Again" hats (or really any red hats these days). I'm both more impressed with LBJ (my god he accomplished a lot!) and more jaded for learning of his machinations (the idea that Democrats had to embroil the nation in Asian land wars with Communists just to parry claims that they were Red sympathizers strikes me, albeit in hindsight, as so ridiculous and so sad, given the toll it took on our country and on the browner peoples of the globe; and it makes me admire Obama that much more for undertaking healthcare without a rattling saber. And the way LBJ treated that loyal gay aide was really shameful), and disgusted and intrigued by Reagan (he used to be a New Deal Democrat? And why are we talking about Mike Pence calling his wife "mother" when Reagan called Nancy "Mommy"? *shudder*). Like so many pre-2016-Election books, this one ends on a hopeful note that seems almost comical in hindsight. This is literally the last paragraph of the book:The problem for today’s political system—and it is an existential one—is that people no longer believe those myths. To fix its broken politics, today’s America needs new stories. Or, perhaps it just needs a new version of an old one: the shared version that Johnson and Reagan discarded in the course of their 1000 days. The old consensus vision of Roosevelt and Kennedy contained lasting wisdom that today’s leaders would do well to adopt. In that world view, politicians had to be deeply realistic and humble when making promises for the future. For they knew that the future never turned out exactly the way it’s going to. But they also had to have the courage to tell people that though government would never be able to solve all of its people’s problems, it had a sacred obligation to try. That old vision could serve America well in an often frightening new century. The answer to our problems may come from a leader who brings such a simple message. It is a message that neither Reagan nor Johnson had much use for, but that the story of both of their lives confirms: what lies ahead of us is not the certain promise of utopia, but the infinite possibilities of life itself.*Sigh* One can hope we'll sober up before it's too late.All in all, an informative and interesting book, even if it was more underappreciated historical summary than anything else....more

title: Alexander Hamilton
author: Chernow, Ron
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This gets a solid 3.5 stars, but more for effort than for objectivity or verve. I feel obligated to mention how I came to this book. I did my undergraThis gets a solid 3.5 stars, but more for effort than for objectivity or verve. I feel obligated to mention how I came to this book. I did my undergraduate studies at the University of Virginia, which Thomas Jefferson founded and which ranked as one of the three accomplishments that Jefferson deemed worthy of constituting his epitaph (he didn't even list "President"!). The love is no less genuine or intense going the other way, either, with the school's unofficial sobriquet being "Mr. Jefferson's University." You could characterize the adoration as distortive, as honest conversations about the man's slaveholding and relationship with Sally Hemings were frowned upon in a Victorian way, such honest accounts being viewed as somehow "untoward." Gradually over my years in Charlottesville I adopted the approach that Jefferson's sins did not cancel out his accomplishments, but nor did his accomplishments expiate his sins. But as with my approach to the Catholic religion that I inherited but disavowed, though my appreciation for the original became complicated by nuance, my hostility to the enemy of the thing I originally revered never much abated. Hamilton being Jefferson's well-known bête noire, I've always been suspicious of the man. Throw in a wildly popular musical whose ubiquitous approbation among liberals beggars credulity and my hefty skepticism for the capitalism, monarchism, and corporatism with which he imbued our early country and, well: that's a sizable deficit of antipathy to overcome. So that was my predisposition before starting the book."Hamilton" is shopped as a biography, but veering as it did into hagiography at times, it felt less even-handed than most biographies I've come across. Chernow seems to me a small-"c" conservative, and that is only lightly occluded by the thrust of the text. Chernow repeatedly displays a clear reverence for incrementalism and tradition over Jacobin impulses, and this flatters Hamilton's approach to politics. There were moments where my jaw dropped at Chernow's pearl-clutching, particularly regarding the French Revolution. At one point, Chernow approvingly repeats a quote by William Pitt the Younger, stating that the beheading of the French monarch during the Reign of Terror was "the foulest and most atrocious act the world has ever seen." I gasped at the myopia of the statement, knowing little but sufficient enough of what gory mischief European monarchs themselves have commissioned in all of their majesty throughout the centuries; reactions such as these gave the impression that the author doubts whether the French Revolution was really worth "all the fuss," history's consensus notwithstanding. But it's not just Chernow's approval of Hamilton's critical influence on the formation of the modern neoliberal regime that seems less than objective. Slanders and calumnies against Hamilton are dismissed almost peremptorily in a way that seems wildly inconsistent. For example, despite knowing, as we all do, that Hamilton died for his bastardry-informed inability to let stand any affront to his honor, Chernow mentions a rumor voiced by a certain Nicholson that Hamilton spirited away 100,000 pounds sterling in British banks while Treasury Secretary; curious then, that although Hamilton knew of this slur, he apparently never did anything to disprove it or "demand satisfaction" [challenge its accuser to a duel]. Yet Chernow just dismisses it as "ridiculous." Overall, Chernow tries to paint a nuanced picture of Hamilton, and one gets the sense that his obfuscations and unevenness are not deliberate, yet when he insists that Hamilton loathed the slave trade and "only" bought *a few* slaves for his brother- and sister-in-law, one wonders how truly critical he has been of all of Hamilton's other faults and inconsistencies.Hamilton seemed by all accounts brilliant, as capable a leader of men as Washington and even more of a polymath than Jefferson (whose was certainly dulled by this account, slanted against him as this work may have been). I truly have never felt less adequate for my age than upon learning that this bastard from the Caribbean was aide-de-camp to George Washington at age 25 and is still one of the most storied politicians in American history, despite having died in his 40s! But this book falls victim to that peculiarly (or perhaps acutely?) American foible of treating our Founding Fathers like heroes, rather than the deeply flawed, complex humans that they were. In a way, reading about fake news in the National Gazette (Jefferson said that anything was made suspicious, merely by dint of appearing in a newspaper!), and about partisan recriminations of the most vile character made our present situation that much more palatable and, well... normal. Not because I think we'll get through it (ha! who knows?), but because we've always been a nation led by self-interested, flawed men, and this is not necessarily much, much worse, just a different variety of bad. By casting the Founding as a time of pure virtue, selflessness, truth, honor and country above self, and unity above all, we do unnecessary disservice to our modern selves. So: let us embrace the flaws in our forebears with the same tenacity with which we bemoan them in the present!...more

review: This was way too short! But it was very enjoyable. As my law school roommate deracinates himself to briefly join the cause of the native people of NorThis was way too short! But it was very enjoyable. As my law school roommate deracinates himself to briefly join the cause of the native people of North Dakota, the contrast between egalitarian, Earth-centered communal living and the infrastructure we require (read: want) for the rest of it could not be more apparent. This book might have been a bit too hamfisted with the evolutionary biology at times, but it really made me ponder how unnatural it must be for us as a species to be so isolated, greedy, divided, and fractious. One thing's for certain: Junger has an amazing voice for reading this. Went by too quickly for sure....more

author: Lorde, Audre
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love it when poets shift to non-fiction--the styles invariably end up blending together in such a pleasant and informative way. This was maybe the fI love it when poets shift to non-fiction--the styles invariably end up blending together in such a pleasant and informative way. This was maybe the first collection of Lorde words I've read, though I have been exposed to her stuff in more episodic form in undergrad and law school classes. I really vibed with Lorde this time--she's so inclusive, so compassionate, and she demands as much as one can give from anyone who has anything to give. And for her commentary on what might otherwise be called "self-loathing" or incorporation of hostile, empowered groups' standards into our own psyches, leading to less compassion rather than more compassion shown to those with whom we are marginalized, her insights are aces.I had a brief moment of self-doubt when I rolled up to the gym today and started listening to this. But I figure if you can't get your mind and body fit at the same time, or if there are places where you think your feminism and queer theory are inappropriate, then you're not doing it right....more

title: Testosterone Rex: Myths of Sex, Science, and Society
author: Fine, Cordelia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For the most part, this short little book was excellent. It was droll, approachable, and informative.The basic premise--Fine uses the metonymy "TestosFor the most part, this short little book was excellent. It was droll, approachable, and informative.The basic premise--Fine uses the metonymy "Testosterone Rex" throughout--is that testosterone is really not so all-important as we often assume. Looking at the vast differences between men and women, whether value-laden or not, scientists, anthropologists, sociologists, gender theorists have all concluded that testosterone is a hell of a hormone, and must be responsible for spurring all of those masculine qualities in men that lead to these disparities. But Fine trenchantly demonstrates that in almost every situation, the case is overpleaded for the role of testosterone. Rather, we as a society (or really all liberal democratic societies) have decided that--unlike for race, say--there are differences between men and women. So naturally, some of them are going to be expressed in ways that work out to benefit men for the most part in some cases, and women in others. And Fine doesn't disagree with this idea, she just thinks it is wildly overblown, and that far more often than not, "boys will be boys" and testosterone and masculine entrepreneurialism are scapegoats for what amounts to our refusal to deal with the (considerable) remnants of sexism in society.Recommended for anyone with daughters and for anyone who suspects that intrinsic differences between the sexes can't add up to our sex disparities and seeks proof thereof....more

title: A Gentleman in Moscow
author: Towles, Amor*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was pretty excellent. Amor Towles, improbably an American man from our contemporary era, wrote this engaging and colorful tale of a deposed countThis was pretty excellent. Amor Towles, improbably an American man from our contemporary era, wrote this engaging and colorful tale of a deposed count in Soviet Moscow, confined to a lavish hotel over the course of decades yet privy to the Western World's intrigues through various invented personages and dispatches. The main character is charming enough--a gentleman in the most proper sense of the world, equal parts noblesse oblige and fustian foppery--the type of man who would be neither interested in nor offended by proletarian claims hostile to his property and class interests, yet who might drop his monocle in indignation if an oyster were served with Sancerre instead of Sauterne. Through the prism of this man's life--a narrator who despite his stuffiness is charming, honorable, and amenable to change when necessary--we glimpse his attempts to cope with a changed world and the embarrassment of deposition from an august perch. We see his tender relationships blossom, then struggle under the weight of whispery Communism, meddlesome apparatchiks lurking in every corner and wider geopolitical narratives coloring what are otherwise ordinary, warm relationships. It's written very well, and it's engaging throughout. This book is The Remains of the Day, were it written from the Lord's or the Second World's point of view, with just as much simmering drama and beautiful prose. Highly recommended....more

title: The Little Book of Hygge: The Danish Way to Live Well
author: Wiking, Meik
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Last week I took a break from work to hold forth on a group text about which one of our friends has the most hygge ("hoo-guh") life. It was my friend Last week I took a break from work to hold forth on a group text about which one of our friends has the most hygge ("hoo-guh") life. It was my friend whose essence is her green velour sweatpants, her love of curling up on couches with yams and mulled wine or port, and her cozy apartment in which she lives alone. One of my other friends who--pregnant with a 2 year old, a working husband and working as an editor for the Op Ed section of the NYT--has much less free time than I do stated "I can't believe you're reading that book" on said group text. But she was not there for the cozy weekend 14 of us spent in the Catskills a few months before, warming by the fire, playing Hammerschlagen, drinking mulled wine and cider to excess, yodeling Enigma's "Return to Innocence" and telling the same inside jokes we have been polishing for the past decade. This was also the weekend in which we all became privy to and talked endlessly about this new Danish concept about which New Yorkers were momentarily astir. But having read this adorable little book, I am at a loss for a riposte to my friend's accusatory statement. Sometimes a book does not need to be finished just because it is short and whimsical and cute. This is one of those books.The Catskills weekend is what I might call "hygge." This book is an exploration of a putatively Danish concept which, as close as I can tell, basically approximates our concept of "coziness," if we talked about coziness like, 200x per day and spent a psychotic amount of time trying to shape our lives, activities, and physical spaces to be as cozy as possible. The book insists that there is some important difference between "hygge" and "coziness" (ditto its various Scandinavian and German variants), but having sifted through this cute book, I don't know that I buy that. As others have noted, this book could have been about 20 pages long. Candles, welfare state, bikes, Christmas, comfort food, shelter from treacherous weather, and being around loved ones. Sounds nice, yes? Well I've also gone and spoiled the ENTIRE book for you. Go take that $20 and buy a candle instead.This would make a good stocking stuffer or coffee table book, but you can probably skip it otherwise....more

review: This was a solid, character-driven book that really captured the poignancy and immediacy of being young. I recognized a lot of my own past in the protThis was a solid, character-driven book that really captured the poignancy and immediacy of being young. I recognized a lot of my own past in the protagonist of Wolitzer's tableau--finding that I could overcome social awkwardness through humor, the alienation of the boring suburb and conventional home life, the barriers and resentments that disparities in wealth can cultivate in otherwise healthy friendships. But I also could not have related less to her protagonist's primary fault, of thinking it easier to warm by the light of others' fires than to make the effort to kindle her own.Overall very enjoyable and comprehensive. A serious improvement on the recent Murakami that I read, even if there were some spots that felt a bit thin or unrealistic. I'll be reading other works by this author, I'm sure....more

title: Hall of Small Mammals: Stories
author: Pierce, Thomas

review: Kind of a stinker. Surprising, too, given that I found this on the list with “Prodigals,” “The Mothers,” and “Homegoing” (and because its author was iKind of a stinker. Surprising, too, given that I found this on the list with “Prodigals,” “The Mothers,” and “Homegoing” (and because its author was in the same MFA cohort with the author of my favorite of the bunch: “Prodigals”). Toward the end I started to realize that all of the stories seem loosely connected, all taking place in or around Atlanta, and involving many of the same proper nouns. Already disenchanted with the book, I wanted to check in to see whether this was something that elevated the book and was responsible for some charm I had been ignorant of, so I looked at its s on goodreads. Many of them gestured to the interconnections, but none really dwelt on them, laudatory as the s tended to be. I guess it’s hard with a book of short stories, but not a one really stuck out to me. Pierce harnesses something authentically Southern, but I was left feeling like he chose to end each story at an intentionally pregnant moment just for the provocation of the act. The stories themselves lacked the magnetism that engrossing short story collections invariably possess....more

review: This was by turns breathtaking and piercing, a stunningly intricate and perceptive group of short stories. I picked it up because it ended up on a lisThis was by turns breathtaking and piercing, a stunningly intricate and perceptive group of short stories. I picked it up because it ended up on a list of "best writers under 35," featuring Homegoing and The Mothers, books which I'd enjoyed for the most part, but whose young authors' promise intrigued me more than the stories. This book did both.I was tempted to remove a star because the stories all started off strong but often ended in a way that seemed abrupt or cryptic, never with the surprise twist or satisfying payoff that characterize so much of my favorite short story writings. But the writing in this I found so virtuoso that I couldn't begrudge the star, particularly given that it's a debut.This is a short, eminently consumable read that I'd feel comfortable recommending to anyone. title: Plutocrats: The Rise of the New Global Super Rich and the Fall of Everyone Else
author: Freeland, Chrystia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I ended up really liking this book, but it took a little while. As others have mentioned, the first 1/3 or so reads like a “Lifestyles of the Rich andI ended up really liking this book, but it took a little while. As others have mentioned, the first 1/3 or so reads like a “Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous” and is devoted to explaining the trappings of extreme plutocracy and the ways by which the purseproud rich have bent the machinery of government and the economy to their wills and fortunes. Freeland, herself a Harvard graduate and a Rhodes Scholar—undoubtedly the single likeliest pedigree for shameful self-promotion and aggrandizement—does not waste an opportunity to mention an academic credential, nor a peak salary earned, nor a second-home-maintained’s location in Cote d’Azur, Southhampton, or Belgravia. But the book redeems itself in its latter parts. Freeland ably demonstrates the maudlin lamentations of the persecuted rich, who imagine themselves besieged by business friendly regimes such as the Obama administration. She explores what are, amazingly, sincere beliefs held by moderate and democratic stalwarts such as Chuck Schumer (ugh) and Mike Bloomberg (ugh), who earnestly believe that “overregulation” of the financial industry is inimical to the prosperity of places like NYC and the United States. And she concludes with the cautionary tale of Venice, once the most prosperous and populous of Europe’s cities, which launched to prominence on the strength of inclusive economic policies and stagnated on a retrenchment of opportunity. It sounds like we’re in for some long-term decay unless we get our policies and priorities in order. ...more

title: To Make Men Free: A History of the Republican Party
author: Richardson, Heather Cox
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this book in physical form while my audiobook was The New Tsar: The Rise and Reign of Vladimir Putin, so I really felt like I was consuming botI read this book in physical form while my audiobook was The New Tsar: The Rise and Reign of Vladimir Putin, so I really felt like I was consuming both the past and the future of the Republican party! Joking (?) aside, this book was really informative. It traces the disconnect between the imperative of equality mandated by the Declaration of Independence and the unequivocal defense of property and class fissures enshrined in the Constitution, and how the parties have tried out various forms of compromise between these two mostly incompatible visions of America. The Republican Party, the Party of Lincoln, was founded (according to Richardson) in support of values of meritocracy, equality, and anti-plutocracy--essentially a party against the symbolism and actual power of the benighted Plantation South. Unfortunately, shortly after prevailing in the Civil War when those ideals were put to the test and prevailed, the GOP lost its way and became bedfellows with big business. Things carried on pell-mell until Teddy Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson sparred over which party was heir to the aegis of progressive politics. The concept belonged to no one, but when the revanchist Taft wing had their bid sundered by Teddy Roosevelt and his progressivism, and when their Democratic opponent had progressive tendencies, the GOP began solidifying its image as the party against progress, though I'm sure that even then they had better branding. Although some progressive notes were sounded in the interim, the first half of the 20th Century was claimed by Democrats; ultimately, the hidebound "Taft Wing" of the party wrested control, leading to the Movement Conservatism that has afflicted us and the world over the past few decades. The true hero of this book seems to be Eisenhower. Eisenhower represented perhaps the last great hope for sanity from a party opposing what experience and peer states have proven to be the superior system, and the rest has been a shambles of manipulation and cynicism. He accepted the New Deal as not only popular but good, and seemed a true statesman, capable of putting country over self and especially over party, a skill of which the modern incarnation of the GOP is wholly bereft. In addition to his baleful warnings about the Military Industrial Complex, Eisenhower realized, we are told, that . . . economically dispossessed people were natural targets for political and religious extremists. They could easily be manipulated by a strong leader to back a cause--any cause--that promised to resurrect a world in which they had enjoyed prosperity and cultural significance. Such extremism had been dangerous enough in the hands of the Nazis, but 1945 gave quite specific shape to Eisenhower's fears. The atomic bomb . . . changed the meaning of human conflict.Richardson's coverage of Sen. McCarthy also rings bells for those who lament our modern political dysphoria: Party that they could advance an agenda by use of fiction, as long as that fiction spoke to Americans' fears and could be kept from pen scrutiny. McCarthy's demagoguery gave Taft's die-hard followers a new style. He yelled; he made crazy accusations; he leaked fragments of truth that misrepresented reality; he hectored and badgered. He got in the faces of people who mattered. His antics got attention. Although a senator--about as inside a job as one can get--he posed as an outsider taking on what he insisted was a corrupt system. Claiming his opponents were bent on destroying America, he promised to defend it.And more presaging of Trump:Conservatives' anti-intellectualism became a strength. That their rhetoric did not address reality mattered less than that it seemed to offer a comforting route to bring back the prosperity and security voters associated with an idyllic American past.There were some periods where I would have been proud to have called myself a Republican, but the influence of business interests seems to have been too strong on the whole. Principled past leaders aside, the current incarnation of the GOP is exactly where the past fifty years has intended for it to be. The grand experiment begun by Lincoln has failed spectacularly. May it die a quick and decisive death....more

In this title he really captures the fire of youthful idealism and the cynicism that strips it away. How is it that the jaundice of maturity makes the few who retain their principles seem quaint and pathetic? What is it to endure the series of barely noticeable rationalizations and capitulations that lead us into a workable adult life? Is the coward or the demagogue to be more pitied, and is our answer governed by something higher or is it just the normativity that stems from the more common recourse? title: The Underground Railroad
author: Whitehead, Colson*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book's brutality precedes it, and I sometimes wonder why white people such as myself read books like this, or watch movies that portray the same.This book's brutality precedes it, and I sometimes wonder why white people such as myself read books like this, or watch movies that portray the same. It would take an extraordinary (and in my opinion: willing) ignorance to fail to grasp the horrors of slavery, the inhumanity whose cast it lent to all involved in the grim spectacle. So unless you are among this benighted group, I wonder at the fascination; there are myriad other motivations for reading this book, but I worry that there is also some kernel of holocaust-as-entertainment here. For my part, I read it because it's now the fodder for a third book club meeting (this one is for work), and because my buddy brought it along to Cuba. It made for some strange beach reading, but the story moves swiftly. I would say my favorite parts were Cora's inner dialogue where she broke with expectations--about how to handle a bully, or whether some white woman had judged her correctly, etc. And as for takeaways, I guess I didn't realize the extent to which Railroad "workers" imperiled their lives and their families' lives by dint of their involvement. Nor did I realize that they were breaking the law by being involved. Not quite apples-to-apples, but it really made me wonder about our obligations and methods of civil disobedience to resist contemporary forms of oppression. Lots of unresolved questions, which is a special type of book. Maybe that's why people read it?...more

title: Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage
author: Murakami, Haruki
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 2.5 stars.A long time hence, I went on one of my first ever international trips. The trajectory was London (solo), Marrakech (with my best friend from2.5 stars.A long time hence, I went on one of my first ever international trips. The trajectory was London (solo), Marrakech (with my best friend from high school), then Lisbon and Madrid (with my best friend from college). The weird thing was that I was in Lisbon and Madrid with a bunch of friends who had been teaching in Morocco, and in Morocco with a group who had been studying at London School of Economics. Weirder still--the college friend whom I was visiting in Lisbon and Madrid is now teaching at the London School of Economics. This is a web of phenomena that I feel like Murakami might be interested in. I mention this because at the time I was a very slow reader and not particularly interested in literature. But my friend in Morocco was reading an intriguing looking tome by Murakami called The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle. I kind of ended up having a total friend crush on this charismatic friend-of-a-friend, and the way he described the book to me sounded irresistible. I bought it upon returning to the United States and commenced reading. I was a different person then with different tastes, but I loathed it. And the length of the book, highlighted by my pre-law-school glacial pace of reading, combined with the way that certain storylines frayed and seemed wholly unnecessary made me resentful of Murakami.But friends and colleagues have been reading him lately and I have been left wondering if I hadn't been too hard on him. So, on a recent trip to Cuba where I had last minute fears that I would run out of books to read, I took to feverishly raiding the Brooklyn and New York public libraries' audiobook collections. This obscure (but short!) book seemed like as good a place to start as any.And I'm willing to give the guy another shot. His main characters still seem a little lifeless, and there were definitely some threads that seemed unresolved, but his stories have charm....more

title: This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs. The Climate
author: Klein, Naomi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: With most of the political screeds I consume, I find myself thinking about them in two- (Congressional) and four- (Presidential) year terms. Not so wiWith most of the political screeds I consume, I find myself thinking about them in two- (Congressional) and four- (Presidential) year terms. Not so with Klein’s trenchant call to action. Klein examines the incompatibility between our current zealous capitalism and the continuation of life as we know it on planet Earth, and strikes an appropriately baleful tone throughout. Our tendencies and habits are both so baked into our way of life and yet so harmful that we are headed for a calamity, either of our comforts or something far less weatherable and reversible. When I read about other issues that engage my sympathies, I tend to think “A better President/Congress will enact this, if we’re lucky,” but the warning Klein issues is that we are already past the tipping point, and even if we took drastic measures we might not avert the disaster she warns of. And because we are nowhere near the point of coordinating for such massive austerity measures, I wonder if there’s much hope for us at all, aside from the magical thinking of global engineering that Klein views with appropriate suspicion.Climate change is something like healthcare reform or educational policy for which I toe the liberal line but which has never been forefront of my concerns about society or the world. I live in the city, I recycle, I take public transportation, I don’t travel much, I buy second-hand clothing and get my books from the library, but I’m sure there is a lot more I could be doing. I’m not sure it will keep the rivers from boiling off the land or the seas from turning subacid, but I’m scared enough to investigate.As with her other works, Klein is brutal, thorough, and brilliant. I missed her acerbity but as always appreciated the monumental effort she puts into calling our attention to that which matters. ...more

title: Cannibalism: A Perfectly Natural History
author: Schutt, Bill*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are very few things I find myself getting squeamish about, but cannibalism is one of them. It's not so much the Donner-Party, necessity-of-surviThere are very few things I find myself getting squeamish about, but cannibalism is one of them. It's not so much the Donner-Party, necessity-of-survival type cannibalism that bothers me, either--hunger knows no morality and forces normal people to do things that they might ordinarily find horrific. It's more of the victim-of-cannibalization type that makes me shudder. I suppose on some fundamental level, I believe that it's wrong for humans to be used as means to an end, and succumbing by way of cannibalization seems to be the ultimate example of that; your life and your body reduced to the fulfillment of some fetish that by its very nature assigns you no greater value than a head of cattle. These were probably the hardest parts of this book for me. Stories of cannibalism in the animal kingdom and its evolutionary advantages were much more interesting than unsettling. This book got me thinking of other taboos, things that are so ingrained that logic alone can't account for the aversion. The only others that came to mind were incest and pedophilia, but at least by degree those things operate in contemporary societies as norms, and certainly have done so to a greater extent in the past. But it's not like the British or the Yoruba have a tradition of eating, say, an arm but would draw the line there; unlike with the other two types of taboos I mentioned, cannibalism seems much more to be an all-or-nothing type of convention. While societies all over the world permit relationships that we might regard as incestuous or pedophilic, it seems that societies that countenance what we would describe as cannibalism are few and far between. And I guess it's Schutt's goal to show that this is more of a Western taboo, which is interesting. He points to our Greek and Shakespearean cautionary tales as powerfully inculcating the supposed evil of cannibalism, and then looks to China for examples that, at the very least, cannibalism wasn't regarded there in such black-and-white terms, citing Imperial delicacies including human flesh and conventions whereby parents would trade children with other families during times of hunger so as to avoid having to consume their own children. China is a big place with a lot of people and a ton of recorded history, though, so you're bound to come across anything sooner or later, right?I think the interesting thing for me has been that I gave it a fair shot but in the end I simply can't get over the taboo. Much as I try, and Chinese evidence to the contrary placed before me, I cannot get past the idea that it's wrong, with nothing more articulate than that to say about it! Oh well, I'm only human. This book was often funny and takes a light touch. Very worth chewing over, if you can stomach it!...more

title: The End of America: Letter of Warning to a Young Patriot
author: Wolf, Naomi*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sigh. Books like this are almost unreadable these days. I wish I had read this earlier, because I think I was woefully ignorant of the abuses and uncoSigh. Books like this are almost unreadable these days. I wish I had read this earlier, because I think I was woefully ignorant of the abuses and unconstitutional postures taken by the Bush administration until at least the beginning of my law school days, but the scope creep of the executive from Bush to Obama to Trump is almost too baleful to contemplate under the current administration. In highest dudgeon I've certainly lobbed my fair share of insults at the current president. I wonder if I'll be flagged as a subversive? A few things in particular stand out as prescient--particularly regarding "fake news"--after a grueling first week of the Trump presidency:"The great masses of the people will more easily fall victims of a big lie than a small one" Hitler wrote in Mein Kampf. Fascists rely on perception management: what the intelligence community calls "info ops" because their tactics won't stand scrutiny by a free press. So, in a fascist shift, as real reporters are being frozen out, smeared, or faced with unemployment, there is an increasing use of spectacle in conveying a message, and the spectacle is accompanied by the production of fake news and false documents. The messaging, combined with the spectacle, can be stunning in a fascist ascendancy. Fascist messaging has advantage that democratic communications and advocacy, even of the highest sophistication, just cannot demonstrate. You can use a monolithic, harmonized voice and vision, unimpeded by dissent, rather than trying to break through a clash of pluralistic arguments. This power of epic messaging--in combination with power of spectacle--is a well known aspect of the seduction of fascism.Dictatorships specialize in faking news and falsifying documents. Hitler wrote that "All effective propaganda must be limited to a very few points, and must harp on these in slogans until the last member of the public understands what you want him to understand." He argued that good propaganda speaks to feelings and not reason, and that it should never admit a glimmer of doubt in its own claims or concede the tiniest element of right in the claims of the other side.After a certain point in a fascist shift, it doesn't matter whether most people believe the faked news or not. Eventually, they simply don't have access to enough good information to assess what is real and what is not.Sending a current of lies into the information scene is part of classic psychological operations to generate a larger shift, a new reality in which the truth can no longer be ascertained and no longer counts. In this reality, citizens no longer feel empowered or able to establish the truth on either side, and therefore give up their agency. At this point, people can be manipulated into supporting almost any state action, for how can citizens know what is right? Truth itself has been cheapened, made subjective, and internal, not absolute and external.And this profoundly sad final note from the last part of the book reminds me of a joke a friend told me recently. He said that in the 1980s a Republican went over to a Democrat's house to play a game of checkers. They agreed on the rules, made a few moves, and then at some point the Republican got up, threw a bomb at the house, and began spraying kerosene everywhere. Meanwhile, inside, the Democrat is looking out for double-jumps and opportunities to get kinged.We in America are used to a democratic social contract in which there is agreement about the rules of the game. When Congress demands an answer, for instance, the President does not simply refuse to pick up the phone. So we keep being startled when the steps of the democratic interplay are ignored. "He can't do that!" It's time to notice that they are playing a different game altogether.It's long past time to wake up....more

title: Nothing Is True and Everything Is Possible: The Surreal Heart of the New Russia
author: Pomerantsev, Peter
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm not sure if this is/was a stock phrase or not, but while reading this book and searching for quotes from Arendt's The Origins of Totalitarianism, I'm not sure if this is/was a stock phrase or not, but while reading this book and searching for quotes from Arendt's The Origins of Totalitarianism, I realized that its title might spring from a passage she wrote on the public's receptivity to lies under totalitarian rule:In an ever-changing, incomprehensible world the masses had reached the point where they would, at the same time, believe everything and nothing, think that everything was possible and that nothing was true.... Mass propaganda discovered that its audience was ready at all times to believe the worst, no matter how absurd, and did not particularly object to being deceived because it held every statement to be a lie anyhow. The totalitarian mass leaders based their propaganda on the correct psychological assumption that, under such conditions, one could make people believe the most fantastic statements one day, and trust that if the next day they were given irrefutable proof of their falsehood, they would take refuge in cynicism; instead of deserting the leaders who had lied to them, they would protest that they had known all along that the statement was a lie and would admire the leaders for their superior tactical cleverness.The shoe fits! Pomerantsev is a television producer who brings his knack for setting up dramatic scenes to his account of his ersatz home of Moscow in the modern era. He describes a Russia bereft of ideology and faith in humanity after decades of Kafkaesque bureaucracy, failed policy, destitution and poverty. Where perestroika led not to a Western-style capitalist state on the Scandinavian model but a corrupt kleptocracy no longer fettered by pseudo-communist compunctions about mass accumulations of wealth from a captive people. In this Russia, the only rule is that those with the power to physically compel--whether Putin and the Kremlin or local gangster panjandrums, to the extent they are even separate entities--get their fat cut, and anyone who argues against this dynamic gets killed--the system is far too dear to be criticized. The book explains that this is why in Russia you can now criticize Putin, agitate for gay rights, etc., without especially fearing reprisal. But woe betide he who threatens the money train.Aside from being an exploration of this new cohort of conspicuously consuming NYC-London-Moscow set of Russian billionaires, there are other little vignettes of what happens when anomie and ennui settle in over a people and truth has less intrinsic value. There are tons of interesting stories about gangster auteurs, high class prostitution, and "sects" (cults) that pop up and exert extraordinary pull. It will be interesting to see how Russia develops over the next few decades and either shakes off this suffocating mantle of corruption or, more likely, contorts itself into something yet more ornate and strange....more

Scott. If I had to oversimplify this, I would say it was Cormac McCarthy in the boreal north with more plot and less symbolism. For how short this book was, it took me a while to read it. But every time I cracked it open I found myself excited to pick up where I left off. This book is taut and entertaining, if you've got the stomach for it....more

title: Indignation
author: Roth, Philip
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was the product of a single day's extensive subway delays, but it was a very quick read. I guess I don't understand why people don't like Roth. YThis was the product of a single day's extensive subway delays, but it was a very quick read. I guess I don't understand why people don't like Roth. Yes the parents are always so overbearing and the Jewish-Newark-blue-to-white-collar transition is always at the forefront, but he writes with such intensity. There's always such real anger, regret, indignation (!)... I always try to be vigilant for the pungent misogyny but the women in this book seemed real, complex, admirable. It's true that I strongly doubt that Roth could ever passably write a protagonist not of his gender while maintaining his level of virtuosity, but that's a high standard for any author.And I think he's a writer particularly suited to double-speed audiobook. The intensity almost becomes narcotic. This is maybe my fifth or sixth Roth book... certainly not his best work but a strong reminder of why I adore him as a writer.A final thought, and hopefully not a spoiler: is the book's ending meant to serve as a warning to those who refuse to capitulate? Knuckle under or else? That it's only the grass that stands tall that gets the blade? I'm not really sure how else to read it, but it's a horrifically depressing and terse finish....more

author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was perhaps a lot to consume via audiobook in such a short period but I had a lot of lazing around and cleaning to do over the past few days and This was perhaps a lot to consume via audiobook in such a short period but I had a lot of lazing around and cleaning to do over the past few days and made surprisingly short work of it.This wasn't, for me, The Handmaid's Tale, but what could be? It was still good, expert storytelling. Atwood is really good at creating razor sharp villains and giving them their just desserts. This one was packed with all sorts of funny little turns of phrase--Atwood really goes in for vernacular--and snappy dialogue. As usual her male characters seemed better informed and her female characters seemed to spend most of their narrative lifetimes as half-baked ingenues. Also, I can't say that I really understood the literary or symbolic merit of the sci-fi novel-within-a-novel, but I very much enjoyed it.Maybe I'll just read Handmaid's Tale again (or watch the TV series! With Elizabeth Moss!!) and hold Atwood to a more mortal standard from hereon......more
