title: A Fighting Chance
author: Warren, Elizabeth
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is the first I've "read" since the Election of 2016 to have breathed onto the pale embers of hope I have for our country and to have found sThis book is the first I've "read" since the Election of 2016 to have breathed onto the pale embers of hope I have for our country and to have found some faint glimmer of light persevering there. Back in 2011 when I was considering law schools, I got a call from a 3L at Harvard who was trying to pitch me on its merits. He was impressive, but not the finest salesman: he was perhaps too honest (he straight up told me that NYU had better clinics, not even attempting to qualify the statement); and he misread my priorities (he told me that one of the advantages of going to Harvard is that you can party at your friends' places in the Hamptons or Martha's Vineyard on weekends and during summers...gag). But he also told me that you had the option of taking classes with the most superlative academic minds in the legal firmament, at which point he dropped the name of Elizabeth Warren, a person whose run for Ted Kennedy's old Senate seat had introduced her to watchful liberals throughout the country. Thankfully Warren became Senator, but with the minuscule disappointment that I never had her for a professor. I didn't really even know what I missed out on until inhaling this book. I mean this in the most admiring, reverential way possible: she is an absolute battleaxe. She is sharp as all get out, not afraid of political fallout, understands this nation's priorities and shortcomings, and fights like hell for the living. It's impossible to say what would have happened had Warren taken up the yoke of the presidential race in 2016, and I'm not entirely sure, given her priorities, whether she would have had the slightest interest (though see Barack Obama's stance on same circa 2006). But I pray that this courageous and tireless woman continues to serve our country in whatever way possible until her outrage--and mine--is exhausted.Also: this audiobook would make a great gift for a liberal/progressive, certainly, but also for moderate or even moderate-conservative friends/family this holiday season. It really does an admirable way of limning opportunity and the political system in a way that would only offend the most hard-bitten of mossbacks....more

review: This really was a history! I kind of thought it would spend more time expatiating on the antecedents to our current class-stratified society and politThis really was a history! I kind of thought it would spend more time expatiating on the antecedents to our current class-stratified society and politics, but it felt more historical than sociopolitical. It just kind of moved through all of the main periods of American history and traced American establishment disdain for poor white folks based solely on their location and squalor, heavily influenced by the sense that such gutter folk were the detestable but necessary barrier between landed whites and non-whites. I guess I'm at a loss for what I thought this book lacked that I hoped it would explain, but I come away armed more with historical context than any understanding of the modern redneck....more

title: Listen, Liberal: Or, What Ever Happened to the Party of the People
author: Frank, Thomas
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Another great and quick listen from Thomas Frank. This is the excoriation that Democrats needed six months ago. It's not a book that presages a lapse Another great and quick listen from Thomas Frank. This is the excoriation that Democrats needed six months ago. It's not a book that presages a lapse into demagoguery, but it does lambaste the Democrats for their unforced error of alienating the working and uneducated classes, classes which the book notes are the bulwark of every successful left or left-leaning political base in the Western world. This book savaged both Clintons (Bill much more so than Hillary), which felt a bit raw. But I appreciated the culmination, a powerful jeremiad against the Clintonian ideology (with a few strong jabs included for good measure against the Clintons' heir and bien pensant Barack Obama), one that feels at once bitter but also necessary medicine in the wake of the 2016 election. I think this is a book that everyone who has thought "WTF?" since Nov. 8th, 2016 should read, if only because--having been written before the election--it avoids the backward-looking, still-divisive critiques of HRC's electability and instead inveighs against the entire Democratic Party/left (to the extent they can be said to overlap at all these days) for its folly and its perfidy toward the lower- and middle-classes, while still imparting object lessons we should all be studying assiduously.One curiosity about this book (aside from its failure to mention the whole Allende/Pinochet/"Chicago Boys" bête noire of the other economic screeds I have been reading lately) is that it doesn't really have a "recommendations" section, the way Stiglitz and Huffington and Krugman and other liberal solons typically shoehorn in at the end. It is pure fire, and I'm half tempted to look Frank up, hide my educational credentials, and ask him what the hell we can do about the world we haven't just inherited, but have caused as well. ...more

title: The Price of Inequality: How Today's Divided Society Endangers Our Future
author: Stiglitz, Joseph E.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Stiglitz comes through again! It's still so hard listening to these books, knowing just how much more unequal this country will become in the coming yStiglitz comes through again! It's still so hard listening to these books, knowing just how much more unequal this country will become in the coming years (and decades, via the federal judiciary, which is sure to be savaged). But it's also probably more important than ever to understand these things in the wake of the election, especially given the degree to which inequality seems to be animating (or at least permitting) so many of our most shameful political impulses. It's probably not unrelated to my having finished this book that I told a gay staffer for the richest member of Congress, Republican Darrell Issa, that he should go fuck himself shortly after meeting him at a Christmas party in DC this weekend. Political animosity runs both ways, and frankly I think we have more to be angry about.One thing in particular to mourn about our gaping inequalities that Stiglitz has brought up in both of his books is the extent to which the increasingly lucrative field of finance now leaches all of our best and brightest, people who formerly invented, thought, governed, and ran nonprofits. With 30, 40, 50 percent of some of our top colleges sending their graduates into finance, it is no wonder that this cycle has been reinforcing itself since the 1980s....more

author: Stiglitz, Joseph E.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Stiglitz is my guy, I think. He's not quite as peevish as Chomsky or restrained as Krugman. He is openly and notoriously left/liberal, and animated byStiglitz is my guy, I think. He's not quite as peevish as Chomsky or restrained as Krugman. He is openly and notoriously left/liberal, and animated by a compelling conviction.This text was not only more informative but also more accessible than other books I have read on the 2008 Recession. Notably, it does an excellent job of warning that our recovery therefrom was less purgative than nepenthe. In the coming era of further deregulation, with our focus on all sorts of other shenanigans, I wonder if we will have the courage and foresight to reign in the excesses of a financial industry that already poses a threat to our democracy and our world's safety and prosperity. I wouldn't say I'm optimistic, and for that reason, as soon as this book ended I eagerly loaded up Stiglitz's The Price of Inequality: How Today's Divided Society Endangers Our Future to broaden my understanding of our country's ills according to his understanding of them....more

title: The Origins of Totalitarianism
author: Arendt, Hannah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So I think it's pretty obvious why I read this, and pretty obvious why I had my first queue for a book older than a few years old: people are freaked,So I think it's pretty obvious why I read this, and pretty obvious why I had my first queue for a book older than a few years old: people are freaked, they are nervous, they want answers and our other institutions have utterly failed us, forget preparing us for any of what we should be expecting.Arendt spends a lot of time tracing the origins of anti-Semitism, which seems appropriate except that she doesn't spill too much ink connecting that to the rise of Nazism. Overall this book was a bit too long and a bit too academic to really grip me, but there were eerie parallels to our present situation that would grab my attention:On today's complaisant GOP:The attraction which the totalitarian movements exert on the elite, so long as and wherever they have not seized power, has been perplexing because the patently vulgar and arbitrary, positive doctrines of totalitarianism are more conspicuous to the outsider and mere observer than the general mood which pervades the pretotalitarian atmosphere. These doctrines were so much at variance with generally accepted intellectual, cultural, and moral standards that one could conclude that only an inherent fundamental shortcoming of character in the intellectual. . . or a perverse self-hatred of the spirit, accounted for the delight with which the elite accepted the 'ideas' of the mob. . . . What the spokesmen of humanism and liberalism usually overlook, in their bitter disappointment and their unfamiliarity with the more general experiences of the time is that an atmosphere in which all traditional values and propositions had evaporated . . . in a sense made it easier to accept patently absurd propositions than the old truths which had become pious banalities . . . . Vulgarity with its cynical dismissal of respected standards and accepted theories carried with it a frank admission of the worst and a disregard for all pretenses which were easily mistaken for courage and a new style of life....on the flourishing of callousness and the demise of decency:Since the bourgeoisie claimed to be the guardian of Western traditions and confounded all moral issues by parading publicly virtues which it not only did not possess in private and business life, but actually held in contempt, it seemed revolutionary to admit cruelty, disregard human values, and general amorality, because this at least destroyed the duplicity upon which the existing society seemed to rest. What a temptation to flaunt extreme attitudes in the hypocritical twilight of double moral standards, to wear publicly the mask of cruelty if everybody was patently inconsiderate and pretended to be gentle . . . ....on the elevation of economic self-interest over societal good:The mass man whom Himmler organized for the greatest crimes ever committed in history bore the features of the philistine rather than of the mob man, and was the bourgeois who in the midst of the ruins of his world worried about nothing so much as his private security, was ready to sacrifice everything—belief, honor, dignity—on the slightest provocation. Nothing proved easier to destroy than the privacy and private morality of people who thought of nothing but safeguarding their private lives. ...on the refusal to disavow repugnant behavior:The Nazis did not strike at prominent figures as had been done in the earlier wave of political crimes in Germany (the murder of Rathenau and Erzberger); instead, by killing small socialist functionaries or influential members of opposing parties, they attempted to prove to the population the dangers involved in mere membership. This kind of mass terror, which still operated on a comparatively small scale, increased steadily because neither the police nor the courts seriously prosecuted political offenders on the so-called Right. It was valuable as what a Nazi publicist has aptly called 'power propaganda': it made clear to the population at large that the power of the Nazis was greater than that of the authorities and that it was safer to be a member of a Nazi paramilitary organization than a loyal Republican. This impression was greatly strengthened by the specific use the Nazis made of their political crimes. They always admitted them publicly, never apologized for 'excesses of the lower ranks'—such apologies were used only by Nazi sympathizers—and impressed the population as being very different from the 'idle talkers' of other parties.The similarities between this kind of terror and plain gangsterism are too obvious to be pointed out....on the contempt for facts, and the interest would-be totalitarians have in anomie and destruction:Mass leaders in power have one concern which overrules all utilitarian considerations: to make their predictions come true. The Nazis did not hesitate to use, at the end of the war, the concentrated force of their still intact organization to bring about as complete a destruction of Germany as possible, in order to make true their prediction that the German people would be ruined in case of defeat. The propaganda effect of infallibility, the striking success of posing as a mere interpreting agent of predictable forces, has encouraged in totalitarian dictators the habit of announcing their political intentions in the form of prophecy. The most famous example is Hitler's announcement to the German Reichstag in January, 1939: 'I want today once again to make a prophecy: In case the Jewish financiers ... succeed once more in hurling the peoples into a world war, the result will be ... the annihilation of the Jewish race in Europe.' Translated into nontotalitarian language, this meant: 'I intend to make war and I intend to kill the Jews of Europe.' . . .As soon as the execution of the victims has been carried out, the 'prophecy' becomes a retrospective alibi: nothing happened but what had already been predicted....This method, like other totalitarian propaganda methods, is foolproof only after the movements have seized power. Then all debate about the truth or falsity of a totalitarian dictator's prediction is as weird as arguing with a potential murderer about whether his future victim is dead or alive—since by killing the person in question the murderer can promptly provide proof of the correctness of his statement. The only valid argument under such conditions is promptly to rescue the person whose death is predicted. Before mass leaders seize the power to fit reality to their lies, their propaganda is marked by its extreme contempt for facts as such, for in their opinion fact depends entirely on the power of man who can fabricate it....In other words, the method of infallible prediction, more than any other totalitarian propaganda device, betrays its ultimate goal of world conquest, since only in a world completely under his control could the totalitarian ruler possibly realize all his lies and make true all his prophecies. *sigh* It's not that I believe that we are going to have a Holocaust redux, it's just that I don't understand how people can be so calm, so willing to give the benefit of the doubt. As Primo Levi and others have pointed out, these things rely on manipulable people and incremental deterioration of societal norms. Are we not experiencing that to degrees seldom seen before? Having read this book I feel fairly certain that the evil genius and psychological understanding of men like Stalin and Hitler is beyond the capacity of a lummox like Trump, but I take such little solace in this because I do believe that he is surrounding himself with the amoral semi-deep-thinkers who are fully capable of wielding extreme power (see, e.g.: this) and trading on bureaucratic inertia to accomplish unknowable and untenable ends.Fuck. I need a hug. And a beer....more

title: The Heart Goes Last
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked three books for my book club: this one, because we said we didn't want anything from 2016 and this was Margaret Atwood's book from 2015; The I picked three books for my book club: this one, because we said we didn't want anything from 2016 and this was Margaret Atwood's book from 2015; The Vegetarian; and Union Atlantic. My friends got to the book before I did, and the early appraisals were that it was not very good. At first I felt bad, but, as with this election, my guy didn't win (I picked "The Vegetarian"), so I don't feel bad about the resulting dystopia into which I was plunged.This book felt like Margaret Atwood was trying to do her best George Saunders and failing. The dialogue was awkward, the story deviated into these odd vignettes. It was just bad. Bad by an author whose previous two works I enjoyed so ardently.I have Hag-Seed waiting for me. People seem to like that one more. Maybe if I get a hankering for some (fictional) dystopian reading I'll give her another shot, but this one was so disappointing!...more

title: The Wrecking Crew: How Conservatives Rule
author: Frank, Thomas
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Thomas Frank--you are the fustigator we need right now. I'm still on board with Stiglitz, but Frank is endowed with a much more gimlet eye and sharperThomas Frank--you are the fustigator we need right now. I'm still on board with Stiglitz, but Frank is endowed with a much more gimlet eye and sharper tongue. And it's delightful to find someone whose playfulness of diction matches his playfulness with the subject matter (some great vocabulary here, though perhaps an over-reliance on the word "boodler" and really no need to use the word enragée more than once). The main thesis of this book, as I take it, is to point out how well made the GOP has it in modern Washington. This is a party whose ethos is "government does not work." Thus they have cover for their efforts to dismantle whatever is good and that people almost universally like about government (taxes on the very wealthy, corporate and environmental responsibility, gun restrictions, enabling voting, taking care of our veterans) because, after all--it's still "government." Yet when they can be shown variously to be obstructionist, to have not accomplished anything, or to have bungled something good, it's always that liberals got in the way, or that government was never competent to handle it in the first place. Frank does an excellent job of showing, too, that conservatives benefit from having the corrupt and incompetent pollute our last stalwart beliefs in civic virtue, and that conservatives can even get on board with government when they are the ones who control it, either through domination or deep capture (the Northern Mariana Islands/Saipan anecdotes are especially poignant in this regard). Truly a cynical but believable tale of why people vote against their best interests, and why a party of incompetent, sociopathic, and kleptocratic morons currently stands to inherit all branches of our government in a few months. Good reading, if you can stomach it....more

title: Because We Say So
author: Chomsky, Noam
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One of the more muted tragedies following this past week's election is that I am finding fiction to be more and more of a decadent pastime. It's not tOne of the more muted tragedies following this past week's election is that I am finding fiction to be more and more of a decadent pastime. It's not that one cannot learn amazing things from fiction--on the contrary--but the type of knowledge that a lawyer should have in Trump's America takes an entirely different cast. There is so much that I feel strongly whose underpinnings are far flimsier than I am comfortable with; it's not that I doubt the conclusions of my scruples, it's just that I want to be more conversant and fleshed-out when representing them. And, invariably, these expeditions into truth-finding turn up all sorts of other unanticipated curios that make for profitable future investigation.Anyway, as indictments of America go, it doesn't get much more blistering than Chomsky. But this was mostly a recapitulation of a lot of his other thoughts--our deviance from the Magna Carta, Israel's perpetuation of apartheid, American environmental recklessness, etc. He had fewer outrageous comparisons than in the last work of his that I read (though the comparison of Putin's invasion of the Crimea with the United States' occupation of Guantanamo Bay left me gobsmacked), and it was all well argued, just nothing particularly new or noteworthy. For my money, Who Rules the World? is a better bet....more

title: The Story of a New Name        (The Neapolitan Novels, #2)
author: Ferrante, Elena
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Am I a convert? I don't know quite yet, but I enjoyed this installment more than its predecessor. I think I began to sense the richness of the dialoguAm I a convert? I don't know quite yet, but I enjoyed this installment more than its predecessor. I think I began to sense the richness of the dialogue and the deft hand for storycraft that I perhaps did not fully appreciate the first time around. Two thoughts that stuck with me the whole way: 1) Growing up in a middle class, Irish-American background, casual racism (ethnicism?) toward other groups of white people--typically other "ethnic" types such as Italians, Poles, and Jews--was practically de rigueur. When my eldest cousin got married to an Italian (Catholic), I remember a relative wringing her hands over whether their prospective children would suffer from their conflicting identities. As a four year old, I knew enough to understand that this was ridiculous and overwrought.But especially after I moved back to the East Coast, traces of this tendency began to percolate into my consciousness. For example, it was schoolyard gospel--taken with only mild umbrage--that the Irish were fecund, given to fighting, and fond of the drink; we parried these insults with relatively innocent ethnic stereotypical barbs/jokes of our own: the Polish were prone to building such contraptions as the submarine with a screen door, or the rocketship to the Sun; the British had bad teeth; the French were lazy and subsisted on snails and red wine; and Italians were irascible firebloods with a predilection for gesticulation. As with all racial and ethnic stereotypes, I have learned them to be pernicious and baseless as an adult, notwithstanding their somewhat durable currency. So it was odd to see one of them resurrected so comprehensively in a contemporary novel, especially one written by an Italian herself. How many times do these characters threaten to kill each other, or explode into angry conflagration upon the slightest provocation? So much passion! Is this a realistic portrayal of the impoverished Neapolitan experience? Was there much gesticulation?!2) Why the continued loyalty to Lila from all characters, most especially Lenu? I get that she is this smoldering femme fatale type, but it's unclear why an intelligent woman such as Lenu would be so loyal to and forgiving of her, especially given her frequent maliciousness, unpredictability, lack of redeeming qualities, and her (view spoiler)[affair with the object of Lenu's occasionally requited affection, Nino Sarratore (hide spoiler)]? I found myself wondering this about the first book, but dismissed it as the callowness of youth blinding the characters to the fact that mature friendships are voluntary rather than the product of proximity and circumstance. As the characters mature to adulthood, I find it somewhat more baffling, but I will assume it is merely an element of Ferrante's deft storytelling that is taking a bit longer to unfold....more

title: The Shock Doctrine: The Rise of Disaster Capitalism
author: Klein, Naomi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Not sure how much more piercing looks I can take into America's rotten, blackened core, but that is due more to fatigue than to any criticism I had ofNot sure how much more piercing looks I can take into America's rotten, blackened core, but that is due more to fatigue than to any criticism I had of this book. Klein presents to us a world that is so paralyzed and bamboozled by entropy and bureaucracy that the only way to catalyze meaningful change is to either take advantage of or foment massive disasters--whether in terms of disaster response, warfare, or regime change. She starts with Allende's Chile, as all books of this ilk do, and moves on to show how blights as diverse as Putin, apartheid Israel, post-Katrina New Orleans, and post-Bush II Baghdad are interlinked, less outliers than harbingers of our coming norms. The "Green Zone" of Baghdad in particular stuck me as baleful, especially juxtaposed with Sandy Springs, GA, its analogue in our own country. Could things get so divided by class, government so privatized, and safety so compromised that we all end up in Atwood-esque compounds determined by our socioeconomic status? Klein at least makes a case for how we might. I suppose we'll have a better idea tomorrow when the election is (hopefully) over for good, but the diverse group of 100+ people who were waiting outline my polling place at 6am in uncontested Brooklyn, NY gives me at least some hope that this outcome can be avoided......more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Controversial opinion time: I didn't really like this book. George Saunders is, in many ways, my favorite living novelist. I know of no one else who cControversial opinion time: I didn't really like this book. George Saunders is, in many ways, my favorite living novelist. I know of no one else who can consistently make me laugh and make me tear up. Saunders' short stories are crystallized genius, and his novellas are really great too. This definitely had traces of Saunders' best stuff--there's the puerile humor that somehow endears. There's the overwhelming pathos. There are the clever turns of phrase and period diction. But this felt too much like George Saunders' take on a modernist play. I loved the parts about Lincoln, a salmagundi of real and fake appraisals of the man and his encounter with the most devastating of tragedies; but I never got into the parts that didn't feature Lincoln, whether Abraham or Willie.The worst part was that this book has been met with universal acclaim! Books by Saunders that I have LOVED have been regarded tepidly by those whose opinions I admire, but this one gave me such high hopes. And how can you go wrong with Lincoln and such a personal tragedy!? Sigh. Not bad at all but a real disappointment for me....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Was it Charles Darnay or Sydney Carton that some famous critic dismissed as suffocatingly boring because of his overwhelming moral probity? I'm generaWas it Charles Darnay or Sydney Carton that some famous critic dismissed as suffocatingly boring because of his overwhelming moral probity? I'm generally a big fan of Dickens but A Tale of Two Cities can suck it through a hose. Why do I mention this in this book's ? Because I spent most of the first 2/3 of this book thinking how irritatingly pious its pre-teen girl protagonist was. She knows every prayer, consecrates herself to God, BFF with the priest... you know, the whole Catholic spiel. I can't say I lived it (though I was born on a Holy Day of Obligation, meaning I had to go to church every year on my birthday, its own type of hairshirt!), but I recognized it.I picked this up because it was new and seemed popular and because it was one of the contenders for my book club last month (it lost out to the similarly "meh" Commonwealth). I had high hopes, because people liked Room so much, but it was kind of a snooze until the last forty or so pages. At times it felt like an irritating Beckett play with the main character running around being the only sane person while everyone else acted completely absurd and as if nothing were awry. Lots of subtle and not-so-subtle commentary on Anglo-Hibernian traits and relations, doubtless Donoghue's own, sparing neither in its critiques.It picks up, sure, saving it from the two-star rating I was reserving for it, but overall this didn't feel terribly substantial or suspenseful. ...more

title: M Train

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was enchanted by Patti Smith's Just Kids, and made a mental note to pick up her newest book, thinking it was something of a rare issue for her. TurnI was enchanted by Patti Smith's Just Kids, and made a mental note to pick up her newest book, thinking it was something of a rare issue for her. Turning past the title page, I realize that she is more prolific as an author than as a chanteuse, it seems, but this book warmed me for the same reasons that "Just Kids" did, albeit without the (sometimes) added benefit of a narrative around which to cohere.Smith write like a animistic priestess, or like a child, talking to inanimate objects, stubbornly sticking to diets of white bean soup, black coffee, toast and olive oil. She floats around the Village with childlike wonder. She haunts some of my favorite places in the world--Mexico City, New York, Spain, South America--and discourses on some books that have moved me--The Master and Margarita, The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle, and Lolita. A picture she had snapped at the West Fourth Street station, a glum column with a "W4" placard on it, appeared the moment I pulled into that station, halfway to Hudson Yards to embark on a frantic 10-hour trip to Philadelphia to be with my oldest friend, who is going through some difficult and alarming mental distress. I wondered if someday I would put pen to paper in order to form the type of reflective vignette that Smith shares with us in this book, or if I take enough stock of or appropriately appreciate the moments that make up my own life....more

review: “The Mothers” made its way onto a lot of lists for best fiction and best new authors of 2016, but in all honesty I picked it up because of the appeali“The Mothers” made its way onto a lot of lists for best fiction and best new authors of 2016, but in all honesty I picked it up because of the appealing cover and its prominent display in the window of my local book store.“The Mothers” starts out lively and engaging, telling the intertwined stories of Aubrey, Nadia, and Luke, three Black kids in San Diego with extremely different pasts and intertwined futures. Bennett can definitely write, but this also very much seemed like a debut novel. Plot wise, there was just a lot that seemed missing—boyfriends introduced over several chapters were extirpated in single sentences, others who were introduced briefly (Nadia’s grandmother, her law school boyfriend, etc.) seemed like they would be late introductions but ended up as enigmas, and tragic mysteries involving both Aubrey and Nadia’s mother went thoroughly--perhaps purposefully--unanswered. Regardless of the intentionality, this book felt like it had more than its fair share of loose ends. But overall a quick and enjoyable read and a promising debut....more

review: I think I'm starting to buy into the Atwood binary--the idea that the best of her books are incandescent while all others are basically throwaways. IfI think I'm starting to buy into the Atwood binary--the idea that the best of her books are incandescent while all others are basically throwaways. If the binary obtains, then this is one of the latter, though I liked it slightly more than I liked The Heart Goes Last.On the one hand I'm not really sure how to rate a remake--is it harder to stay faithful to the plot, or is it easier because everything is already there, waiting for its cipher? Regardless, this was pretty readable, if subject to the same Shakespearean suspensions of disbelief that characterize its source material (The Tempest): people falling in love at first sight, an almost Walter-White-esque serendipity of everything working out according to plan, all brown people being morally suspect. Also at times it felt like Atwood was using her prisoners' Elizabethan cursing conventions as a roux to thicken up an otherwise watery and insubstantial text, but I suppose some people might find it amusing. And oh god, and those rapping scenes! Is there anyone less equipped to credibly pen prison rap than a septuagenarian author from Ottawa? Did she just see "Hamilton" and think "Yeah, this is what people get down with these days!"?Now I'm afraid to read The Blind Assassin! What if it's the last great book of hers that I haven't yet read?!...more

title: Who Rules the World?
author: Chomsky, Noam
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So this was my first Chomsky, and I think I am a fan. He is pretty glib and glum, but justifiably. One gets the impression that there is no world in wSo this was my first Chomsky, and I think I am a fan. He is pretty glib and glum, but justifiably. One gets the impression that there is no world in which Chomsky can be satisfied, but that should not take away from his dressing down of many valid targets of derision and ridicule. There were times in this book where the slant was palpable. For instance, he praises Hugo Chavez, of all people, for making a (hollow) call for environmentalism, while savaging every one of his other targets for any deviation from stated intention; much of the same for Israel and Palestine. It's just irritating when he lets traditional scallawags off the hook, ostensibly to provide a balanced view, when he holds all of our traditional powerbrokers to such a (justifiably) high standard.Despite his errant hypocrisies, we need more public intellectual iconoclasts like Chomsky in our society. (Also, this being Halloween weekend and having been to the Brooklyn Halloween Dog Costume Parade in Ft. Greene, I couldn't help but think that Noam Chomp-sky would be a cute name for a dog)...more

Lloyd Blankfein and the rest of the rogue's gallery are such loathsomOy, what a morass we have gotten ourselves into with our financial heedlessness. After listening to this, however, I think the worst of the blackguards may be private equity managers.Overall this was a great primer on the financial chicanery that has further unbalanced wealth in this country, an industry whose tendrils fully envelop both of our major political parties. Listening to it made me glad that I had swapped my vote with someone in North Carolina, who promised me he would vote for Hillary if I voted for Stein in my non-competitive state (read more, here: http://www.vocativ.com/372898/vote-sw...). title: The Crash of 2016: The Plot to Destroy America--and What We Can Do to Stop It
author: Hartmann, Thom
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So I don't mind a tendentious book, typically. After all, I am a tendentious guy--I worked for the ACLU, listen to my NPR, and openly advocate eating So I don't mind a tendentious book, typically. After all, I am a tendentious guy--I worked for the ACLU, listen to my NPR, and openly advocate eating Republicans as a way of maintaining a carbon-negative non-vegetarian life. But at times this book got a little annoying in its smugness. For instance, I get that the author doesn't really think we need to have such a big and costly military--what sane person does?--but that does not mean that there is *no* return on investment to buying a Tomahawk missile, a point he makes a few times in this book, at least not if you're taking for granted that wind power generators and funding liberal arts majors through the GI Bill are unequivocally beneficial to society. And then there were things that he said that were just flat wrong: I'm no fan of Chief Justice John Roberts, but no, he is not the most radical conservative to sit on the bench over the last fifty years; he is not even the most radical conservative on his current bench, even with Scalia dead. But this book on the whole was fine. A nice, quick little polemic by an unabashed liberal is sometimes what you need on the subway when you are trying to forget that half of your countrymen (and more than half of your benighted race) want to elect Donald Trump for president. The crash of 2016 has not come to pass (though with Brexit, the Sanders ascendancy, and the near-election of Trump, I wonder how pleased the author is with himself), but hopefully we can have some of the revolution he promises in 2017 and thereafter....more

review: Mark Greif, founder of n+1 and professional intellectual holds forth on topics as disparate as Radiohead, modern warfare, and Thoreau in this highly iMark Greif, founder of n+1 and professional intellectual holds forth on topics as disparate as Radiohead, modern warfare, and Thoreau in this highly intelligent but dry collectanea. I'm not a reader of n+1, but a "certain" type of friend is, and suffice it to say I've never been drawn to it. Greif has an admirable ability to form complex, richly coherent thoughts from mundane observations. His mind is clearly formidable, and at times this was funny and clever. But for every feat of pure cerebral originality (e.g., his "Afternoon of the Sex Children," one of the better pieces in the book, connects our collective perversion of sexualizing children to an exhortation that we begin to esteem the old and spavined for their virtues), there are two extended meditations on abstruse philosophy and punk rock, things I'd prefer to be deconstructed by others. Overall an impressive collection, but feel free to skip the ones that don't merit your extended attention....more

title: My Further Disillusionment in Russia
author: Goldman, Emma
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Don't meet your heroes. That's what they say. Emma Goldman is kind of a hero--she was a true radical in early 20th Century America, and they expelled Don't meet your heroes. That's what they say. Emma Goldman is kind of a hero--she was a true radical in early 20th Century America, and they expelled her for it. This book is a chronicle of her disappointment in the radical revolution--arguably the revolution with the greatest potential for paradigm change in human history--in Russia, and her gradual realization that humans massing under aspirational banners and behind idealistic rhetoric are nonetheless subject to human vices. I say don't meet your heroes because this book was quite boring. Boring, repetitive, and without much poetic voice--and this from the woman who deployed the rallying cry "No gods, no masters!"Still, it's admirable that Goldman didn't take the wholesale refutation of the Communist principle and go all Ayn Rand on us. It must have been superhuman to have resisted that impulse, but Goldman succeeds, as we know from history, and continued on as a radical and anarchist for the rest of her life. I think next I may read a book about Emma Goldman, as opposed to a memoir by her own hand....more

title: White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You
author: Johnson, Simon
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't really know too much about the debt, but lately I have been making an effort to become at least conversant in these issues that occasionally cI don't really know too much about the debt, but lately I have been making an effort to become at least conversant in these issues that occasionally crop up at family reunions and outside of my politically monolithic groups of friends, things that I typically dismiss with a roll of my eyes: Benghazi, email-"gate," the deficit. But whereas cursory examination exposes the first two as almost pure political distraction (or, at very least: as some instances of serious false equivalency), the topic of the deficit is much more complex, going even to the question of whether we should be worried about it at all. And the short answer seems to be that we should be, but that cataclysm is not yet nigh. It's odd that we don't hear much about the deficit any more--it was all we could talk about back in 2009, and it's only gotten bigger and our economy has only healed, arguably giving us some leeway to deal with it, were we so inclined. I think this reveals the Congressional handwringing to be little more than opportunistic skulduggery, and the next time the topic comes up hopefully I will be more capable and fluent, ready to parry my opponents claims of excessive spending with facts and figures demonstrating otherwise, rejoinders about tax cuts, military spending, and Medicare at the ready....more

review: I loved this book from the very beginning; a very enthusiastic 4.5 stars for Haslett."Imagine Me Gone" tells the story of an Anglo-American family in I loved this book from the very beginning; a very enthusiastic 4.5 stars for Haslett."Imagine Me Gone" tells the story of an Anglo-American family in the grips of two generations of mental illness, each family member trying to beat back the tide of inevitability that they understand to be beyond what can be expected or achieved and yet feeling the acute onus of responsibility all the same. The prose in here, particularly what scarce morsels we get in the voice of John the patriarch, is breathtaking at times. This is a sad (or ever so slightly bittersweet) tale, shades of which anyone who has tried to serve as a rock of stability or savior amidst a family member's unspooling will recognize. review: This was certainly piquant. A really interesting and provocative but short and digestible read. At first I could not really understand why it provokedThis was certainly piquant. A really interesting and provocative but short and digestible read. At first I could not really understand why it provoked such profound controversy upon its release, but as the text became more polemical and as I remembered that my agnosticism in any American setting outside of Brooklyn would be considered obdurate, those feelings started to flag. This maybe loses a star or a half of one because of the peremptory way that Aslan presents his conclusions--any inference is presented as inescapable truth, which is irksome to the lawyer's mind, even if those inferences were on the whole fairly compelling and seemingly well-researched--but "Zealot" really stands out not so much for what it says about Jesus but instead for what it suggests about those who constructed his church and carried it into the next two millennia. I mourn for a worldwide church that might have been less messianic, less focused on the supernatural and the afterlife, more like modern Judaism, and especially for the social gospel of James that was subsumed and overwhelmed by the sophistry of Paul (who, it must be said, comes across as a massive dickhead in this account)....more

review: This was an interesting one to read over Thanksgiving!I opened this up on an early bus to the Jersey Shore, by way of Philadelphia. It's a short ride This was an interesting one to read over Thanksgiving!I opened this up on an early bus to the Jersey Shore, by way of Philadelphia. It's a short ride and this is a short book, but I got through almost half of it despite sleeping for the first hour--it was so tense and taut from the very beginning, and I can't remember the last time I was so enraptured by a book so quickly. I have to do more thinking about this, but it seemed like the lack of agency and interest paid to the book's protagonist caused her transition, through which she became the embodiment of unimposing, inert vegetation, paradoxically exerting herself as unique, obstreperous, and unflagging in the process. Ultimately, for as brutal and erotic the first two sections were, respectively, the final section disappointed me somewhat, which is why this gets 4 stars instead of 5. I'd welcome others' thoughts, though, on why the ending was consistent with the masterfulness of the rest of this eerie thriller....more

review: DeLillo, you sly fox. I've written about this before, but why do I keep repairing to this author whose works always leave me a bit unsatisfied? Is it DeLillo, you sly fox. I've written about this before, but why do I keep repairing to this author whose works always leave me a bit unsatisfied? Is it the succulent bits that stand out amongst the idiosyncratic filler? Is it the occasional brilliance that never quite manifests its full potential? I don't really know, but this was peak DeLillo. Inexplicable events barely engendering comments from disaffected characters, precocious nihilistic children speaking in riddles, people holding forth with odd constructions of language (e.g. "The whole point of Sir Albert Einstein is how can the sun be up if you're standing on the sun?" and "The point of rooms is that they're inside. title: Nothing to Envy: Ordinary Lives in North Korea
author: Demick, Barbara*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At some point the author pauses to mention something very self-evident but important to keep in mind while reading this book--North Korea invites paroAt some point the author pauses to mention something very self-evident but important to keep in mind while reading this book--North Korea invites parody, but for those hermetically sealed on the inside of its borders, that which we lampoon is gospel truth. This is so critical to bear in mind because otherwise it's easy to get distracted by the litany of questions that crop up for the Western reader: "Why would you ever tolerate this life?" "How could people love this regime/dictator?" "Did no one see through all of this absurd obsequiousness and pageantry?" But I think all of these questions assume that critical thinking is something innate, rather than acquired, which is something this book made me question. In a world without alternative narratives, with only binary political truths, where all who are not devout loyalists are traitors, I found myself wondering: would I be bold enough to question and escape the confines of the state or would I accept the narrative that I was responsible for upholding the beleaguered vanguard, that questioning the state's motives or integrity was playing into the enemies' hands? After reading this book, I am honestly not sure.It's painful to take in at times--the human suffering is so acute and widespread, but the stories we are told make the forbearance of these people relatable, understandable if not rational. It does a lot to explain why North Korea hasn't collapsed, despite perpetrating untold human rights violations and a cratering economy. ...more

review: I’m not sure I learned anything from this book. I was looking forward to a primer on how to make life more playful—I am perpetually pingponging betweeI’m not sure I learned anything from this book. I was looking forward to a primer on how to make life more playful—I am perpetually pingponging between being way too stimulated and way too bored—but it did not reveal too much about how to reify playfulness in everyday life. There are a lot of extended meditations on irony, insincerity, consumption, etc. but, as I began to suspect halfway in, it’s one of those “change your way of thinking” books, not an “implement a way of thinking” books, making it distinctly less practical. I appreciate the insight that we need to stop dismissing things because we think that they are passé or that they cannot offer us anything, but all that stuff about irony and constraints fomenting creativity are pretty available to any remotely self-reflecting person.Shrug. I should know myself better, but it got a good write-up in Slate and I have made a pledge to increase my ratio of non-fiction to fiction, and this fit the bill....more

title: Modern Romance
author: Ansari, Aziz
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really love Aziz Ansari, and this was another feather in his cap, albeit a surprising one--I enjoyed this, but it was decidedly less interspersed wiI really love Aziz Ansari, and this was another feather in his cap, albeit a surprising one--I enjoyed this, but it was decidedly less interspersed with his signature humor than I would have thought. But I was mainly surprised by how sophisticated the research was: how many international cities he visited/polled, how many august dating sociologists he consulted with, and the breadth of topics covered. Not that this book was peer ed or anything--broad pronunciations on how French men regard monogamy or Argentine courtship rituals leave some nuance to be desired--but it was undertaken with more seriousness than I'd anticipated.As someone who is woefully familiar with the travails of online dating, much of this book rang very true, especially given that I recently ended a relationship over a disagreement over it being "open." This book centers on the new paradigms of dating--how the digitalization of dating has raised our expectations over those of previous generations, how the paradox of choice can both enable and thwart finding happiness, and how the Internet's role in making us more picky has eroded traditional conventions like monogamy. Like Ansari, I think the hardest thing to grapple with is knowing when to write someone off, while ensuring that you're not squandering your chance at having something great. Ansari advocates patience, but this is easier advocated than practiced. We'll see if this book proves useful in the Augean stables that is New York City dating, but even if not it was an entertaining listen....more

review: So this took forever, but it was an enjoyable companion. I decided to listen to it in Spanish, because I'll need to use my Spanish for the new job I'mSo this took forever, but it was an enjoyable companion. I decided to listen to it in Spanish, because I'll need to use my Spanish for the new job I'm starting in a month, and I never read (or listen) to something in Spanish whose plot I don't already vaguely know. Hillary's pre-Senate life was less known to me than I had anticipated, but the bones were there and my Spanish compensated where something about which I knew very little (like Whitewater) came up. I must say, Spanish really humanized Hillary (and certainly made the revelation of Bill's perfidious cheating that much more dramatic!). I liked the book overall, and Hillary is much more of a badass than I knew. Like me, she started off as a conservative/Republican and gradually but deliberately developed more liberal positions when she left her little bubble. I can see why people don't trust her--my god, the Clinton scandals never cease!--because for every scandal, instead of contrition there was just a bunch of "total ignorance," "just a big misunderstanding," or calumny of some sort, and this starts to wear a bit thin after 600ish pages. But despite these troubles with each "page" I also grew less and less tolerant of the visceral hatred of Hillary in this country. There are plenty of reasons to hate Hillary or wish for a better candidate, but I feel like the vast majority of the reasons animating the general public's dislike and distrust of her are the illegitimate, misogynistic ones.I had hoped that this book would touch on her Senate and Secretary of State stints, but unfortunately I think those come in subsequent memoirs, memoirs which the Brooklyn Public Library does not have in Spanish audiobook. title: The Good Earth        (House of Earth, #1)
author: Buck, Pearl S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: OK, so this book started out pretty good. I liked the story of the poor peasant rising through poverty by dutifully working the land and eschewing comOK, so this book started out pretty good. I liked the story of the poor peasant rising through poverty by dutifully working the land and eschewing common vices. I liked that the great house got its comeuppance. I liked that Wang Lung and O-Lan forged a relationship built on mutual respect and interdependence. I even liked when the family came upon hard times, with extreme famine necessitating its hushed elements of infanticide and cannibalism. It had the agrestic character and sense of triumph over adversity of "East of Eden."But at some point I really started to hate Wang Lung. He's such a loathsome little cockalorum, vain and self-reassuring, disloyal and proud. He owes everything--the stability of his home life, his initial ability to acquire wealth, his later ability to turn stolen wealth into land, and his many children--all to her, yet he treats her terribly over and over again. He is prone to sharp bouts of anger and is cowardly and self-congratulatory for every irritating failure we witness, from his disinclination to interfere with his layabout father's uselessness during famine times, to his decision to take his first and then second concubines, to his caving to his sons regarding a servant's burial posture, a servant whose generosity years before had likely saved those sons from succumbing to starvation. And I'm sure this was a function of listening to this via audiobook, but it is so goddamn annoying that two out of every three sentences of dialogue in this book start out with "Well." Can that really be how Chinese people talked?...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: OK, so in retrospect I realize that this is quite dumb, but I don't think I fully realized what this book was before I started listening to it. I say OK, so in retrospect I realize that this is quite dumb, but I don't think I fully realized what this book was before I started listening to it. I say it's dumb because check the title: "Reasons to Stay Alive." I had assumed that it was going to be the author's description of his journey from depression to wellness, and his reflections along the way. But, while it incorporates some of those elements, it functions more as a full-throated exhortation to the depressed and desperate to not end it all. This is a brave piece of writing and something that I can imagine might be very helpful to others (although I kept wondering whether something as monumental as I understand depression to be is susceptible to "trust me on this" advice and it-simply-has-to-get-better logic), but not being depressed myself and luckily not having experienced it, I felt a bit like I had stumbled into a support group without license to intrude....more

title: You're Not Doing It Right: Tales of Marriage, Sex, Death, and Other Humiliations
author: Black, Michael Ian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a huge surprise, but I really loved this book. Like most of the comedy books I consume, this was an audiobook. I had recently made my way thrThis was a huge surprise, but I really loved this book. Like most of the comedy books I consume, this was an audiobook. I had recently made my way through a few mediocre audiobooks by Demetri Martin and David Cross, and I just downloaded this one because Black's name was recognizable and I hadn't really researched anything else. I certainly wasn't a huge Michael Ian Black fan before selecting it.As I've said elsewhere, I think writing a comedy book is an almost intrinsically doomed enterprise. In my mind, the author's best bet is to try to tell a story or impart some wisdom filigreed with (rather than dominated by) humor. This is what I loved about Bossypants, and this is what I love about the TV of comics like Louis C.K. If that be a genre of book, this book is its standard bearer. MIB tells brutally honest and surprisingly heartfelt tales of love and loss, growth and stagnation, all interlaced with refreshing, clever, appropriately apportioned humor. He can be dark as his name at times, and some of the ways in which he described his marriage and/or his coping mechanisms for his life left me thinking that they would be followed up with "we ended up divorced" or "things are much better now" or "so, obviously I went to rehab." But none of these neat little qualifiers ever appeared, because that's not what life is like. But I still finished this book a bit choked up, confident in the hard-won strength of his relationships and the often grudging devotion he has to making them work. Like Louis C.K. and others of his ilk, Black is a bit more acerbic and honest than we non-comedians might be when describing the most intimate details of his life and relationships, but there can be no doubting the sincerity of his love for his family, and the struggles and doubt he describes underscore rather than undermine this conclusion.This was elegant storytelling and surprisingly poignant. I would recommend it without reservation....more

title: Christodora
author: Murphy, Tim*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book sucked me in from the beginning. It's a rollicking, decades-long panorama of New York City in the style of The Amazing Adventures of KavalieThis book sucked me in from the beginning. It's a rollicking, decades-long panorama of New York City in the style of The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay, and at times I liked it just as much. Weaving together stories of gentrification, substance abuse, mental illness, adoption, the HIV/AIDS epidemic, and family dynamics, "Christadora" tells the story of one Alphabet City family--as well as those locked in its orbit--in poignant detail. I really enjoy books based in New York, because I get a thrill from the mention of places I've frequented--I used to live on Orchard and Houston in the LES, so I habituated Katz's, Russ & Daughters, Two Boots Pizza, The Blue and Gold, Tompkins Square Park, etc.--but it was also gripping to read about organizations I've actually worked with, like Gay Men's Health Crisis, and to understand a bit more of the saga decades before things had stabilized from Tim Murphy, a herald as entitled as any other to tell it. There were times when the "white guy writes dialogue for non-white people" trope got a bit awkward, and at times plot points felt too forced or realizations were made too hastily or clunkily. And I think that perhaps Jared's redemption was never realized and a few others left out or hastily concluded, but overall this was a highly enjoyable page-turner and tear-jerker. And for the dignity that it gives without sanitizing the HIV/AIDS rights movement, "Christadora" is a standout. It humanizes people who won small and quiet but vital (in the truest sense of the word!) victories in the face of imposing odds and social antipathy, and it does not airbrush out the scars they earned in their battles. As Murphy puts it, That was the thing about the [HIV/AIDS] movement, wasn't it? People came thinking they were dying but they ended up finding out how powerful they really were....more

review: Alright, so I pretty much love John Hodgman. I love his imperiousness, his cocksure tendency to hold forth on all matter of esoteric subjects, his bluAlright, so I pretty much love John Hodgman. I love his imperiousness, his cocksure tendency to hold forth on all matter of esoteric subjects, his blustery blending of pure balderdash with true trivia that almost certainly leaves people thinking true things he's said were made up of whole cloth, and vice versa.I saw some other s of this book, and they lamented the tediousness of it. A lot of them had read the first of the books in this trilogy, and really, I can't imagine his schtick changes much. So I'm sympathetic. But this is the first one that I read all the way through (I may have read the first one a long time ago, or at least part of it), and I really liked it. That is, until the end. For some odd reason the last full quarter of the book repeated the blandest of the tropes, "On this day in [year]... blah blah blah happened" and I kept finding myself thinking "Good god, this still?" Not something you should find yourself thinking in a comedy book.But I would give this book 3.5 stars. Also, as this was the audiobook, the first half of it featured John Hodgman riffing with Jonathan Coulton, whose bed I once drunkenly slept in one New Year's Day with my friend Alice and her then boyfriend. They got to stay in his magnificent townhouse in Cobble Hill in exchange for taking care of the family's pet rat because they were all in the same a cappella troupe as Coulton at Yale, albeit separated by a decade's time (you know Ivy League rituals--so esoteric!). title: I Drink for a Reason
author: Cross, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Definitely like David Cross a bit less after this one. I'm hesitant to criticize him, as he spent a good portion of this book callowly criticizing othDefinitely like David Cross a bit less after this one. I'm hesitant to criticize him, as he spent a good portion of this book callowly criticizing others who had criticized him in the past, telling them why they were wrong and also why they sucked. Then again, he always made it seem like he was righting some cosmic untruth or evenhandedly supplementing a skewed account, so I will try to be fair. Also I doubt he's haunting esoteric goodreads.com accounts...I like the guy's acting, and I assume without knowing that I must like a lot of stuff he has written. I doubt he had much to do with writing Arrested Development, but his performance in it is brilliant. He was likely much more involved in Todd Margaret and Mr. Show, both of which are excellent. But the book is not always the easiest medium to demonstrate one's sense of humor. Nonfiction memoir-y books by comedians tend to be good when they are conveying lessons or observations, and those things are framed with humor. But translating stand-up to audiobook--which is what a lot of this felt like--is bound to fall flat. Also, what is with straight guys who are "with it" feeling licensed to throw "faggot" and its derivatives around? In a way that mirrors misogynistic language but distinctly cleaves from practice with racial epithets, these mostly white guys, often comedians, deploy homophobic (and misogynistic) language to be transgressive and edgy or whatever. But Cross, himself a secular Jew who spends a considerable amount of time ridiculing Judaism, never uses any anti-Jewish slurs, even in his transgressive "that's not what I say, it's what that type of person we hate would say." Walk it back, assholes.Whatever. My biggest gripe was that this did not seem worthy of his talents. I liked the angry ranting about Larry the Cable Guy, sure, but a book with weird McSweeney's-rejects listicles and bitter recriminations against all of one's enemies needed to be more original to qualify as entertaining....more

title: Drift: The Unmooring of American Military Power
author: Maddow, Rachel*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was amazing. I can only compare it to taking a class with Prof. Jon Hanson in law school in terms of the scales it pulled from my eyes. How This book was amazing. I can only compare it to taking a class with Prof. Jon Hanson in law school in terms of the scales it pulled from my eyes. How could it be that someone who majored in History--with a focus on 20th Century American history, no less!--and who studied separation of powers and was forced to grapple with the limits of executive power in law school could be so ignorant of the seminal events in Grenada, Iran/Nicaragua, and Iraq I? I didn't even have a passing understanding of the first imbroglio, and Iran-Contra was something about which I could have offered you maybe two uncertain sentences. The first Iraq War was somewhat more developed in my mind (perhaps because it was the only one of the three that started after I was born?), but even then, I had no grasp of its indelible connection to the first two situations.Maddow emphasizes that the Founders strongly abhorred the idea of a standing army, and having studied history and understood that the spoils and glory of war accrue to the executive branch (and with the common-sense notion that the ability to make war should not be vested in a single individual) decided that the decision about whether to go to war should be something committed to the people who would be paying for it with their fortunes and their lives, something that they could affirm through the Congressional organ only if they truly thought the sacrifice merited suffering. Starting with Reagan and continuing with Bush I, she explores how Edwin Meese conjured up the idea of the president's unencumbered right to take swift military action in the name of American interests, and how that has unraveled so disastrously and alarmingly through the Bush II and Obama presidencies. She ably points out that the Cold War was something of a chimera, the Soviet Union mostly a stalking horse used to project American power and enrich contractors' coffers which should not have been recognized as a military equal or superior when the Politburo could not even keep its own people fed and was perpetually on the brink of collapse. The twin themes of military folly and transposition of the power to make war are followed through to show what led us to become this hectoring belligerent of a country, and how scary and contradictory to original intent it is that our military forces are now composed so substantially of contractors, guardsmen, and the CIA, who bear none of the accountability and little of the connection to public sentiment that were intended to make war an unpalatable last resort.But going back to Reagan--I want to know how all of these Republican dickheads who apotheosize Reagan can perseverate about Benghazi when Grenada was a way worse oversight, caused far more deaths, pissed off our most important ally, deceitfully circumvented Congress, and violated international law. Worse yet, Benghazi was a passive boondoggle, whereas Grenada was volitional. I suppose it's based on some glib distinction about how soldiers are supposed to die and Reagan, clumsy and senile as he was, was at least trying to protect American interests, whereas Benghazi involved civilians and an alleged disinterest in American integrity. But, as Maddow convincingly demonstrates: the idea of defending "American interests" is an almost laughably pliant concept used to justify all manner of deadly, destructive mischief, and these days the CIA more resembles our military wing than anything civilian....more

title: Here Comes the Sun
author: Dennis-Benn, Nicole *
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Here Comes the Sun" delivers. The story revolves around a Jamaican family of women, variously victims of sexual depredation, exploitation, incest, an"Here Comes the Sun" delivers. The story revolves around a Jamaican family of women, variously victims of sexual depredation, exploitation, incest, and rape, who pin their hopes to the reluctant youngest daughter of the group, whose prescribed ambition of becoming a doctor in order to lift the family from poverty begins to flag in light of a nascent interest in becoming an artist. The sacrifices that each endures are unfathomable, as is the degree to which the family members feel entitled to trammel on the others' lives to ensure the betterment of the whole. But without adequate communication this would-be alliance devolves into mutual recrimination, everyone focusing on her own sacrifices and unable to see the other members' means as anything but a selfish wrench thrown into the works.This book is heartbreakingly depressing and poignant, and it spares no one. There is a "Gift of the Magi" quality to the book, and from early on you can tell that things are not positioned to end well for any of the characters. And yet, despite the bleakness with which it must be described, there is an unmissable warmth that pervades the text, from the tender love stories expertly conveyed, to the reedy patois that breaks up the narrative. I enjoyed it all....more

title: The Sellout
author: Beatty, Paul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really disliked this one. It started off strong--the prologue is a flash forward (featuring Clarence Thomas angrily interrogating the protagonist) fI really disliked this one. It started off strong--the prologue is a flash forward (featuring Clarence Thomas angrily interrogating the protagonist) from the bulk of the text--but the actual body of the book was spent skipping around. Beatty never really developed any characters or settings, except insofar as they could be arranged to force some sort of snappy repartee, the characters dropping koans and bons mots while engaging in antics not much more sophisticated than what you would find in a Wayans brothers film (smoking weed under the defendant's table in front of the Supreme Court? Eyeroll). And while this book is marketed as "funny" I would say it was more clever than anything else. But it felt forced in a way that reminded me of Oscar Wilde--when a book is little more than a framing device for your witty observations, a different medium might be more economical.ETA: for those who enjoyed this one for its frank and humorous discussion of racial dynamics in the United States, consider checking out the overlooked and recently reprinted Oreo, by Fran Ross....more

review: This was a really sad tale. It starts off foreboding, but then morphs into something like Little-Rascals-in-the-Warsaw-Ghetto; who doesn't like pluckyThis was a really sad tale. It starts off foreboding, but then morphs into something like Little-Rascals-in-the-Warsaw-Ghetto; who doesn't like plucky little scamps sticking it to Jerry and quisling Jews alike? But, given that the end of the book is written in history, there was only one way for this book to end and it is very unsettling. I think Shepard does a great job of conveying what it is like for a young child to grow up amidst such anomie. Despite all the horror, crying is something of a luxury and the loss of a parent or sibling is barely significant enough to acknowledge. And through it all the children are warped but retain some essential kernel of juvenility--singing songs on marches, cadging for sweets despite general malnutrition, and carrying around totems of lost family members. Really evocatively rendered. ...more

review: I'm sure I'm holding Franzen to a higher standard, but I just didn't like "Purity" very much. Not that it was bad, I just can't really recall anythingI'm sure I'm holding Franzen to a higher standard, but I just didn't like "Purity" very much. Not that it was bad, I just can't really recall anything I particularly enjoyed. When I think of nuance and storytelling, I think of "The Corrections." But this book had little of what I loved of that earlier work, in favor of much that didn't appeal. The characters in "The Corrections" all had such complete stories, motivations, and narrative arcs, while characters in "Purity" seem alternatively static or to develop in staccato. And what's with the on-the-nose invocations of the book's title? And are we meant to find Andreas to be a believable character?Part of me picked this up because I wanted an audiobook and although I had higher hopes for "Freedom," I already own that in physical form. Given how frequently "The Corrections" is adulated and how often "Purity" is panned, I feel like this will give me much needed balance to weigh "Freedom" objectively....more

title: I Will Send Rain
author: Meadows, Rae*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I decided to read this on a visit to see my nieces in Dallas, given that Texas is maybe the closest I'll ever come to the Oklahoma in which this was sI decided to read this on a visit to see my nieces in Dallas, given that Texas is maybe the closest I'll ever come to the Oklahoma in which this was set. Plus, about 10 people were in line behind me to rent this from the Brooklyn Public Library, so I bumped it up in the queue so as not to deprive anyone the pleasure.As others have said, this book read like some of the best of Steinbeck. I'm sure the Okie connection and motherhood themes invite comparisons more often to "The Grapes of Wrath," but to me it felt a lot more like my favorite of Steinbeck's, "East of Eden." This book has the same satisfyingly lyrical descriptions--e.g., anger "crackles" behind eyes reminded me of Steinbeck's grass "shouting" up from the ground--the same loving attention to detailing the agrestic environment, a similar supernatural latency, and many family dynamics centered on redemption, the power of rebirth, and maintaining faith amidst wanton suffering. Unlike "East of Eden," it was economical with its storytelling and engrossing from the outset. All of the main characters are developed just well enough to generate attachment and sympathy, and they interact to tell a confined, rich tale. The writing in this book was really top-notch. I'm excited to read your other works, Rae!...more
