title: Call Me by Your Name
author: Aciman, André*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked this book up with not a small amount of trepidation. I was apprehensive because of how immensely beloved yet controversial it is in the worldI picked this book up with not a small amount of trepidation. I was apprehensive because of how immensely beloved yet controversial it is in the world of gay literature aficionados who make up large swathes of my friend groups, my book clubs, and this website's users. Around the time that the movie came out, the book was the topic du jour of the gay world, and I found myself buttonholed by even pointedly illiterate gays asking what I thought about it. Its plot and writing aside, it makes for energetic discussion: it's written by a straight man, its movie acted by some straight guys, full of purple prose, etc. About a year prior my friend Toby was the first to tell me about Mr. Aciman. He was justifiably skeptical of this ostensibly heterosexual author--just why was he writing indulgent poetry about youthful gay escapades? "How good could it really be?" we wondered. Toby loaned me a friend's copy of Enigma Variations, and I confusedly thought that I had CMBYN stored away for whenever I was ready for it. So, when I made it through my queue of book club books and finally dug around in my literal pile of books for this title, I came up empty handed and had to wait quite a while behind the rest of the frugal, straggler, New York gays who rely on the public library to see what all the fuss was about.I admit that I'm less interested in/concerned with the straight writer thing than most people seem to be--I think it's kind of impressive for this guy to write this book that different generations of gay men--a famously persnickety crowd!--can moon over in common. It really is quite the feat! I'm sure there is a normative question in there about whether privileged individuals should be writing the stories of marginalized individuals, but I'll leave that criticism for a clumsier production. My hesitation had a separate etiology--I'm just generally skeptical of anything involving taste that people all gush over. It's why I've almost entirely stopped seeing "critical darling" movies--people talk about them as if they're life-changing and then curse you if you don't have the exact same intensity of reaction. And, if anything, the expectations were piled even higher for this at-most biennial cultural phenomenon--the book that all and sundry cannot stop discussing.So I was ready for CMBYN to underwhelm me. About halfway through I might have described myself as only mildly impressed. The writing really is poetic, but often it felt belletristic, nothing I would describe as genius or breathtaking. And some of its devices fell flat for me--for example, the whole "call me by your name" bit seems like something a straight person would imagine would be the acme of erotica for gay couples, something that only same-sex couples and the rare Alex-Alex, Jordan-Jordan heterosexual couple can ever achieve. But it just struck me as kind of odd and not adequate for the amount of gravitas the author hoped to invest it with. Yet the book is peppered with freshets of reflection and lyricism that are truly magnificent, and overall the effect of reading it is a highly pleasant, engrossing one. But I think this book stands out above all else for its faithful recreation of youthful infatuation and concupiscence, the all-consuming, excruciating, ineffable experience of a first true crush. Reading CMBYN recreates all of the aching pain and unbearable excitement of young love, but also of honeyed summer days, self-consciously trying out the nascent freedom of young adulthood, and the plummy charm of handsome youth. It's a masterwork of nostalgia, and I enjoyed it. Who knows, I might even go see the movie...!...more

title: The Plot Against America
author: Roth, Philip
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When Roth is good, he is so very good. This book was sheer entertainment. Roth has such a marvelous imagination and knack for conjuring credible emotiWhen Roth is good, he is so very good. This book was sheer entertainment. Roth has such a marvelous imagination and knack for conjuring credible emotional and conversational dynamics. I think back to Herman's officiousness with Mr. Taylor, DC tour guide extraordinaire, and of Philip getting locked in the bathroom, and of Selden perseverating about his birthday party and the clarity of the long-distance line in the midst of the Louisville riots--everything is just so perfectly constructed and believable. I couldn't help wondering, wryly, about how different this book might have been had it been written in 2017 instead of 2004. Roth is painstaking in his portrayal of the ascent of Lindbergh as a rational, sober, and dispassionate choice only tangentially and incidentally connected to the racist regime of the Nazis. He resists the urge to portray Lindbergh as a vitriolic messiah who rides to power on a wave of bile cultivated through inflammatory rhetoric and unstatesmanlike conduct. Oh, to live in a time when such a conceit was necessary to preserve verisimilitude!...more

title: The Fire Next Time
author: Baldwin, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Not much to say about this quick read. Not because it isn't powerful, evocative, and brilliant, but because there's nothing I can add to Baldwin's indNot much to say about this quick read. Not because it isn't powerful, evocative, and brilliant, but because there's nothing I can add to Baldwin's indictment of America, and of the idea that the downtrodden are the ones in need of spiritual elevation. The following passage, however, seemed especially relevant in our present "Make America Great Again" times:The American Negro has the great advantage of having never believed that collection of myths to which white Americans cling: that their ancestors were all freedom-loving heroes, that they were born in the greatest country the world has ever seen, or that Americans are invincible in battle and wise in peace, that Americans have always dealt honorably with Mexicans and Indians and all other neighbors or inferiors, that American men are the world’s most direct and virile, that American women are pure....more

review: This was a really short one, which was kind of hard to imagine coming from Roth. I hadn't even heard of it (I picked it up at the library from the conThis was a really short one, which was kind of hard to imagine coming from Roth. I hadn't even heard of it (I picked it up at the library from the contemporary shelf, having been listening to The Plot Against America and really remembering why I love Roth after the disappointment that was Sabbath's Theater), and that's perhaps not very surprising. Not that it wasn't good (it was, in a lot of ways), it's just that people have such strong feelings about Roth and those who care for him enough to plumb the more remote depths of his oeuvre will probably not be satisfied. I say that because it has none of the character development or the intricate story arcs of the best Roth novels. It's an able meditation on death and frailty, but feels more like a concept he thought about abandoning halfway through before burnishing it and tying up some loose ends.ETA: this won Roth his third PEN/Faulkner award?!...more

author: Knausgård, Karl Ove
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So because this is the book/series of books of the moment, there's a running meta-commentary on the decision to even read it. My boss, a live-wire autSo because this is the book/series of books of the moment, there's a running meta-commentary on the decision to even read it. My boss, a live-wire author herself said "Why would you want to read about some Norwegian guy navel-gazing for 400 pages?" My co-worker with whom I trade book suggestions said "It's really bad, but also really good." A date said it was "Absolutely astounding." And countless people have given me looks on the subway or while waiting for the elevator, or asked how I'm finding it. As I indicated in a recent status update, I still fail to grasp what it is that people love or hate about this book. I don't really understand why it's so compelling for the literary commentariat, as nothing really stood out to me; furthermore, if the really compelling stuff is to be found in the later books in the anthology, then I don't really understand what propels people to undertake to tackle them. I bought the first and second books at a thrift store for $3 each because of the thrill of buying new books for low prices (I've said before that because I buy all of my books used from half.com, the newest, most ballyhooed titles are rarely available), so I may get around to reading the next installment, but we shall see. Another thought about the hubbub surrounding this book--where is the ethical quandary? How is this different from "This Boy's Life"? Shrug.As to the plot, let me just say that I am so very grateful to have both healthy and independent relationships with my parents. And though alcoholism bedevils many friends and family members, it's a blessing that it never (not yet, at least) manifests in the hellish, grotesque, almost "As I Lay Dying" mortification that takes up the latter half of this book....more

title: A Moveable Feast
author: Hemingway, Ernest
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Story time with Papa, and it's worth it just for the quirky little anecdotes you get about the Lost Generation's most remarkable rogues. This book wasStory time with Papa, and it's worth it just for the quirky little anecdotes you get about the Lost Generation's most remarkable rogues. This book was a bit thin on substance and not very long, its vignettes slightly picaresque and only loosely strung together in a way that recalled Calvino's "Marcovaldo." I came away with two distinct impressions:1) It is a wonderful thing to have just enough money and to live in a city that can lay credible claim to serving as capital of the world. When Hemingway says:There is never any ending to Paris and the memory of each person who has lived in it differs from that of any other. We always returned to it no matter who we were or how it was changed or with what difficulties, or ease, it could be reached. Paris was always worth it and you received return for whatever you brought to it. But this is how Paris was in the early days when we were very poor and very happy.I can substitute "New York" for Paris and every word rings true. I don't do it nearly enough, but every once in a while I walk around marveling at the city: its people, its mechanics, the improbable semifunctionality of the whole endeavor. I proselytize in only one way--by encouraging people to live here--mostly because I haven't the vocabulary to convey what it is to be part of the Leviathan. 2) I've always thought it strange that F. Scott Fitzgerald and Hemingway were buds. Hemingway is so brusque and confident and hypermasculine and contemptuous of ornamentation. F. Scott is insecure and epicene and lyrical, with an arriviste's obsession with the trappings of the Eastern elite. And the stories Hemingway relates don't much hint at some uniting factor that transcends these incongruities: F. Scott is importunate, hypochondriacal, can't hold his liquor, and married to a sociopathic loon. But Papa tolerates him anyway, showers rare (and appropriate) praise upon The Great Gatsby, and his infant son's cat is even named F. Puss!! Amazing.But I really wish this relationship had been the whole book. Who needs fusty old Gertrude Stein or that coxcomb Ford Maddox Ford. I want more of this odd couple; someone should write "The Untold Tales of Fitz' and Ernie." I mean, how about that bro-mantic moment when F. Scott asks Hemingway if his endowment is adequate, and then Hemingway takes him to see a bunch of statuary at the Lourve!? And then Fitzgerald doubles down by confessing that he's a shower--not a grower--and Hemingway reassures him anyway? Tender-is-the-ego, and that is some solid gold right there....more

title: Rabbit Redux        (Rabbit Angstrom, #2)
author: Updike, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I guess this didn't take me quite as long as I imagined, but it sure felt like it took a while.I mentioned in my  of Rabbit, Run that I was moreI guess this didn't take me quite as long as I imagined, but it sure felt like it took a while.I mentioned in my  of Rabbit, Run that I was more curious about how this book/remainder of the tetrarchy could be pulled off than enamored of the characters or storyline or even really the writing. As such, I resolved to read the rest when I had the chance, but was in no special hurry to do so.Fast forward about a month and I was walking around SoHo on a particularly beautiful day. Contrary to my usual custom I was neither looking at the ground nor lost in a book (far too much foot traffic in SoHo for the latter), and happened to be a bit lower than eye-level with one of those monstrous pine green transformer boxes affixed to a streetlight. Sitting atop it were two books: "Cold Mountain" and this title. "Cold Mountain" was in better shape, and the cover of the 1971 copy of "Rabbit Redux" crumbled away completely before I was halfway through the book, but I kept it anyway and hoped the other book would be descried by someone in search of it before the next rain came along.I'm not sure what to make of this book, really. It's amazing (though a bit jarring) that the infanticide (babyslaughter?) from the previous entry is so papered over. Instead of forming the main dramatic pretense for the book, it is only mentioned in passing, typically deployed by Rabbit as lightly mordant jabs without much counterreaction. Instead, our protagonist begins the book as this fusty, almost comically hawkish racist/misogynist/idiot bigot who, for whatever reason, takes in an 18-year-old debutante manqué and her Leninist African American lover and rather seamlessly transforms into an unholy Archie-Bunker-meets-Colonel-Kurtz pastiche. The debates (many of which--focusing on wealth and power and the wisdom of blindly supporting one's government--we are only just thawing out 40 some years later) are very interesting and intense, but the weird voyeuristic sex triangle and drug-addled interpersonal conflict between the debaters felt tedious and disruptive. One final thought: Updike gets a lot of flak for his misogyny. It's true that there are a lot of dumb (Janice), weak (Jill, Peggy) women in this series. But there are also intelligent, liberated women (Mim, Mrs. Angstrom). And I think we have to view all of the characters in the context of Rabbit, who has plenty of quips but whose opinions verge on regurgitated and whose behavior is the most deplorable of any main character in the series. Aside from Skeeter (maybe) or Nelson, this book lacks heroes of either gender. They are stories of industrial frustration and interpersonal pettiness followed by inevitable reconciliation, and neither men nor women come away smelling of roses.I'm probably less certain that I will finish with the tetrarchy having read the second installment (sorry, Steve!), but if Rabbit Angstrom teaches anything, it's that life is long, full of unexpected twists, and that connections endure, even in the absence of strong affection. I'll keep glancing at transformers and see whether the universe will conspire to put the third book in my hands, one way or another. ...more

review: Now this was an American bildungsroman for the (relatively) modern era.In this book author Tobias Wolff tells the story of his childhood in the small Now this was an American bildungsroman for the (relatively) modern era.In this book author Tobias Wolff tells the story of his childhood in the small town America of the 1950s. I have no reason to believe it was embellished or fabular, and thus it resonated with me more than the fictive bildungsromans we read in school by the likes of Twain and his ilk. Wolff fits the fairly common "deposed patrician" mold, living in unstable, spartan circumstances with his mother while his father shacks up with millionaires and his brother bops around Princeton, both mostly exhibiting the sense of invulnerability and studied aloofness that one would expect of Deerfield and Choate (respectively) men of that era. Despite the reader's knowledge of this lofty pedigree, in the end Wolff's (view spoiler)[acceptance to the Hill School (hide spoiler)] seems almost a deus ex machina, because it so radically reshapes his circumstances and his character. Although the circumstances of his life amply justified his desire to escape the proximity and circumstances of Dwight et al., Wolff discloses how he actually covets status and money, the liveries thereof, and all the other elitist trappings that an Eastern prep school imparts. This not only sets him apart from the relatable, "every boy" protagonists of Twain's novels, it makes him, in my mind, a bit contemptuous, especially given his other failings (most especially(view spoiler)[ his failure to apologize to the destitute Welches, but also his continuous lying, moral failings, quiet betrayals, manipulations and misrepresentations (hide spoiler)]).But you don't have to like or admire the boy to enjoy this book. Reading it felt a lot like that recent ballyhooed film "Boyhood." It ably displayed the simultaneous naivete and wisdom of young children, how quickly and completely pettiness metastasizes within failed men, and the anxious bargaining and hand wringing that cramp the autonomy of single mothers. Most memorably for me, it was a view into the small-town white America of the 1950s, of which my father tells me stories and whose frustrated masculinity and omnipresent practicality instinctively repel me, yet whose sense of childhood wonder seems so much more vivid and capable than my own....more

review: What an amazing accomplishment this book is! I am kind of a lexiphile, and was surprised that this type of list did not exist on the internet. EventuaWhat an amazing accomplishment this book is! I am kind of a lexiphile, and was surprised that this type of list did not exist on the internet. Eventually I came across the grandiloquent dictionary (http://www.islandnet.com/~egbird/dict..., which is mostly a condensed form of Mrs. Byrne's compendium), but by then I was committed to combing through all of the pages of this book and copying down those that I thought most enjoyable and useful. At times it got tedious--there are a ton of Latin and Greek words in here that are essentially just mechanical conjunctions for mostly inutile words along the lines of "reverse heart shaped" and "fear of the number 14", etc.--but there were enough French and Germanic words and useful Greek/Latin ones to make it worth the while. There was no plot to this, but I am enclosing my favorite word for each letter of the alphabet, along with its definition. Enjoy!Afterclap – an unexpected repercussionBreedbate – someone looking for an argumentCooster – a worn-out libertineDearbought – purchased at a high priceEnucleate – to extract the kernel of truth fromFootle – to waste time, to talk nonsenseGrimgribber – technical legal jargonHellkite – an extremely cruel personImbonity – lack of good qualitiesJawbone – to attempt to influence or pressure by persuasion rather than by the exertion of force or one's authority, as in urging voluntary compliance with economic guidelinesKokshut – used up or worn outLypophrenia – a feeling of vague sadness without causeMossback – a conservative reactionaryNostrificate – to accept as one’s ownObganiate – to cause irritation by repetitionPilpul – an ingenious, hairsplitting argumentQuonking – sideline or audience chatter that disturbs a performanceRejectamenta – things rejected as worthlessSpizzerinctum – ambition or will to succeedThoke – to lie or idle in bedUltracrepidarian – overstepping one’s boundariesViraginity – masculinity in a womanWight – brave and strongXanthochroid – light skinned and blondeYesterfang – something taken yesterday (or long ago)Zygal – shaped like the letter H ...more

title: Cloud Atlas
author: Mitchell, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a bit of a rollercoaster for me. It was so disjointed at the beginning that I admit to reading the plot summary for each minibook on the WikiThis was a bit of a rollercoaster for me. It was so disjointed at the beginning that I admit to reading the plot summary for each minibook on the Wikipedia page. But eventually I anchored my understanding of what the book was doing and what it was trying to achieve and it became enjoyable, progressively so. For me, the acme was probably the middle, uninterrupted section. That and the one before it were suspenseful, interesting, compelling in a way that the other novellas seemed to lack. It could just be my proclivity for future dystopias and alternate worlds, but when we trundled back to the present and began to go backward in time, my enjoyment began to wane.I'm not sure I felt that I fully realized what Mitchell was trying to achieve, here. Apparently he was trying to show that human nature is indelible and manifests itself in predictable patterns in all of our lives and circumstances, societies and interpersonal relationships. The movie makes this visual by having the same actor play the same characters in different scenarios, but (perhaps: blame it on the audiobook, again?) I didn't see that the characters were strong analogues for each other throughout the epochs.I'd give this 3.5 stars, and I will certainly read more of Mitchell: he has a marvelous imagination, can write plaintive and comic scenes dexterously, and obviously has an interest in complex plots....more

review: This book, at only roughly 200 pages, felt like a huge slog. I understand that it was a watershed book in the science fiction/dystopia genre, of whichThis book, at only roughly 200 pages, felt like a huge slog. I understand that it was a watershed book in the science fiction/dystopia genre, of which I am generally a fan. And more legitimate fans than I might see the Doric antecedents of the Corinthian tropes to come, but it felt stilted and poorly written to me. It was difficult to tell what was going on, and so I constantly had to consult summaries just to have an understanding of what was transpiring. A shorter and more difficult subway commute might also have something to do with it, but in 3-5 page increments, subduing my frustration with the strange conventions--everyone is given a name in the form of Letter-Number; ellipses eliding seemingly important information (e.g. "It was almost as if. . ."; "I couldn't help but think . . .")--and restarting it after my first 60-page attempt was aborted, this felt like it took forrrevvvverrrrr. ...more

review: More than any other author who comes to mind, DeLillo seems to be the one modern readers are the most conflicted over. Glancing through the s ofMore than any other author who comes to mind, DeLillo seems to be the one modern readers are the most conflicted over. Glancing through the s of this book from the GR users whom I follow, there are many "I loved/hated [this DeLillo book] but hated/loved [this other DeLillo book]" and many other "DeLillo is my favorite author whom I would never recommend to anyone else"-type comments.It's curious. But I found myself without an explanation for why I was undertaking my third DeLillo book this year despite having had only mixed impressions of the first two. And these were not short books--Underwold clocks in at over 800 pages, while Libra is 500+. Granted, Mao II is much shorter and I finished it on bookended weekend bus trips from NYC to Philadelphia, but I have dozens of other books awaiting me in my room from authors who only exist in my mind as unblemished potential. So why persist with DeLillo?I had a suspicion about this book: the things that I didn't love about DeLillo in his longer works (too many characters tenuously sketched, difficult plot development, rambling stories and anecdotes) would likely be precluded by necessity in a shorter book. Unfortunately, I was wrong. In fact, I think it must be DeLillo's style, regardless of the length of the work. He's like one of those pendulums you see in museums, with a pencil attached to the bottom: he swings in wide arcs and soars in dubiously related tangents but every once in a while deigns to add to the plot he is continuously teasing us with by scratching a bold stroke right through the story's center. It can be frustrating but also very rewarding. His books are sprawling and betray a numinous imagination, an unsurpassed talent for developing unique perspectives and dialogues and vernaculars, all leavened with a healthy shot of good old fashioned Americana. And throughout it all, it's unmistakable that he is a gifted writer. There are passages in DeLillo that you have to watch out for (lest you miss them amongst the gratuitous perambulating) that will leave you gobsmacked. Mao II was so loosely constructed and its characters underdeveloped that I really did not enjoy it. It makes three DeLillo books/1500+ DeLillo pages with an average of fewer than three stars. But there is no way it will be the last of his works that I read....more

title: Atonement
author: McEwan, Ian*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked up this somewhat short book a while back, but I went to an excellent nouveau cirque performance interpreting the works of Salvador Dalí and fI picked up this somewhat short book a while back, but I went to an excellent nouveau cirque performance interpreting the works of Salvador Dalí and forgot my bag in the coat check. I picked up "A God in Ruins" (which deals with very similar subject matter) but then left that at a bar after an unusually lively Friday night that saw me climbing into bed at 4am. Before I committed to juggling three books at once and risked ferhoodling the details of the books' very posh, wartime-British protagonists I decided it was time to retrieve my briefcase, in which I had stuffed "Atonement."I wasn't totally enamored of the book throughout its first third. There was too much ambient description and not enough character development(view spoiler)[, which is something that the young Briony is criticized for in the letter she receives from her editors. If we're meant to believe that she wrote the first part as a young girl and honed her writing skill as an adult following this advice, I'm not sure to what extent it shone through. I also thought that the relationship between Robbie and Cee was too tenuous to support the believability of the ardor and devotion that followed--after all, these people had gone years without speaking to one another. Robbie had carried a torch for Cee, certainly, but the basis of her love for him was a childhood intimacy wholly glossed over, then teenage detente, then classist segregation at university, before receiving a crude note, followed by a single instance of making love--"fucking," as Robbie amends--in the library the very same night a ghastly accusation is made. It seemed like something that could have been developed at the expense of the excruciating description that plagued many parts of this book, as it did Briony's first novella (hide spoiler)].But where there was dialogue, things seemed to move apace. Sometimes too quickly, actually. And when others saw me reading this book I encountered similar dissatisfaction with McEwan's pacing--"I wish he would write short stories" and "That is certainly a plodding book," etc.Ultimately the ending I thought was very well done and rescued this from a two-star rating. McEwan also did an admirable job of portraying the gruesome aspects of war from both the soldier's and the nurse's point of view; I only wish he had seen fit to lard the story with more of it....more

review: I really love Yates, and this book had all the hallmarks of his usually great stuff--bleak family drama, characters' inability to cope or help themselI really love Yates, and this book had all the hallmarks of his usually great stuff--bleak family drama, characters' inability to cope or help themselves, the ennui of the modern corporate job. And it's shot through with snappy, realistic dialogue and credible eccentricities. But this was also the first time that Yates' ending seemed lazy to me. The writing process is nothing to belittle or underestimate, but the more I read of Yates the more I believe that predominant bleakness has less artistic and entertainment merit if it fails to offer any hope or whiff of redemption. I will continue to read him in hopes of finding an exception, but the shine has been taken off a bit....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I joined this site around the time that Yanagihara's A Little Life was just starting to blow up. I would mention that I wanted to read it, people woulI joined this site around the time that Yanagihara's A Little Life was just starting to blow up. I would mention that I wanted to read it, people would immediately mention that I should prepare for a month of public crying, and I patiently waited for the queue to tick down at the Brooklyn public library. During this interlude, however, several friends whose opinions about art and literature more closely mirror my own started to dissent a bit. It wasn't that they didn't like the book, it just felt gratuitous. The more I thought about it, the less inclined I was to read it.But many in the former camp also lauded this, Yanagihara's debut, and although I think it's a bit peculiar to have something as specific and dark as child sexual abuse frame your first and only two novels, this seemed at least somewhat lighter fare, to the extent that such distinctions can be made in the context. As my friend Robert said in his , "Nabokov with half the fireworks still lights up the sky." I was continuously reminded of Nabokov throughout--it has the provocation, the lyricism, the taboos, and the deep commitment to detail and character that highlight Nabokov's best-known works, plus the moral issues surrounding incest/ephebophilia of Ada, or Ardor: A Family Chronicle/Lolita and the amoral apologist Charles Kinbote-ish narrator of Pale Fire!I guess I'm torn about whether to read "A Little Life" because I really enjoyed this. Yanagihara is a master storyteller and she weaves together moral quandaries, character development, and sultry mysticism very deftly. Perhaps I'll wait for her next effort to guide me?...more

title: Ada, or Ardor: A Family Chronicle
author: Nabokov, Vladimir
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Nabokov's "Lolita" was the first book I ever truly loved, and the first time I remember being humbled by an author's lovely genius. I'm not sure if thNabokov's "Lolita" was the first book I ever truly loved, and the first time I remember being humbled by an author's lovely genius. I'm not sure if that was just because I was 17 or if it would have been as impactful had I picked it up for the first time today, but I have a hunch that the balance tilts toward the latter. During my pre-law school days of glacial reading, I picked up "Pale Fire" and "Pnin" and the sense of awe was only renewed. Three for three, and a fecund postgrad period of reading recently upon me, I decided I should check out the rest of his oeuvre. I read "Bend Sinister" a few months ago, but was not very impressed with it. I flew to California this weekend and wanted a long book to occupy me on my flight, and chose "Ada, or Ardor"... a (non-rhotic) pun is in the title! How could I not love it?Ada is Nabokov's longest work by a considerable margin. It is also very recondite and often difficult to follow. Most notably, it is supersaturated with details of an incestuous love triangle between three siblings. Given these details, I think that old Vlad would forgive me the anachronism of dubbing it "Infinite 'Cest."But I got fatigued by this book. The word play is savant-level, as always (perhaps eclipsing Lolita, here), and I looked up literally hundreds of words, many of them presumably made up by Nabokov himself (for comparison, I have since read a 300 page John Updike novel and am 100 pages into McEwan's "Atonement" and haven't hit up the dictionary once). But at 600+ pages it gets a bit self-indulgent. I felt the same way about Roth's Sabbath's Theater -- clearly written by a master, but it could have benefited from more exacting editing. Even if we acknowledge Nabokov's amazing ability to make incest seem normal and even tender at times, we have to contend with all of the other child rape and pederasty and violence and gourmandise and it just begins to feel gratuitous. Ditto for all of the other Nabokov peculiarities (parenthetical editing, toggling between French, Russian, and odd pidgin languages that may or may not exist in the real world, etc.) in this book.I understand that he synthesized this novel from two book concepts he intended to pursue. But Nabokov was enough of a genius to pack nuance and humor and insight better than anyone into 300 pages. It begins to become garbled at 600+. So I'd say give this book a shot if you're curious--lots of folks I respect adore (*pats lips with napkin affectedly*) this novel, but it really is an investment in time, patience, and fortitude.Finally, random Nabokov fanboy thought: stop trying to make "limpid" happen, Gretchen! Honestly that word appears probably 20x in this book, disproportionately in his other works, and maybe five other times in all of English spoken or written word. Overuse of it makes him seem like a stupid limping imp sdkfkanf;ksdfngxmvksgdnds;ms...more

title: What Belongs to You
author: Greenwell, Garth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My, this was a sad one: at some point in the near past, a young, sexually repressed American teacher in stagnant Sofia, Bulgaria attempts to suage hisMy, this was a sad one: at some point in the near past, a young, sexually repressed American teacher in stagnant Sofia, Bulgaria attempts to suage his loneliness and foreignness with a young Slavic hustler named Mitko. Or at least that's how the book was pitched to me.In reality the gay prostitution only seemed incidental, and this to me was a powerful tale of the teleological nature of class and economic opportunity. It is hinted that Mitko came from relative prosperity, but that means little in a Bulgaria where the students at the author's high school--the most prestigious one in the country--continuously bemoan their lack of economic opportunity and yearn to leave the country, never to return. Instead, Mitko turns tricks, cadges gaudy tech baubles from his suitors, and maintains an exploitative relationship with the author that is seemingly more ambiguous to the audience than to the author himself. When the exploitation turns to desperation--a worrying reliance on alcohol and drugs, medicines incidental to the sex trade that are hard to come by outside of the West--we (Westerners) are faced with the grim and discomfiting reality of the capriciousness of our own access to comfort, dignity, and opportunity.I think this is best reflected in the title--at first, it appears to be a reference to the inability to claim one whom you love, especially when that person is very obviously entangled with others and may not reciprocate your affections, or at the very least their intensity. But just as importantly I think it invokes the concepts of privilege and position that are in so many ways our most vital and determinative--if wholly unearned--possessions....more

review: This feels like the godfather of the graphic novels.** The one that transitioned the hackneyed medium of comic books into the respectable genre of graThis feels like the godfather of the graphic novels.** The one that transitioned the hackneyed medium of comic books into the respectable genre of graphic novels by distilling what makes them great and dispensing with--or inverting--the cliches that bedevil them: what "The Sopranos" and "Mad Men" were to TV, what "The Dark Knight" was to superhero movies.It starts out feeling like not-your-father's-comic-book, with some seriously heavy anti-hero stuff, but it kind of collapses back into the hokeyness of the genre by the end. Or it at least feels that way, aesthetically. There's plenty of surprising wanton violence, an excellent weaving of storylines together across a truly astounding volume of pages, panels, and characters, and let us not forget that truly sinister, unsettling, and cynical ending, but I think I will enjoy this work's progeny more, even if they owe it all to "Watchmen."**This is pure conjecture, but it seems influential, divergent, and precocious enough, no?...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Something close to four stars for this one. It was light, funny, surprisingly quick and very engaging. The invitation to comparison with Franzen's "ThSomething close to four stars for this one. It was light, funny, surprisingly quick and very engaging. The invitation to comparison with Franzen's "The Corrections" is inevitable, but CDAS writes with less of a sense of justice. I actually say that as a compliment--this book is more clement, more magnanimous. It's nice that characters you're rooting for emerge bettered by the progression of plot, and nicer still when it doesn't come at the expense of the more problematic characters' redemptions. I thought that this book was a pretty marvelous exploration of Manhattanite priorities, quirks, and idiosyncrasies. Between the four kids and the unglued matriarch, they cover all of the important bases. Still--and maybe this is too quibbling--the way this book was pitched and the way that the characters seem positioned within society, it's surprising that they all come so undone over an amount of money roughly amounting to $500,000 each. Now don't get me wrong, I buy my groceries at the Stop-and-Shop and take the subway everywhere, I work in nonprofit law and do not come from means, so $500,000 would literally change my life forever. But for a bunch of upper-crust New Yorkers, it doesn't seem like a sum that could realistically set this wave of drama into motion....more

author: Robinson, Marilynne

review: Housekeeping is the story of Ruthie and Lucille, "Irish twins" who spend the first 20 pages cycling through variously hapless and derelict forebears bHousekeeping is the story of Ruthie and Lucille, "Irish twins" who spend the first 20 pages cycling through variously hapless and derelict forebears before ending up in bucolic Idaho with their idiosyncratic aunt Sylvie to watch over them in the house in which their grandmother raised both generations of women. Lucille is a slave to convention and pushes her family away in exchange for her what she imagines is the approbation of more respectable members of the community/country. Ruthie, gradually revealed to take after Sylvie more than her younger sister, is the laconic introvert, content but not tied to having her younger sister be her sole friend and seemingly more suited to spare panhandle Idaho.What initially appears to be Lucille’s ungrateful stolidity gradually reveals itself to be judicious self-preservation; this is one understandable approach. The other is Ruthie’s—catching as catch can a connection that is flawed and tragic but sympathetic when taken by someone whose life has been marked by abandonment and remote isolation. I didn’t like this half as much as Gilead, but the writing is sublime. At her best, Marilynne Robinson verges on oracular. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Goddamn, James Baldwin can call down a blistering jeremiad!Told through the lens of a mass murder trial set in Atlanta in the 1980s, this book simultaGoddamn, James Baldwin can call down a blistering jeremiad!Told through the lens of a mass murder trial set in Atlanta in the 1980s, this book simultaneously calls white and black America to task for rushing to pin the murders of 28 black children on a man who was loathsome but nevertheless unlikely to have had any part in these horrors. Baldwin thoroughly vitiates the presumption that Germans or the English or Americans are the stewards of civilization, pointing out the Holocaust, the colonization and genocide of the Irish, and that of Native Americans ("The dream of safety can reach culmination or climax only in the nightmare orgasm of genocide") as ample evidence undermining these claims, and extends the criticism to a "post-Civil Rights" America where whites continue to brutalize blacks, and where blacks are all too willing to collaborate in this brutalization themselves.Reading this after binge watching American Crime Story: The People vs. O.J. Simpson felt surreal. But when you have as piercing a gaze as Baldwin possessed, I suppose it will always feel prescient....more

Really simple, beautiful, (unsurprisingly) lyrical writing. Smith chronicles a New York that is mystifyingly mourned by so many of its modern denizens. People want the grit, but they want to paper over all of the dirt, death, and peril. It's like people who idealize the Middle Ages without pausing to consider how much they value modern hygiene or suffrage or living past the age of 50. This book speaks to the beauty and uniqueness of that time in New York without letting its reader forget the hellish aspects that made it possible for the someone like Smith to make a life here among outcasts and celebrities like Maplethorpe, having little more than talent and a bus ticket to get her NYC life started. ...more

review: I feel like a parent whose brainy and capable child has shown me his D+. Such disappointment from an author I usually read with relish! There are a feI feel like a parent whose brainy and capable child has shown me his D+. Such disappointment from an author I usually read with relish! There are a few stories in here that might be salvageable, but the rest--and in particular the title story--are scattered and sophomoric, penises being lopped off left and right and fubsy Midwesterners pummeling each other with abandon. This collection was published in the same year that Saunders was awarded the MacArthur "genius" grant. I have to imagine the MacArthur people read this and thought "My god, we've made a huge mistake!" Luckily I think the decision was vindicated by the return to greatness that is Tenth of December, but this one is just a miss. So much of what was annoying about this book Saunders deploys so charmingly in his other collections, but I think he also does so more subtly. This was that unlucky child of handsome parents who inherits too many strong features for a normal countenance to contain. ...more

title: A Constellation of Vital Phenomena
author: Marra, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was holding this on an elevator when a colleague asked me what I was reading. I showed her the title and she grimaced. I asked her whether the subjeI was holding this on an elevator when a colleague asked me what I was reading. I showed her the title and she grimaced. I asked her whether the subject matter was too heavy for her, that being the only reasonable reason I could conjure for why someone would dislike this book, but it just didn't resonate with her, apparently.I can't really understand why. This book contains so much of what makes good storytelling. The characters are endearing and flawed and they evolve. They operate in a complex and richly detailed world. Their interactions and connections are human and realistic. It is a heady mix of tragedy and hopefulness that is deftly achieved.And the writing is something to behold. As a younger man I would take stock of my more famous coevals when they would host, for instance, SNL. At a slightly riper age I am astounded by the empathy, imagination, patience, and lyricism that Marra had to marshall at my current age to generate a work like this. Surely there are conventions that he leans too heavily on--the omniscient narrator noting that "in X years, [character] would [do something]," for instance--but overall the sense of perspective and knack for storytelling is something close to numinous. This book prefigured the marvel that is The Tsar of Love and Techno, and augurs the career of a talented author and gifted storyteller. Through personal connections I have it on good authority that the author is currently working on his next book, which will have the same Slavic setting as his previous two books but with an Italian-American narrator more closely approximating the author's own experience ("It's something subtle that I can't really define, but it's clear that you're not really a Russian" my first generation Russian-American roommate advised him at a wedding last month); I cannot wait!...more

title: The Tsar of Love and Techno
author: Marra, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked this up for a few reasons: it’s actually my roommate’s, and she is gone for the weekend. Also, because of student loan thriftiness, I tend toI picked this up for a few reasons: it’s actually my roommate’s, and she is gone for the weekend. Also, because of student loan thriftiness, I tend to buy most of my books from used book stores online, which typically precludes my buying anything published in the most recent 2-3 years, save for the most popular fiction. Third (and fourth?), both my roommate and one of my best friends from college (independently--small world!) are good friends with the author’s long-term girlfriend (mentioned in the acknowledgements), and I met her when she stayed at my apartment a few months back, finding her lovely and charming. Fifth, some friends wrote encomiums about Marra’s debut effort.Having just finished it, I’m not sure what to make of this novel. But let’s be clear—despite lots of (in my opinion: odd) reports of prejudice against this book for being a collection of short stories (which it also very much is), the plot lines are sufficiently interconnected that they form a cogent whole. And not in the “Mad About You” and “Friends” way (sophisticated analogy, I know), but rather the “Cheers” and “Frasier” way—deep and important connections between characters that you are meant to recognize and which enrich the experience considerably. I don't believe you can appreciate the significance of any one story without absorbing each of the others.When I first picked this up I was dazzled by the lyricism and the frabjous tableau that Marra had begun painting. Perhaps it was inattentive reading, or a fatigue with the Russian gulag/oppressive state trope of late (“Libra,” “House of Meetings,” “Bend Sinister,” FX’s excellent “The Americans”), but my interest flagged in the middle—five star potential, lowed to a 4, perhaps approaching a 3! Yet as the connections emerged toward the book’s conclusion the intricacy and accomplishment of Marra’s vision became apparent, with his dexterous storytelling and facility with the written word enhancing the experience considerably. I came away impressed....more

review: I took the day off for my birthday but woke up at my typical 5am hour. I stayed in bed all morning reading this fiery little gem and couldn't have picI took the day off for my birthday but woke up at my typical 5am hour. I stayed in bed all morning reading this fiery little gem and couldn't have picked a better pastime! I went to see a comedy show featuring Ilana Glazer on a date a few months ago, and one of the opening acts was Isaac Oliver. As I listened to him read a chapter from his book, Ilana sidled to the front of the crowd and standing right next to me, at a diminutive 5'3" I peered over her shoulder to see that she was texting Bitmojis with Abbi Jacobson herself. Despite the fact that I was swooning over pretty much having become best friends with both of them in my head, I remembered thinking that this guy was pretty funny.And the book is even better! It's tawdry and unapologetically gay but really sharp, witty, and well-told. Bravo, Isaac Oliver! Let's be friends, or at least ride the subway together....more

title: The Drowned and the Saved
author: Levi, Primo
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Levi, a survivor of Auschwitz, takes a chillingly evenhanded look at human nature to expose what we are capable of, and complicit in, when in the midsLevi, a survivor of Auschwitz, takes a chillingly evenhanded look at human nature to expose what we are capable of, and complicit in, when in the midst of extreme environments such as Nazi Germany. With an admirable lack of hatred but a searing battery of accusations, he takes German excuses of ignorance and attitudes of resignation to task, backing his analysis with his own experiences in the Lager and communiques he had with Germans following his antecedent books' publications.This book really made me begin to examine my complicity in the horrors of systems like capitalism and mass incarceration, especially when exposed to Levi's disgust with the self-serving "Well, /really/, what could I have done?" plea that I might be tempted to put forth. But aside from those inchoate, still-unprocessed thoughts, the most baleful of passages were those that admonished us not to be too sanguine about our own failsafes--cultural, legal, or human. I am not one for casual Nazi allusions, but reading this in the current moment of great ferment, it was impossible not to worry given Levi's well-pleaded case that Hitler's rise was not the result of some perfect storm of military, economic, and egotistical debasement or uniquely German capacity for manifesting hatred, evil, and violence. Aptly:"Few countries can be considered immune to a future tide of violence generated by intolerance, lust for power, economic difficulties, religious or political fanaticism, and racialist attritions. It is therefore necessary to sharpen our senses, distrust the prophets, the enchanters, those who speak and write 'beautiful words' unsupported by intelligent reasons."Later on, Levi observes that Nazism's military opponents likely organized so staunchly against the ideology and its state because of how ruthless and dangerous it had shown itself to be from the very beginning. He leaves unsaid that a slightly more restrained, slightly less hectoring entity might amass power more slowly, in imperceptible increments rather than alarming bounds, like the frog that allows itself to be boiled alive in a slowly heated pot, despite the same inevitable outcome. Certainly this level of alarm can be directed at any potentially dangerous nascent political coalition or movement. But I think that's beside the point--Levi himself explains why so many Jews, himself included, failed to escape the creeping specter of Nazism, even as the signs appear to us so obvious in hindsight. As the above quote shows, Levi does call us to resist the rise of disquieting systems of power, but the obligation to resist is proportional to the certainty with which one knows (or, critically: should know) that an injustice is being perpetrated.Levi's object is not so much to call on us to prevent some prefigured cataclysm as it is to obligate us to actively and consciously resist participating in a system that is manifestly hateful and oppressive to any human who does not willfully cultivate his ignorance. Regardless, may we draw on formidable reserves of our knowledge of human behavior and human tragedy to rise to either challenge....more

title: Stoner
author: Williams, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Another book that fell casualty to my habit of bringing books to pass time on the subway and then forgetting them at bars. This time it was a FleetwooAnother book that fell casualty to my habit of bringing books to pass time on the subway and then forgetting them at bars. This time it was a Fleetwood Mac remix dance party, so I feel especially bad, as I think our hero Stoner would have felt very out of place there indeed. But he would have borne the burden stoically, manfully, taking stock of the young people enjoying their merriment and wondering why he'd never jigged to Stevie and Lindsey when he'd had the chance.I really liked this book. The writing is spare and the title character endlessly sympathetic. He is the last honorable man in a world where less principled and measured people are arrayed against him. He cannot stop their assault on what small dignities he has carved out of his austere life, but he has his small victories and wins our admiration.At various points when Stoner foregoes the happiness that he so truly deserves because of his sense of principle, I wanted to reach into the pages and throttle him. It made me think of how the world will conspire meanly against you if you are inflexible and do not look out for yourself. I doubt that this was the conclusion the author intended to promote, but for a while it made me feel tainted and unscrupulous. Ultimately it's got to be a balancing act; I'm not Stoner, and I don't envy him his fate, but he certainly sets an example to which the aspirationally honorable should seek to repair....more

title: This Way for the Gas, Ladies and Gentlemen
author: Borowski, Tadeusz
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've always felt that there is some sort of duty to witness pain that others have felt the need to record. Maybe not a duty, but I am often contemptuoI've always felt that there is some sort of duty to witness pain that others have felt the need to record. Maybe not a duty, but I am often contemptuous of people who say that such and such is just too painful to watch, listen to, or behold. This doesn't hold true for fictionalizations, and I'm not referring to situations that would trigger past traumas that the beholder has experienced him or herself--in that case, one's personal knowledge is educational enough, and any further exposure is just gratuitous and painful. I'm talking about the person who has no experience with something but who refuses to engage with it for fear of how painful they will find it. It strikes me as some mix of cowardly and disrespectful to the person who actually endured it, whose sharing of the experience indicates that they believe that there is something to be salvaged from the experience.But I have to reevaluate this after reading this book. It was remarkably difficult to get through.Borowski was a Polish (gentile) political dissident who survived Auschwitz, arriving less than a month after Aryans had ceased being gassed there. As such, he enjoyed some informal authority and escaped the worst treatment. He describes the typical mistreatment of prisoners, the disregard for human life, and both tormentors and captors come away shamed. In particular, the dissolution of familial bonds is used to underscore the dehumanization of the camps, with one woman being clubbed for abandoning the encumbering child wailing for her upon entering the camp, one man sending his father to the gas chambers right after reuniting with him rather than deal with him, and another man describing dispassionately how he had his son hanged for stealing commissary bread. Daily life for the Aryan is punctuated by absurdities--at one point the narrator remarks that "[b]etween two throw-ins in a soccer game, right behind [his] back, three thousand people had been put to death." There are plenty more grotesque and inhuman details that I will refrain from sharing here.Details aside, there are the familiar meditations on the dangers of hope and what makes man capable of such atrocities. And on this latter point, perhaps because (unlike most Holocaust narratives) Borowski was both captor and captive, he sees the natural regression proceeding from fear to duty, and duty to habit, but hastens to add how quickly habit can give way to taking pleasure in cruelty. The portrayal of humanity is irredeemably bleak, and despite reuniting with his wife after the War, Borowski, like so many Holocaust survivors, took his life (asphyxiation from gas) in 1951, three days after the birth of his only child....more

review: Reading Nabokov is always intimidating. I think I have a pretty expansive vocabulary, but I rarely made it a page without typing a word into my cellphReading Nabokov is always intimidating. I think I have a pretty expansive vocabulary, but I rarely made it a page without typing a word into my cellphone dictionary. Sure enough, Nabokov invents his fair share of words and, unlike his idol Shakespeare--whom he eulogizes in this book without apparent relevance to the plot--his words have not yet made it into the English canon, so I never felt too badly about coming across one. As plot goes, I was underwhelmed. Nabokov pillories the bumbling autocratic state, but I think it was too easy of a target for the man who somehow successfully made pedophilia sympathetic. I'm sure it had more depth to the author as a Russian émigré, but as an American, it seemed like a bit of a lazy straw man for leftist big government. Reading Lolita or Pale Fire, the temptation to anoint him as a genius is irresistible. This book had many of the same ingredients, but the sum total felt underwhelming....more

I don't have many thoughts about this novel, except that it was a really fun, quick, and accessible read. Neither noir nor Westerns is really my cup of tea, but the cover of this one caught my eye and it was a refreshing change of pace. Patrick deWitt employs limpid prose and terse dialogue to tell a story in a fast-paced, economical fashion. He has a great grasp of subtle humor and sympathy, and uses these to both develop characters and to engage the reader, both very effectively. Sometimes I thought that Eli, the main character, was too incongruous and modern for the book's late 19th Century setting, but that slight irritation faded because he was so likable. ...more

title: Fourth of July Creek
author: Henderson, Smith
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a solid book, and a debut at that! It felt like the last episode of a season of the show "Justified": humor and some dust-ups gradually resolThis was a solid book, and a debut at that! It felt like the last episode of a season of the show "Justified": humor and some dust-ups gradually resolve and we are shown the lilting genius and earthly evil of reclusive and unadorned country folk. Underestimate them at your peril!I won't go into the plot too much, except to say that it struck me as a bit clumsy to have a woman be at fault for each of the disasters and inhumanities that befalls one of the central characters. I don't think this is a misogynistic book, but it seemed like something that could have been avoided. But the voice in this book is incredible. It mixes that hardboiled stolidity and economical-yet-esoteric diction common to the masculine, agrestic type of book, with a poetic side, and somehow did so seamlessly. There's plenty of intrigue, ghastly horror, gore, violence, and seedy underbellies to pull you through the nearly 500 pages without any noticeably dull gaps.A funny thing this book made me realize: sometimes--especially now that the collapse of society feels so nigh--I look around at my fellow epicene New Yorkers and take stock of my natural assets in comparison with them: I don't eat much, I don't sleep much, I'm a pretty decent sprinter, I speak Spanish, I can cook, I have an almost X-man-esque ability to tolerate cold temperatures, I can win over animals like St. Francis himself, and I'm a good driver. I have my deficits, too: quick to anger, poor vision, intolerance for canned and shelf-preserved foodstuffs, weak hand-to-eye coordination, loss aversion, and like most effete liberals I've never shot a gun outside of a videogame. But all the same--I weigh myself against my fellow urbanites and it is usually they who are found wanting.But holy shit! The aforementioned dubious comparison's accuracy notwithstanding, there is no question that I would falter so quickly against these folk. They can track, they are stealthy, they are good marksmen, they do not require showers, they can hunt, dress deer, avoid poisonous sources of water, etc. If government faltered, a scant 400 of them could round us up and destroy us like Pizarro did the Inca! ...more

title: Interpreter of Maladies
author: Lahiri, Jhumpa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Seldom am I so handsomely rewarded for giving an author I didn't love a second chance!This book gripped me from the start. It is composed of short stoSeldom am I so handsomely rewarded for giving an author I didn't love a second chance!This book gripped me from the start. It is composed of short stories, and I harbor a suspicion that they are Lahiri's true métier. It's evident from the way she crafts narratives and prose in these stories--they are crisp and economical and banal yet riveting. I wonder what "The Lowland" might have been if it had been condensed into 25 pages. I sensed shades of Lorrie Moore in this. But where the tragedy and misery in Moore's stories tend to accelerate at a linear rate, Lahiri's do so geometrically. Somewhat of a side note: as much as I love New York, this book made me miss the academic enclaves and peculiarly pointy-headed cosmopolitanism that Cambridge exudes. It was fun to relive the old haunts--Central, Harvard, Davis and Kenmore squares; Back Bay; Cordullo's!! For anyone who remembers how much I groused and kvetched about Boston while I lived there, this nostalgia for the area is testament enough to Lahiri's genius and skill as a writer.Final postscript: I read every single line of looney centenarian Mrs. Croft's dialogue in the final story in the voice of Agnes Skinner from The Simpsons and it was perfect: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V8Sq_......more

title: Rabbit, Run        (Rabbit Angstrom, #1)
author: Updike, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Welp, this was an odd one to read on the plane coming back from a truly amazing wedding...It took me a while to get into this book. The first 1/3 or sWelp, this was an odd one to read on the plane coming back from a truly amazing wedding...It took me a while to get into this book. The first 1/3 or so felt very plodding, comprised of shopworn material. The writing is minimalist--I've heard his prose described as "dense"... what?--but Updike paints vividly, even though he sticks to primary colors. Some of the dialogue--any character upbraiding that meddlesome Rev. Eccles, for instance--is crackerjack stuff. It seems like it's going to be another psychological profile of a young, feckless all-American white man in mid-century exurban hell: lots of ego (check), overly forgiving women (check), and a conspiracy of factors that manfully prevent the protagonist's life from spinning off its axis, despite his most destructive motives and efforts, setting us up for a dawning maturity (check?). And Updike almost wrote that book, but then he hits us with a gut-punch plot twist that converts the lives of the main characters from somewhat depressing to completely wretched. Like, we're talking can't-bounce-back, drink-the-bleach-before-they-find-you type stuff. Tainted as they are, the rest of the rogues' gallery of characters have circumstances that arguably mitigate their guilt. Rabbit, on the contrary, is loathsome throughout the book, and his antics in its coda make me wonder how Updike wrings enough sympathy out of the rest of his life to merit three subsequent novels and a novella. I am sufficiently intrigued to find out......more

title: A People’s History of the United States
author: Zinn, Howard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's appropriate that I finished this on the day of the first 2016 Presidential Debate, because tonight we'll witness the apotheosis of the greed, falIt's appropriate that I finished this on the day of the first 2016 Presidential Debate, because tonight we'll witness the apotheosis of the greed, falsehoods, and willful ignorance that this work sought to expose. This audiobook was in 35 segments, each on average an hour long. Some people I had spoken with said that they found this book tedious, but I was mostly enthralled. If anything, maybe hearing about American colonization, genocide, rapine, and corruption only felt more blunted as the blows came.If there's one word that this book made me feel, it is "ashamed." I grew up in a patriotic somewhat liberal family, and yet nary a whiff of any of this was present in the childhood in which I was encouraged--in school, by the media, by friends and by family--to honor and revere the United States and its vaunted, idealistic provenance. I guess in my pre-law school politics it was always enough to focus on the future and how we are handling things now, but Zinn's masterwork shows the startling, shameful roots of our current system in the depraved dealings of our past.In this work, Zinn de-bowdlerizes a history made out of whole, faux-patriotic cloth. It is absolutely indispensable for any student of American history or for anyone wishing to understand the current state of American society....more

review: People love this book. I think I understand the appeal--it's a very nostalgic look at Edwardian England. The subject matter is a little stuffy but excPeople love this book. I think I understand the appeal--it's a very nostalgic look at Edwardian England. The subject matter is a little stuffy but excellently written. For myself, when I feel a voyeuristic craving to immerse myself in the cosseted world of breathlessly aristocratic Brits, I prefer more modern, humorous writers such as Edward St. Aubyn and Kate Atkinson. Brideshead often felt like something written by our own chronicler of the hoary elite, F. Scott Fitzgerald: the first half was "This Side of Paradise" and the second "Tender is the Night." And I suppose that that is my main complaint about this book: it felt too disjointed. It felt like two novellas clumsily tethered together. Sebastian, the object of the narrator's affection in the first half of the book, is dropped out of the second half of the book entirely, only mentioned in passing as a dissolute waif off pickling in spirits in some dusty forgotten corner of the Levant or Sahara. We never really even get a satisfactory answer for why this beautiful, charming, naifish, obscenely wealthy and well-connected young man turns, suddenly, to a life of unregenerate alcoholism. If we are meant to infer that Sebastian's thwarted sexual desires are the reality he seeks to escape through drink, I think we could at least have been given more to chew over here. Instead, drinking to excess is presented quite accurately as mere tedium, the tediousness exaggerated given the lack of any apparent cause or reflection on the condition. And can I just say that I was scandalized by how very not gay this book was? Did I receive a bowdlerized version, or is my literary gaydar on the fritz?...more

title: Middlesex
author: Eugenides, Jeffrey
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm sympathetic to people who thought that this book was too long, too plodding. The first half of the book reads a lot like a Greek 100 Years of SoliI'm sympathetic to people who thought that this book was too long, too plodding. The first half of the book reads a lot like a Greek 100 Years of Solitude--all incest and curses and lovemaking and old country and indistinguishable names and superstition (I even started referring to it myself as "100 Gyrs of Socratude"). I think in most books, it would be permissible to tell the epic from the very beginning. But this book is different; it beckons with its lightning rod premise: the narrator is a hermaphrodite. And while each chapter usually begins with an adumbration of the plot we all came to behold, the details are always so skinflinty as to make it seem like a tease or a gimmick. It gets tiresome to drink in gallons of Anatolian drama in exchange for every few sips of gender formation. But, when snow and incompetence conspire to bugger your return trip from Colombia and it takes you 36 hours to get home, you can afford to be patient with your literature.I can understand why friends have put this book down. It's long, and the first half (and maybe more) does not live up to the hype that surrounds this book, in my opinion. But I don't think it's being too forgiving to say that, in the end, it deserved to be included, that it makes sense and also enriched the story. The most prominent theme in this novel is that seemingly dramatic changes are not fundamental, and everyone has one foot planted firmly in the past. This is true whether we talk of Detroit--with its moldering landmarks and racial divisions--or Desdemona--whose incestuous relationship with her husband seems to rise and fall from consciousness continuously throughout the novel--or Cal--who lives like a man but still fills the role of daughter, who reveals his gender transition over plates of baklava, the acceptance of which is facilitated by folklore from the old country. To the extent that it was pitched as important to frame Cal's genetic provenance, I think it was a miss; but to the extent it underscored the notion that we all retain our core identities, regardless of what we encounter or how we're perceived, I very much appreciated this thick novel as a whole....more
